ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	1- The primary preventive strategy for community-acquired pneumonia is.	Antibiotic therapy	Good hand hygiene	Adherence to healthy lifestyle behaviors	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.		D	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.	Vaccination is the single most effective intervention against the major causes of CAP, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Influenza.	Pneumococcal and Influenza vaccines are the primary prevention for CAP.	CAP Prevention				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	2- A 30 years man from Australia returned from a business trip to Indonesia 6d ago presenting with complaints of fever, joint and muscle ache and headache, in particular behind the eye for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis?	Malaria	Chicken pox	TB	Lyme's disease	Dengue	E	Dengue	The combination of fever, retro-orbital headache, and severe joint/muscle pain (breakbone fever) following travel to endemic Indonesia is classic for Dengue fever.	Dengue is characterized by retro-orbital pain and breakbone fever after travel to tropical/subtropical areas.	Dengue				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	3- Which of the following is not a RNA virus?	Hepatitis A virus	Hepatitis B virus	Hepatitis C virus	Hepatitis D virus		B	Hepatitis B virus	Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a DNA virus (a hepadnavirus). A, C, and D are RNA viruses.	HBV is a DNA virus; all other Hepatitis viruses (A, C, D, E) are RNA viruses.	Viral Hepatitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	4- The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, except.	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection	Leptospirosis is transmitted by animal urine (zoonosis). Lice are vectors for diseases like relapsing fever, not leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis is a zoonosis spread by animal urine; it is NOT spread by lice.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	5- Worldwide, the most common mode of infection with HIV is?	Homosexual transmission	Heterosexual transmission	Blood and blood products	Infected mothers to infants		B	Heterosexual transmission	Globally, heterosexual transmission accounts for the largest number of HIV infections.	Globally, heterosexual sex is the predominant route of HIV transmission.	HIV Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	6- Release of which of the following results in fever?	Interleukin (IL) 1	Interleukin (IL) 8	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor	All of the above		A	Interleukin (IL) 1	Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a primary endogenous pyrogen that acts on the hypothalamus to raise the body's set point, causing fever.	IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α are key endogenous pyrogens that trigger fever.	Fever Pathophysiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	7- The single most useful clinical sign of severity of pneumonia in a person without underlying lung disease is?	Respiratory rate >30/minute	Pulse rate > 100/minute	Hypothermia	Postural fall of SBP>10 mm Hg		A	Respiratory rate >30/minute	A respiratory rate >30 breaths/minute is a key component of severity scores (like CURB-65) and indicates significant respiratory compromise.	A Respiratory Rate >30/min is a major sign of severe pneumonia (CURB-65 criteria).	CAP Severity				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	8- Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring how many hours after hospital admission?	At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	HAP is defined as pneumonia developing 48 hours or more after hospital admission.	HAP is defined as pneumonia onset >48 hours after hospital admission.	HAP Definition				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	9- Which bacterial pathogen is most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in adults?	Staphylococcus aureus	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Chlamydophila pneumoniae		C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococcus) is the most common bacterial cause of CAP in adults.	Streptococcus pneumoniae is the number one cause of CAP.	CAP Etiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	10- A 7-year school boy has been dx with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis in close contacts (including classroom contacts) of a patient with meningococcal meningitis.	Rifampicin (or Ceftriaxone/Cipro) is used for meningococcal prophylaxis in close contacts.	Meningitis Prophylaxis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	1- Rifampicin is used in all except.	Legionnaires' disease	Chemoprophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis	Leprosy	Bartonellosis		D	Bartonellosis	Rifampicin is used for the others. Bartonellosis (Cat-Scratch Disease) is typically treated with macrolides or doxycycline.	Rifampicin is used for TB, Leprosy, Meningitis Prophylaxis, but NOT Bartonellosis.	Antimicrobial Use				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	2- Most reliable clue to poor tissue perfusion in septic shock is.	Hyponatraemia	High level of blood lactate	Hypochloraemia	Low level of HCO3​		B	High level of blood lactate	Elevated blood lactate is the most reliable biochemical marker of tissue hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism in septic shock.	Lactate level is the best biochemical marker for poor tissue perfusion in shock.	Septic Shock Markers				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	3- Micobacterial flora of GI tract does not contain.	Bacteroides fragilis	Clostridium perfringens	Pseudomonas	Klebsiella ozaenae		D	Klebsiella ozaenae	Bacteroides fragilis and Clostridium species are normal gut anaerobes, and Clostridium perfringens can be found in the intestinal tract. Pseudomonas species may occasionally colonize the gut (especially in hospitalized or immunocompromised patients). Klebsiella ozaenae is classically associated with the nasal mucosa/atrophic rhinitis (ozena) and is not a normal component of the gastrointestinal flora.	Klebsiella ozaenae is classically associated with the nasal mucosa/atrophic rhinitis (ozena) and is not a normal component of the gastrointestinal flora.	Normal Flora				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	4- Which of the following are the features of enteric fever in the first week?	Continued type pyrexia	Pea-soup diarrhoea	Relative tachycardia	Typhoid state		A	Continued type pyrexia	The first week of enteric (typhoid) fever is characterized by a step-ladder pattern of continued type pyrexia.	Continued type pyrexia (step-ladder fever) is characteristic of Typhoid fever in the first week.	Enteric Fever

Relapse bears relationship with agglutinin titre	Agglutinin against flagellar antigen is most important	Agglutinins begin to appear after 3rd day of infection	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week		D	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week			Typhoid Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	6- Treatment of choice in chronic carrier of enteric fever is.	Cholecystectomy	Quinolones	Ceftriaxone	Furazolidone		A	Cholecystectomy	Chronic carriers harbor Salmonella in the gallbladder, making Cholecystectomy the definitive treatment when antibiotics fail to clear the infection.	The treatment for a chronic carrier of typhoid (bacteria in the gallbladder) is often cholecystectomy.	Typhoid Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	7- Rat-bite fever is caused by the organism.	Spirillum minus	A gram-positive cocci	Yersinia multocida	Treponema pertenue		A	Spirillum minus	Rat-bite fever is caused by either Spirillum minus or Streptobacillus moniliformis.	Rat-bite fever is caused by Spirillum minus (sodoku) or S. moniliformis (Haverhill fever).	Zoonoses				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	8- Cyclical periods of pyrexia alternating with a pyrexia is found in all except.	Relapsing fever	Leprosy	Hodgkin's disease	Brucellosis		B	Leprosy	Cyclical fever (undulant fever, Pel-Ebstein) is seen in the others. Leprosy fever is usually due to erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) and is NOT classically characterized by cyclical fever.	Cyclical/Undulant fever is seen in Relapsing fever, Brucellosis, and Hodgkin's disease; NOT Leprosy.	Fever Patterns				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	9- Drug of choice in pneumonic legionellosis is.	Rifampicin	Ceftizidime	Erythromycin	Co-amoxyclav		C	Erythromycin	Erythromycin (or a newer macrolide like Azithromycin) is the preferred treatment for Legionnaires' disease.	Macrolides (like Erythromycin or Azithromycin) or Fluoroquinolones are the treatment for Legionnaires' disease.	Legionnaires' Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	10- Faget's sign (relative bradycardia) is first described in.	Typhoid fever	Yellow fever	Acute rheumatic fever	Brucellosis		B	Yellow fever	Faget's sign (pulse–temperature dissociation — relative bradycardia with fever) was first described in yellow fever. It's also seen in other infections (typhoid, Legionella, brucellosis, psittacosis, some rickettsial infections), but historically linked to yellow fever.	Faget's sign (relative bradycardia) is classically first described in yellow fever.	Typhoid Signs				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	11- Cat-scratch disease is characterized by all except.	Regional lymphadenopathy	Erythema nodosum	Positive Hanger-Rose intra-dermal test	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroid		D	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroid	Cat-scratch disease (caused by Bartonella henselae) typically causes regional lymphadenopathy and can be associated with immune reactions such as erythema nodosum. The historical Hanger–Rose intradermal test may be positive. Treatment is usually conservative or with antibiotics (e.g., azithromycin) — corticosteroids are not routinely used except in rare severe/systemic or ocular complications.	Mild cases resolve without treatment, or may be treated with antibiotics alone (e.g. azithromycin).  Corticosteroids are avoided except in rare severe complications (e.g. neuroretinitis).	Bartonellosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	12- Cerebral malaria is.	Treated by oral quinine sulphate	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Associated with signs of meningeal irritation	IV dexamethasone reduces mortality rate		B	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Cerebral malaria is a severe complication of P. falciparum that commonly involves severe systemic disease and multi-organ failure (e.g., ARDS, renal failure).	Cerebral malaria (P. falciparum) is a medical emergency with a high risk of multi-organ failure.	Cerebral Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	13- Regarding primary amoebic meningoencephalitis, which is false.	Almost invariably fatal	Caused by Naegleria fowleri	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Acquired by swimming in fresh warm water		C	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	PAM is caused by N. fowleri and is fatal; the drug of choice is Amphotericin B, not Dehydroemetine (used for amoebiasis).	Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) is caused by Naegleria fowleri and is treated with Amphotericin B.	Amoebic Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	14- 'River blindness' is due to.	Toxoplasmosis	Trichinasis	Onchocerciasis	Cysticerosis		C	Onchocerciasis	Onchocerciasis is caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus, which leads to eye damage and blindness, hence the common name 'river blindness'.	Onchocerciasis is the parasitic infection that causes River Blindness.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	15- Drug of choice in Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia is.	Pentamidine isethionate	Zidovudine	Cefoperazone	Aztreonamo		A	Pentamidine isethionate	Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the current standard of care. Pentamidine isethionate is an alternative treatment, making it a viable answer in this context.	The drug of choice for Pneumocystis Pneumonia (PCP) is TMP-SMX; Pentamidine is a second-line agent.	PCP Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	16- In hepatic amoebiasis.	Left lobe is commonly affected	Liver function tests (LFT) are of diagnostic value	Jaundice is uncommon	Serological tests are not helpful in diagnosis		C	Jaundice is uncommon	Jaundice is uncommon in amoebic liver abscess because the damage is typically focal rather than diffuse.	Amoebic Liver Abscess typically does NOT cause jaundice.	Amoebic Liver Abscess				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	17- Tuberculous focus in brain is known as.	Rich's focus	Wigard's focus	Ashman's focus	Simmon's focus		A	Rich's focus	A Rich's focus is a small subpial or subependymal tuberculous focus that can rupture into the subarachnoid space, leading to tuberculous meningitis.	A Rich's focus is the primary tuberculous lesion in the brain that can rupture to cause TBM.	CNS TB				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	18- Malta fever is caused by. Malta fever is another name for Brucellosis, caused by Brucella species.	Brucellosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	19- Which is false regarding brucellosis.	Acquired through contact or ingestion of raw goat's milk	Brucella melitensis is the most common type of infection	CFT is more important in acute infection than that of agglutination reaction	May present as pyrexia of unknown origin		C	CFT is more important in acute infection than that of agglutination reaction	The standard and most commonly used serological test for acute brucellosis is the Agglutination Reaction, not the CFT.	The Standard Tube Agglutination Test (STAT) is the most common diagnostic test for acute Brucellosis, not the Complement Fixation Test (CFT).	Brucellosis Diagnosis

Acute Shigellosis is associated with HUS and Reiter's syndrome, NOT Liver Abscess.	Shigellosis Complications

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	22- Botulism is manifested by all except.	Normal pupils	Entirely normal sensory functions	Increased protein in CSF	Progressive descending muscle paralysis		C	Increased protein in CSF	Botulism is a neuroparalytic syndrome with a typically normal CSF profile; increased protein is characteristic of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).	Botulism presents with flaccid paralysis but has a NORMAL CSF (distinguishing it from GBS).	Botulism

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	24- Which is not a cause of aseptic fever.	Crush injury	SLE	AIDS	Pontine haemorrhage		C	AIDS	Aseptic fever is non-infectious. AIDS is caused by HIV, a viral infectious disease, and is therefore a cause of infectious, not aseptic (non-infectious), fever.	Aseptic fever is non-infectious (e.g., from drugs, trauma, malignancy, or SLE); AIDS is an infectious cause of fever.	Aseptic Fever

The Casoni's test (for Hydatid Disease) is NOT 100% sensitive and is rarely used now; serology is preferred.	Hydatid Disease

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	1) The patient is considered comatose when Glasgow coma scale less than or equal to.	3	10	8	5	12	C	8	A Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8 or less is the critical threshold used to define coma and indicates a need for airway protection.	GCS ≤ 8 is the clinical definition of Coma and often an indication for intubation.	GCS Coma

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	4) Which of the following causing aseptic meningitis?	H. influenza B.	Neisseria meningitides.	Strept. Pneumonia.	Staph. aureus.	Cryptococcus neoformans.	E	Cryptococcus neoformans.	Aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis is caused by non-bacterial pathogens. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	5) Which of the following is correct about CSF examination in bacterial meningitis?	Low Tension <180 mm H2​O.	Turbid aspect.	High lymphocytes.	High protein 50−100 mg/dl.	Glucose >40 mg/dl.	B	Turbid aspect.	The extremely high number of neutrophils (WBCs) and protein in bacterial meningitis causes the CSF to appear turbid (cloudy).	CSF in Bacterial Meningitis is characterized by Turbid appearance, high Neutrophils, low Glucose, and high Protein.	Bacterial CSF				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	6) Which of the following is incorrect about CSF examination in viral meningitis?	Low Tension <180 mm H2​O.	Turbid aspect.	High lymphocytes.	High protein 50−100 mg/dl.	Glucose >40 mg/dl.	B	Turbid aspect.	Viral meningitis (aseptic) typically has a clear appearance, not turbid CSF, which is characteristic of bacterial infection.	CSF in Viral Meningitis is characterized by a Clear appearance, high Lymphocytes, and normal Glucose.	Viral CSF

Malaria's global disease burden is in the hundreds of millions of cases annually.	Malaria Epidemiology

P. falciparum causes the most severe form of malaria.	P. falciparum				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	9) The infective stage of malaria is.	Ring stage	Trophozite	Sporozoites	Merozoites		C	Sporozoites	The sporozoites are the form of the parasite that is injected into the human host by the mosquito and travels to the liver.	The Sporozoite is the infectious stage transmitted from the mosquito to the human host.	Malaria Life Cycle
