ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	11) Sexual cycle of malaria.	Inside liver cells	Inside R.B.C	In the W.B.C	Gut of mosquito		D	Gut of mosquito	The sexual reproductive cycle (sporogony) occurs in the midgut of the female Anopheles mosquito.	The sexual cycle of Plasmodium occurs in the mosquito gut.	Malaria Life Cycle				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	12) Complicated malaria can develop in.	Children	Pregnant female	Both			C	Both	Both children and pregnant women are considered high-risk groups for developing complicated/severe malaria.	High-risk groups for complicated malaria include children and pregnant women.	Complicated Malaria Risk				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	13) Malaria can be transmitted by.	Sand fly	Male anopheles mosquito	Female anopheles mosquito			C	Female anopheles mosquito	Only the female Anopheles mosquito feeds on blood and transmits the parasite.	Malaria is transmitted by the bite of the female Anopheles mosquito.	Malaria Transmission				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	14) Uncomplicated falciparum can be treated.	Chloroquine	Chloroquine + primaquine	ACTs therapy			C	ACTs therapy	Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies (ACTs) are the standard treatment for uncomplicated P. falciparum due to widespread drug resistance.	Treatment for uncomplicated P. falciparum is ACTs therapy.	P. falciparum Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	15) Sickle cell patient are.	More liable to malaria	Less liable to malaria	Has no role			B	Less liable to malaria	The sickle cell trait confers evolutionary protection against severe P. falciparum malaria, making them less liable to severe disease.	The Sickle Cell Trait provides protection against severe P. falciparum malaria.	Sickle Cell & Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	16) Which type of bite represents a potential medical emergency in an asplenic patient?	Cat bite	Dog bite	Fish bite	Human bite		B	Dog bite	Dog bites carry a high risk of infection with Capnocytophaga canimorsus, which causes rapid, overwhelming sepsis in asplenic patients.	Dog bites are dangerous in asplenic patients due to the risk of Capnocytophaga canimorsus sepsis.	Asplenia Emergency				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	17) Mefloquinine is used for prophylaxis against malaria.	One day before travelling to endemic area	2 days before travelling	3 days before travelling	One week before travelling		D	One week before travelling	Mefloquine requires several days to reach therapeutic levels, so it must be started 1–3 weeks before travel.	Malaria prophylaxis with Mefloquine must begin 1-3 weeks prior to travel.	Malaria Prophylaxis Timing				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	18) Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is.	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA) is defined as the enlargement of two or more non-contiguous (separate) lymph node regions.	GLA is defined as enlargement of ≥2 non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Generalized Lymphadenopathy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	19) Male patient 50 years old, farmer, came to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case is.	Myelofibrosis	Egyptian splenomegaly	Hyperthyroidism	syphilis		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	Egyptian splenomegaly is a term historically used for the massive splenomegaly caused by Schistosomiasis, which leads to portal hypertension and varices.	Massive splenomegaly with esophageal varices (portal hypertension) in a farmer from endemic areas suggests Schistosomiasis (Egyptian Splenomegaly).	Schistosomiasis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page1-14	20) Male patient 22 years old, presented by fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, weight loss, he has a history of IV drug addiction. What most highly suspected in such case?	TB infection	Meningitis	Acute myeloid leukemia	AIDS		D	AIDS	The combination of fever, weight loss, generalized lymphadenopathy, and IV drug use history is highly suggestive of advanced AIDS.	The combination of risk factors (IVDA) and symptoms (fever, LAD, weight loss) is highly suggestive of AIDS.	AIDS/IVDA				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q1: Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring how many hours after hospital admission?	At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	**Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP)** is defined as pneumonia that was **not incubating** at the time of **hospital admission** and presents **48 hours** or **more** after admission. **Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP)** is a subset of **HAP** occurring **48 hours** or **more** after endotracheal intubation.	**HAP Definition:** ≥48 hours after hospital admission.	Pneumonia				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q2: A 7-year school-boy has been dx with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Close contacts of meningococcal meningitis cases require **chemoprophylaxis**. Rifampicin is the standard prophylactic antibiotic given to close contacts including classmates and family members. Alternatives include ciprofloxacin or ceftriaxone.	**Meningococcal prophylaxis:** Rifampicin for close contacts (class and family).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q3: Which of the following CSF results suggests TB meningitis?	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, normal protein, and normal glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose		C	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	TB meningitis characteristically shows **lymphocytic pleocytosis**, **elevated protein**, and **low glucose** in CSF analysis. This pattern distinguishes it from bacterial meningitis (neutrophilic) and viral meningitis (normal glucose).	**TB meningitis CSF:** Lymphocytes ↑, Protein ↑, Glucose ↓.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q4: Mefloquine is used for prophylaxis against malaria	One day before travelling to endemic area	3 days before travelling	2 days before travelling	One week before travelling		D	One week before travelling	Mefloquine should be started **one week before travel** to allow time to reach therapeutic levels and to assess tolerability before departure. It is continued weekly during travel and for 4 weeks after leaving the endemic area.	**Mefloquine prophylaxis:** Start 1 week before travel.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q5: Most reliable clue to poor tissue perfusion in septic shock is	Hyponatremia	High level of blood lactate	Hypochloremia	Low level of HCO3		B	High level of blood lactate	Elevated **blood lactate** is the most reliable indicator of tissue hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism in septic shock. Lactate >4 mmol/L indicates severe shock and predicts mortality.	**Septic shock marker:** Elevated lactate = tissue hypoperfusion.	Sepsis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q6: Drug of choice in Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia?	Cefoperazone	Zidovudine	Aztreonamo	Pentamidine isethionate		D	Pentamidine isethionate	Pentamidine isethionate is a treatment option for **Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)**, though **trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)** is the first-line agent. Pentamidine is used for TMP-SMX intolerance or failure.	**PCP treatment:** TMP-SMX first-line, Pentamidine alternative.	Opportunistic Infections				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q7: Release of which of the following results in fever?	Interleukin (IL) 8	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor	Interleukin (IL) 1	Tumor necrosis factor		C	Interleukin (IL) 1	**IL-1** is a key endogenous pyrogen that acts on the hypothalamus to raise body temperature by stimulating prostaglandin E2 production. TNF and IL-6 also cause fever, but IL-1 is the primary mediator.	**Fever mediators:** IL-1 (primary), TNF, IL-6 → PGE2 → hypothalamic reset.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q8: In neutropenic fever, absolute count of neutrophils is?	≤ 1000 per mm3	≤ 500 per mm3	≤ 850 per mm3	> 1000 per mm3		B	≤ 500 per mm3	**Neutropenic fever** is defined as a single oral temperature ≥38.3°C (101°F) or ≥38.0°C (100.4°F) sustained over 1 hour, with an **absolute neutrophil count (ANC) ≤500 cells/mm3** or expected to fall below 500 cells/mm3 within 48 hours.	**Neutropenic fever:** ANC ≤500 cells/mm3 + fever.	Oncology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q9: Male patient 50 years old, farmer, came to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case is	Myelofibrosis	Egyptian splenomegaly	Syphilis	Hyperthyroidism		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	**Egyptian splenomegaly** (hepatosplenic schistosomiasis) is common in farmers in endemic areas (Egypt), presenting with **massive splenomegaly**, **portal hypertension**, and **esophageal varices** due to periportal fibrosis. The liver function remains relatively preserved.	**Egyptian splenomegaly** = Hepatosplenic schistosomiasis with portal hypertension in endemic areas.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q10: Which of the following is false regarding Widal test:	Titre of 0-antigen above 1:640 is often very significant in enteric fever	Antibiotic therapy may depress the agglutination titres	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	An agglutination reaction		C	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	This statement is **FALSE**. In vaccinated subjects, **H-agglutinins** (flagellar antigens) appear early and disappear quickly, while **O-agglutinins** (somatic antigens) persist longer. The statement reverses the actual pattern.	**Widal test:** O-titres persist longer, H-titres disappear faster in vaccinated individuals.	Typhoid Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q11: Which is not a recognised complication of acute shigellosis	Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome	Reiter's syndrome	Liver abscess	Endotoxic shock		C	Liver abscess	**Liver abscess** is typically associated with **Entamoeba histolytica**, not Shigella. Recognized complications of shigellosis include **HUS** (hemolytic uremic syndrome), **Reiter's syndrome** (reactive arthritis), seizures, and **septic shock**.	**Shigella complications:** HUS, Reiter's syndrome, septic shock. **NOT** liver abscess (that's amoebiasis).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q12: Cysticercosis is the larval stage of	Taenia solium	Hyrnenolepiasis n.ana	Taenia saginata	Ancylostoma duodenale		A	Taenia solium	**Cysticercosis** is caused by the **larval stage (cysticercus)** of **Taenia solium** (pork tapeworm) when humans accidentally ingest eggs. This causes cysts in tissues including brain (neurocysticercosis), muscles, and eyes.	**Cysticercosis** = Larval stage of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q13: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitaris	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	**Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)** causes **HYPERTHERMIA**, not hypothermia. It's characterized by fever, muscle rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic instability. Causes of hypothermia include myxedema coma, hypopituitarism, and circulatory failure.	**NMS causes hyperthermia**. Causes of hypothermia: myxedema, hypopituitarism, circulatory failure, hypothalamic lesions.	Thermoregulation				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q14: As regard campylobacter food poisoning the following are correct except:	the most common causes of foodborne illness.	Pets may also be a source of infection	unpasteurized milk not cause campylobacter food poisoning.	It is present in the gut of a wide range of animals, especially birds		C	unpasteurized milk not cause campylobacter food poisoning.	This is **FALSE**. **Unpasteurized milk IS a common source** of Campylobacter infection. Campylobacter is one of the most common causes of bacterial gastroenteritis worldwide, transmitted through contaminated poultry, unpasteurized milk, contaminated water, and pets.	**Campylobacter sources:** poultry, **unpasteurized milk**, contaminated water, pets (puppies/kittens).	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q15: Giving routine iron and folic acid to all pregnant women is a form of:	Primary prevention	Secondary prevention.	Tertiary prevention.	Chemoprophylaxis.		A	Primary prevention	**Primary prevention** prevents disease before it occurs by removing risk factors. Routine supplementation in pregnancy prevents **anemia** and **neural tube defects** (folic acid). Secondary prevention is early detection, tertiary is reducing complications.	**Prevention levels:** Primary (prevent disease), Secondary (early detection/screening), Tertiary (reduce complications).	Public Health				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q16: The following are risk factor for candida infection except?	HIV and AIDS	Long term steroids use	HAV	Immunosupressive therapy	Long term antibiotics use	C	HAV	**Hepatitis A virus (HAV)** is not a risk factor for candidiasis. Risk factors for Candida infection include immunosuppression (HIV/AIDS, steroids, immunosuppressive drugs), diabetes, prolonged antibiotic use, central venous catheters, and total parenteral nutrition.	**Candida risk factors:** Immunosuppression (HIV, steroids, chemo), diabetes, antibiotics, catheters. **NOT HAV**.	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q17: The main causative agent of urinary tract infections is:	Klebsiella pneumonia	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Escherichia coli		D	Escherichia coli	**E. coli** accounts for **80-85%** of community-acquired UTIs and about 50% of hospital-acquired UTIs. Other causes include Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus, and Staphylococcus saprophyticus (especially in young sexually active women).	"**UTI causative agents:** E. coli #1 (80-85% community-acquired), then Klebsiella, Proteus, S. saprophyticus."	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q18: Regarding primary amoebic meningoencephalitis, which is false	Almost invariably fatal	Caused by Naegleria fowleri	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Acquired by swimming in fresh warm water		C	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	**Dehydroemetine is NOT the drug of choice**. **Amphotericin B** is the primary treatment for primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), often combined with rifampin, azithromycin, and miltefosine. Despite treatment, PAM has a mortality rate >95%.	**PAM:** Naegleria fowleri, almost always fatal (>95% mortality), treated with **amphotericin B** (not dehydroemetine).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q19: A newly married female has decided to receive (MMR) vaccine, the doctor advised her to post-pone pregnancy for:	Only one month	For at least 3 months	For one year.	Not at all.		B	For at least 3 months	**MMR** is a **live attenuated vaccine**. Pregnancy should be avoided for **at least 3 months** (some guidelines say 4 weeks minimum, but 3 months is safer) after vaccination to prevent theoretical risk of congenital rubella syndrome.	**MMR vaccine:** Avoid pregnancy for ≥3 months post-vaccination (live vaccine contraindicated in pregnancy).	Vaccination				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q20: the WHO established a standardized vaccination schedule for the original EPI which included the following vaccines except:	Bacillus - Calmette Guérin (BCG)	Rota virus vaccine	Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTP	Oral polio, and Measles		B	Rota virus vaccine	The **original EPI** (Expanded Programme on Immunization) established by WHO in **1974** included **BCG, DTP, polio, and measles**. Rotavirus vaccine was added to the WHO recommendations much later (2009 globally, earlier in some regions).	**Original EPI vaccines (1974):** BCG, DTP, Polio, Measles. Rotavirus added later (2009).	Vaccination				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q21: Toxoplasmosis is infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The only known hosts of this organism are domestic cats and their relatives. Infection with T. gondii in humans can occur in various ways. Which of the following is the most common mode of infection in humans?	Blood transfusion	Ingestion of oocysts	Ingestion of tissue cysts	Transplacental transmission		B	Ingestion of oocysts			Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q22: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	Prostaglandin F	T-regulator cells	Prostaglandin E2	Cell adhesion molecule		C	Prostaglandin E2	**Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)** acts on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center to **reset the set point** to a higher temperature, causing fever. Pyrogens (IL-1, TNF, IL-6) stimulate PGE2 production in the hypothalamus.	**Fever mechanism:** Pyrogens → PGE2 production → hypothalamic thermostat reset ↑ → fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q23: Which of the following organisms causes epidemic meningitis cases at military recruits?	Haemophilus influenzae type b	Neisseria meningitidis	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes		B	Neisseria meningitidis	**N. meningitidis** causes **epidemic meningitis** in crowded conditions like military barracks, college dormitories, and refugee camps. Close living quarters facilitate respiratory droplet transmission. Serogroups A, B, C, W, Y cause most disease.	**Epidemic meningitis** in crowded settings (military, dorms): N. meningitidis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q24: Cinchonism is a possible side effect for:	Primaquin	Proguanil	Chloroquine	Mefloquine	Quinine	E	Quinine	**Cinchonism** is a syndrome of toxicity from **quinine/quinidine**, characterized by **tinnitus**, hearing loss, headache, nausea, visual disturbances (blurred vision, photophobia), and confusion. It occurs with therapeutic or toxic doses.	**Cinchonism:** Quinine/quinidine toxicity → tinnitus, hearing loss, visual changes, nausea, confusion.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q25: Acyclovir is an antiviral drug that is usually used in treatment of……	Hepatitis C virus	Herpes Zoster virus	Hepatitis B virus	Human immunodeficiency virus	Cytomegalovirus	B	Herpes Zoster virus	**Acyclovir** is used for **herpes viruses** including HSV-1, HSV-2, and **VZV (Herpes Zoster/chickenpox)**. It is NOT effective against HCV, HBV, HIV, or CMV (ganciclovir/valganciclovir for CMV). Acyclovir inhibits viral DNA polymerase.	**Acyclovir:** HSV-1, HSV-2, VZV (Herpes Zoster). **NOT** HCV, HBV, HIV, CMV.	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q26: Improper contact lens -care practices may lead to	River blindness	Acanthamoeba keratitis	African eye worm	Ocular toxocariasis	Ocular toxoplasmosis	B	Acanthamoeba keratitis	**Acanthamoeba keratitis** is associated with **improper contact lens care**, especially using **tap water** to rinse lenses or swimming/showering while wearing contacts. It causes severe painful keratitis that can lead to vision loss.	**Contact lens infection:** Acanthamoeba keratitis (avoid tap water with contacts, use sterile solutions only).	Ophthalmology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q27: Retinochroiditis is caused by eye infection with	Loa-loa	Onchocerca volvulous	Demodex folliculorum	Toxoplasma gondi	Toxocara cani	D	Toxoplasma gondi	**Toxoplasma gondii** causes **retinochoroiditis**, especially in **congenital infection** or immunocompromised patients. It is a leading cause of posterior uveitis and can cause vision loss. Classic finding is focal necrotizing retinitis with vitritis.	**Retinochoroiditis:** Toxoplasma gondii (congenital or immunocompromised). Leading cause of posterior uveitis.	Ophthalmology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q28: SARS is described as a zoonotic virus - what does this mean?	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	They cause pandemics	Such viruses are confined to animals	They do not cause disease in human		A	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	**Zoonotic viruses** originate in animals and can **cross species barriers** to infect humans. This transmission occurs infrequently but can lead to outbreaks (SARS-CoV from civets/bats, MERS-CoV from camels, influenza from birds/pigs).	**Zoonotic:** Animal viruses that cross species barrier to infect humans (e.g., SARS, MERS, influenza).	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q29: The chain of infection has five main components. the habitat (animals, human or environment) in which the agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies is known as	the reservoir of the infectious agent	the portal of exit	portal of entry	mode of transmission of the infectious agent	the susceptible host to the infectious agent	A	the reservoir of the infectious agent	The **reservoir** is where the infectious agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies (human, animal, or environmental). Chain: Reservoir → Portal of exit → Mode of transmission → Portal of entry → Susceptible host.	**Chain of infection:** Reservoir → Portal of exit → Transmission → Portal of entry → Susceptible host.	Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q30: A 19-year-old student presents with a fifteen week history of diarrhoea. He has lost 2kg in weight, and has no recent travel abroad. A smear of a duodenal biopsy reveals many trophozoites. What is the best treatment option?	Ciprofloxacin	Gluten free diet	Metronidazole	Prednisolone	Quinine	C	Metronidazole	Duodenal trophozoites suggest **Giardia lamblia** (giardiasis). **Metronidazole** is the treatment of choice. Other options include tinidazole or nitazoxanide. Giardia causes chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss.	**Giardiasis treatment:** Metronidazole (trophozoites in duodenal biopsy, chronic diarrhea).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q31: A person with liver disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni would be most likely to have	Ascites	esophageal varices	gynecomastia	Jaundice	spider nevi	B	esophageal varices	**S. mansoni** causes hepatosplenic schistosomiasis with **periportal fibrosis** (Symmers' pipe-stem fibrosis) leading to **portal hypertension** and **esophageal varices**, but **WITHOUT hepatocellular damage**. Therefore, no jaundice, ascites, spider nevi, or gynecomastia (these occur in cirrhosis).	**Schistosoma mansoni:** Portal hypertension → esophageal varices (periportal fibrosis, **NOT cirrhosis** - liver function preserved).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q32: All of the following antifungal medications may be used for the treatment of Candida albicans fungemia except	amphotericin B	Caspofungin	fluconazole	Terbinafine	voriconazole	D	Terbinafine	**Terbinafine** is used for **dermatophytes** (tinea infections), **NOT Candida**. Candida fungemia is treated with **azoles** (fluconazole, voriconazole), **echinocandins** (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin), or **amphotericin B**.	**Candida fungemia:** Azoles, echinocandins, amphotericin B. **NOT terbinafine** (for dermatophytes/tinea).	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q61: 'River blindness' is due to	Toxoplasmosis	Trichinasis	Onchocerciasis	Cysticerosis		C	Onchocerciasis	**Onchocerciasis** (caused by **Onchocerca volvulus**) is transmitted by **blackflies** breeding in fast-flowing rivers, hence **'river blindness'**. Microfilariae in the eye cause keratitis and chorioretinitis leading to blindness. Treatment: ivermectin.	**River blindness** = Onchocerciasis (Onchocerca volvulus) transmitted by blackflies in rivers. Treated with ivermectin.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q62: One of these fungal infections has bad prognosis if associated with covid 19	Cryptococcosis	Candidiasis	Mucormycosis	Histoplasmosis	Asperigillosis	C	Mucormycosis	**Mucormycosis** (black fungus) has particularly **poor prognosis** in COVID-19 patients, especially those with **diabetes** and on **steroids**. It causes rapidly progressive rhinocerebral or pulmonary disease with high mortality despite aggressive surgical debridement and antifungals.	**COVID-19 fungal complication:** Mucormycosis (bad prognosis) - risk factors: diabetes, steroids, immunosuppression.	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q63: The most affected WBC of the immune system with HIV infection is :	CD8 T- lymphocyte	CD4 T- lymphocyte.	Plasma cell	Macrophage.	CD3 T- lymphocyte	B	CD4 T- lymphocyte.	**HIV** primarily targets **CD4+ T lymphocytes** (helper T cells) via the CD4 receptor and CCR5/CXCR4 co-receptors, leading to progressive immunodeficiency. AIDS is defined as CD4 count <200 cells/μL or presence of AIDS-defining illness.	**HIV:** Primarily targets CD4+ T helper cells → progressive depletion → immunodeficiency (AIDS: CD4 <200).	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q64: In the developed world, seroprevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection is currently	Decreasing	increasing	staying the same	unknown		A	Decreasing	**H. pylori** seroprevalence is **decreasing in developed countries** due to improved sanitation, hygiene, less crowded living conditions, and antibiotic use. However, it remains **high in developing countries** (>80% in some regions).	**H. pylori prevalence:** Decreasing in developed countries (better sanitation), high in developing countries.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q65: Malta fever is caused by	Pasteurella tularensis	Haemophilus influenzae	Brucella abortus	Pseudomonas mallei		C	Brucella abortus	**Malta fever** (Brucellosis) is caused by **Brucella** species, particularly **B. abortus** (cattle), **B. melitensis** (goats/sheep - most virulent), **B. suis** (pigs). It causes undulant fever, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly. Transmission: unpasteurized dairy, contact with animals.	**Malta fever** = Brucellosis (Brucella abortus/melitensis) - undulant fever from unpasteurized dairy/animal contact.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q66: Woolsorker's disease is	Plague	Legionnaires' disease	Klebsiella-induced pneumonia	Anthrax		D	Anthrax	**Woolsorter's disease** is **inhalational anthrax**, historically seen in wool workers exposed to **Bacillus anthracis** spores from contaminated animal hides/wool. It causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis with high mortality despite treatment.	**Woolsorter's disease** = Inhalational anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) - occupational exposure to contaminated wool/hides.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q67: Which is not a cause of aseptic fever	Crush injury	SLE	AIDS	Pontine haemorrhage		C	AIDS	**AIDS itself doesn't cause aseptic fever**; fever in AIDS patients is usually due to **opportunistic infections**. **Aseptic fever** causes include: trauma (crush injury), autoimmune diseases (SLE), malignancy, drug fever, CNS hemorrhage (pontine hemorrhage), pulmonary embolism.	**Aseptic fever:** Trauma, autoimmune (SLE), malignancy, drug fever, CNS hemorrhage. **NOT AIDS** (infections cause fever in AIDS).	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q68: The best score in Glasgow coma scale is	10	15	20	22	12	B	15	**Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)** ranges from **3 (worst/coma)** to **15 (best/normal)**. It assesses: Eye opening (1-4), Verbal response (1-5), Motor response (1-6). GCS ≤8 indicates severe brain injury/coma requiring intubation.	**GCS range:** 3 (worst/coma) to 15 (best/normal). ≤8 = severe injury/coma.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q69: Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	**Generalized lymphadenopathy** is defined as enlargement of **≥2 non-contiguous** (not adjacent) lymph node regions. Localized lymphadenopathy involves 1 region. Causes: infections (HIV, EBV, TB), malignancy (lymphoma, leukemia), autoimmune diseases.	**Generalized lymphadenopathy:** ≥2 **non-contiguous** lymph node groups enlarged. Causes: HIV, EBV, TB, lymphoma, SLE.	Hematology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P45-64, Q70: One of the following is not a method of HIV infection:	Feco-oral route.	I.V drug users and shairing needle	Sexual relations.	Vertical transmission of infected mothers.	Lactation	A	Feco-oral route.	**HIV is NOT transmitted via feco-oral route**. HIV transmission routes: **Blood** (IVDU, transfusions, needlestick), **Sexual contact**, **Vertical** (mother-to-child: transplacental, delivery, breastfeeding). HIV requires direct blood/body fluid contact with mucosa or bloodstream.	**HIV transmission:** Blood, sex, vertical (pregnancy/delivery/breastfeeding). **NOT** feco-oral, casual contact, mosquitoes.	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q1: A 7-year school-boy has been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Close contacts of meningococcal meningitis require **chemoprophylaxis** with rifampicin (or ciprofloxacin/ceftriaxone). Close contacts include household members, classmates in same classroom, and anyone with direct contact with oral secretions.	**Meningococcal prophylaxis:** Rifampicin for close contacts (class and family, NOT whole school).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q2: Which one of the following is the most likely presentation of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning?	Tenesmus	Watery diarrhoea	Dysentery	Severe vomiting		D	Severe vomiting	**S. aureus** produces **preformed enterotoxin** causing **rapid onset** (1-6 hours) of **severe nausea and profuse vomiting** with minimal diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and NO fever. Self-limited (24-48 hours). Source: food handlers with skin infections.	**S. aureus food poisoning:** Rapid onset (1-6h) **severe vomiting** > diarrhea, no fever, preformed toxin, self-limited.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q3: All of the following diseases can cause huge splenomegaly except:	HCV infection	Biharziasis	Thalassemia	Malaria		A	HCV infection	**HCV** causes chronic liver disease and cirrhosis but typically **NOT massive splenomegaly**. Causes of **massive splenomegaly** (>8 cm below costal margin): **Schistosomiasis** (Bilharziasis), **Malaria**, **Thalassemia**, Myelofibrosis, CML, Gaucher disease, Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar).	**Massive splenomegaly causes:** Schistosomiasis, malaria, thalassemia, myelofibrosis, CML. **NOT HCV** (causes cirrhosis with moderate splenomegaly).	Hematology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q4: Which type of bite represents a potential medical emergency in an asplenic patient?	Cat bite	Dog bite	Fish bite	Human bite		B	Dog bite	**Asplenic patients** are at high risk for **overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)** from **encapsulated organisms**. **Dog bites** can transmit **Capnocytophaga canimorsus** and **Streptococcus** species, causing fulminant sepsis in asplenic patients. Also at risk from **Streptococcus pneumoniae**, **Haemophilus influenzae**, **Neisseria meningitidis**.	**Asplenic patient + dog bite** = Risk of OPSI from Capnocytophaga, Streptococcus. Also vaccinate against encapsulated organisms.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q5: A 47-year-old man was admitted with right flank and right iliac fossa pain, of 1 month's duration. He described weight loss, night sweats, fever and an intermittent non-productive cough on direct questioning. Chest radiograph showed right upper lobe and left mid-zone infiltration. The left cardiac border was indistinct. Small cavities were visible in both infiltrates. what is the most probable diagnosis	Intestinal T.B	Colorectal cancer	CMV colitis	Bacterial gastroenteritis		A	Intestinal T.B	**Constitutional symptoms** (fever, night sweats, weight loss) + **chronic course** (1 month) + **cavitary lung lesions** on chest X-ray suggest **pulmonary tuberculosis** with possible **intestinal TB** involvement (abdominal pain). TB commonly affects terminal ileum and cecum (right lower quadrant pain).	**TB presentation:** Constitutional symptoms + chronic course + cavitary lung lesions ± intestinal involvement (terminal ileum/cecum).	Tuberculosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q6: Rate of transmission of HCV after needle stick injury is:	1 %	0.3 %	3 %	30 %		C	3 %	**HCV transmission** risk after needlestick is approximately **1.8-3%**. For comparison: **HIV ~0.3%** (higher with deep injury, visible blood, source with high viral load), **HBV ~30%** without vaccination/prophylaxis. Post-exposure: Test baseline and follow-up, no prophylaxis available for HCV.	**Needlestick transmission risk:** HCV ~3%, HIV ~0.3%, HBV ~30% (without vaccination).	Occupational Health				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q7: Chronic hepatitis is considered when duration of more than:	3 months	4 months	5 months	6 months		D	6 months	**Chronic hepatitis** is defined as **liver inflammation persisting for more than 6 months**. Acute hepatitis is <6 months. Common causes of chronic hepatitis: HBV, HCV, alcohol, autoimmune hepatitis, NASH, drugs, Wilson disease, hemochromatosis.	**Chronic hepatitis:** Inflammation >6 months. Causes: HBV, HCV, alcohol, autoimmune, NASH.	Hepatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q8: A 10 years old child comes to the clinic complaining of fever of 2 days duration, sore throat and fatigue. He reports that there is painful swelling in his neck. His CBC shows lymphocytosis with many atypical cells. What is the appropriate treatment of this patient?	Symptomatic treatment	corticosteroid	Broad spectrum antibiotic	acyclovir		A	Symptomatic treatment	Clinical presentation suggests **infectious mononucleosis (EBV)**: fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, atypical lymphocytosis. Treatment is **supportive/symptomatic** (rest, hydration, antipyretics). **Avoid ampicillin/amoxicillin** (causes maculopapular rash). No role for antivirals. Warn about splenic rupture risk (avoid contact sports).	**EBV/Mono treatment:** Symptomatic only. **Avoid ampicillin** (causes rash), avoid contact sports (spleen rupture risk).	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q9: A 53-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for fever. He underwent elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery 2 days ago. urinary catheter was inserted in the operating room. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C, blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg, pulse rate is 88/min, and respiration rate is 18/min. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The sternotomy incision site is clean and dry. He has mild suprapubic tenderness but no costovertebral angle or flank tenderness. Urine analysis reveals 10 to 20 leukocytes/hpf. Urine culture reveals> 400 colonies gram-negative rods. Chest radiograph shows no infiltrate. In addition to removing the urinary catheter, which of the following is the most appropriate management?	wait antimicrobial sensitivity before beginning antimicrobial therapy	Begin antimicrobial therapy now	Repeat urinalysis and urine culture in 24 hours	Provide no additional treatment		B	Begin antimicrobial therapy now	**Symptomatic catheter-associated UTI (CA-UTI)** with fever, pyuria, and positive culture requires **immediate removal of catheter AND empiric antibiotic therapy**. Don't wait for sensitivities in symptomatic infection. Cover gram-negatives empirically (e.g., ceftriaxone, fluoroquinolone), then adjust based on culture results.	**CA-UTI management:** Remove catheter + start empiric antibiotics immediately (don't wait for sensitivities in symptomatic cases).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q10: Each attack of FMF usually lasts for:	6 hours to 2 days	12 hours to 3 days	24 hours to 7 days	3 days to 10 days		B	12 hours to 3 days	**Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF)** episodes typically last **12-72 hours (0.5-3 days)** with spontaneous resolution. Features: recurrent fever, serositis (peritonitis, pleuritis, synovitis), rash. Autosomal recessive (MEFV gene). Prevention: **colchicine** (prevents attacks and amyloidosis).	**FMF attacks:** 12-72 hours duration, recurrent fever + serositis. Prevention: colchicine.	Rheumatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q11: Which of the following produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Heat stroke	Peripheral circulatory failure	Thyrotoxicosis		C	Peripheral circulatory failure	**Peripheral circulatory failure (shock)** causes **hypothermia** due to poor tissue perfusion. NMS and heat stroke cause **hyperthermia**. Other hypothermia causes: hypothyroidism (myxedema coma), hypoglycemia, sepsis (late stage), hypothalamic lesions, exposure.	**Hypothermia causes:** Shock/circulatory failure, hypothyroidism, hypoglycemia, exposure. **NOT** NMS/heat stroke (cause hyperthermia).	Thermoregulation				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q12: Cinchonism is a possible side effect for:	Primaquin	Proguanil	Chloroquine	Mefloquine	Quinine	E	Quinine	**Cinchonism** is **quinine/quinidine toxicity** manifesting as: **tinnitus**, hearing loss, visual disturbances (blurred vision, photophobia, impaired color vision), headache, nausea, vertigo, confusion. Occurs with therapeutic or toxic doses. Severe toxicity causes arrhythmias, hypotension, blindness.	**Cinchonism:** Quinine/quinidine toxicity → tinnitus, hearing loss, visual changes, nausea, confusion.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q13: A 31-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 5-day history of abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and loose stools, accompanied by progressively increasing fever. He also has a moderate headache and a rash. On physical examination, temperature is 40 °C , pulse rate is 64/min, normal blood pressure and respiratory rate, The patient appears sick. There are blanching erythematous macules on the lower chest and upper abdominal wall. The pharynx is erythematous. Abdominal examination reveals tender hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination is normal .His CBC shows leucopenia with lymphopenia. liver profile shows elevated liver enzymes. Two sets of aerobic blood cultures show gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	Brucellosis	Lassa fever	Leptospirosis	Typhoid fever		D	Typhoid fever	Classic **typhoid fever** (Salmonella typhi): **High fever** + **relative bradycardia** (pulse-temperature dissociation) + **rose spots** (blanching salmon-colored macules on trunk) + **hepatosplenomegaly** + **leucopenia** + positive blood culture. Treatment: ceftriaxone or fluoroquinolone. Complications: intestinal perforation, hemorrhage.	**Typhoid fever:** High fever + **relative bradycardia** + rose spots + hepatosplenomegaly + leucopenia + gram-negative bacilli in blood.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q14: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. He states that the symptoms are worse with eating, and that his abdominal pain has been increasing over the past three to four months. He reports a history of travel to endemic area with parasites five months ago. After that he developed a cough associated with mild shortness of breath which he attributed to a viral respiratory infection, as it resolved shortly thereafter. His physical examination is significant for moderate periumbilical tenderness. His laboratory results are significant for an eosinophil count of 20 percent. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed small bowel dilation proximal to a whirlpool-like mass in the mid-jejunum causing intestinal obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Clonorchis sinensis	Ascaris lumbricoides	Trichuris trichiura	Cystoisospora belli	Taenia saginata	B	Ascaris lumbricoides	**Ascaris lumbricoides** lifecycle: **Pulmonary phase** (larvae migrate through lungs causing cough, Loeffler syndrome) → **Intestinal phase** (adult worms in small intestine). Complications: **intestinal obstruction** (bolus of worms), biliary obstruction, pancreatitis. Diagnosis: stool ova, imaging. Treatment: albendazole/mebendazole.	**Ascaris:** Pulmonary phase (cough, eosinophilia) → intestinal phase → complications (bowel obstruction, biliary obstruction).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q15: A 19-year-old man plans on traveling to Nigeria. He comes to clinic interested in travel advice and any vaccinations he may need. He has no medical history and takes no medicines. In addition to DEET and mosquito netting, which of the following recommendations would be important for prophylaxis against malaria?	Tetracyclin	Mefloquine	Primaquin	Atovaquone		B	Mefloquine	For travel to malaria-endemic areas (Nigeria has chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum), prophylaxis options include: **Mefloquine** (start 1 week before), **Atovaquone-proguanil** (start 1-2 days before), or **Doxycycline** (start 1-2 days before). Continue during travel and 4 weeks after (1 week for atovaquone-proguanil).	**Malaria prophylaxis options:** Mefloquine (start 1 week before), atovaquone-proguanil, or doxycycline. Plus DEET and bed nets.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q16: One of the following bundle has been shown to reduce ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP ) rates:	elevate the head of the bed to between 90 and 120 degrees.	daily sedation and intubation	daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	no prophylaxis for peptic ulcer is needed.	early ambulation to prevent anti-deep venous thrombosis.	C	daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	**VAP prevention bundle** includes: **Head of bed elevation 30-45°** (not 90-120°), **Daily sedation vacation** and spontaneous breathing trials, **Daily oral care with chlorhexidine**, **Peptic ulcer prophylaxis**, **DVT prophylaxis**. Also: subglottic suctioning, avoid reintubation.	**VAP bundle:** HOB 30-45°, sedation breaks, **oral chlorhexidine**, PUD prophylaxis, DVT prophylaxis.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q17: 12 patients presented to a local emergency department with similar symptoms of severe nausea, profuse vomiting, and severe abdominal cramps. A few patients reported diarrhea. The patients report that they were all present at a lunch party two hours ago. The dishes were served from slow cookers, and the food handlers did not wear gloves. None of the patients were found to be febrile. The patients were treated with supportive care and hydration. Within 24 hours, all the patients had resolution of their symptoms. What is the most likely cause of this disease outbreak?	Salmonella infection.	Norovirus infection	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	perfringens infection.		C	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	**Rapid onset (1-6 hours)** + **severe vomiting** + minimal fever + **quick resolution** (24h) + food handlers without gloves = **S. aureus preformed enterotoxin**. Contrast: Norovirus (12-48h onset, more diarrhea), Salmonella (12-72h, fever, longer duration), C. perfringens (8-16h, more diarrhea).	**S. aureus food poisoning:** **Rapid onset (1-6h)**, severe vomiting, no fever, self-limited (24h), from food handlers.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q18: A 24 years old male coming to you complaining of epigastic discomfort and vomiting ,You requested testing for H.pylori which was positive .In addition to PPI .Choose the most suitable antimicrobials	Ceftriaxone	Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	Azithromycin	Doxycyclin		B	Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	**H. pylori treatment** (triple therapy): **PPI** (omeprazole, lansoprazole) **+ Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin** for **14 days** is standard first-line. Alternative: quadruple therapy (PPI + bismuth + tetracycline + metronidazole) for 14 days. Confirm eradication with urea breath test or stool antigen 4+ weeks post-treatment.	**H. pylori triple therapy:** PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin × 14 days. Confirm eradication with urea breath test.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q19: Refering to the last question, one month after receiving a 14-day course of the antimicrobials, you prescribed for Helicobacter pylori. He still has mild dyspepsia and pain after meals. What is the appropriate next step in management?	Empirical long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy	Endoscopy with biopsy to rule out gastric adenocarcinoma	Second-line therapy for H. pylori with omeprazole, bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole	Urea breath test	H. pylori serology testing	D	Urea breath test	After H. pylori treatment, must **confirm eradication** with **urea breath test** or **stool antigen test** (NOT serology, which remains positive for years). Test at least **4 weeks** after completing antibiotics and **2 weeks** after stopping PPI. If positive, use second-line quadruple therapy.	**H. pylori eradication test:** Urea breath test or stool antigen (≥4 weeks post-treatment). **NOT serology** (stays positive).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q20: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Ascaris lumbricoides infection except:	asymptomatic carriage	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	non-productive cough and pleurisy with eosinophilia	right upper quadrant pain and fever	small-bowel obstruction	B	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	These symptoms suggest **meningitis**, NOT ascariasis. **Ascaris manifestations**: **Asymptomatic** (most common), **Loeffler syndrome** (pulmonary eosinophilia with cough during larval migration), **Biliary obstruction** (RUQ pain, cholangitis), **Intestinal obstruction**, **Pancreatitis**, Nutritional deficiency.	**Ascaris manifestations:** Asymptomatic, Loeffler syndrome (pulmonary), biliary obstruction, bowel obstruction. **NOT meningitis**.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q21: A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by friends for confusion and altered mental status. They state that many colleagues have upper respiratory tract infections. He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. His physical examination is notable for confusion, fever, and a rigid neck. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination reveals a white blood cell count of 1800 cells/μL with 98% neutrophils, glucose of 1.9 mmol/L (35 mg/dL), and protein of 1.0 g/L (100 mg/dL). What is the most probable diagnosis:	Bacterial meningitis	Viral meningitis	Viral encephalitis	Tubercoulus meningitis		A	Bacterial meningitis	CSF with **neutrophilic pleocytosis (98% PMNs)**, **low glucose** (<40% of serum), and **elevated protein** indicates **bacterial meningitis**. Viral meningitis: lymphocytic, normal glucose. TB meningitis: lymphocytic, low glucose, very high protein. In college student: likely N. meningitidis or S. pneumoniae.	**Bacterial meningitis CSF:** Neutrophils ↑ (>80%), Glucose ↓ (<40% serum), Protein ↑ (>45 mg/dL).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q22: Referring to the last question: Which of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate as initial therapy?	Ampicillin plus vancomycin	Ampicillin plus gentamycin	Cefotaxime plus vancomycin	Cefotaxime plus doxycyclin		C	Cefotaxime plus vancomycin	For bacterial meningitis in **young adults (18-50 years)**, empiric therapy is **ceftriaxone/cefotaxime PLUS vancomycin** (covers S. pneumoniae including penicillin/cephalosporin-resistant strains, and N. meningitidis). Add ampicillin if >50 years or immunocompromised (for Listeria). Give dexamethasone before/with first antibiotic dose.	**Bacterial meningitis empiric therapy (18-50 yo):** Ceftriaxone/cefotaxime + vancomycin (± dexamethasone).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q23: Which of the following statements regarding Clostridium difficile–associated disease relapses is true?	A first recurrence does not imply greater risk of further recurrences.	Most recurrences are due to antibiotic resistance.	Recurrent C. difficile–associated disease has been associated with a higher risk of colon cancer.	Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	Testing for clearance of C. difficile is warranted after treating recurrences.	D	Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	**Recurrent C. difficile infection** can lead to severe complications including toxic megacolon, perforation, and death. **First recurrence increases risk** of subsequent recurrences (up to 65% after 2nd recurrence). Most recurrences are **reinfection**, not resistance. Do **NOT** test for clearance (colonization persists). Treat recurrences with fidaxomicin or vancomycin taper/pulse, consider fecal microbiota transplant.	**C. difficile recurrence:** Increased risk of complications and further recurrences. Don't test for clearance. Consider FMT after multiple recurrences.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q24: Retinochroiditis is caused by eye infection with:	Loa-loa	Onchocerca volvulous	Demodex folliculorum	Toxoplasma gondi	Toxocara cani	D	Toxoplasma gondi	**Toxoplasma gondii** causes **retinochoroiditis** (necrotizing retinitis), a leading cause of posterior uveitis. Most common in **congenital toxoplasmosis** (classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications) or reactivation in immunocompromised. Treatment: pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine + leucovorin.	**Retinochoroiditis:** Toxoplasma gondii. Congenital (triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, calcifications) or reactivation in immunocompromised.	Ophthalmology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 45-64	P145-157, Q25: A 23-year-old previously healthy female letter carrier works in an area in which the presence of rabid foxes have been documented. She is bitten by a bat, which then flies away. Initial examination reveals a clean break in the skin in the right upper forearm. She has no history of receiving treatment for rabies and is unsure about vaccination against tetanus. The physician should:	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution and administer tetanus toxoid	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, and administer human rabies immune globulin intramuscularly	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, administer human rabies immune globulin IM, and administer human diploid cell vaccine	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution and administer human diploid cell vaccine	D	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, administer human rabies immune globulin IM, and administer human diploid cell vaccine	**Bat bite with skin break** in rabies-endemic area requires **complete post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)**: (1) **Thorough wound cleaning** with soap/water, (2) **Tetanus prophylaxis** if needed, (3) **Rabies immune globulin (RIG)** - infiltrate wound + IM, (4) **Rabies vaccine series** (4-5 doses: days 0, 3, 7, 14, ±28). Bat bites are high-risk even if minor (bats have small teeth).	**Rabies PEP (bat bite):** Wound cleaning + tetanus + **RIG (infiltrate wound + IM)** + **rabies vaccine series** (days 0,3,7,14).	Rabies				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q171: A 34-year-old man presents with a widespread maculopapular rash and mouth ulcers. Two months ago he presented to the local GUM clinic after developing a painless penile ulcer. At the time he was noted to have inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible?	Lymphogranuloma venereum	Herpes simplex virus type 2	Mycoplasma genitalium	Haemophilus ducreyi	Treponema pallidum	E	Treponema pallidum	This patient has symptoms of secondary syphilis. Primary features: chancre (painless ulcer at site of sexual contact), local non-tender lymphadenopathy. Secondary features (6-10 weeks after primary): systemic symptoms (fevers, lymphadenopathy), rash on trunk/palms/soles, buccal 'snail track' ulcers (30%), condylomata lata. Tertiary features: gummas, ascending aortic aneurysms, general paralysis of the insane, tabes dorsalis, Argyll-Robertson pupil.	**Syphilis stages:** Primary (painless chancre), Secondary (rash on palms/soles, buccal ulcers, condylomata lata), Tertiary (gummas, aortic aneurysm, tabes dorsalis).	Syphilis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q172: A 32-year-old woman attends the emergency department 8 days after returning from a Safari holiday in Uganda with headache, fever, muscle pains and malaise. She did not have vaccinations or antimalarial prophylaxis. Her temperature is 39.5ºC, blood pressure 100/70 mmHg, heart rate 110/min, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, oxygen saturations 98% on air. Her blood sugar is 2.8 mmol/L. Her blood film shows P. falciparum with 5% parasitaemia. How would you treat her?	Oral artesunate combination therapy	Oral chloroquine	IV artesunate	IV mefloquine	IV quinine	C	IV artesunate	This lady has severe falciparum malaria: high parasitaemia (>2%), hypoglycaemia, high temperature. Latest WHO guidelines recommend IV artesunate as 1st line treatment for severe falciparum malaria. IV quinine can be used if artesunate not available but inferior. Criteria for severe malaria: parasitaemia >2%, hypoglycaemia, severe anaemia, renal failure, pulmonary oedema, metabolic acidosis, abnormal bleeding, multiple convulsions, seizures, shock. If parasite count >10% consider exchange transfusion.	**Severe falciparum malaria:** parasitaemia >2%, schizonts on film, hypoglycaemia, temp >39°C. **Treatment:** IV artesunate (1st line), IV quinine (2nd line).	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q173: Which one of the following statements is true regarding Listeria monocytogenes?	Multiplies rapidly at high temperatures	The organism is resistant to ampicillin	It is a Gram negative bacillus	It is diagnosed by the presence of urinary antigen	May cause ataxia	E	May cause ataxia	Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram positive bacillus with unusual ability to multiply at low temperatures. Spread via contaminated food (unpasteurised dairy). Features: diarrhoea, flu-like illness, pneumonia, meningoencephalitis, ataxia and seizures. Diagnosis: blood cultures, CSF may show pleocytosis with 'tumbling motility' on wet mounts. Management: sensitive to amoxicillin/ampicillin (cephalosporins inadequate). Listeria meningitis treated with IV amoxicillin/ampicillin + gentamicin.	**Listeria:** Gram-positive bacillus, multiplies at low temp, ataxia/seizures, sensitive to ampicillin (not cephalosporins), treat meningitis with ampicillin + gentamicin.	Listeria				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q174: Which one of the following statements regarding hepatitis B is correct?	Ribavirin is the treatment of choice for chronic hepatitis B	All patient immunised against hepatitis B require an anti-HBs check to assess their response to the vaccine	10-15% of adults fail to respond or respond poorly to 3 doses of the vaccine	The vaccine is of the live-attenuated type	An anti-HBs level of 20 mIU/ml indicates an adequate response to the vaccine	C	10-15% of adults fail to respond or respond poorly to 3 doses of the vaccine	Only those at risk of occupational exposure (healthcare workers) and CKD patients require anti-HBs check. Around 10-15% of adults fail to respond or respond poorly to 3 doses. Risk factors: age >40 years, obesity, smoking, alcohol excess, immunosuppression. Anti-HBs interpretation: >100 mIU/ml adequate response; 10-100 mIU/ml suboptimal (give one more dose); <10 mIU/ml non-responder (repeat full course, if still fails then HBIG required).	**Hepatitis B vaccine:** 10-15% poor response. Anti-HBs >100 adequate, 10-100 give one more dose, <10 repeat course.	Hepatitis B				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q175: A 45-year-old female presents to the Emergency Department three days after returning from Thailand complaining of severe muscle ache, fever and headache. On examination she has a widespread maculopapular rash. Results show: Malaria film negative, Hb 16.2 g/dl, Plt 96 × 10⁹/l, WBC 2.4 × 10⁹/l, ALT 146 iu/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Hepatitis A	Japanese encephalitis	Rheumatic fever	Malaria	Dengue fever	E	Dengue fever	The low platelet count and raised transaminase level is typical of dengue fever. Transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito, incubation 7 days. Features: headache (retro-orbital), fever, myalgia, pleuritic pain, facial flushing, maculopapular rash. Dengue haemorrhagic fever (DHF) is a form of DIC; 20-30% develop dengue shock syndrome (DSS). Treatment is symptomatic (fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion).	**Dengue fever:** Aedes aegypti, thrombocytopenia, raised transaminases, retro-orbital headache, maculopapular rash. DHF → DSS.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q176: Which one of the following is the most likely presentation of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning?	Tenesmus	Watery diarrhoea	Dysentery	Severe vomiting	Presentation 24-48 hours after eating affected food	D	Severe vomiting	Severe nausea and vomiting are caused by enterotoxins A-E. Staphylococcus aureus causes acute food poisoning with severe vomiting and short incubation period. Other acute food poisoning organisms: Bacillus cereus, Clostridium perfringens.	**S. aureus food poisoning:** severe vomiting, short incubation period (1-6 hours).	Gastroenteritis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q177: Following a diagnosis of tetanus, what is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy to give with human tetanus immunoglobulin?	IV clarithromycin	IV benzylpenicillin	IV gentamicin	IV metronidazole	IV ciprofloxacin	D	IV metronidazole	Tetanus caused by tetanospasmin exotoxin from Clostridium tetani. Spores in soil, introduced via wounds. Prevents GABA release. Features: prodrome (fever, lethargy, headache), trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, spasms. Management: supportive (ventilatory support, muscle relaxants), IM human tetanus immunoglobulin for high-risk wounds, metronidazole now preferred to benzylpenicillin as antibiotic of choice.	**Tetanus:** Clostridium tetani, prevents GABA release, trismus/risus sardonicus/opisthotonus. Treat with IM immunoglobulin + IV metronidazole.	Tetanus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q178: A 37-year-old sewer worker presents to the Emergency Department with flu-like symptoms and pyrexia for the past 3 days. Since this morning he has started to develop a headache and signs of meningism are found on examination. Blood tests show: Sodium 145 mmol/l, Potassium 4.7 mmol/l, Urea 10.3 mmol/l, Creatinine 133 μmol/l. What is the antibiotic treatment of choice?	Co-trimoxazole	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	Benzylpenicillin	Erythromycin	D	Benzylpenicillin	This patient has leptospirosis. Treatment of choice is benzylpenicillin. Lumbar puncture should ideally be done first to confirm meningeal involvement. Leptospirosis (Weil's disease) common in sewage workers, farmers, vets, abattoir workers. Caused by spirochaete Leptospira interrogans, spread by rat urine. Features: fever, flu-like symptoms, renal failure (50%), jaundice, subconjunctival haemorrhage, headache (may herald meningitis). Treatment: high-dose benzylpenicillin or doxycycline.	**Leptospirosis:** sewage workers/farmers, rat urine, hepatorenal failure, subconjunctival haemorrhage. Treat with benzylpenicillin/doxycycline.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q179: A 30-year-old woman presents with a white, malodorous vaginal discharge. There is no associated itch or dyspareunia. A diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is suspected. Overgrowth of which one of the following organisms is most likely to cause this presentation?	Lactobacilli	Trichomonas	Candida	Mycoplasma hominis	Gardnerella	E	Gardnerella	Bacterial vaginosis is caused by overgrowth of predominately Gardnerella vaginalis (anaerobic organism). Features: fishy, offensive vaginal discharge; asymptomatic in 50%. Amsel's criteria (3 of 4): thin white homogenous discharge, clue cells on microscopy, vaginal pH >4.5, positive whiff test. Management: oral metronidazole 5-7 days.	**Bacterial vaginosis:** Gardnerella vaginalis overgrowth, fishy discharge, pH >4.5, clue cells, treat with metronidazole.	Gynecology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q180: A 7-year-old boy is admitted to hospital after presenting with fever, headache and neck stiffness. A diagnosis of pneumococcal meningitis is made. There are no other reports of meningitis in the local area over the past 4 weeks. How should the close contacts of this boy be managed?	No action is needed	Pneumococcal vaccine booster	Oral amoxicillin	Oral amoxicillin + pneumococcal vaccine booster	Oral ciprofloxacin	A	No action is needed	Carriage of pneumococcus is extremely common and no antibiotic prophylaxis is generally required. However, exceptions exist if a 'cluster' of cases develop.	**Pneumococcal meningitis:** no prophylaxis for contacts unless cluster of cases. **Meningococcal:** ciprofloxacin/rifampicin for close contacts.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q181: A 62-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a 'rash' on his left shin. This has grown in size over the past two days and is now a painful, hot, erythematous area on his anterior left shin spreading around to the back of the leg. He is systemically well and a decision is made to give oral treatment. He has a past history of penicillin allergy. What is the most appropriate antibiotic to give?	Ciprofloxacin	Cefaclor	Flucloxacillin	Vancomycin	Clarithromycin	E	Clarithromycin	Cellulitis in penicillin-allergic patient. First-line for cellulitis is flucloxacillin, but with penicillin allergy, clarithromycin or doxycycline should be used.	**Cellulitis:** flucloxacillin (1st line). If penicillin-allergic: clarithromycin or doxycycline.	Cellulitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q182: A 25-year-old intravenous drug user with chronic hepatitis C becomes pregnant. Approximately what is the chance of the virus being transmitted to her child?	<10%	10-20%	20-30%	30-40%	40-50%	A	<10%	Vertical transmission of hepatitis C is less than 10%. Risk increases if mother co-infected with HIV.	**Hepatitis C vertical transmission:** <10% (higher if co-infected with HIV).	Hepatitis C				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q183: A 22-year-old woman who is an immigrant from Malawi presents for review as she thinks she is pregnant. This is confirmed with a positive pregnancy test. She is known to be HIV positive. Which one of the following should NOT be part of the management plan to ensure an optimal outcome?	Oral zidovudine for the newborn until 6 weeks of age	Maternal antiretroviral therapy	Encourage breast feeding	Intrapartum zidovudine infusion	Elective caesarean section	C	Encourage breast feeding	BHIVA guidelines suggest vaginal delivery may be option for women on HAART with undetectable viral load. All mothers known to be HIV positive, regardless of antiretroviral therapy and infant PEP, should be advised to exclusively formula feed from birth. HIV transmission risk via breastfeeding.	**HIV in pregnancy:** maternal HAART, intrapartum zidovudine, oral zidovudine for newborn 6 weeks, **NO breastfeeding** (exclusively formula feed).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q184: An 18-year-old male is admitted with fever, headache and neck stiffness. He receives IV ceftriaxone. A lumbar puncture and culture of his cerebrospinal fluid reveal that the pathogenic organism is Neisseria meningitides. What is the appearance of this bacterium on gram staining?	Gram-positive cocci	Gram-negative cocci	Gram-positive rod	Gram-negative rod	Poorly staining organism	B	Gram-negative cocci	Neisseria species are gram-negative cocci. Bacteria cluster in pairs to form diplococci. Other gram-negative cocci include Moraxella catarrhalis and Haemophilus influenzae.	**Neisseria:** Gram-negative cocci (diplococci). Also Moraxella catarrhalis.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q185: A 30-year-old man presents for review two weeks after returning from a camping holiday in the New Forest. For the past few days he has felt general unwell with lethargy and arthralgia. On examination he has a rash consistent with erythema chronicum migrans. What is the most appropriate test to perform given the likely diagnosis?	ELISA test for antibodies to Borrelia burgdorferi	Polymerase chain reaction for Borrelia DNA	Blood cultures	Blood film	Bone marrow biopsy	A	ELISA test for antibodies to Borrelia burgdorferi	Serological tests are most appropriate first line investigation for diagnosing Lyme disease. ELISA tests preferred to Western blots as more sensitive. Lyme disease features: erythema chronicum migrans (bulls-eye rash 70%), systemic symptoms, later CVS (heart block, myocarditis), neurological (cranial nerve palsies, meningitis), polyarthritis.	**Lyme disease diagnosis:** ELISA for Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies (more sensitive than Western blot). Erythema chronicum migrans (bulls-eye).	Lyme Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q186: Which of the following types of viral meningitis may be characteristically associated with a low cerebrospinal fluid glucose level?	Mumps	Cytomegalovirus	Measles	HIV	Echovirus	A	Mumps	Mumps meningitis is associated with a low CSF glucose in up to a third of patients. Most viral meningitis causes normal or slightly raised CSF glucose, but mumps is exception.	**Mumps meningitis:** low CSF glucose (up to 1/3 patients). Most viral meningitis has normal/raised glucose.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q187: A 19-year-old woman is reviewed in the genitourinary medicine clinic. She presented with vaginal discharge and dysuria. Microscopy of an endocervical swab showed a Gram-negative coccus that was later identified as Neisseria gonorrhoea. This is her third episode of gonorrhoea in the past two years. What is the most likely complication from repeated infection?	Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome	Cervical cancer	Arthropathy	Infertility	Uterine abscess	D	Infertility	Infertility secondary to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is most common complication of gonorrhoea. It is second most common cause of PID after Chlamydia. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (complication of PID) and arthropathy may occur but far less common. Local complications: urethral strictures, epididymitis, salpingitis (leading to infertility). Disseminated infection: tenosynovitis, migratory polyarthritis, dermatitis, septic arthritis, endocarditis, perihepatitis.	**Gonorrhoea complication:** infertility (PID/salpingitis). 2nd most common cause of PID after Chlamydia.	STI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q188: A 44-year-old man who is known to have HIV is admitted to the Emergency Department following a seizure. He has been taking antiretroviral therapy for the past two years. A CT scan (without contrast) shows a solitary lesion in the basal ganglia. What is the most effective method to help differentiate between lymphoma and toxoplasmosis?	MR spectroscopy	CT with contrast	Thallium SPECT	Peripheral blood film	Lumbar puncture	C	Thallium SPECT	Differentiating toxoplasmosis and lymphoma is important in HIV neurocomplications. Given limited availability of SPECT, many patients treated empirically based on scoring systems. 90% likelihood of toxoplasmosis if: toxoplasmosis IgG in serum, CD4 <100 not on prophylaxis, multiple ring enhancing lesions on CT/MRI. Thallium SPECT: toxoplasmosis negative, lymphoma positive.	**HIV CNS lesions:** Toxoplasmosis (multiple ring enhancing, Thallium SPECT negative), Lymphoma (single/homogenous enhancing, Thallium SPECT positive).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q189: A 33-year-old is investigated for lethargy. The full blood count is reported as: Hb 10.1 g/dl, Plt 156 × 10⁹/l, WBC 3.7 × 10⁹/l. His daughter was unwell one week previously with a pyrexial illness associated with a red rash on her cheeks. What is the most likely cause?	Measles	Coxsackie a16	Group A haemolytic streptococci	Parvovirus B19	HHV-6 (Human Herpesvirus-6)	D	Parvovirus B19	Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease, 'slapped-cheek syndrome'). Rose-red rash on cheeks, spreads to body (rarely palms/soles). Child feels better as rash appears. Infectious 3-5 days before rash, no longer infectious once rash appears. Other presentations: asymptomatic, pancytopaenia in immunosuppressed, aplastic crises in sickle-cell disease (suppresses erythropoiesis). Can affect unborn baby in first 20 weeks pregnancy.	**Parvovirus B19:** slapped-cheek syndrome, aplastic crisis in sickle-cell, pancytopaenia in immunosuppressed, risk to fetus <20 weeks.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q190: A 34-year-old female is admitted to hospital with fever, rigors and myalgia. She reports being bitten by her rabbit 4 days prior. On examination, you notice an ulcer around the site of the bite with tender regional lymphadenopathy. On closer inspection of the lymph nodes, you notice pus coming out from them. Blood tests reveal: Hb 119 g/l, Platelets 153 × 10⁹/l, WBC 12.4 × 10⁹/l, Na⁺ 128 mmol/l, K⁺ 3.7 mmol/l, Urea 11.3 mmol/l, Creatinine 187 μmol/l, Bilirubin 30 μmol/l, ALP 85 u/l, ALT 111 u/l, Albumin 37 g/l, Creatine kinase 831 iu/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Legionella	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Tularaemia	Psittacosis	Leptospirosis	C	Tularaemia	Tularaemia is zoonotic infection from F. tularensis commonly transmitted through lagomorphs (rabbits, hares, pikas) and ticks. Produces erythematous papulo-ulcerative lesion at bite site with reactive and ulcerating regional lymphadenopathy. Treated with doxycycline. Psittacosis, legionella, mycoplasma present with atypical pneumonic pattern. Leptospirosis associated with vermin contact, liver involvement with thrombocytopaenia and AKI.	**Tularaemia:** rabbit/hare bite, F. tularensis, ulcer at bite site, ulcerating lymphadenopathy. Treat with doxycycline.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q191: A 48-year-old man with a past medical history of poorly controlled HIV is admitted with shortness of breath. He also complains of haemoptysis. Imaging and blood tests confirm a diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. He is treated with amphotericin B. What is the mechanism of action of amphotericin B?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Converted to to 5-fluorouracil	Binds with ergosterol	Inhibits synthesis of beta-glucan	Interacts with microtubules to disrupt mitotic spindle	C	Binds with ergosterol	Amphotericin B binds with ergosterol, a component of fungal cell membranes, forming pores that cause lysis of cell wall and subsequent fungal cell death. Adverse effects: nephrotoxicity, flu-like symptoms, hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia. Used for systemic fungal infections. Flucytosine converted to 5-fluorouracil. Caspofungin inhibits beta-glucan synthesis. Griseofulvin interacts with microtubules. Aciclovir inhibits viral DNA polymerase.	**Amphotericin B:** binds ergosterol, forms pores in fungal cell membrane. Nephrotoxic. For systemic fungal infections.	Antifungals				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q192: A 20-year-old student presents complaining of multiple painful ulcers on the shaft of his penis. He tells you he has had a new sexual partner recently but she has not reported any symptoms. He feels generally unwell and had tender enlarged inguinal lymph nodes bilaterally. He denies urethral discharge or dysuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Behcets syndrome	Herpes simplex	Syphilis	Lymphogranuloma venereum	Donovanosis	B	Herpes simplex	Syphilis, Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) all cause painless genital ulcers. Behcets may cause painful genital ulcers but herpes simplex more likely given recent change in sexual partner and lack of other symptoms. Genital herpes most often HSV type 2. Typically multiple painful ulcers. Primary attacks severe with fever, subsequent attacks less severe and localised.	**Painful genital ulcers:** herpes > chancroid. **Painless:** syphilis > LGV, granuloma inguinale. **Herpes:** multiple painful ulcers.	STI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q193: A 29-year-old HIV positive man is admitted with right-sided hemiplegia. For the past four days he has been complaining of headache and flu-like symptoms. CT scan shows multiple ring enhancing lesions. A diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. What is the most suitable management?	Artemether and lumefantrine	Co-trimoxazole	Supportive treatment	Pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine	Metronidazole and gentamicin	D	Pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine	Toxoplasma gondii is protozoa infecting via GI tract, lung or broken skin. Oocysts release trophozoites migrating to eye, brain, muscle. Usual reservoir is cat. Most infections asymptomatic. Symptomatic: self-limiting, resembles infectious mononucleosis (fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy). Other: meningoencephalitis, myocarditis. Diagnosis: antibody test, Sabin-Feldman dye test. Treatment reserved for severe or immunosuppressed: pyrimethamine plus sulphadiazine for at least 6 weeks. Congenital toxoplasmosis: microcephaly, hydrocephalus, cerebral calcification, chorioretinitis.	**Toxoplasmosis treatment:** pyrimethamine + sulphadiazine (≥6 weeks). Prophylaxis when CD4 <100. HIV: multiple ring enhancing lesions.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q194: A 19-year-old student is brought to the Emergency Department by friends due to a severe headache and drowsiness. On examination he has a widespread purpuric rash. Meningococcal infection is strongly suspected but he is known to be penicillin allergic (previous anaphylaxis). What is the antibiotic of choice?	Chloramphenicol	Meropenem	Teicoplanin	Erythromycin	Ciprofloxacin	A	Chloramphenicol	If patient has history of immediate hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin or cephalosporins, BNF recommends chloramphenicol for meningitis treatment.	**Meningitis with penicillin allergy:** chloramphenicol.
