ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q195: A 54-year-old homosexual man presents to the emergency department with fever and malaise 24 hours after being treated for syphilis with intramuscular benzathine penicillin in his local GUM clinic. He has a florid maculopapular rash over his arms, legs and torso which he tells you has been present for the last 2 weeks. The patient informs you he has no sexual contacts for the last 2 months and his last HIV test was performed 3 days ago when he tested positive for syphilis and was negative. Observations are normal and there are no other findings on systemic examination. What would be the most appropriate response to this presentation?	Repeat HIV test, viral load and CD4 count	Admit for CT head, lumbar puncture and observation	Reassure the patient and discharge him	Repeat syphilis serology and repeat treatment if this is positive	Refer to dermatology for outpatient biopsy	C	Reassure the patient and discharge him	The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is known phenomenon following syphilis treatment that does not require specific treatment or investigations. Flu-like reaction following syphilis treatment with benzathine penicillin, usually self-limiting 24-48 hours. Important to inform patients prior to treatment. As examination normal and no neurological symptoms, no need to investigate for neurosyphilis. Syphilis serology will likely still be positive 1 day after treatment.	**Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:** fever, rash, tachycardia after first antibiotic dose for syphilis. Due to endotoxin release from bacterial death. Self-limiting 24-48h.	Syphilis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q196: A 27-year-old male presents with malaise, pyrexia, lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. The Monospot test is negative. Given a history of high-risk sexual behaviour you are asked to exclude a HIV seroconversion illness. What is the most appropriate investigation?	Antibodies to HIV-2	gp120 polymerase chain reaction	p24 antigen test	CCR5 polymerase chain reaction	Antibodies to HIV-1	C	p24 antigen test	HIV seroconversion: p24 antigen test most appropriate as antibodies may not yet be detectable. HIV seroconversion features: sore throat, lymphadenopathy, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, diarrhoea, maculopapular rash, mouth ulcers, rarely meningoencephalitis.	**HIV seroconversion diagnosis:** p24 antigen test (antibodies may not be detectable yet). Features: sore throat, lymphadenopathy, rash.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q197: A 93-year-old woman is seen on the acute ward round with refractory Clostridium difficile infection. She has already received 2 weeks of oral metronidazole, oral vancomycin and intravenous metronidazole. Which of the following may be implemented as the next line of management?	Probiotics	IV Vancomycin	Fidaxomicin	Meropenem	IV Immunoglobulins (IVIg)	C	Fidaxomicin	Fidaxomicin is used for Clostridium difficile infections that don't respond to metronidazole/vancomycin. It has relatively narrow spectrum and may reduce likelihood of recurrence compared to oral vancomycin. IV vancomycin has no role in C. difficile. Probiotics have no valuable evidence. IVIg has some evidence, very last line. Meropenem may worsen situation. C. difficile management: first-line oral metronidazole 10-14 days, if severe or not responding use oral vancomycin, if not responding to vancomycin try oral fidaxomicin, severe unremitting colitis consider colectomy.	**C. difficile:** 1st line oral metronidazole, 2nd oral vancomycin, 3rd fidaxomicin. IV vancomycin has NO role.	Clostridium difficile				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q198: A 63-year-old man who migrated from India 7 months ago is referred to the acute medical unit with a history of headache and pyrexia. A lumbar puncture suggests a diagnosis of meningeal tuberculosis. What treatment should he be started on?	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol	Rifampicin and streptomycin	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol and streptomycin	Rifampicin and isoniazid with prednisolone	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol with prednisolone	E	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol with prednisolone	Use of steroids in tuberculous meningitis supported by Cochrane review 2008. Standard TB therapy: Initial phase first 2 months (RIPE): Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol. Continuation phase next 4 months: Rifampicin, Isoniazid. Latent TB: 3 months isoniazid (with pyridoxine) and rifampicin OR 6 months isoniazid (with pyridoxine). Meningeal tuberculosis treated for prolonged period (at least 12 months) with addition of steroids.	**TB treatment:** Initial 2 months RIPE, then 4 months rifampicin + isoniazid. **TB meningitis:** at least 12 months + steroids.	Tuberculosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q199: A 38-year-old man who has recently emigrated from eastern Europe presents to Emergency Department one hour after sustaining a 4 cm laceration to the dorsum of his left hand. He works as a builder and sustained the laceration after cutting into a cardboard box using a Stanley knife. On examining the wound there is no sign of a foreign body or neurovascular deficit. He is referred to Plastics for apposition of the wound. You ask him about his tetanus vaccination status. He has 'no idea' but can remember getting some vaccinations as a child. What is the most appropriate action with respect to tetanus?	Requires human tetanus immunoglobulin + tetanus vaccine + complete vaccine course at a later date	Requires tetanus vaccine + complete vaccine course at a later date	Requires human tetanus immunoglobulin	No action required	Requires tetanus vaccine + oral penicillin V prophylaxis for one week	B	Requires tetanus vaccine + complete vaccine course at a later date	This wound is not high risk for tetanus. Greenbook recommends vaccinating against tetanus. Immunisation status unknown so prudent to ensure complete course of tetanus vaccination. Tetanus vaccine given in UK at: 2, 3, 4 months, 3-5 years, 13-18 years (5 doses provides adequate long-term protection). IM human tetanus immunoglobulin for high-risk wounds (compound fractures, delayed surgery, significant devitalised tissue) irrespective of vaccination history. If vaccination history incomplete/unknown, give tetanus vaccine combined with IM immunoglobulin for high-risk wounds.	**Tetanus vaccination:** 5 doses provide long-term protection. **High-risk wounds:** immunoglobulin regardless of status. **Unknown status + high-risk wound:** vaccine + immunoglobulin.	Tetanus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q200: A 37-year-old immigrant from Bolivia is admitted to the Emergency Department following a collapse. He is known to have a history of Chagas' disease. Which one of the following complications of Chagas' disease accounts for the majority of mortality in affected patients?	Large bowel perforation secondary to megacolon	Myocarditis	Perinephric abscess	Meningoencephalitis	Pulmonary haemorrhage	B	Myocarditis	Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death in patients with Chagas' disease. American trypanosomiasis (Chagas' disease) caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. 95% asymptomatic in acute phase, sometimes chagoma (erythematous nodule at infection site) and periorbital oedema. Chronic Chagas mainly affects heart and GI tract: myocarditis may lead to dilated cardiomyopathy (with apical atrophy) and arrhythmias; GI features include megaoesophagus and megacolon causing dysphagia and constipation. Management: most effective in acute phase using azole or nitroderivatives (benznidazole or nifurtimox); chronic disease involves treating complications (e.g. heart failure).	**Chagas disease (T. cruzi):** myocarditis leading cause of death, dilated cardiomyopathy, megaoesophagus/megacolon. Treat acute phase with benznidazole/nifurtimox.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q201: A 58-year-old man presents with fever, chills and back pain for the past four weeks. A chest x-ray and urine culture are unremarkable. Around two months ago he went to stay with family on a Cypriot sheep farm. A chest x-ray and urine culture are unremarkable. A diagnosis of Brucellosis is suspected. Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?	Stool culture	Blood cultures	Brucella serology	Liver biopsy	Urinary antigen	C	Brucella serology	Brucellosis is zoonosis more common in Middle East and farmers. Four major species: B melitensis (sheep), B abortus (cattle), B canis, B suis (pigs). Incubation 2-6 weeks. Features: non-specific (fever, malaise), hepatosplenomegaly, sacroilitis (spinal tenderness), complications (osteomyelitis, infective endocarditis, meningoencephalitis, orchitis), leukopenia often seen. Diagnosis: Rose Bengal plate test for screening but other tests required to confirm; Brucella serology is best test for diagnosis; blood and bone marrow cultures may be suitable but often negative. Management: doxycycline and streptomycin.	**Brucellosis:** sheep/cattle/pig contact, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, sacroilitis. Diagnosis: Brucella serology. Treat with doxycycline + streptomycin.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q202: A 30-year-old man presents to the acute medical receiving ward, one week after returning from Tanzania. He has developed a high fever, 38.9, which started abruptly, headache and generalised severe joint pain preventing him from walking. You note his finger looks swollen. There is no rash. He has been taking his anti-malarial pills. His blood results are: Hb 160 g/l, Platelets 300 × 10⁹/l, WBC 6 × 10⁹/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Septic arthritis	Malaria	Chikungunya	Zika	Dengue	C	Chikungunya	Severe joint pain and high fever point to chikungunya after return from Africa. Absence of rash makes chikungunya more likely than dengue. Feature pointing to chikungunya is severe joint pain often debilitating and normal blood results (dengue may have low platelets). Zika not as common in Africa, produces milder symptoms including low-grade fever (most cases South America). Malaria less likely as taking anti-malarials, joint swelling not feature of malaria. Septic arthritis more commonly affects one joint whereas this man has generalised severe joint pain. Chikungunya: alphavirus from infected mosquitoes. Areas: Africa, Asia, Indian subcontinent, recent cases Southern Europe. Symptoms: severe joint pain and abrupt onset high fever. Other: flu-like illness, muscle ache, headache, fatigue. Shares symptoms with dengue but more joint pain which can be debilitating. Rash may develop, joint swelling not uncommon. Treatment: symptomatic relief only.	**Chikungunya:** severe debilitating joint pain + high fever, Africa/Asia, normal blood tests. **Dengue:** thrombocytopenia, raised transaminases, rash common.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q203: A 19-year-old man presents with a 12-hour history of a headache and fever. On examination, you elicit neck stiffness, photophobia and a positive Kernig's sign. He scores 15 on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and there has been no change in behaviour and there is no evidence of raised intracranial pressure. He is haemodynamically stable and there is no rash. Blood cultures are taken and a lumbar puncture is performed. You decide to treat empirically for bacterial meningitis and prescribe intravenous cefotaxime every 6 hours. Which of the following is most appropriate in addition to intravenous cefotaxime?	Give intravenous aciclovir	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose and continue every 6 hours	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose only	Await the cerebrospinal fluid results and prescribe intravenous dexamethasone only if Streptococcus pneumoniae is isolated	Give intravenous amoxicillin	B	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose and continue every 6 hours	Corticosteroids (dexamethasone) should be given as adjunct to prevent neurological sequelae. Aciclovir should be given if herpes simplex encephalitis suspected (reduced consciousness or change in behaviour/cognition - not present here). IV dexamethasone should be given prior to or with first dose of antibiotic to reduce risk of neurological sequelae by reducing cerebrospinal inflammation. If pneumococcal meningitis suspected/confirmed, dexamethasone continued for 4 days. Stopped if another organism strongly suspected/confirmed. Amoxicillin recommended in addition to cefotaxime for patients 50 years old. BNF recommendations: 50 years IV cefotaxime + amoxicillin. Prophylaxis for contacts needed for meningococcal (ciprofloxacin or rifampicin), not generally for pneumococcal unless cluster.	**Bacterial meningitis:** IV dexamethasone with first antibiotic dose, continue for 4 days if pneumococcal. Age 50 years: add amoxicillin.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q204: A 22-year-old woman presents with lethargy, pyrexia and headaches. She is a student and returned from a holiday in Ibiza ten days ago. These symptoms have been present for the past six days and she is wondering whether she may need an antibiotic. She also has a history of menorrhagia and is concerned that she may be anaemic. Clinical examination reveals a temperature of 37.9ºC and marked cervical lymphadenopathy. You order a full blood count which is reported as: Hb 12.1 g/dl, Platelets 189 × 10⁹/l, WCC 13.1 × 10⁹/l, Neutrophils 5.2 × 10⁹/l, Lymphocytes 6.2 × 10⁹/l, Film: Atypical lymphocytes seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia	Hashimoto's thyroiditis	Infectious mononucleosis	HIV seroconversion	Septicaemia secondary to streptococcal throat infection	C	Infectious mononucleosis	Atypical lymphocytes suggest glandular fever. Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (90% cases). Less frequent: cytomegalovirus, HHV-6. Most common in adolescents/young adults. Classic triad (98%): sore throat, pyrexia, lymphadenopathy (anterior and posterior neck triangles). Other features: malaise, anorexia, headache, palatal petechiae, splenomegaly (50%, may predispose to splenic rupture), hepatitis/transient ALT rise, lymphocytosis (50% lymphocytes with at least 10% atypical), haemolytic anaemia (IgM cold agglutins), maculopapular pruritic rash in 99% taking ampicillin/amoxicillin. Symptoms resolve after 2-4 weeks. Diagnosis: heterophil antibody test (Monospot) - NICE suggests FBC and Monospot in 2nd week. Management: supportive (rest, fluids, avoid alcohol, simple analgesia), avoid contact sports for 8 weeks (reduce splenic rupture risk).	**Infectious mononucleosis (EBV):** sore throat, pyrexia, lymphadenopathy, atypical lymphocytes, splenomegaly. Avoid ampicillin (causes rash), avoid contact sports 8 weeks.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q205: A 43-year-old man from Sierra Leone presents with a flu-like illness. On examination he has very large posterior cervical lymph nodes. A diagnosis of African trypanosomiasis is confirmed on blood smear. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Atovaquone-proguanil	Sodium stibogluconate	Benznidazole	Metronidazole	Pentamidine	E	Pentamidine	Two forms of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness): Trypanosoma gambiense (West Africa) and Trypanosoma rhodesiense (East Africa). Both spread by tsetse fly. T. rhodesiense follows more acute course. Features: Trypanosoma chancre (painless subcutaneous nodule at infection site), intermittent fever, enlargement of posterior cervical lymph nodes, later CNS involvement (somnolence, headaches, mood changes, meningoencephalitis). Management: early disease IV pentamidine or suramin; later disease or CNS involvement IV melarsoprol. American trypanosomiasis (Chagas' disease) caused by Trypanosoma cruzi - treatment with benznidazole or nifurtimox most effective in acute phase.	**African trypanosomiasis:** tsetse fly, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, CNS involvement. Early: IV pentamidine/suramin. Late/CNS: IV melarsoprol.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q206: Which one of the following is a Gram negative coccus?	Haemophilus influenzae	Moraxella catarrhalis	Enterococcus faecalis	Listeria monocytogenes	Campylobacter jejuni	B	Moraxella catarrhalis	-Gram-positive cocci = staphylococci + streptococci (including enterococci).  -Gram-negative cocci = Neisseria meningitidis + Neisseria gonorrhoeae, also Moraxella catarrhalis.   -Gram-positive rods (ABCD L): Actinomyces, Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium, Diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae), Listeria monocytogenes.   -Remaining organisms are Gram-negative rods: E. coli, Haemophilus influenzae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter jejuni.	**Gram-negative cocci:** Neisseria (meningitidis, gonorrhoeae), Moraxella catarrhalis. **Gram-positive cocci:** staphylococci, streptococci, enterococci.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q207: A 38-year-old man presents to the genitourinary clinic with multiple, painless genital ulcers. A diagnosis of granuloma inguinale is made. What is the causative organism?	Klebsiella granulomatis	Chlamydia	Herpes simplex virus	Treponema pallidum	Haemophilus ducreyi	A	Klebsiella granulomatis	Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (previously Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). Genital herpes (HSV type 2): multiple painful ulcers. Syphilis (Treponema pallidum): painless chancre in primary stage. Chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi): painful genital ulcers with ragged undermined border, unilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Lymphogranuloma venereum (Chlamydia trachomatis): stage 1 small painless pustule then ulcer, stage 2 painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, stage 3 proctocolitis. Treated with doxycycline.	**Painless genital ulcers:** syphilis (single), LGV, granuloma inguinale (Klebsiella granulomatis). **Painful:** herpes (multiple), chancroid (ragged edge).	STI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q208: Which of the following antibiotics is predominately bactericidal?	Trimethoprim	Erythromycin	Ciprofloxacin	Chloramphenicol	Minocycline	C	Ciprofloxacin	Bactericidal antibiotics: penicillins, cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, nitrofurantoin, metronidazole, quinolones, rifampicin, isoniazid. Bacteriostatic antibiotics: chloramphenicol, macrolides, tetracyclines, sulphonamides, trimethoprim.	**Bactericidal:** penicillins, cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, quinolones, metronidazole, rifampicin, isoniazid. **Bacteriostatic:** macrolides, tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, trimethoprim.	Antibiotics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q209: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with left leg cellulitis. A swab is taken and oral flucloxacillin is started. The following result is obtained: Skin swab: Group A Streptococcus. How should the antibiotic therapy be changed?	No change	Add topical fusidic acid	Add clindamycin	Switch to phenoxymethylpenicillin	Add erythromycin	D	Switch to phenoxymethylpenicillin	Penicillin is antibiotic of choice for group A streptococcal infections. BNF suggests stopping flucloxacillin if streptococcal infection confirmed in cellulitis due to high sensitivity. Balance with variable absorption of phenoxymethylpenicillin. Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes): responsible for erysipelas, impetigo, cellulitis, type 2 necrotizing fasciitis, pharyngitis/tonsillitis. Immunological reactions cause rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Erythrogenic toxins cause scarlet fever.	**Group A Strep cellulitis:** switch from flucloxacillin to phenoxymethylpenicillin (penicillin is drug of choice for Strep).	Cellulitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 151-169 (MRCP6)	P151-169, Q210: Which of the following is least recognised as a cause of a false positive VDRL test?	Pregnancy	SLE	Oral contraceptive pill	Tuberculosis	HIV	C	Oral contraceptive pill	Syphilis diagnosis based on clinical features, serology, microscopic examination. Serological tests: cardiolipin tests (not treponeme specific) - VDRL, RPR; insensitive in late syphilis, becomes negative after treatment. Treponemal specific antibody tests - TPHA; remains positive after treatment. Causes of false positive cardiolipin tests: pregnancy, SLE, anti-phospholipid syndrome, TB, leprosy, malaria, HIV. Oral contraceptive pill is NOT a recognized cause.	**False positive VDRL/RPR:** pregnancy, SLE, anti-phospholipid syndrome, TB, leprosy, malaria, HIV. **NOT OCP.**	Syphilis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q211: Which one of the following viruses is associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?	Adenovirus	Rhinovirus	Herpes simplex virus	Epstein-Barr virus	Picornavirus	D	Epstein-Barr virus	$\mathbf{EBV}$ is associated with several malignancies: $\mathbf{Burkitt's}$ $\mathbf{lymphoma}$, $\mathbf{Hodgkin's}$ $\mathbf{lymphoma}$, $\mathbf{nasopharyngeal}$ $\mathbf{carcinoma}$, and $\mathbf{HIV-associated}$ $\mathbf{CNS}$ $\mathbf{lymphomas}$. The non-malignant condition $\mathbf{hairy}$ $\mathbf{leukoplakia}$ is also associated with $\mathbf{EBV}$ infection.	$\mathbf{EBV}$ malignancies: Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, HIV-associated CNS lymphomas	Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q212: A 38-year-old HIV-positive woman who is 38 weeks into her first pregnancy comes to the obstetric clinic for review. She has been compliant with medication and her viral load has been consistently <50 copies. She would like to have a vaginal delivery and is keen to breastfeed after the birth. What would you advise her regarding breastfeeding?	She can breastfeed regardless of the viral load	Breastfeeding is not recommended	She can breastfeed as long as the baby is on the neonatal antiretroviral therapy	She can breastfeed to a maximum of approximately 100ml a day	She can breastfeed as long as the viral load remains at <50 copies	B	Breastfeeding is not recommended	In the $\mathbf{UK}$ all $\mathbf{HIV}$ $\mathbf{positive}$ women should be advised $\mathbf{not}$ $\mathbf{to}$ $\mathbf{breastfeed}$, regardless of viral load, antiretroviral therapy status, or amount of breastfeeding. Factors that reduce vertical transmission from 25-30% to 2% include: maternal antiretroviral therapy, caesarean section (if viral load >50 copies/ml at 36 weeks), neonatal antiretroviral therapy, and bottle feeding.	$\mathbf{UK}$ $\mathbf{guideline}$: All HIV-positive women should NOT breastfeed	HIV/Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q213: A 31-year-old man from Russia who is known to be HIV positive presents with purple plaques on his skin. Which of the following viruses is thought to be the cause of Kaposi's sarcoma?	HTLV-1	HIV-2	HHV-8	CMV	HPV-8	C	HHV-8	$\mathbf{Kaposi's}$ $\mathbf{sarcoma}$ is caused by $\mathbf{HHV-8}$ (human herpes virus 8). It presents as $\mathbf{purple}$ $\mathbf{papules}$ or $\mathbf{plaques}$ on the skin or mucosa (e.g., gastrointestinal and respiratory tract). Skin lesions may later ulcerate. Respiratory involvement may cause massive haemoptysis and pleural effusion. Treatment includes radiotherapy and resection.	$\mathbf{Kaposi's}$ $\mathbf{sarcoma}$ = $\mathbf{HHV-8}$ (purple papules/plaques)	HIV/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q214: A 67-year-old patient with known emphysema presents to the Emergency Department with a two-week history of cough productive of blood-stained sputum. Chest X-Ray shows a circular area of dense right upper lobe consolidation. Despite seven days of intravenous antibiotics (piperacillin and tazobactam) his condition has not improved. An urgent inpatient bronchoscopy reveals no endobronchial lesion but broncho-alveolar lavage reveals an underlying pathogenic organism. Ziehl-Nielson staining is negative. What organism would you suspect?	Moraxella catarrhalis	Aspergillus fumigatus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Burkholderia cepacia	B	Aspergillus fumigatus	This patient likely has an $\mathbf{aspergilloma}$ in an emphysematous cavity, explaining lack of improvement with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, haemoptysis, and chest X-Ray findings. Moraxella and pseudomonas are usually sensitive to piperacillin + tazobactam and do not classically cause clinical haemoptysis. M. tuberculosis is unlikely given negative Ziehl-Nielson staining. Burkholderia is typically seen in cystic fibrosis patients, not emphysema.	{Aspergilloma}in f{emphysematous}$ $\mathbf{cavity}$: haemoptysis, circular consolidation, no response to antibiotics	Respiratory/Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q215: Which one of the following is least associated with rabies?	Hydrophobia	Opisthotonus	Pyrexia	Headache	Hypersalivation	B	Opisthotonus	$\mathbf{Opisthotonus}$ is associated more with $\mathbf{tetanus}$. It describes hyperextension and spasticity where a patient's neck and spinal column enter into an arching position. It is an extrapyramidal effect caused by spasm of axial muscles. $\mathbf{Rabies}$ features include: prodrome (headache, fever, agitation), $\mathbf{hydrophobia}$ (water-provoking muscle spasms), $\mathbf{hypersalivation}$, and Negri bodies (cytoplasmic inclusion bodies in infected neurons).	$\mathbf{Rabies}$: hydrophobia, hypersalivation, fever, headache. $\mathbf{Opisthotonus}$ = tetanus	Virology/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q216: A 64-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department as his wife is concerned that he is becoming confused following a recent bad chest infection. She reports that he has not improved after a course of amoxicillin. On examination, his respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure 88/60 mmHg, heart rate 120/min. Crackles are noted on the right side of his chest. What is the most appropriate fluid therapy to give?	20 ml/kg stat	30 ml/kg stat	500ml stat	20 ml/kg over 1 hour	10 ml/kg over 1 hour	C	500ml stat	This patient has $\mathbf{red}$ $\mathbf{flag}$ $\mathbf{sepsis}$ features (confusion, low blood pressure, raised respiratory rate). The $\mathbf{sepsis}$ $\mathbf{6}$ should be started. $\mathbf{NICE}$ $\mathbf{guidelines}$ on sepsis recommend: if patients over 16 years need intravenous fluid resuscitation, use crystalloids containing sodium 130–154 mmol/litre with a bolus of $\mathbf{500}$ $\mathbf{ml}$ over $\mathbf{less}$ $\mathbf{than}$ $\mathbf{15}$ $\mathbf{minutes}$.	Sepsis} fluid}$ $\mathbf{resuscitation}$: $\mathbf{500ml}$ crystalloid over <15 minutes	Sepsis/Emergency				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q217: A 25-year-old woman has recently moved to the United Kingdom from sub-Saharan Africa to attend University. She comes from an area where there is a high prevalence of tuberculosis (TB). The patient is not pregnant and is currently asymptomatic. She thinks she may have had a BCG vaccination in the past but is not sure. She has no other medical history and is a non-smoker. Which test should initially be used to screen this lady for TB?	Mantoux test	Interferon gamma blood test	Early morning urine sample	Chest x-ray	Send three sputum samples	A	Mantoux test	The patient is asymptomatic (no active TB), but may have $\mathbf{latent}$ $\mathbf{TB}$. Recent $\mathbf{NICE}$ $\mathbf{guidelines}$ state the initial screening test is the $\mathbf{Mantoux}$ $\mathbf{test}$. A diameter of $\mathbf{≥5}$ $\mathbf{mm}$ is considered positive regardless of BCG history. $\mathbf{Interferon}$ $\mathbf{gamma}$ blood test is recommended if Mantoux test is positive. Early morning urine sample is no longer recommended. Patient is asymptomatic so cannot collect sputum.	TB}$ $\mathbf{screening}$: Mantoux test first (≥5mm = positive regardless of BCG)	Tuberculosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q218: Which one of the following conditions is not associated with prior Epstein-Barr virus infection?	Hodgkin's lymphoma	Adult T-cell leukaemia	Burkitt's lymphoma	Nasopharyngeal carcinoma	Hairy leukoplakia	B	Adult T-cell leukaemia	$\mathbf{Adult}$ $\mathbf{T-cell}$ $\mathbf{leukaemia}$ is associated with $\mathbf{HTLV-1}$ infection, NOT EBV. $\mathbf{EBV}$ associated malignancies include: $\mathbf{Burkitt's}$ $\mathbf{lymphoma}$, $\mathbf{Hodgkin's}$ $\mathbf{lymphoma}$, $\mathbf{nasopharyngeal}$ $\mathbf{carcinoma}$, and HIV-associated central nervous system lymphomas. The non-malignant condition $\mathbf{hairy}$ $\mathbf{leukoplakia}$ is also associated with EBV.	$\mathbf{Adult}$ $\mathbf{T-cell}$ $\mathbf{leukaemia}$ = $\mathbf{HTLV-1}$ (NOT EBV)	Virology/Oncology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q219: A 75-year-old woman is admitted with confusion to the Emergency Department. Her urine dipstick is positive for nitrites and leucocytes and a diagnosis of urinary tract infection is suspected. She is prescribed a 7-day course of trimethoprim. Bloods on admission: Na+ 141 mmol/l, K+ 3.7 mmol/l, Urea 4.3 mmol/l, Creatinine 78 μmol/l, CRP 21 mg/l. Five days later: Na+ 140 mmol/l, K+ 3.9 mmol/l, Urea 5.3 mmol/l, Creatinine 125 μmol/l, CRP 6 mg/l. What is the most likely explanation for the change in renal function?	Impaired renal function secondary to acute pyelonephritis	Crystal-induced nephropathy secondary to trimethoprim	Trimethoprim competitively inhibiting the tubular secretion of creatinine	Interstitial nephritis secondary to trimethoprim	Spurious result due to plasma-bound trimethoprim being confused with creatinine	C	Trimethoprim competitively inhibiting the tubular secretion of creatinine	The fall in $\mathbf{CRP}$ is not consistent with acute pyelonephritis. $\mathbf{Trimethoprim}$ causes a $\mathbf{transient}$ $\mathbf{rise}$ in $\mathbf{creatinine}$ by competitively inhibiting tubular secretion of creatinine, resulting in a temporary increase which $\mathbf{reverses}$ $\mathbf{upon}$ $\mathbf{stopping}$ the drug. This does not represent true renal impairment.	$\mathbf{Trimethoprim}$ causes reversible $\uparrow$ creatinine (inhibits tubular secretion)	Pharmacology/Nephrology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q220: A 64-year-old gentleman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the GP with increasing dyspnoea. He is febrile and gives a history of a cough productive of green sputum over the last few days. You diagnose an infective exacerbation of his underlying lung disease. After sending a sputum sample you make the decision to start oral steroids and appropriate antibiotics. On reviewing the results of the sputum sample the lab has reported an initial culture of a Gram-negative cocci. What is the most likely organism?	Haemophilus influenzae	Moraxella catarrhalis	Neisseria meningitidis	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Streptococcus pneumoniae	B	Moraxella catarrhalis	Of all available organisms, only $\mathbf{Neisseria}$ and $\mathbf{Moraxella}$ are $\mathbf{Gram-negative}$ $\mathbf{cocci}$. Neisseria meningitidis is not a common respiratory pathogen, therefore the likely organism is $\mathbf{Moraxella}$ $\mathbf{catarrhalis}$. Moraxella is a common cause of respiratory infections in patients with underlying lung disease, and also commonly causes sinusitis and middle ear infections.	$\mathbf{Gram-negative}$ $\mathbf{cocci}$: Neisseria + Moraxella. $\mathbf{Moraxella}$ = respiratory pathogen in COPD	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q221: A 31-year-old man is admitted to hospital with a 4-day history of fever and dyspnoea. He is known to be HIV positive but poorly compliant with his antiretroviral therapy (ART). Bloods from two weeks ago show CD4 180 cells/μl. On examination today his pulse is 102/min, oxygen saturations 97% on room air with a temperature of 38.1ºC. He has coarse crackles on the right side of his chest. A chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right mid zone. What is the most likely causative organism?	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Cryptococcus neoformans	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis jirovecii	Histoplasma capsulatum	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Patients who are immunocompromised are more likely to develop infections due to $\mathbf{common}$ $\mathbf{pathogens}$ affecting immunocompetent individuals. $\mathbf{Streptococcus}$ $\mathbf{pneumoniae}$ is the most likely cause of community-acquired pneumonia in this patient. Pneumocystis jirovecii presents differently with very few chest signs and $\mathbf{bilateral}$ $\mathbf{interstitial}$ pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray (not lobar consolidation).	In HIV patients: $\mathbf{common}$ $\mathbf{pathogens}$ are most common! S. pneumoniae = most common CAP	HIV/Respiratory				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q222: A 24-year-old male attends the clinic for a yellow fever vaccine before travelling to South America. He has no past medical history and takes no regular medicines. He states that he also had a varicella zoster vaccination a few weeks ago. What is the minimum interval required between the last vaccination?	1 week	2 weeks	3 weeks	4 weeks	1 year	D	4 weeks	$\mathbf{Live}$ $\mathbf{vaccines}$ given by injection may be either given $\mathbf{concomitantly}$ (same day) or a minimum interval of $\mathbf{4}$ $\mathbf{weeks}$ apart to prevent risk of immunological interference. If not given on the same day, there must be a 4-week interval between further live vaccinations.	$\mathbf{Live}$ $\mathbf{vaccines}$: same day OR ≥4 weeks apart	Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q223: A 50-year-old sewage worker presents with a one-week history of fever and feeling generally unwell. Which one of the following features would be least consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis?	Meningism	Conjunctival erythema	Productive cough	Decreased urine output	Severe myalgia	C	Productive cough	Pulmonary complications can occur in $\mathbf{leptospirosis}$ but generally happen in $\mathbf{severe}$ and $\mathbf{late-stage}$ disease. Severe disease may result in acute respiratory distress syndrome or pulmonary haemorrhage. Classic features of leptospirosis (Weil's disease) include: fever, flu-like symptoms, $\mathbf{renal}$ $\mathbf{failure}$ (50% of patients), jaundice, $\mathbf{subconjunctival}$ $\mathbf{haemorrhage}$, and headache (may herald meningitis). Consider in sewage workers, farmers, vets, or abattoir workers.	$\mathbf{Leptospirosis}$ (Weil's): fever, renal failure, jaundice, subconjunctival haemorrhage. Think: sewage workers	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q224: A 78-year-old woman is admitted to the general medical ward with lobar pneumonia and is commenced on Co-amoxiclav. A few days later, she reports having some loose stool and abdominal pain. Microbiology reports come back positive for Clostridium difficile. Which classification of bacteria do Clostridium species belong to?	Gram positive cocci	Gram negative cocci	Gram positive bacilli	Gram negative bacilli	Intracellular bacteria	C	Gram positive bacilli	$\mathbf{Clostridium}$ species are classified as $\mathbf{Gram}$ $\mathbf{positive}$ $\mathbf{bacilli}$ (rods). Other Gram-positive bacilli include: Actinomyces, Bacillus anthracis, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and Listeria monocytogenes (mnemonic: $\mathbf{ABCD}$ $\mathbf{L}$).	$\mathbf{Gram-positive}$ $\mathbf{bacilli}$: ABCD L (Actinomyces, Bacillus, Clostridium, Diphtheria, Listeria)	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q225: A 52-year-old male is admitted to hospital with a temperature of 38.2°C and a 3-day history of productive cough. Moraxella catarrhalis	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Klebsiella	Staphylococcus aureus	Chlamydia pneumoniae	D	Staphylococcus aureus	Preceding $\mathbf{influenza}$ predisposes to $\mathbf{Staphylococcus}$ $\mathbf{aureus}$ pneumonia. This patient has had flu-like symptoms for 10 days followed by pneumonia. $\mathbf{S.}$ $\mathbf{aureus}$ is commonly seen after 'the flu' and typically presents with bilateral consolidation.	$\mathbf{S.}$ $\mathbf{aureus}$ $\mathbf{pneumonia}$: commonly after influenza	Respiratory				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q226: A 25-year-old woman has recently moved to the United Kingdom from sub-Saharan Africa to attend University. She comes from an area where there is a high prevalence of tuberculosis (TB). The patient is not pregnant and is currently asymptomatic. She thinks she may have had a BCG vaccination in the past but is not sure. She has no other medical history and is a non-smoker. A chest x-ray is normal. She has a Mantoux test which is positive and subsequently an interferon-gamma release assay which is also positive. What is the best management option for this patient?	Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 6 months	No treatment indicated at present	Rifampicin and isoniazid with pyridoxine for 6 months	Arrange a bronchoscopy and lavage	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol for 6 months	A	Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 6 months	2016 $\mathbf{NICE}$ $\mathbf{guidelines}$: if Mantoux positive (>5mm) with no evidence of active TB and interferon-gamma release assay positive, treat for $\mathbf{latent}$ $\mathbf{TB}$. Options: (1) $\mathbf{3}$ $\mathbf{months}$ of isoniazid with pyridoxine and rifampicin, or (2) $\mathbf{6}$ $\mathbf{months}$ of isoniazid with pyridoxine. Active TB treatment is RIPE for 2 months, then rifampicin + isoniazid for 4 months.	Latent TB treatment: 3mo (INH+RIF) OR 6mo (INH alone), both with pyridoxine	Tuberculosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q227: A 72-year-old woman who is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and heart failure is reviewed. One week ago she was treated with oral flucloxacillin and penicillin V for a right lower limb cellulitis. Unfortunately there has been no response to treatment. What is the most appropriate next line antibiotic?	Co-amoxiclav	Erythromycin	Clindamycin	Vancomycin	Gentamicin	C	Clindamycin	For $\mathbf{cellulitis}$ not responding to first-line treatment (flucloxacillin), $\mathbf{clindamycin}$ is the appropriate second-line antibiotic. Standard treatment for cellulitis is flucloxacillin (or clarithromycin/clindamycin if penicillin-allergic).	Cellulitis: 1st line = flucloxacillin; 2nd line = clindamycin	Dermatology/Antibiotics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q228: A 57-year-old businessman presents to the emergency department with fevers, myalgia and headache which have been ongoing for the past 10 days. He also reports that he has noticed the beginnings of a rash on his face and trunk, which you would describe as maculopapular. He has no significant past medical history, and recently returned from a trip to Bangkok three weeks ago, where he admits to having intercourse with a local sex worker. He cannot remember if he used protection. Otherwise he made sure to take appropriate precautions with malarial prophylaxis and pre-travel vaccines. Which of the following tests would be most likely to give a diagnosis in this history?	Malarial films	HIV antibody test	CD4 count	P24 antigen	Dengue serology	D	P24 antigen	This patient's symptoms suggest acute HIV}$ $\mathbf{seroconversion}$ $\mathbf{syndrome}$ occurring 1-4 weeks from infection. In the majority of patients, this is accompanied by flu-like illness with maculopapular rash. $\mathbf{HIV}$ $\mathbf{antibody}$ testing is most reliable 3 months post-exposure and is often still negative during seroconversion. $\mathbf{p24}$ $\mathbf{antigen}$ is positive for the first 3-4 weeks following exposure, while antibodies take up to 3 months to be detected.	Acute HIV seroconversion: p24 antigen positive (weeks 1-4); HIV antibody positive (3 months)	HIV/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q229: You are counselling a 26-year-old man who has recently had a positive HIV test. His most recent CD4 count is 650 cells/mm³. Which one of the following vaccinations is contraindicated?	Oral poliomyelitis	Yellow fever	Pneumococcus	Parenteral poliomyelitis	Measles, Mumps, Rubella	A	Oral poliomyelitis	$\mathbf{Oral}$ $\mathbf{poliomyelitis}$ (OPV), $\mathbf{cholera}$ CVD103-HgR, $\mathbf{intranasal}$ $\mathbf{influenza}$, and $\mathbf{BCG}$ are $\mathbf{contraindicated}$ in HIV-infected adults. Vaccines that can be used if $\mathbf{CD4}$ $\mathbf{>}$ $\mathbf{200}$ include: MMR, Varicella, and Yellow Fever. Most other vaccines (hepatitis A/B, Hib, parenteral influenza, meningococcus, pneumococcus, parenteral polio, rabies, tetanus-diphtheria) can be used in all HIV-infected adults.	$\mathbf{HIV}$ $\mathbf{contraindicated}$ $\mathbf{vaccines}$: OPV, cholera CVD103-HgR, intranasal influenza, BCG	HIV/Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q230: A 28-year-old man from Zimbabwe presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever, cough, headache, vomiting and neck stiffness. He is known to be HIV positive and is on treatment. His most recent CD4 count was 450 cells/mm³. On examination he has no focal neurological signs but appears drowsy and confused. You suspect meningitis and perform a lumbar puncture. Results: Opening pressure 25mm H₂O, Appearance cloudy, White cells 200 cells/mm³, Cells 90% lymphocytes, CSF protein 3 g/L, CSF glucose 1.1 mmol/L, Blood glucose 6.8 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Meningococcal meningitis	TB meningitis	Cryptococcal meningitis	Partially treated bacterial meningitis	Herpes simplex meningitis	B	TB meningitis	The lymphocytic CSF with high protein and low glucose could be due to both cryptococcal and TB meningitis. However, the $\mathbf{insidious}$ $\mathbf{onset}$ of symptoms, $\mathbf{very}$ $\mathbf{high}$ $\mathbf{protein}$ (3 g/L), and $\mathbf{low}$ $\mathbf{glucose}$ $\mathbf{compared}$ $\mathbf{to}$ $\mathbf{plasma}$ (<1/3 of plasma) point more toward $\mathbf{TB}$ $\mathbf{meningitis}$. Also, this patient has a relatively high CD4 count (450) and only mildly raised opening pressure, making cryptococcal meningitis less likely. TB and HIV co-infection are common, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.	$\mathbf{TB}$ $\mathbf{meningitis}$ $\mathbf{CSF}$: lymphocytic, very high protein (>1g/L), low glucose (<1/2 plasma)	HIV/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q231: A 23-year-old woman comes for review. She has had recurrent genital warts for the past 4 years which have failed to respond to topical podophyllum. On one occasion she had cryotherapy but will not have it again due to local discomfort. On examination she has a large number of fleshy genital warts around her introitus. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?	Topical glutaraldehyde	Oral podophyllum	Topical imiquimod	Oral aciclovir	Topical salicylic acid	C	Topical imiquimod	$\mathbf{Genital}$ $\mathbf{warts}$ (condylomata accuminata) are caused by $\mathbf{HPV}$ types 6 & 11. First-line treatments: topical podophyllum or cryotherapy depending on location/type. $\mathbf{Multiple}$, $\mathbf{non-keratinised}$ warts are best treated with topical agents. $\mathbf{Imiquimod}$ is a topical cream generally used $\mathbf{second}$ $\mathbf{line}$ when first-line treatments fail or are not tolerated. Genital warts are often resistant to treatment and recurrence is common.	Genital warts: HPV 6 & 11. 1st line = podophyllum/cryotherapy; 2nd line = imiquimod	Sexual Health				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q232: A 30-year-old man has returned from South America after one week. He has developed a mild fever, muscle pain, headache and conjunctivitis. He has been taking his anti-malarial tablets. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Dengue	Chikungunya	Malaria	Influenza	Zika	E	Zika	$\mathbf{Zika}$, Chikungunya and Dengue can produce similar symptoms. $\mathbf{Zika}$ is prevalent in South America and tends to cause $\mathbf{mild}$ $\mathbf{fever}$ whereas dengue and chikungunya cause $\mathbf{abrupt}$ $\mathbf{onset}$ of $\mathbf{high}$ $\mathbf{fever}$. Chikungunya and dengue cause more joint pain and $\mathbf{conjunctivitis}$ is less common with these. He has been taking antimalarials making malaria less likely. Classic Zika features: fever, rash, arthralgia/arthritis, $\mathbf{conjunctivitis}$, myalgia, headache.	$\mathbf{Zika}$: mild fever + conjunctivitis (vs dengue/chikungunya = high fever + joint pain)	Tropical Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q233: A 25-year-old man who is taking immunosuppressive therapy for Adult onset Still's disease has come into contact with a child who has chicken pox. He is varicella zoster IgG antibody negative. He has a small number of early chicken pox blisters and you decide to start aciclovir therapy. Which of the following fits best with the mode of action of aciclovir?	DNA polymerase inhibitor	DNA gyrase inhibitor	Reverse transcriptase inhibitor	NS3/4A inhibitor	NS5A inhibitor	A	DNA polymerase inhibitor	$\mathbf{Aciclovir}$ is phosphorylated after entry into herpes-infected cells to form aciclovir triphosphate. The first step requires HSV-coded thymidine kinase. Aciclovir triphosphate acts as an $\mathbf{inhibitor}$ of, and substrate for, the $\mathbf{herpes-specific}$ $\mathbf{DNA}$ $\mathbf{polymerase}$, preventing further viral DNA synthesis. It is $\mathbf{10-30}$ $\mathbf{times}$ $\mathbf{more}$ $\mathbf{specific}$ for viral DNA polymerase versus human enzyme. Bacterial DNA gyrase is the target of quinolones. Reverse transcriptase targets RNA viruses like HIV. NS3/4A and NS5A are hepatitis C targets.	Aciclovir: inhibits viral DNA polymerase (10-30x more specific than human enzyme)	Pharmacology/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q234: A 55-year-old man who was admitted following a stroke two weeks ago is reviewed. Yesterday he started to have a temperature and become more confused. A septic screen has shown radiological evidence of pneumonia. On examination his respiratory rate is 36/min, pulse 112/min, oxygen saturations of 95% on room air and blood pressure of 102/66 mmHg. What is the most appropriate antibiotic to use?	Teicoplanin	Cefuroxime	Amoxicillin	Imipenem with cilastatin	Piperacillin with tazobactam	E	Piperacillin with tazobactam	This is $\mathbf{hospital-acquired}$ $\mathbf{pneumonia}$ (HAP) occurring $\mathbf{more}$ $\mathbf{than}$ $\mathbf{5}$ $\mathbf{days}$ after admission. Treatment: $\mathbf{piperacillin}$ $\mathbf{with}$ $\mathbf{tazobactam}$ OR broad-spectrum cephalosporin (e.g., ceftazidime) OR quinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin). Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin with limited action against Gram-negative bacteria, making it a poor choice. HAP within 5 days of admission: co-amoxiclav or cefuroxime.	HAP >5days}$: piperacillin-tazobactam OR ceftazidime OR ciprofloxacin	Respiratory/Antibiotics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q235: A 55-year-old man is referred to the medical admissions unit. He recently returned from a holiday in Italy and has failed to respond to a course of co-amoxiclav for a suspected lower respiratory tract infection. Chest x-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. Bloods: Na+ 122 mmol/l, K+ 4.3 mmol/l, Urea 8.4 mmol/l, Creatinine 130 μmol/l. What is the likely diagnosis?	Goodpasture's syndrome	Legionella pneumonia	Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia	Pulmonary eosinophilia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	B	Legionella pneumonia	$\mathbf{Legionnaire's}$ $\mathbf{disease}$ is caused by Legionella pneumophila, typically colonizing water tanks (air-conditioning systems, foreign holidays). Classic features: flu-like symptoms with fever (>95%), $\mathbf{dry}$ $\mathbf{cough}$, $\mathbf{relative}$ $\mathbf{bradycardia}$, confusion, $\mathbf{lymphopaenia}$, $\mathbf{hyponatraemia}$, deranged LFTs, and pleural effusion (30%). Diagnosis: $\mathbf{urinary}$ $\mathbf{antigen}$. Treatment: erythromycin (macrolide).	$\mathbf{Legionella}$: hyponatraemia, deranged LFTs, lymphopaenia, dry cough. Diagnosis = urinary antigen	Respiratory				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q236: A 65-year-old man who has recently moved to the UK from India presents with multiple pale patches on his skin. He has no previous medical problems and is not taking any medications. On examination he has 10 hypopigmented patches with reduced sensation. You suspect lepromatous leprosy. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Rifampicin, dapsone and clofazimine for 12 months	Dapsone, ethambutol and pyrazinamide for 12 months	Dapsone and ethambutol for 6 months	Rifampicin and isoniazid for 6 months	Rifampicin and dapsone for 6 months	A	Rifampicin, dapsone and clofazimine for 12 months	This patient has $\mathbf{multibacillary}$ $\mathbf{leprosy}$ ($\mathbf{>6}$ $\mathbf{lesions}$) requiring triple therapy: $\mathbf{rifampicin}$, $\mathbf{dapsone}$, and $\mathbf{clofazimine}$ for $\mathbf{12}$ $\mathbf{months}$. For $\mathbf{paucibacillary}$ $\mathbf{leprosy}$ (≤5 lesions): rifampicin and dapsone for 6 months. Leprosy is a granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae affecting peripheral nerves and skin. Features: hypopigmented skin patches with sensory loss.	$\mathbf{Leprosy}$: >6 lesions = multibacillary (RIF+DDS+CFZ x12mo); ≤5 lesions = paucibacillary (RIF+DDS x6mo)	Tropical Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q237: A 31-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a headache. She has had 'flu'-like symptoms for the past three days with the headache developing gradually yesterday. The headache is described as being 'all over' and is worse on looking at bright light or when bending her neck. On examination her temperature is 38.2°C, pulse 96/min and blood pressure 116/78 mmHg. There is neck stiffness present but no focal neurological signs. On close inspection you notice a number of petechiae on her torso. She has been cannulated and bloods (including cultures) have been taken. What is the most appropriate next step?	IV cefotaxime	Arrange a CT head	Perform a lumbar puncture	IV dexamethasone	Intramuscular benzylpenicillin	A	IV cefotaxime	This patient has $\mathbf{meningococcal}$ $\mathbf{meningitis}$ (petechiae, neck stiffness, photophobia). She needs appropriate $\mathbf{intravenous}$ $\mathbf{antibiotics}$ $\mathbf{immediately}$. With modern PCR diagnostic techniques, there is $\mathbf{no}$ $\mathbf{justification}$ for delaying potentially lifesaving treatment by performing lumbar puncture in patients with suspected meningococcal meningitis. $\mathbf{IV}$ $\mathbf{cefotaxime}$ or $\mathbf{ceftriaxone}$ are first-line treatments.	$\mathbf{Meningococcal}$ $\mathbf{meningitis}$: DO NOT delay antibiotics for LP. Give IV cefotaxime/ceftriaxone immediately	Neurology/Emergency				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q238: A 34-year-old man is diagnosed as being HIV positive. He was born and brought up in the United Kingdom and is currently fit and well with no past medical history. At what point should anti-retroviral therapy be started?	At the time of diagnosis	CD4 < 200 × 10⁶/l	CD4 < 250 × 10⁶/l	CD4 < 300 × 10⁶/l	CD4 < 350 × 10⁶/l	A	At the time of diagnosis	Following the $\mathbf{2015}$ $\mathbf{BHIVA}$ $\mathbf{guidelines}$, it is now recommended that patients start $\mathbf{HAART}$ $\mathbf{as}$ $\mathbf{soon}$ $\mathbf{as}$ $\mathbf{diagnosed}$ with HIV, rather than waiting until a particular CD4 count. HAART involves combination of at least three drugs, typically two NRTIs and either a PI or NNRTI. This decreases viral replication and reduces risk of viral resistance.	$\mathbf{HIV}$ $\mathbf{treatment}$: Start HAART immediately at diagnosis (no longer wait for CD4 threshold)	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 170-185 (MRCP7)	P170-185, Q239: A 17-year-old male presents with a severe sore throat, fever and lethargy. On examination he is noted to have cervical lymphadenopathy. He has now been unwell for 6 days. Blood test: Hb 15.5 g/L, Platelets 300 × 10⁹/L, WBC 9 × 10⁹/L, Neuts 3 × 10⁹/L, Lymphs 5.5 × 10⁹/L, Mono 0.5 × 10⁹/L, Eosin 0.1 × 10⁹/L. Heterophil antibody test POSITIVE. What is the most appropriate next step in management?	Ultrasound of spleen	Amoxicillin	Observation	Oseltamivir	Zanamivir	C	Observation	This patient has $\mathbf{infectious}$ $\mathbf{mononucleosis}$ (EBV). $\mathbf{No}$ $\mathbf{active}$ $\mathbf{treatment}$ is required as it is generally a $\mathbf{self-limiting}$ condition. Patients should be counselled regarding the need to $\mathbf{avoid}$ $\mathbf{contact}$ $\mathbf{sports}$ for $\mathbf{8}$ $\mathbf{weeks}$ given the risk of splenic rupture. Do NOT give amoxicillin (causes maculopapular rash in EBV).	$\mathbf{Infectious}$ $\mathbf{mononucleosis}$ (EBV): self-limiting. Avoid contact sports x8 weeks (splenic rupture risk)	Virology

When polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) are in the stool for some time, the lobed nuclei come apart and can resemble protozoan cysts with four separate nuclei.	PMNs in stool can be misidentified as protozoan cysts.	Parasitology

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 319-336	P319-336, Q28: As regard rabies vaccine for non-immunized adults:	RIG should not be administered	Vaccine HDCV or PCECV 1.0 mL, IM (deltoid area), one each on days 0 and 3	Vaccine HDCV or PCECV 1.0 mL, IM (deltoid area), one each on days 0, 3, 7, and 14	Anterolateral aspect of the thigh is preferred		C	Vaccine HDCV or PCECV 1.0 mL, IM (deltoid area), one each on days 0, 3, 7, and 14	the file in one time solved it =D High-Yield Notes  Adults and Older Children: The deltoid muscle (upper arm) is the only acceptable site for vaccine administration. Infants and Small Children: The anterolateral aspect of the thigh is the preferred site, as their deltoid muscle is too small to ensure the vaccine is delivered into the muscle tissue. Crucial Contraindication: The gluteal area (buttock) must never be used because the fatty tissue in this area can significantly interfere with the vaccine's absorption, leading to a suboptimal or failed immune response.	Non-immunized rabies vaccine: days 0, 3, 7, and 14.	Rabies				ASK C
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 319-336	P319-336, Q29: Which of the following is associated with ischemic necrosis?	Mucormycosis	Histoplasmosis	Coccidiomycosis	Candidiasis		A	Mucormycosis	File answer is C  Ischemia and Necrosis: The resulting lack of blood supply (ischemia) to the affected tissue leads to rapid tissue death (infarction and necrosis). This is why mucormycosis often presents as a rapidly destructive, necrotic lesion (e.g., black eschar in the nose or palate in rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis).	Mucormycosis is associated with ischemic necrosis.	Fungal Infections				A ASK

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 228-241	P228-241, Q28: How do people get infected from the plague?	When a person is bitten by a flea infected with the plague bacteria.	People get infected through direct contact with infected tissues or fluids while handling an animal that is sick or has died from the plague.	People can become infected from inhaling the respiratory droplets after close contact with cats and humans with pneumonic plague.	All the above.		D	All the above.	People become infected from the plague when they are bitten by a flea that is infected with the plague bacteria. They can also become infected through direct contact with infected tissues or fluids while handling an animal that is sick or died due to the plague. Also, people get an infection from inhaling respiratory droplets after close contact with cats and humans with pneumonic plague.	Plague transmission: flea bites, direct contact with infected tissues, or respiratory droplets.	Plague

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 228-241	P228-241, Q31: Which of the following is/are the symptoms of bubonic plague? The swelling is known as bubo and is commonly found at the site of the infected flea bite.	Bubonic plague symptoms: fever, muscle pain, swollen lymph nodes (buboes).	Plague
