ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q240: A 28-year-old nurse on your ward receives a needle stick injury after taking blood from a known HIV positive patient. You give her first aid treatment and send bloods for an initial HIV test. She asks you about post exposure prophylaxis. What would you advise?	Tenofovir, repeat HIV test in 12 weeks	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavir/ritonavir) repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	Nevirapine, repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavir/ritonavir), repeat HIV test in 12 weeks	Tenofovir, repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	B	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavir/ritonavir) repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	Combination antiretrovirals should be given rather than single therapy as it is more effective and helps prevent development of resistance. Nevirapine can be used in post exposure prophylaxis in newborn babies born to HIV positive mothers. Repeat testing for HIV antibody/antigen should be done at 12 weeks as this is how long it can take to develop antibodies. HIV PEP: combination of oral antiretrovirals (e.g. Tenofovir, emtricitabine, lopinavir and ritonavir) as soon as possible (i.e. within 1-2 hours, but may be started up to 72 hours following exposure) for 4 weeks. Serological testing at 12 weeks following completion of post-exposure prophylaxis. Reduces risk of transmission by 80%. Estimates of transmission risk for single needlestick injury: Hepatitis B 20-30%, Hepatitis C 0.5-2%, HIV 0.3%.	HIV PEP: **combination antiretrovirals** for **4 weeks**, test at **12 weeks**. Reduces transmission by **80%**.	HIV/Needlestick Injury				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q241: A 34-year-old man from Venezuela presents with a flu-like illness and periorbital oedema. Generalised lymphadenopathy is noted. A diagnosis of Chagas' disease is confirmed on blood smear. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Benznidazole	Sodium stibogluconate	Metronidazole	Pentamidine	Atovaquone-proguanil	A	Benznidazole	Trypanosomiasis - see Q-1 for details.	**Benznidazole** is the treatment for **Chagas' disease** (American trypanosomiasis).	Trypanosomiasis/Chagas				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q242: A 69-year-old man is brought into the emergency department with a few days history of increasing shortness of breath, fever and a productive cough. HR 105 bpm, O2 sat 90% on air, BP 100/65 mmHg, Temp 38.9°C, RR 32 breaths per minute. Chest X-ray shows right mid-zone cavity with surrounding consolidation. He reports catching a 'bad cold' from grandchildren about a month ago. What is the most likely cause?	Lung cancer	Klebsiella pneumoniae infection	Staphylococcus aureus infection	Pulmonary tuberculosis	Streptococcus pneumoniae infection	C	Staphylococcus aureus infection	Staphylococcus aureus is associated with cavitating lesions when it causes pneumonia. This gentleman likely developed influenza a few weeks prior, which is associated with the development of S. aureus pneumonia following resolution. S. aureus is associated with cavitating lung lesions in pneumonia, especially when caused by strains producing Panton-Valentine Leukocidin cytotoxin. Although lung cancer, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and pulmonary TB are associated with cavitating lung lesions, they are less likely: Squamous cell carcinoma is most common oncological cause but no smoking history given; Klebsiella pneumoniae is associated with alcoholism; Pulmonary TB has more drawn out, subacute presentation. Streptococcus pneumoniae is not associated with cavitating lung lesions.	**S. aureus pneumonia** follows **influenza** and causes **cavitating lesions**. **Panton-Valentine Leukocidin** toxin causes necrotic, hemorrhagic pneumonia.	Pneumonia/Staphylococcus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q243: A 19-year-old man presents with a two-day history of diffuse headache and sore throat. He is pyrexial at 37.8°C and reluctant to have fundoscopy due to photophobia. Lumbar puncture: Serum glucose 5.9 mmol/l, CSF appearance Clear, Glucose 4.1 mmol/l, Protein 0.3 g/l, White cells lymphocytes 2/mm³, polymorphs 0/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Guillain-Barre syndrome	Viral meningitis	Bacterial meningitis	Cerebral malaria	Normal CSF result	E	Normal CSF result	These results are consistent with normal CSF - an alternative diagnosis should be considered.	**Normal CSF values**: Glucose 3.3-4.4 mmol/l (>50% serum), Protein <0.45 g/l, WBC <5/mm³ (mainly lymphocytes).	Meningitis/CSF Analysis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q244: A 44-year-old farmer presents to ED with high temperature and confusion. Pulse 124 bpm, BP 84/56 mmHg, Temp 39.8°C. He has a generalised erythematous rash starting to desquamate on palms and a paronychial infection of a fingernail on the left hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Paraquat overdose	Leptospirosis	Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome	Disseminated herpes simplex infection	Organophosphate poisoning	C	Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome	Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome describes severe systemic reaction to staphylococcal exotoxins. CDC diagnostic criteria: fever (temp >38.9°C), hypotension (systolic BP <90 mmHg), diffuse erythematous rash, desquamation of rash especially of palms and soles, involvement of three or more organ systems (e.g. GI diarrhea/vomiting, mucous membrane erythema, renal failure, hepatitis, thrombocytopenia, CNS involvement like confusion).	**Toxic shock syndrome**: **fever >38.9°C**, **hypotension**, **diffuse erythematous rash**, **desquamation** (palms/soles), **≥3 organ systems** involved.	Staphylococcal Infection				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q245: A 17-year-old female presents for review. Four days ago she presented with severe sore throat, lethargy and headache. Her doctor prescribed amoxicillin for URTI. Two days ago she developed widespread, pruritic maculopapular rash. Her original symptoms have not improved. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Infectious mononucleosis	Kawasaki disease	Penicillin allergy	HIV seroconversion	Beta-lactamase producing streptococcal sore throat	A	Infectious mononucleosis	URTI symptoms + amoxicillin → rash suggests glandular fever. A rash develops in around 99% of patients who take amoxicillin whilst they have infectious mononucleosis. Treatment should be supportive.	**99%** of patients with **infectious mononucleosis** develop **rash** with **amoxicillin**.	Infectious Mononucleosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q246a: What is the most appropriate antibiotic to use in cholera?	Erythromycin	Metronidazole	Doxycycline	Penicillin V	Trimethoprim	C	Doxycycline	Cholera: caused by Vibrio cholerae (Gram negative bacteria). Features: profuse 'rice water' diarrhea, dehydration, hypoglycemia. Management: oral rehydration therapy, antibiotics (doxycycline, ciprofloxacin).	**Cholera** treatment: **ORT** + **doxycycline** or **ciprofloxacin**. Causes **'rice water' diarrhea**.	Cholera				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q246b: A 27-year-old pregnant woman is found to have Chlamydia. She reports being allergic to penicillin. What is the most appropriate treatment?	No antibiotic therapy is indicated	Cefixime	Erythromycin	Doxycycline	Ciprofloxacin	C	Erythromycin	NICE Clinical Knowledge Summaries recommends azithromycin, erythromycin or amoxicillin for pregnant women who have Chlamydia. The efficacy of amoxicillin was supported in a recent Cochrane review. A test of cure should be carried out following treatment.	**Chlamydia in pregnancy**: **azithromycin**, **erythromycin**, or **amoxicillin**. **Test of cure** required.	Chlamydia/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q247: A 25-year-old man is bitten by his assailant during a fight outside a nightclub. Alongside Streptococci spp. and Staphylococcus aureus, which of the following organisms is most likely to be isolated?	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Eikonella corrodens	Neisseria gonorrhoeae	Acinetobacter baumannii	Enterococcus faecalis	B	Eikonella corrodens	Eikenella is notable as a cause of infections following human bites. Found in around 10-30% of human bite wounds. Human bites commonly cause multimicrobial infection including aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Common organisms: Streptococci spp., Staphylococcus aureus, Eikenella, Fusobacterium, Prevotella. Co-amoxiclav is recommended. Risk of viral infections such as HIV and hepatitis C should also be considered.	**Human bites**: **Eikenella corrodens** (10-30%), Streptococci, S. aureus. Treat with **co-amoxiclav**.	Human Bite/Eikenella				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q248: A 21-year-old female complains of three day history of dysuria, frequency and mild fever. No abdominal or loin pain. Urine dipstick shows 2+ leucocytes but negative for blood, protein and nitrites. Which organism is the most likely cause?	Escherichia Coli	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Proteus mirabilis	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Klebsiella pneumoniae	B	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	This patient has lower UTI. The clue is that despite being leucocyte positive, the dipstick is nitrite negative. Gram negative organisms test positive on nitrite test as they convert nitrates to nitrites for energy. Gram positive organisms cannot reduce nitrate to nitrite and test negative. Staphylococcus species are the only gram positive organisms listed.	**Nitrite negative UTI** suggests **Gram positive** organism like **Staphylococcus saprophyticus**. Gram negatives convert nitrate→nitrite.	UTI/Staphylococcus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q249: A 19-year-old man presents with compound fracture of his leg with mud soiling of the wound. He has had five previous tetanus vaccinations. What is the most appropriate action to prevent tetanus?	Clean wound + intramuscular human tetanus immunoglobulin	Clean wound + tetanus vaccine	Clean wound + tetanus vaccine + intramuscular human tetanus immunoglobulin	Clean wound + tetanus vaccine + benzylpenicillin	Clean wound	A	Clean wound + intramuscular human tetanus immunoglobulin	A soiled, compound fracture is regarded as high-risk for tetanus and intramuscular human tetanus immunoglobulin should be given. There is a role for antibiotics given the soiled wound although benzylpenicillin would not be the drug of choice.	**High-risk tetanus wound** (soiled, compound): clean + **HTIG** (even if fully vaccinated).	Tetanus Prophylaxis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q250: A 19-year-old medical student undergoes primary immunisation against hepatitis B. His post immunisation bloods: Anti-HBs <10 mIU/ml. What is the most appropriate course of action?	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Do a HIV test	Test for current or past hepatitis B + repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of vaccine	Give two further doses of hepatitis B vaccine	Give a course of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) + one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	C	Test for current or past hepatitis B + repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of vaccine	Non-responder to hepatitis B vaccination requires testing for current/past infection and repeat full course.	**Non-responder** to HBV vaccine (anti-HBs <10): test for **current/past HBV** + **repeat 3-dose course**.	Hepatitis B Vaccination				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q251: A 25-year-old sexually active woman presents with dysuria and urgency. Urine dipstick positive for leukocytes and nitrites. Urine culture and gram staining reveal gram-positive organism in clusters that is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely causative organism?	Escherichia coli	Staphylococcus aureus	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Proteus mirabilis	Klebsiella	C	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Staphylococcus saprophyticus is the second most common cause of UTIs in sexually active young women (E. coli is most common). It is gram-positive coccus that grows in clusters and is coagulase-negative. E. coli is gram-negative. S. aureus is gram-positive in clusters but coagulase-positive. Proteus mirabilis is gram-negative bacilli and urease-positive. Klebsiella is gram-negative bacilli.	**S. saprophyticus**: **2nd most common UTI** in **young sexually active women**. **Gram-positive cocci** in **clusters**, **coagulase-negative**.	UTI/Staphylococcus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q252: A 28-year-old male with IV drug use history presents with SOB, dry cough, fever for one week. Prior months: weight loss, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, myalgia. O2 sats 88% on air, HR 112, BP 124/85, RR 24/min, Temp 37.8°C. On mobilising O2 sats drop to 75%. CXR: bilateral perihilar shadowing. ABG on 5L O2: pH 7.41, PaO2 8.9 kPa, PaCO2 3.6 kPa. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Amoxicillin and clarithromycin	Co-trimoxazole	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	Doxycycline	Oseltamivir	C	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	This patient has Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia most likely on background of undiagnosed HIV infection. Treatment for pneumocystis pneumonia is with oral co-trimoxazole or IV pentamidine if oral not tolerated. Steroids are also given if there is severe hypoxemia, as in this case.	**PCP** treatment: **co-trimoxazole** (or IV pentamidine). Add **steroids** if **severe hypoxemia** (PaO2 <9.3 kPa on air).	PCP/HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q253: A woman 14 weeks pregnant came into contact with child with chickenpox 4 days ago. Unsure if she had it as a child. Blood tests: Varicella IgM Negative, Varicella IgG Negative. What is the most appropriate management?	Varicella zoster immunoglobulin	No action required	IV aciclovir	Varicella zoster vaccination	Varicella zoster vaccination + varicella zoster immunoglobulin	A	Varicella zoster immunoglobulin	Chickenpox exposure in pregnancy - if not immune give VZIG. The negative IgG indicates no previous exposure to chickenpox.	**Chickenpox exposure in pregnancy** + **IgG negative**: give **VZIG**.	Chickenpox/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q254: A 24-year-old man from Sudan presents with worsening headache. Emigrated 2 weeks ago. Cough for 6 weeks. Tuberculin skin test negative, not responded to oral antibiotics. No medical history. HIV serology positive, cryptococcal antigen negative, toxoplasmosis serology negative. CT: single 3cm lesion and meningeal enhancement. What is the most likely organism responsible for his headache?	Toxoplasma gondii	Cryptococcus neoformans	Cytomegalovirus	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	JC virus	D	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	This young patient has headache in context of untreated HIV (likely low CD4). He has chronic cough with significant history of time in Sudan, making him high risk for TB. Meningeal enhancement on CT increases suspicion of TB. In immunosuppression, tuberculin skin test is unreliable. Cryptococcal infection unlikely with negative antigen test. Toxoplasmosis possible but lack of confusion/drowsiness and neurological deficit makes it less likely, especially with negative serology. Absence of fever and confusion makes CMV encephalitis unlikely. PML shows widespread demyelination.	**TB meningitis** in HIV: **meningeal enhancement** on CT. **Tuberculin test unreliable** in immunosuppression.	TB/HIV/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q255: A 28-year-old man immunosuppressed from HIV admitted with dyspnea and dry cough. CXR: bilateral interstitial pulmonary infiltrates. Started on co-trimoxazole. Next morning: sudden worsening dyspnea with left-sided chest pain. Which complication is most likely?	Empyema	Pulmonary embolism	Acute respiratory distress syndrome	Pericarditis	Pneumothorax	E	Pneumothorax	Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia - pneumothorax is a common complication.	**PCP complication**: **pneumothorax** is common.	PCP/Pneumothorax				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q256: A patient recently returned from Ivory Coast presents with cyclical fever and headache. Splenomegaly on examination. Blood film diagnoses Plasmodium vivax malaria. Treated with chloroquine then given primaquine. What is the benefit of primaquine?	Destroy liver hypnozoites and prevent relapse	Reduce the risk of chloroquine-related retinopathy	Reduce the incidence of chloroquine resistance	Cover Plasmodium ovale in case of co-infection	Prevent immature trophozoites forming gametocytes	A	Destroy liver hypnozoites and prevent relapse	Primaquine destroys liver hypnozoites (dormant liver forms) in P. vivax and P. ovale to prevent relapse.	**Primaquine** destroys **liver hypnozoites** in **P. vivax/ovale** to **prevent relapse**.	Malaria/Primaquine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q257: A 39-year-old man presents with SOB following one week of flu-like symptoms. Non-productive cough but no chest pain. CXR: bilateral consolidation. Examination: erythematous lesions on limbs and trunk. Which investigation is most likely to be diagnostic?	Cold agglutins	Sputum culture	Urinary antigen for Legionella	Serology for Mycoplasma	Blood culture	D	Serology for Mycoplasma	Mycoplasma - serology is diagnostic. The flu-like symptoms, bilateral consolidation and erythema multiforme point to diagnosis of Mycoplasma. Most appropriate diagnostic test is Mycoplasma serology.	**Mycoplasma pneumonia**: **bilateral consolidation** + **erythema multiforme**. Diagnose with **serology**.	Mycoplasma/Pneumonia				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q258: A 27-year-old student presents with 24-hour history of explosive diarrhea and vomiting. No blood in stool, no foreign travel. Has been eating rice kept warm in rice cooker for several days. What is the likely pathogenic organism?	Bacillus cereus	Campylobacter jejuni	Shigella flexneri	Norwalk virus	Staphylococcus aureus	A	Bacillus cereus	Bacillus cereus characteristically occurs after eating rice that has been reheated. Bacillus cereus spores germinate in cooked rice and produce toxin if cooked product is kept insufficiently chilled. S. aureus causes toxigenic food poisoning but specific history makes this less likely. Norwalk virus can cause explosive diarrhea/vomiting but not associated with specific foodstuffs. Campylobacter and Shigella cause bacterial food poisoning and would likely have longer history with bloody diarrhea.	**Bacillus cereus**: **reheated rice**. Spores germinate and produce **toxin** if insufficiently chilled.	Food Poisoning/Bacillus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q259: A 29-year-old woman presents to GUM clinic for treatment of recurrent genital warts. Which viruses are most likely responsible?	Human papilloma virus 16 & 18	Human papilloma virus 13 & 17	Human papilloma virus 6 & 11	Human papilloma virus 12 & 14	Human papilloma virus 15 & 21	C	Human papilloma virus 6 & 11	Genital warts - 90% are caused by HPV 6 & 11. Types 6 and 11 responsible for 90% of genital warts cases. HPV types 16, 18 & 33 predispose to cervical cancer.	**Genital warts**: **HPV 6 & 11** (90%). **Cervical cancer**: HPV 16, 18, 33.	HPV/Genital Warts				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q260: A 54-year-old man presents with positive serology for syphilis found during insurance medical. Travels for work, paid for sex with male sex workers in Thailand. Never tested before, asymptomatic, feels well. Which advice should you give him?	Asymptomatic (latent) infection implies late disease	Symptomatic syphilis requires repeated antibiotic treatments; latent disease requires one-off treatment only	Spontaneous clearance of Treponema pallidum does not occur	Only symptomatic patients need treatment for syphilis	Almost all patients with syphilis will describe a chancre as their first symptom	C	Spontaneous clearance of Treponema pallidum does not occur	Latent syphilis (asymptomatic) can occur at early and late stage and requires same antibiotic treatment. Syphilis can be present without symptoms at either early or late stage: 'early latent' (<2 years since last negative test) and 'late latent' (>2 years since last negative test). Whether latent or symptomatic does not alter treatment; only affected by whether not tested in last 2 years (further doses required) or if neurosyphilis suspected. Many patients unaware of having had chancre. No known clearance of Treponema pallidum without antibiotic treatment.	**Latent syphilis** requires **same treatment** as symptomatic. **No spontaneous clearance** of T. pallidum - **treatment always needed**.	Syphilis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q261: A 30-year-old man presents to GUM clinic. Handed slip from ex-girlfriend stating she tested positive for Chlamydia. Last slept with her 2 months ago. No symptoms, no dysuria or discharge. What is the most appropriate management?	Reassure symptoms would have presented by now	Offer antibiotic therapy	Offer Chlamydia testing and antibiotic treatment immediately without waiting for results	Offer Chlamydia testing and antibiotic treatment if positive	Notify public health	C	Offer Chlamydia testing and antibiotic treatment immediately without waiting for results	Chlamydia contact: offer testing and treat immediately without waiting for results due to high transmission risk and often asymptomatic nature.	**Chlamydia contact**: **test** + **treat immediately** without waiting for results.	Chlamydia				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q262: A 46-year-old woman presents 3 days after returning from safari in Tanzania. Fever, chills, myalgia, malaise started 2 days ago. Now daytime somnolence and nighttime insomnia. Husband reports strange behavior. Took malarone prophylaxis and recommended vaccines. HIV test negative. Temp 38.5°C, HR 90/min, BP 118/90, RR 18/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Cerebral malaria	Human African Trypanosomiasis	Yellow fever	Tuberculosis meningitis	Bacterial meningitis	B	Human African Trypanosomiasis	The reversal of sleep-wake cycle is typical of trypanosomiasis (African sleeping sickness) and can be accompanied by behavioral changes. Cerebral malaria unlikely given malarone prophylaxis and reversal of sleep-wake cycle would not be feature. TB meningitis unlikely, especially without HIV or immunosuppression. Bacterial meningitis does not cause sleep-wake cycle reversal and onset quite long. Yellow fever found in Tanzania (low risk) - initial symptoms similar but later stages involve jaundice, abdominal pain, bleeding not behavioral and sleep disturbances.	**African trypanosomiasis** (sleeping sickness): **reversal of sleep-wake cycle** + **behavioral changes**.	Trypanosomiasis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q263: A 44-year-old man known HIV positive presents with shortness-of-breath. Which feature is most characteristic of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia?	Usually occurs when CD4 count is 200-300/mm³	Absence of fever	Productive cough	Oxygen saturations usually improve after short period of exertion	Normal chest auscultation	E	Normal chest auscultation	PCP characteristically has normal chest auscultation despite bilateral infiltrates on imaging. Occurs when CD4 <200, fever present, dry cough (not productive), oxygen desaturates on exertion.	**PCP**: **normal chest auscultation** despite bilateral infiltrates. **Desaturates on exertion**.	PCP/HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q264: A 34-year-old man from West Africa admitted with confusion, left-sided weakness and ataxia. Known HIV positive but not on ART. CD4 43 u/l. CT head: Low attenuation diffusely, no mass effect or enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Toxoplasmosis	Tuberculosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcus	Cerebral lymphoma	C	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	PML (caused by JC virus) shows diffuse low attenuation on CT without mass effect or enhancement in severely immunosuppressed patient (CD4 <50). Toxoplasmosis typically shows ring-enhancing lesions with mass effect. Lymphoma shows enhancement. TB shows meningeal enhancement. Cryptococcus shows meningeal enhancement or normal CT.	**PML**: **diffuse low attenuation** on CT, **no mass effect/enhancement**, **CD4 <50**. Caused by **JC virus**.	PML/HIV/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 186-195 (MRCP8)	P186-195, Q265: A patient who was IV drug user in 1990s asks for hepatitis C test. What is the most appropriate action?	Refer him for pre-test counselling to discuss pros and cons of testing	Advise him that no accurate test is currently available but undertake normal precautions	Arrange an anti-HCV antibody test	Arrange a HCV RNA test	Refer him to gastroenterology for liver biopsy	C	Arrange an anti-HCV antibody test	HCV RNA tests are normally only ordered following positive antibody test. Initial screening for hepatitis C is anti-HCV antibody test.	**HCV screening**: **anti-HCV antibody** test first. HCV RNA test if antibody positive.	Hepatitis C				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, Q1: The two types of viral hepatitis most likely to be associated with an acute infection are:	HAV and HEV	HCV and HDV	HBD and HDV	HEV and HCV		A	HAV and HEV	Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and Hepatitis E virus (HEV) are both typically associated with acute infection patterns, rather than chronic infection. They are transmitted via fecal-oral route and generally cause self-limited acute hepatitis.	**HAV and HEV** cause **acute hepatitis** (not chronic). Both **fecal-oral transmission**.	Viral Hepatitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, Q2: Which hepatitis virus requires another virus for replication?	HDV	HBV	HCV	HEV		A	HDV	Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is a defective virus that requires Hepatitis B virus (HBV) for replication. HDV is also known as delta agent and can only infect individuals who are already infected with HBV.	**HDV (delta agent)** requires **HBV** for replication. Only occurs in **HBV-infected** patients.	Viral Hepatitis/HDV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, Q3: Which hepatitis virus(es) below is (are) transmitted by the fecal/oral route?	Hepatitis D (delta agent) virus	Hepatitis B virus	Hepatitis A virus	Hepatitis C virus		C	Hepatitis A virus	Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and Hepatitis E virus (HEV) are transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Hepatitis B, C, and D are transmitted parenterally (blood-borne). The question shows Hepatitis A as option 3, which is the correct answer among the choices listed.	**Fecal-oral hepatitis**: **HAV** and **HEV**. Blood-borne: HBV, HCV, HDV.	Viral Hepatitis/Transmission				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q1: What is the primary mode of transmission for most viral hemorrhagic fevers?	Airborne	Fecal-oral	Vector-borne	Direct contact		C	Vector-borne	Most viral hemorrhagic fevers are transmitted by vectors such as mosquitoes, ticks, or through contact with infected animal reservoirs. Examples include dengue (mosquitoes), Crimean-Congo HF (ticks), and Rift Valley fever (mosquitoes).	**Most VHF**: **vector-borne** transmission (mosquitoes, ticks) or animal contact.	Viral Hemorrhagic Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q2: Which virus is responsible for Ebola virus disease?	Hantavirus	Dengue virus	Ebola virus	Lassa virus		C	Ebola virus	Ebola virus disease is caused by Ebola virus, a filovirus. It causes severe hemorrhagic fever with high mortality rates, transmitted through direct contact with infected bodily fluids.	**Ebola**: caused by **Ebola virus** (filovirus). **Direct contact** transmission.	Ebola/VHF				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q3: Which organ is commonly affected in patients with viral hemorrhagic fevers?	Heart	Liver	Kidneys	Lungs		B	Liver	The liver is commonly affected in viral hemorrhagic fevers, leading to hepatitis, elevated liver enzymes, and coagulopathy. Other organs can also be affected depending on the specific virus.	**VHF commonly affects liver**, causing hepatitis and coagulopathy.	Viral Hemorrhagic Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q4: What is the incubation period for most viral hemorrhagic fevers?	1-2 days	1-2 weeks	2-4 weeks	4-6 weeks		C	2-4 weeks	Most viral hemorrhagic fevers have an incubation period of 1-4 weeks, though this can vary by specific virus. This is the typical timeframe between exposure and symptom onset.	**VHF incubation**: typically **1-2 weeks**.	Viral Hemorrhagic Fever				ASK b
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q5: Which of the following is a characteristic symptom of viral hemorrhagic fevers?	Rash	Joint pain	Hemorrhage	Headache		C	Hemorrhage	Hemorrhage is the characteristic and defining symptom of viral hemorrhagic fevers. Patients may experience bleeding from multiple sites including mucous membranes, GI tract, and internal organs.	**VHF characteristic**: **hemorrhage** from multiple sites.	Viral Hemorrhagic Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q6: Which virus is associated with the following symptoms: sudden fever, muscle pain, vomiting, and bleeding? It is a filovirus similar to Ebola with high mortality rates.	**Marburg virus**: sudden fever, myalgia, vomiting, **bleeding**. Filovirus, high mortality.	Marburg/VHF				ASK b
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q7: What is the recommended preventive measure for Lassa fever?	Bed rest	Vaccination	Antibiotic therapy	Insect repellent use		B	Vaccination	Vaccination is the recommended preventive measure for Lassa fever. However, it should be noted that currently there is no licensed vaccine widely available, though research is ongoing.	**Lassa fever prevention**: vaccination (though not widely available yet). Rodent control also important.	Lassa Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q8: Which of the following animals is a common reservoir for the Hantavirus, causing Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome?	Bats	Rodents	Mosquitoes	Birds		B	Rodents	Rodents are the common reservoir for Hantavirus. The virus is transmitted to humans through inhalation of aerosolized rodent urine, feces, or saliva. Hantavirus causes Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome (HPS) and hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS).	**Hantavirus reservoir**: **rodents**. Transmitted via **inhalation** of aerosolized excreta.	Hantavirus				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q9: In which geographic regions is Dengue hemorrhagic fever most commonly found?	Sub-Saharan Africa	Southeast Asia and the Pacific	North America	Europe		B	Southeast Asia and the Pacific	Dengue hemorrhagic fever is most commonly found in Southeast Asia and the Pacific regions, though it also occurs in tropical and subtropical areas worldwide including Latin America and parts of Africa.	**Dengue HF**: endemic in **Southeast Asia** and Pacific. Also tropical/subtropical worldwide.	Dengue				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q10: How is Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever primarily transmitted to humans?	Mosquito bites	Tick bites	Direct contact with infected blood or tissues	Inhalation of respiratory droplets		B	Tick bites	Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is primarily transmitted to humans through tick bites. It can also be transmitted through direct contact with infected blood or tissues of animals or infected humans.	**CCHF transmission**: **tick bites** (primary). Also direct contact with infected blood/tissues.	Crimean-Congo HF				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q11: Which viral hemorrhagic fever is associated with a distinctive biphasic fever pattern, with an initial febrile phase followed by a brief period of improvement before a more severe febrile phase?	Rift Valley fever	Junin virus (Argentine hemorrhagic fever)	Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever	Yellow fever		A	Rift Valley fever	Yellow fever is characterized by a biphasic fever pattern with an initial febrئile phase, followed by a period of remission (period of calm), and then a second toxic phase with fever, jaundice, and hemorrhage in severe cases.	**Yellow fever**: **biphasic fever** (initial fever → remission → toxic phase with jaundice/hemorrhage).	Yellow Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 337-352	P337-352, VHF Q12: Which hemorrhagic fever is known for causing bleeding from the gums, nose, and gastrointestinal tract?	Lassa fever	Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome	Dengue hemorrhagic fever	Marburg virus disease		C	Dengue hemorrhagic fever	Dengue hemorrhagic fever is characterized by bleeding manifestations including bleeding from gums, nose (epistaxis), and gastrointestinal tract. It can progress to dengue shock syndrome if severe.	**Dengue HF**: bleeding from **gums, nose, GI tract**. Can progress to shock syndrome.	Dengue

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, Hospital Q1: An elderly patient, hospitalized with a gastrointestinal disorder, was on bed rest and required assistance for activities of daily living. The nurse's hands were not washed before manipulating the tubing attached to the urinary catheter of the second patient who developed CAUTI 3 days later. What is your explanation?	It is a community-acquired infection	It is a hospital-acquired infection	It is autoinfection	It is a colonization	It is an endogenous infection	B	It is a hospital-acquired infection	This is a hospital-acquired infection (HAI) because the patient developed CAUTI 3 days after hospitalization, and the infection was transmitted through poor hand hygiene practices by healthcare personnel in the hospital setting. Hospital-acquired infections occur 48 hours or more after admission.	**HAI** (nosocomial infection): infection acquired **≥48 hours after admission**. CAUTI often transmitted via **poor hand hygiene**.	Hospital-Acquired Infection/CAUTI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, Hospital Q2: There is no vaccine against HIV because of which of the following?	The virus is so antigenically variable	Such a vaccine would be too expensive	The virus can be controlled by a change in sexual habits	Latency can abrogate any vaccine effect	The virus has high communicability	A	The virus is so antigenically variable	HIV has extreme antigenic variability due to its high mutation rate and ability to integrate into host genome. This antigenic variation makes it extremely difficult to develop an effective vaccine, as the virus constantly changes its surface proteins.	**No HIV vaccine** due to **extreme antigenic variability**. High mutation rate prevents effective vaccine development.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, Hospital Q3: Which clinical sample is used to diagnose hepatitis B? Serological testing on blood is the primary diagnostic method for hepatitis B.	**Hepatitis B diagnosis**: **blood** sample for serological testing (HBsAg, anti-HBc, anti-HBs, etc).	Hepatitis B				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, IPC Q1: The most important practice in reducing HAIs is.	washing your hands after using the toilet	washing your hands when they are visibly soiled	carrying out hand hygiene frequently using the correct technique	wearing gloves and gowns	wearing gloves and surgical mask	C	carrying out hand hygiene frequently using the correct technique	Hand hygiene performed frequently using correct technique is the single most important practice in reducing healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). It should be performed at key moments regardless of visible soiling, not just after toilet use.	**Most important HAI prevention**: **frequent hand hygiene** with **correct technique** at all key moments.	Infection Prevention Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, IPC Q2: Infectious waste includes:	radioactive materials	papers and food	needles and scalpels	laboratory cultures	broken thermometers	D	laboratory cultures	Laboratory cultures are infectious waste as they contain potentially pathogenic microorganisms. Needles and scalpels are sharps waste, radioactive materials are radioactive waste, papers and food are general waste, and broken thermometers are hazardous waste.	**Infectious waste**: **laboratory cultures** with pathogens. Sharps are separate category.	Infection Control/Waste Management				ASK
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, IPC Q3: Disinfection is a process in addition to cleaning. These items require at least high-level disinfection. Items touching intact skin only require cleaning.	**Disinfection needed**: items contacting **mucous membranes** (semi-critical items require high-level disinfection). ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q1: The most important practice in reducing the transmission of infectious agents causing HAIs is.	washing hands after using the toilet	washing hands when they are visibly soiled	washing frequently using the correct technique	wearing gloves and gowns	wearing gloves and a surgical mask	C	washing frequently using the correct technique	Frequent hand washing using correct technique at all key moments is the most important practice in reducing transmission of infectious agents causing HAIs. This is more comprehensive than only washing after toilet use or when visibly soiled.	**HAI prevention**: **frequent handwashing** with **correct technique** is most important intervention.	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q2: Your patient is on airborne isolation, and he will undergo ultrasound-guided thoracentesis. This minimizes risk of transmission during transport.	**Airborne isolation transport**: **surgical mask on patient**, **N95 mask on personnel**.	Airborne Isolation				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q3: A patient is to begin IV antibiotic therapy for a pulmonary infection. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q5: A patient is being admitted to a medical unit with a diagnosis of Covid-19. Which type of room should this patient be assigned by the nurse? Negative pressure prevents contaminated air from escaping the room, protecting other patients and staff. Air is exhausted outside or filtered through HEPA filters.	**COVID-19/airborne isolation**: **negative pressure room** prevents air escape, protects others.	COVID-19/Isolation				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q6: A nurse is teaching a new nursing assistant about ways to prevent the spread of infection. Included in the instruction would be that the cycle of the infectious process must be broken, which may be accomplished primarily through:	Hand washing before and between providing client care	Thoroughly cleaning the environment	Wearing infection control-approved protective equipment when providing patient care	Using medical and surgical aseptic techniques at all times	Proper use of disinfectants	A	Hand washing before and between providing client care	Hand washing before and between client care is the primary method to break the chain of infection. It removes transient organisms from hands that could be transmitted between patients, breaking the transmission link.	**Breaking chain of infection**: **hand washing before and between** patient care is primary method.	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q7: A nurse discusses the procedure for protective isolation with the husband of a patient who is receiving chemotherapy and has been hospitalized for neutropenia. The husband asked the nurse: is this means that protective isolation helps prevent the spread of infection?	to my wife from the outside environment	from my wife to health care personnel and visitors	from my wife by disinfecting infectious fluids and secretions	to my wife by using sterilization techniques for personal items before use	to my wife by special washing machine for her linens	A	to my wife from the outside environment	Protective isolation (reverse isolation) protects immunocompromised patients like those with neutropenia from acquiring infections from the outside environment, healthcare workers, and visitors. It's the opposite of isolation to prevent spread from patient.	**Protective/reverse isolation**: protects **immunocompromised patient FROM environment** (not others from patient).	Protective Isolation/Neutropenia				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q8: The nurse must assign a room to a patient with scabies. Which of the following options would be the best choice for this patient? Patients with same infection can be cohorted, but a private room is best option listed.	**Scabies**: **contact isolation** in **private room**. Transmitted by direct skin contact.	Scabies/Contact Isolation				ASK
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q9: A nurse administering immunizations to prevent infection such as Influenza by: which of the following mechanism? They stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies and memory cells, providing active immunity against specific pathogens.	**Vaccines/immunizations**: work by **enhancing host defenses** (active immunity, antibody production). ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q10: A patient has an infection that is spread through droplets. Which of the following is essential for the nurse to use when taking this client's temperature?	Gloves	Goggles	A gown	A mask	A face shield	D	A mask	For droplet precautions, a mask is essential PPE. Droplets are generated during coughing, sneezing, or talking and travel short distances (usually <6 feet). A mask protects the healthcare worker's nose and mouth from droplet exposure.	**Droplet precautions**: **mask essential** (droplets travel <6 feet from coughing/sneezing).	Droplet Precautions				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q11: What should you do if your hands touch the sink while you are washing your hands?	add more soap to your hands	continue to wash your hands	repeat the procedure	apply more friction during procedure	take care and repeat this step only	C	repeat the procedure	If hands touch the sink during handwashing, they are considered contaminated (as sinks are reservoirs for microorganisms), and the entire handwashing procedure must be repeated from the beginning.	**Handwashing**: if hands touch sink (contaminated), **repeat entire procedure**.	Hand Hygiene				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q12: Which of the following infections should you use handwashing with soap and water?	Pneumonia	Clostridium difficile	Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus	Hepatitis A virus	Mycotic infections	B	Clostridium difficile	Clostridium difficile requires handwashing with soap and water (not alcohol-based hand rub) because alcohol does not effectively remove C. difficile spores. Mechanical friction and rinsing are needed to remove spores.	**C. difficile**: requires **soap and water** handwashing (alcohol ineffective against spores).	C. difficile/Hand Hygiene				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q13: When caring for a patient with bronchitis, what is the best way the nurse can prevent the spread of infection?	By empirical antibiotics	ET Intubation	Hand Washing	Vaccination	Wearing mask	C	Hand Washing	Hand washing is the best way to prevent the spread of infection when caring for any patient, including those with bronchitis. It's the most effective single intervention to break the chain of infection.	**Preventing infection spread**: **hand washing** is best single intervention.	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q14: Antibiotics is given	to treat colonized patients	with the induction of anaesthesia	to be changed after 5 days	until the wound is healed	until there is no painful wound	B	with the induction of anaesthesia	Prophylactic antibiotics for surgical site infection prevention are given with the induction of anesthesia (within 60 minutes before surgical incision) to ensure adequate tissue levels during surgery.	**Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis**: given **with induction of anesthesia** (within 60 min before incision).	Antibiotic Prophylaxis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q15: The chain of infection has five main components. The habitat (animals, human or environment) in which the agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies is known as the	the reservoir of infection	the portal of exit	mode of transmission	portal of entry	the susceptible host	A	the reservoir of infection	The reservoir of infection is the habitat where the infectious agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies. Reservoirs can be humans, animals, or the environment (soil, water).	**Reservoir of infection**: habitat where agent **lives, grows, multiplies** (human, animal, environment).	Chain of Infection				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q16: You should always wash your hands even if you were wearing gloves.	True	False				A	True	Hands should always be washed after removing gloves because gloves can have microscopic defects or tears, and hands can become contaminated during glove removal. Hand hygiene is essential even when gloves are worn.	**Always wash hands after gloves**: gloves can have defects, hands contaminated during removal.	Hand Hygiene				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q17: It is impossible to break the Chain of Transmission.	True	False				B	False	The chain of transmission CAN be broken through various infection control measures including hand hygiene, isolation precautions, sterilization/disinfection, proper waste disposal, and vaccination. Breaking any link stops transmission.	**Chain of transmission CAN be broken** via hand hygiene, isolation, sterilization, vaccination, etc.	Chain of Infection				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 213-227	P213-227, ID Q18: What is a pandemic?	An outbreak which may occur in a community or geographical area	It may last for a few days or weeks, or even for several years	affects a wider geographical area, often worldwide with a greater number of people	It occurs when an infectious disease spreads rapidly to many people	It occurs when an infectious disease is present in a certain locality for a long time	C	affects a wider geographical area, often worldwide with a greater number of people	A pandemic affects a wider geographical area, often worldwide, with a greater number of people affected. It's distinguished from an epidemic (localized) and endemic (constantly present in an area).	**Pandemic**: affects **worldwide/wider geographical area** with **large numbers**. vs epidemic (localized) vs endemic (constantly present).	Pandemic

Such viruses are confined to animals	They do not cause disease in humans	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	They cause pandemics	They transmitted by birds	C	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	Zoonotic viruses like SARS emerge from animal reservoirs and cross the species barrier to infect humans. These spillover events occur infrequently but can lead to human outbreaks when they do occur.	**Zoonotic virus (SARS)**: **emerges from animals**, **crosses species barrier** infrequently to infect humans. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P198, Q11: The following are correct for food poisoning except for	a person gets sick after consuming a particular pathogenic microorganism	B- Food poisoning must be suspected when an acute illness with gastrointestinal or neurological manifestation affect two or more persons, have shared a meal during the previous 72 hours	C- Intoxication involves food poisoning in which the organism grows in food and releases a heat stable toxin from the cells on pre-formed food as salmonella spp	D- Salmonella cause a gastro-flu-like’ infection which in most cases lasts about 2 to 5 days. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P202, Q30: The most important factors affecting evaporation when exercising are:	heat and humidity.	duration.	time of day.	intensity.		A	heat and humidity. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P202, Q31: Which of the following environments would allow for the best convective cooling?	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	running in the winter wearing a sweat suit, cap, and gloves	running on a track in an enclosed gym	running outside in 80-degree F weather and 80-percent humidity		A	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	Convective cooling is enhanced by air movement (wind) over the skin. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P203, Q32: Which of the following groups is the MOST susceptible to heat illness?	the highly fit	the elderly	high school students	those jogging by themselves		B	the elderly	The elderly have diminished thermoregulatory capacity and are among the most susceptible to heat illness. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P203, Q33: The result of evaporation is:	no change in temperature.	warming.	cooling.	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.		D	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.	AI sloved it C (Cooling).  Option (c) cooling is always correct — it reflects the nature of the process.    Option (d) is incorrect, because even at 100% humidity, evaporation simply stops (no change in temperature), but it never reverses into warming.		Heat Illness			D	ASK
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P203, Q34: The best way to determine if environmental conditions are imposing a heat load on your body is to:	take your temperature.	weigh yourself before and after exercise to measure water weight loss.	monitor your heart rate.	measure your blood pressure.		C	monitor your heart rate.			Heat Illness				ASK
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P204, Q35: In order to minimize the possibility of overheating, exercise clothing should be all of the following EXCEPT:	lightweight.	minimal.	dry.	cotton or linen.		C	dry.	Cotton absorbs sweat and becomes heavy/wet, impairing evaporation. Moisture-wicking synthetic fabrics are better.  AI solved it (D) cotton or linen   To minimize the possibility of overheating during exercise, clothing should:    Be lightweight → allows heat dissipation.    Be minimal → exposes more skin for evaporation of sweat.    Be dry → keeps evaporation efficient.    However, cotton or linen (option d) are not ideal for exercise because:    They absorb sweat and become wet and heavy, reducing evaporation and trapping heat.    They don’t dry quickly, so the body loses its ability to cool effectively.    👉 Modern athletic wear uses synthetic “moisture-wicking” fabrics (like polyester blends) that draw sweat away from the skin and help prevent overheating, unlike cotton or linen.	Exercise Clothing: Lightweight, minimal, moisture-wicking (not cotton).	Heat Illness				ASK
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P204, Q36: Heat acclimatization:	decreases the exercise heart rate.	increases the risk of heat injuries.	needs more research before it should even be considered.	increases body temperature.		A	decreases the exercise heart rate.	Heat acclimatization improves thermoregulation, leading to a lower heart rate during exercise in the heat.	Heat Acclimatization: Lowers heart rate, increases sweat rate, improves cooling.	Heat Illness				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P204, Q37: Symptoms of heat exhaustion are:	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	increased blood pressure.	seizures.	hot, red, dry skin.		A	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	Heat exhaustion is characterized by heavy sweating, cool/clammy skin, weakness, and nausea. Hot, dry skin is seen in heat stroke.	Heat Exhaustion: Profuse sweating, cool/clammy skin, weakness, nausea.	Heat Illness				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P205, Q38: Heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke are similar in all the following ways EXCEPT:	very heavy sweating.	significant loss of water and electrolytes.	high inner core temperature of the body.	increased heat storage in the body.		A	very heavy sweating.	Heat stroke involves cessation of sweating and hot, dry skin, unlike heat cramps and exhaustion.	Heat Stroke: Hot, DRY skin; Altered mental status; High core temperature.	Heat Illness				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P205, Q39: When exercising in the heat, it is recommended that all of the following be kept in mind EXCEPT:	monitor your heart rate.	keep the exercise session short.	drink plenty of water before, during and after the workout.	take a salt tablet after the workout.		D	take a salt tablet after the workout.	Salt tablets are generally not recommended; electrolyte replacement is better achieved through balanced fluids/food.	Exercise in Heat: Hydrate with water/electrolytes; Avoid salt tablets.	Heat Illness				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P205, Q40: Heat injury can occur when the activity heat load exceeds the body's ability to regulate body temperature. Which of the following is not a common type of heat injury?	heat evaporation	heat cramps	heat exhaustion	heat stroke		A	heat evaporation	Heat evaporation is not a type of heat injury. The common types are heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke.	Heat Injuries: Heat cramps, heat exhaustion, heat stroke.	"Heat Illness""Question Stem"				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P206, Q41: A 16-year-old boy is admitted to hospital with severe upper abdominal pain radiating to his back, associated with nausea and vomiting. He opens his bowels 2 times per day with loose stools but no mucos or blood. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis six months ago, and controlled on azathioprine 50 mg daily, mesalamine 3 gm daily. On examination, there is tenderness in the epigastrium with normal bowel sounds. Normal abdominal ultrasound and upper endoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis to explain his current admission?	Acute gastroenteritis complicating ulcerative colitis	Acute pancreatitis secondary to drugs (azathioprine)	Choledocholithiasis associated with ulcerative colitis	Peptic ulcer disease secondary to high-dose steroids	Steroid refractory ulcerative colitis	B	Acute pancreatitis secondary to drugs (azathioprine)	Azathioprine is a known cause of drug-induced pancreatitis. The presentation (epigastric pain radiating to back, nausea/vomiting) is classic for pancreatitis.	Drug-induced Pancreatitis: Azathioprine, 5-ASAs, corticosteroids, metronidazole. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P206, Q42: A 50 year old woman presents with dysphagia and intermittent vomiting. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P207, Q43: A 42-year-old male presents with a 12-hour history of severe abdominal pain, fever and myalgia. He has a healed laparotomy scar from a previous hospital admission with similar symptoms which was inconclusive and was given broad spectrum antibiotics. Which medication would you prescribe? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P208, Q45: A 32-year-old man is seen with a long history of microcytic hypochromic anemia. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P208, Q48: A 61-year-old male presented with recent onset of ascites. Paracentesis was done and he results show a white blood cell count of 100 leukocytes 25% polymorphonuclear cells. The peritoneal albumin level is 1.2 g/dL, protein is 2.0 g/dL, and triglycerides are 20 mg/dL. Peritoneal cultures are pending. Serum albumin is 2.6 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	Bacterial peritonitis	Chylous ascites	Congestive heart failure	Peritoneal carcinomatosis	Peritoneal tuberculosis	C	Congestive heart failure	The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is 2.6 - 1.2 = 1.4 g/dL (high, >1.1), suggesting portal hypertension. However, the ascitic fluid protein is low (<2.5 g/dL) and the cell count is not typical for SBP.	Ascites: High SAAG (>1.1) = Portal hypertension. Low SAAG (<1.1) = Non-portal hypertensive causes (e.g., TB, malignancy).	Gastroenterology

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P209, Q50: A 38-year-old male is seen in the urgent care center with several hours of severe abdominal pain. he reports several months of pain in the epigastrium after. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P210, Q52: A 45-years old known hepatic patient presenting with a big oblique inguinal heria was referred to you from surgery for pre-operative assessment. On examination, he was conscious, but with jaundice, spider naevi, shrunken cirrhotic liver, splenomegaly and no ascites nor flapping tremors. Serum ALT was 40 (N. 45 IU/dl), s. bilirubin 3.5mg/dl (N. up to 1mg/dl), s. albumin 3.3gm/dl and prothrombin time INR was1.5. what is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh Classification and total score of that patient?	Child-C score 10	Child-B score 10	Child-B score 8	Child-B score 6	Child-C score 12	C	Child-B score 10	Calculating CTP score: Bilirubin 3.5 (2 points), Albumin 3.3 (2 points), INR 1.5 (2 points), Ascites (None = 1 point), Encephalopathy (None = 1 point). Total = 8 points, which is Child-Pugh Class B. The options list Child-B score 10, which seems to be a misprint; the correct class based on the calculated 8 points is Child B.	Child-Pugh Score: Class A (5-6), B (7-9), C (10-15).	Hepatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 196-212	P210, Q53: A 24-years old man was doing pre-employment examination. Clinical examination revealed evidence of chronic liver disease. ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q20: Which is true in Widal test?	Relapse bears relationship with agglutinin titre	Agglutinin against flagellar antigen is most important	Agglutinins begin to appear after 3rd day of infection	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week		D	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week	Widal test agglutinins typically peak around the 5th-6th week of illness. They appear after day 7-10, not day 3. The O antigen is more significant for acute infection than the H antigen.	Widal test: Titers peak at 5-6 weeks. O antigen more specific for acute typhoid.					Enteric fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q21: Which of the following is not characteristic of rose spots in typhoid fever?	Appears during the early second week	Do not blanch on pressure	Erythematous macules	They are bacterial emboli in skin capillaries		B	Do not blanch on pressure	Rose spots in typhoid fever are erythematous macules that blanch on pressure. They appear in the second week and are due to Salmonella emboli.	Rose spots (Typhoid): Blanchable, 2nd week, due to bacterial emboli.					Enteric fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q22: Normal flora of mouth does not contain:	Actinomyces species	Fusobacteria	Staphylococci	Escherichia species		D	Escherichia species	Escherichia coli is part of the normal gut flora but not the normal oral flora. Normal oral flora includes Actinomyces, Fusobacterium, Streptococcus, Veillonella, etc.	Normal oral flora: Streptococcus, Actinomyces, Fusobacterium, Veillonella. E. coli = gut flora.					Microbiology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q23: Anti-pseudomonal activity is maximally present in:	Ceftazidime	Cefpodoxime proxetil	Ceftriaxone	Ceftizoxime		A	Ceftazidime	Among cephalosporins, ceftazidime has the best anti-pseudomonal activity due to its side chain. Cefepime (4th gen) also has good activity.	Anti-pseudomonal cephalosporins: Ceftazidime, Cefepime.					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q24: Treatment of choice in chronic carrier of enteric fever is:	Cholecystectomy	Quinolones	Ceftriaxone	Furazolidone		A	Cholecystectomy	Chronic carriers (shedding >1 year) often have gallstones or chronic cholecystitis. Cholecystectomy, combined with antibiotics (e.g., quinolones), is the definitive treatment.	Chronic typhoid carrier: Gallbladder reservoir. Treatment: Cholecystectomy + antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin).					Enteric fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q25: Malta fever is caused by:	Pasteurella tularensis	Brucella abortus	Haemophilus influenzae	Pseudomonas mallei		B	Brucella abortus	Malta fever is another name for brucellosis, classically caused by Brucella melitensis (from goats), but Brucella abortus (from cattle) also causes it.	Malta fever = Brucellosis (Brucella melitensis classically).					Infections Zoonotic
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P3, Q26: Koch-Weeks bacillus is:	Haemophilus parainfluenzae	Haemophilus aphrophilus	Haemophilus ducreyi	Haemophilus aegypticus		D	Haemophilus aegypticus	Koch-Weeks bacillus (Haemophilus aegyptius) causes acute contagious conjunctivitis (pink eye).	Koch-Weeks bacillus = H. aegyptius → acute conjunctivitis.					Ophthalmology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q27: All of the following are susceptible to have Haemophilus infections except?	G6PD deficiency	Agammaglobulinaemia	Splenectomised subject	Sickle-cell disease		A	G6PD deficiency	Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is an encapsulated bacterium. Susceptibility increases in conditions with impaired antibody production (agammaglobulinemia) or impaired splenic function (splenectomy, sickle cell disease). G6PD deficiency does not increase risk.	Encapsulated bacteria (Hib, S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis) risk in: Asplenia, antibody deficiencies.					immunology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q28: Non-member of microbial flora of skin is:	Streptococcus faecalis	Streptococcus epidermidis	Erysipelothrix insidioma	Streptococcus viridans		C	Erysipelothrix insidioma	Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae causes erysipeloid in humans (an occupational disease in butchers, fishermen) and is not part of normal skin flora. Normal skin flora includes S. epidermidis, Corynebacterium, Propionibacterium. S. faecalis (Enterococcus) is gut flora.	Normal skin flora: S. epidermidis, Corynebacteria, Propionibacteria, Malassezia. Erysipelothrix = pathogen.					Microbiology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q29: Which is false regarding brucellosis?	Acquired through contact or ingestion of raw goat's milk	Brucella melitensis is the most common type of infection	CFT is more important in acute infection than that of agglutination reaction	May present as pyrexia of unknown origin		C	CFT is more important in acute infection than that of agglutination reaction	The standard tube agglutination test (SAT) is the mainstay for diagnosing acute brucellosis. The Complement Fixation Test (CFT) is more useful for chronic infections.	Brucellosis diagnosis: Standard tube agglutination test for acute infection.					Infections Zoonotic
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q30: Which is not a recognised complication of acute shigellosis?	Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome	Reiter's syndrome	Liver abscess	Endotoxic shock		C	Liver abscess	Complications of shigellosis include HUS (S. dysenteriae type 1), Reiter's syndrome (post-infectious), and toxic megacolon. Liver abscess is not a typical complication.	Shigellosis complications: HUS (S. dysenteriae), Reiter's syndrome, toxic megacolon, seizures.					Gastrointestinal Infections
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q31: Commonest cause of childhood otitis media is:	Haemophilus influenzae	Pneumococcus	Staphylococcus	Pseudomonas		B	Pneumococcus	Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of acute otitis media in children, followed by non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae and Moraxella catarrhalis.	Otitis media: Most common cause = S. pneumoniae.					ENT Infections
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q32: Which is not a complication of Salmonella species?	Endocarditis	Bronchiectasis	Osteomyelitis	Pyclonephritis		B	Bronchiectasis	Salmonella can cause endocarditis, osteomyelitis (especially in sickle cell disease), and pyelonephritis. Bronchiectasis is not a recognized direct complication.	Salmonella complications: Osteomyelitis (sickle cell), endocarditis, abscesses, septicemia.					Enteric fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q33: Pseudobubo is caused by:	Haemophilus ducreyi	HIV	Donovan body	Treponema pallidum		C	Donovan body	Pseudobubo is a term for the granulomatous inguinal swelling in Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis), caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (Donovan bodies).	Pseudobubo = Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis) → Donovan bodies.					Infections Sexually Transmitted
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q34: Woolsorter's disease is:	Plague	Legionnaires' disease	Klebsiella-induced pneumonia	Anthrax		D	Anthrax	Woolsorter's disease is the pulmonary form of anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, acquired by inhaling spores from contaminated animal products.	Woolsorter's disease = Pulmonary anthrax.					Infections Zoonotic
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P4, Q35: Botulism is manifested by all except:	Normal pupils	Entirely normal sensory functions	Increased protein in CSF	Progressive descending muscle paralysis		C	Increased protein in CSF	Botulism presents as an acute, afebrile, descending flaccid paralysis with bulbar palsy, dilated/fixed pupils, and normal sensory exam. CSF is typically normal.	Botulism: Descending flaccid paralysis, bulbar palsy, dilated pupils, normal CSF.					Infections Neurological
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P5, Q36: Pontiac fever is due to:	Serratia infection	Acinetobacter infection	Legionella infection	Haemophilus infection		C	Legionella infection	Pontiac fever is a self-limiting, flu-like illness caused by Legionella species, distinct from the pneumonic Legionnaires' disease.	Pontiac fever = Legionella (non-pneumonic, flu-like). Legionnaires' disease = pneumonic.					Infections respiratory
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P5, Q37: Rat-bite fever is caused by the organism:	Spirillum minus	A gram-positive cocci	Yersinia multocida	Treponema pertenue		A	Spirillum minus	Rat-bite fever can be caused by Spirillum minus (Sodoku) or Streptobacillus moniliformis (Haverhill fever).	Rat-bite fever: Spirillum minus (Sodoku) or Streptobacillus moniliformis (Haverhill fever).					Infections Zoonotic
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P5, Q38: Tuberculous focus in brain is known as:	Rich’s focus	Wigard’s focus	Ashman’s focus	Simmon’s focus		A	Rich’s focus	Rich focus is a caseous tubercle in the brain or meninges that ruptures, causing tuberculous meningitis.	Rich focus = TB focus in brain/meninges leading to TBM.					Tuberculosis
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P5, Q39: The other name for Oroya fever is:	Uveoparotid fever	Rocky Mountain spotted fever	Q fever	Bartonellosis		D	Bartonellosis	Oroya fever is the acute, febrile hemolytic anemia phase of Bartonellosis, caused by Bartonella bacilliformis, transmitted by sandflies.	Oroya fever = Acute Bartonellosis (B. bacilliformis). Carrion's disease includes Oroya fever and Verruga peruana.					Infections Zoonotic

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P5, Q41: Which of the neurological complications of diphtheria is last to appear? Peripheral neuropathy appears later (3-7 weeks).	Diphtheria neuropathy: Palatal palsy (early), peripheral neuropathy (late, 3-7 weeks).					Infections Neurological

Botulism: Anticholinergic symptoms (dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation), descending paralysis.					Infections Neurological

Cryptococcus neoformans = Encapsulated yeast fungus, causes meningitis in immunocompromised.					Fungal Infections
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P6, Q44: Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction may be seen in all except:	Syphilis after penicillin therapy	Relapsing fever after receiving antimicrobials	Enteric fever after ceftriaxone therapy	Leprosy after dapsone therapy		C	Enteric fever after ceftriaxone therapy	The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an acute febrile reaction following antibiotic treatment for spirochetal infections (syphilis, relapsing fever, Lyme disease) and sometimes in leprosy. It is not associated with enteric fever treatment.	Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction: Spirochetal infections (Syphilis, Relapsing fever) after antibiotics.					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P6, Q45: Which of the following is not seen in secondary syphilis? Secondary syphilis presents with condylomata lata (broad, flat plaques), snail-track ulcers, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular rash.	Secondary syphilis: Condylomata lata (not acuminata), maculopapular rash (incl. palms/soles), lymphadenopathy.					Infections Sexually Transmitted
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P6, Q46: All are stigma of congenital syphilis except:	Mulberry molars	Charcot joints	Sabre tibia	Interstitial keratitis		B	Charcot joints	Charcot joints are a complication of tertiary syphilis (tubes dorsalis), not congenital syphilis. Stigmata of congenital syphilis include Hutchinson's triad (interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson's incisors, VIII nerve deafness), mulberry molars, sabre tibia, and rhagades.	Congenital syphilis stigmata: Hutchinson's triad, Mulberry molars, Sabre tibia, Rhagades. Charcot joint = tertiary syphilis.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Leukocytosis is common, not leukopenia.	Weil's disease (Leptospirosis): Jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, conjunctival suffusion, leukocytosis.					Infections Zoonotic

Thalidomide uses: ENL, multiple myeloma. Teratogenic.					Leprosy
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P6, Q49: Cyclical periods of pyrexia alternating with apyrexia is found in all except:	Relapsing fever	Leprosy	Hodgkin’s disease	Brucellosis		B	Leprosy	Relapsing fever, Hodgkin's disease (Pel-Ebstein fever), and brucellosis (undulant fever) can have cyclical fevers. Leprosy does not typically cause cyclical fever.	Cyclical fevers: Relapsing fever (Borrelia), Brucellosis (undulant), Hodgkin's (Pel-Ebstein), Malaria.					fever

Secondary syphilis rash: Non-pruritic, symmetrical, involves palms/soles, coppery-red.					Infections Sexually Transmitted
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P6, Q51: Which is the most sensitive test for syphilis? Non-treponemal tests (RPR, VDRL) are used for screening and quantitative follow-up.	Syphilis: FTA-ABS = highly sensitive treponemal test. RPR/VDRL = non-treponemal screening tests.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Q fever endocarditis: Most common valve = Aortic.					Cardiac Infections

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P8, Q61: Which of the following is an RNA virus?	Papovavirus	Herpesvirus	Coronavirus	Adenovirus		C	Coronavirus	Coronaviruses are positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses. Papovavirus (DNA), Herpesvirus (DNA), and Adenovirus (DNA) are all DNA viruses.	RNA viruses: Corona, Influenza, Paramyxo, Picorna, Retro, Flavi, Toga, Rhabdo.					Virology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P8, Q62: Q fever is transmitted to human by:	Flea	Body louse	Ticks	Mites		C	Ticks	Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) is primarily transmitted by inhalation of aerosols from infected animals/placentas. Ticks can transmit among animals but are not the primary route for humans.	Q fever transmission: Inhalation of aerosols from infected animals. Ticks maintain animal reservoir.					Infections Rickettsial
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P8, Q63: Which of the following is not associated with measles?	Transient loss of PPD (purified protein derivative)	Remission of Hodgkin’s disease	Warthin-Finkeldey cells in hyperplastic lymphoid tissue	Lighter maculopapular lesions than rubella		D	Lighter maculopapular lesions than rubella	Measles rash is a prominent, confluent maculopapular rash, darker and more extensive than the finer, fainter rash of rubella. Measles causes transient anergy (loss of PPD reactivity), Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells, and temporary remission of Hodgkin's lymphoma.	Measles: Koplik's spots, confluent maculopapular rash, Warthin-Finkeldey cells, transient immunosuppression.					Infections Viral

Faget's sign (relative bradycardia): Yellow fever, Typhoid, Legionella, Psittacosis.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P8, Q65: Cat-scratch disease is characterised by all except:	Regional lymphadenopathy	Erythema nodosum	Positive Hanger-Rose intradermal test	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroid		D	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroid	Cat-scratch disease (Bartonella henselae) causes regional lymphadenopathy. Erythema nodosum can occur. The Hanger-Rose skin test is historical. Treatment is supportive; antibiotics (azithromycin) may help in severe cases; corticosteroids are not standard.	Cat-scratch disease: Bartonella henselae, regional lymphadenopathy, suppurative nodes. Treatment: Supportive, azithromycin in severe cases.					Infections Zoonotic

Genital herpes is more commonly caused by HSV-2, though HSV-1 incidence is increasing.	HSV-1: Orolabial, gingivostomatitis, keratitis, encephalitis, whitlow. HSV-2: Genital (classically). Mumps complications: Parotitis, orchitis, pancreatitis, presternal edema.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q70: Which is false in glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis)?	Splenomegaly	Ampicillin-induced skin rash	Positive monospot test	Acyclovir helps cure		D	Acyclovir helps cure	Infectious mononucleosis (EBV) features splenomegaly, ampicillin/amoxicillin-induced rash, and positive heterophile antibody test (Monospot). Acyclovir has no significant clinical benefit in uncomplicated cases.	Infectious Mono (EBV): Splenomegaly, ampicillin rash, heterophile antibodies (Monospot). Acyclovir not useful.
