ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q72: Congenital rubella is not associated with:	Corneal clouding	Cardiac malformations	Mental retardation	Macrocephaly		D	Macrocephaly	Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) includes cataracts (not corneal clouding), cardiac defects (PDA, pulmonary stenosis), sensorineural deafness, and microcephaly with mental retardation. Macrocephaly is not a feature.	Congenital Rubella: Cataracts, Heart defects (PDA), Deafness, Microcephaly, Mental retardation.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q73: Cerebral malaria is:	Treated by oral quinine sulphate	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Associated with signs of meningeal irritation	IV dexamethasone reduces mortality rate		B	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Cerebral malaria, caused by P. falciparum, is a medical emergency with high mortality, often complicated by multi-organ failure (renal, hepatic, pulmonary). Parenteral artesunate is first-line; steroids are not beneficial.	Cerebral malaria (P. falciparum): Coma, seizures, multi-organ failure. Treatment: IV Artesunate.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q74: Regarding primary amoebic meningoencephalitis, which is false?	Almost invariably fatal	Caused by Naegleria fouleri	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Acquired by swimming in fresh warm water		C	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) from Naegleria fowleri is fatal. Amphotericin B is the drug of choice, not dehydroemetine. Infection occurs via nasal inoculation from warm fresh water.	PAM (Naegleria fowleri): Fatal, fresh warm water, amphotericin B treatment.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q75: ‘River blindness’ is due to:	Toxoplasmosis	Onchocerciasis	Trichinosis	Cysticerosis		B	Onchocerciasis	River blindness is caused by Onchocerca volvulus, transmitted by black flies (Simulium).	River blindness = Onchocerciasis (Onchocerca volvulus).					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P9, Q76: Haemorrhagic fever may be produced by all except:	Chikungunya	Yellow fever	Dengue	Colorado tick fever		D	Colorado tick fever	Colorado tick fever is a viral illness causing fever, myalgia, and leukopenia, but hemorrhagic manifestations are rare. Chikungunya, Yellow Fever, and Dengue can all cause hemorrhagic fever.	Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers: Dengue, Yellow Fever, Lassa, Ebola, Marburg, CCHF. Colorado tick fever = not typically hemorrhagic.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q77: Which of the following is false in tropical splenomegaly syndrome:	Very high level of serum IgG	Sinusoidal lymphocytosis on liver biopsy	High malarial antibody titre	Associated with massive splenomegaly		A	Very high level of serum IgG	Tropical Splenomegaly Syndrome (Hyperreactive Malarial Splenomegaly) is characterized by massive splenomegaly, high serum IgM (not IgG), sinusoidal lymphocytosis on liver biopsy, and high malarial antibody titers.	Tropical Splenomegaly Syndrome: Massive spleen, high IgM, sinusoidal lymphocytosis, malarial antibodies.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q78: Drug of choice in Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia is:	Pentamidine isethionate	Zidovudine	Cefoperazone	Aztreonam		A	Pentamidine isethionate	First-line treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii (carinii) pneumonia (PCP) is Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). Pentamidine is an alternative for sulfa-allergic patients.	PCP treatment: First-line = TMP-SMX. Alternative = Pentamidine, Dapsone-TMP, Atovaquone.					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q79: Which of the following is not a recognised complication of infectious mononucleosis?	Guillain-Barré syndrome	Meningoencephalitis	Myoclonus	Transverse myelitis		C	Myoclonus	Complications of Infectious Mononucleosis (EBV) include splenic rupture, airway obstruction, Guillain-Barré syndrome, meningitis, encephalitis, and transverse myelitis. Myoclonus is not a typical complication.	EBV complications: Splenic rupture, GBS, meningitis, encephalitis, hemolytic anemia, agranulocytosis.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q80: In hepatic amoebiasis:	Left lobe is commonly affected	Liver function tests (LFT) are of diagnostic value	Jaundice is uncommon	Serological tests are not helpful in diagnosis		C	Jaundice is uncommon	In amoebic liver abscess, the right lobe is more commonly affected. LFTs are often normal or mildly elevated. Jaundice is uncommon. Serology (e.g., IHA) is very sensitive (>94%) and helpful.	Amoebic liver abscess: Right lobe, 'anchovy paste' pus, serology positive, jaundice uncommon.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q81: Rectal biopsy is diagnostic in all of the following except:	Amoebiasis	Strongyloidosis	Amyloidosis	Schistosomiasis		B	Strongyloidosis	Rectal biopsy can diagnose Amoebiasis (trophozoites), Schistosomiasis (ova), and Amyloidosis (Congo red). Strongyloidosis is best diagnosed by duodenal/jejunal biopsy or stool larvae detection.	Rectal biopsy diagnostic for: Schistosomiasis, Amyloidosis, Amoebiasis, Inflammatory bowel disease.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q82: Which is false in acute acquired toxoplasmosis?	Absence of cerebral calcification	Severe than congenital form	Lymphadenopathy is the most common clinical manifestation	Ocular manifestation is very rare		D	Ocular manifestation is very rare	In acute acquired toxoplasmosis, ocular manifestations (retinochoroiditis) can occur, though they are more classically associated with congenital toxoplasmosis. Lymphadenopathy (often cervical) is the most common sign. Cerebral calcification is a feature of congenital toxoplasmosis.	Acquired Toxoplasmosis: Lymphadenopathy (common), flu-like illness. Ocular toxoplasmosis can occur.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P10, Q83: Herpes labialis is classically seen in:	Enteric fever	Lobar pneumonia	Kala-azar	Pulmonary tuberculosis		B	Lobar pneumonia	Herpes labialis (cold sores) can be triggered by various stressors, including other infections. It is classically associated with pneumococcal lobar pneumonia.	Herpes labialis triggers: Fever, sunlight, stress, pneumococcal pneumonia.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q84: Koplik’s spot is diagnostic of:	Mumps	Enteric fever	Measles	Diphtheria		C	Measles	Koplik's spots are pathognomonic for measles (rubeola), appearing before the rash on the buccal mucosa.	Koplik's spots = Measles (Rubeola).					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q85: Which is not a cause of aseptic fever?	SLE	Crush injury	AIDS	Pontine haemorrhage		C	AIDS	Aseptic fever refers to fever without infection. Causes include autoimmune (SLE), tissue injury (crush, MI), CNS lesions (pontine hemorrhage), and drugs. AIDS itself does not cause fever; opportunistic infections in AIDS do.	Aseptic fever causes: Autoimmune, tissue necrosis, CNS lesions, drugs, malignancy.					fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q86: Romana’s sign is classically found in infection by:	Schistosoma mansoni	Trypanosoma cruzi	Pneumocystis carinii	Toxoplasma gondii		B	Trypanosoma cruzi	Romana's sign (unilateral painless periorbital edema) is a classic finding in acute Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi) from conjunctival inoculation.	Romana's sign = Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi).					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q87: Which of the following is not a feature of familial Mediterranean fever?	Autosomal dominant disorder	Abdominal pain occurs in majority	Amyloidosis is a recognised complication	Colchicine is the drug of choice for treatment		A	Autosomal dominant disorder	Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) is an autosomal recessive disorder, not dominant. It features recurrent febrile episodes with serositis (abdominal pain), and amyloidosis is a complication. Colchicine prevents attacks.	FMF: Autosomal recessive, recurrent fever & serositis, amyloidosis risk, colchicine treatment.					Rheumatology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q88: Leonine-like face is seen in all except:	Amyloidosis	Carcinoid syndrome	Dermatomyositis	Lepromatous leprosy		C	Dermatomyositis	Leonine facies (thickened, furrowed skin) is seen in Lepromatous Leprosy and occasionally in advanced Amyloidosis or Carcinoid syndrome. It is not a feature of Dermatomyositis.	Leonine facies: Lepromatous leprosy, Amyloidosis, Carcinoid syndrome.					Dermatology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q89: Which of the following is false in hydatid disease of liver?	Caused by larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus	Diagnostic aspiration may produce anaphylaxis	Casoni’s test is positive in all	Albendazole therapy is most efficacious		C	Casoni’s test is positive in all	Casoni's skin test for hydatid disease has low sensitivity and specificity and is no longer used. Aspiration risks anaphylaxis and spillage. Albendazole is the primary medical treatment.	Hydatid disease: E. granulosus, liver/lung cysts. Casoni test unreliable. Treatment: Albendazole, PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration).					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q90: Acute kala-azar is diagnosed by all of the following except:	Complement fixation test	Counterimmunoelectrophoresis	Bone marrow aspiration for LD bodies	Aldehyde test		D	Aldehyde test	Kala-azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis) is diagnosed by demonstration of LD (Leishman-Donovan) bodies in aspirates (bone marrow, spleen). Serological tests (IFA, ELISA) are also used. The Aldehyde test (Napier's) is a non-specific test for elevated globulins, not diagnostic.	Kala-azar diagnosis: Splenic/Bone marrow aspirate (LD bodies), serology. Aldehyde test = non-specific.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P11, Q91: Cysticercosis is the larval stage of:	Taenia solium	Hymenolepiasis nana	Taenia saginata	Ancylostoma duodenale		A	Taenia solium	Cysticercosis is caused by the larval form (Cysticercus cellulosae) of Taenia solium. Ingestion of T. solium eggs (fecal-oral) leads to cysticercosis, while undercooked pork leads to intestinal tapeworm.	Cysticercosis = Larval T. solium. Neurocysticercosis = common cause of seizures in endemic areas.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P12, Q92: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia?	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitarism	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is characterized by hyperthermia, not hypothermia. Hypothermia can occur in pituitary insufficiency, shock, and myxedema coma.	Hypothermia causes: Hypothyroidism, hypopituitarism, shock, sepsis, drugs. NMS = Hyperthermia.					Endocrinology

Tuberculosis is not a common cause.	False-positive RPR/VDRL: Leprosy, Mono, Malaria, SLE, Pregnancy, IV drug use.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P12, Q97: Tularaemia may produce all the following manifestations except:	Conjunctivitis	Mental confusions	Painful lymphadenopathy	Circulatory failure		D	Circulatory failure	Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) can cause ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, pneumonic, and typhoidal forms. It does not typically cause circulatory failure.	Tularemia: Ulceroglandular form common. Can cause conjunctivitis, pneumonia, lymphadenopathy.					Infections Zoonotic

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P12, Q99: Diphtheria may be associated with all except:	Toxic neuritis	Myocarditis	Meningitis	Bull-neck		C	Meningitis	Diphtheria complications include myocarditis, toxic neuritis (palatal palsy, peripheral neuropathy), and 'bull-neck' from severe cervical lymphadenopathy. Meningitis is not a typical complication.	Diphtheria complications: Myocarditis, neuritis (palatal palsy, peripheral neuropathy), airway obstruction.					Bacterial Infections

Rose spots = Enteric fever (Salmonella Typhi/Paratyphi).					Enteric fever
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P13, Q101: Severe cases of lassa fever may be associated with all except:	Respiratory failure	Renal failure	Circulatory failure	Hepatic failure		A	Respiratory failure	Lassa fever, an arenavirus, causes hemorrhagic fever with multi-organ failure including renal failure, circulatory shock, and hepatic involvement. Respiratory failure is not a primary feature.	Lassa fever: Hemorrhagic fever, multi-organ failure, sensorineural hearing loss is a common sequela.					Infections Viral

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P13, Q103: Which secondary neoplasm is not related to AIDS:	Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma	Primary lymphoma of brain	Carcinoma of the cervix	Kaposi’s sarcoma		C	Carcinoma of the cervix	AIDS-defining malignancies are Kaposi's Sarcoma (HHV-8), Primary CNS Lymphoma (EBV), and Invasive Cervical Carcinoma (HPV). The question asks for NOT related, so Cervical Ca is related. Wait, re-read: 'Which secondary neoplasm is not related to AIDS'. All listed are AIDS-related. Perhaps they mean Carcinoma of cervix is not as strongly associated virologically as the others? Standard list includes Cervical Ca. This might be a trick. KS, NHL, and Cervical Ca are AIDS-defining. Primary Brain Lymphoma is a type of NHL. So all are related. The provided answer is C, suggesting they don't consider Cervical Ca related, which is incorrect per current guidelines.	AIDS-defining malignancies: Kaposi's sarcoma, Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Primary CNS lymphoma, Invasive cervical cancer.					Oncology

It can occur on the cervix and vaginal wall, but intraurethral chancres are very rare.	Syphilis chancre: Genital, anal, oral. Intraurethral is rare.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Cryptococcus: Primary infection in lungs → can disseminate to CNS (meningitis).					Fungal Infections

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P14, Q111: Which of the following is not a cysticidal drug in amoebiasis?	Tetracycline	Diloxanide furoate	Chloroquine	Paromomycin		A	Tetracycline	Cysticidal drugs eliminate the cyst form of Entamoeba histolytica. These include Diloxanide furoate, Paromomycin, and Nitazoxanide. Tetracycline is not cysticidal. Chloroquine is used for hepatic amoebiasis (tissue trophozoites), not primarily cysticidal.	Amoebiasis: Luminal agents (cysticidal) = Diloxanide furoate, Paromomycin. Tissue amoebicides = Metronidazole, Tinidazole, Chloroquine (liver).					Parasitology

HTLV-2 has weaker associations, but some studies link it to Hairy Cell Leukemia and other rare neurological disorders.	HTLV-1: ATLL, TSP. HTLV-2: Hairy Cell Leukemia (association weaker). ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P14, Q113: Non-specific urethritis is associated with all except:	Chlamydia trachomatis	Trichomonas vaginalis	Herpes simplex	Urcaplasma urealyticum		B	Trichomonas vaginalis	Non-specific urethritis (NGU) is primarily caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Mycoplasma genitalium, and occasionally HSV. Trichomonas vaginalis causes a specific urethritis and is not classified under 'non-specific'.	Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU): Chlamydia trachomatis (most common), Ureaplasma, Mycoplasma genitalium. Trichomonas = specific cause.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Currently, due to resistance, first-line treatment is Ceftriaxone IM plus Azithromycin orally.	Gonorrhea treatment (current): Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Causes include Diabetes Mellitus, Tabes Dorsalis (tertiary syphilis), Syringomyelia, and Leprosy. Reiter's syndrome (Reactive Arthritis) does not cause Charcot joint. Now, with ART, Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma is also very common, but KS is still the classic answer.	AIDS malignancies: Kaposi's sarcoma (HHV-8), Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (EBV), Cervical Cancer (HPV). ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P14, Q117: Skin lesions in secondary syphilis may take any of the following forms except:	Vesicular	Maculopapular	Follicular	Psorasiform		A	Vesicular	Secondary syphilis rash is polymorphic: maculopapular (most common), papular, follicular, pustular, and psoriasiform. Vesicular lesions are NOT a feature; this helps distinguish it from varicella-zoster.	Secondary syphilis rash: Polymorphic, non-vesicular, involves palms/soles.					Infections Sexually Transmitted

Peripheral neuropathy is not typical.	Measles CNS complications: Encephalitis (1:1000), SSPE (rare, late).					Infections Viral

Urethro-enteric fistula is not a recognized complication.	Gonorrhea complications: DGI (arthritis, tenosynovitis, dermatitis, endocarditis), PID, epididymo-orchitis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis. ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q120: Which of the following drug is not used in Pneumocystis carinii infection?	Dapsone	Pentamidine	Corticosteroid	Co-trimoxazole		C	Corticosteroid	Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are used as adjunctive therapy for moderate-severe PCP (to reduce inflammation) but are not anti-pneumocystis drugs themselves. TMP-SMX, Pentamidine, Dapsone-TMP, and Atovaquone are anti-pneumocystis agents.	PCP treatment: Anti-pneumocystis = TMP-SMX, Pentamidine, Dapsone-TMP, Atovaquone. Adjunctive steroids for PaO2 <70 mmHg.					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q121: As a complication, lymphogranuloma venereum does not produce:	Perirectal abscess	Rectal stricture	Septicaemia	Extensive scarring		C	Septicaemia	LGV (Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3) causes genital ulcers, painful lymphadenopathy (buboes), which can suppurate, leading to perirectal abscesses, fistulas, strictures, and extensive scarring. It does not typically cause septicemia.	LGV complications: Genital elephantiasis, strictures, fistulas, rectal strictures (in proctocolitis).					Infections Sexually Transmitted
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q122: Drug of choice in cysticercosis is:	Suramin	Albendazole	Metrifonate	Niclosamide		B	Albendazole	Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Praziquantel is an alternative. Niclosamide is for intestinal tapeworms.	Neurocysticercosis treatment: Albendazole (preferred) or Praziquantel. Steroids for inflammation.					Parasitology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q123: The fourth-generation cephalosporin is:	Cefepime	Ceftibuten	Cefuroxime axetil	Cefamandole		A	Cefepime	Fourth-generation cephalosporins include Cefepime and Cefpirome. They have extended gram-negative coverage and better gram-positive coverage than 3rd gen, and stability against some beta-lactamases.	4th Gen Cephalosporins: Cefepime, Cefpirome. Good Gram +ve & Gram -ve coverage, anti-pseudomonal (Cefepime).					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q124: Terbinafine is an:	Antiprotozoal agent	Antiviral agent	Antibacterial agent	Antifungal agent		D	Antifungal agent	Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal, used primarily for dermatophyte infections (onychomycosis).	Terbinafine: Allylamine antifungal, fungicidal, for dermatophytes (nail, skin).					Antimicrobials
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q125: Thalidomide may be used in all except:	HIV-associated aphthous ulcers	Beheet’s disease	Reactive arthritis	Pyoderma gangrenosum		C	Reactive arthritis	Thalidomide is used for ENL, multiple myeloma, Behçet's disease, HIV-associated aphthous ulcers, and pyoderma gangrenosum. It is not used for Reactive Arthritis.	Thalidomide uses: ENL, MM, Behçet's, aphthous ulcers (HIV), pyoderma gangrenosum. Teratogenic.					Pharmacology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q126: In an immunocompromised patient, cytomegalovirus commonly produces:	Encephalitis	Hepatitis	Myelitis	Retinitis		D	Retinitis	In immunocompromised hosts (especially AIDS with CD4 <50), CMV commonly causes retinitis, colitis, and esophagitis. Encephalitis and myelitis are less common.	CMV in immunocompromised: Retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis.					Infections Viral
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q127: Drug-induced cataract may develop from all except:	Ethambutol	Busulphan	Phenothiazines	Corticosteroids		A	Ethambutol	Cataracts can be induced by corticosteroids, busulfan, and phenothiazines. Ethambutol's main toxicity is optic neuritis (red-green color blindness), not cataracts.	Drug toxicities: Cataracts (Steroids, Busulfan, Phenothiazines). Optic neuritis (Ethambutol).					Pharmacology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P15, Q128: In syphilis, the response to treatment is best monitored by:	TPI	FTA-ABS	TPHA	VDRL		D	VDRL	Non-treponemal tests (VDRL, RPR) are quantitative and are used to monitor treatment response. Titers should decline (e.g., 4-fold decrease) after successful therapy. Treponemal tests (FTA-ABS, TPHA) usually remain positive for life and are not used for monitoring.	Syphilis follow-up: Quantitative RPR/VDRL to monitor treatment.					Infections Sexually Transmitted
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P16, Q129: AIDS-chorioretinitis is commonly due to infection by:	Toxoplasma gondii	Cytomegalovirus	Candida albicans	Cryptococcus neoformans		B	Cytomegalovirus	CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts (<50).	AIDS retinitis: CMV most common. Toxoplasma can cause retinochoroiditis.					Ophthalmology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P16, Q130: Fluoroquinolones resistance in enteric fever is due to:	Plasmid-mediated	Interference with antibiotic transport into the cells	Chromosomally-mediated	Not defi nitly known		C	Chromosomally-mediated	Fluoroquinolone resistance in Salmonella Typhi is primarily due to chromosomal mutations in the quinolone resistance-determining region (QRDR) of DNA gyrase (gyrA) and topoisomerase IV (parC). Acute HIV seroconversion can mimic Infectious Mononucleosis.					Virology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P16, Q132: ‘Rigor’ is not characteristic of:	Acute pyelonephritis	Acute cholangitis	Acute rheumatic carditis	Acute thrombophlebitis		C	Acute rheumatic carditis	Rigor is a pronounced chill often associated with bacteremia/sepsis, seen in pyelonephritis and cholangitis. ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P16, Q133: Characteristics of brucellosis are all except:	Marked sweating	Leucopenia	Spondylitis	Mental depression		B	Leucopenia	Brucellosis is characterized by undulant fever, profuse sweating, arthralgia/arthritis (spondylitis - classic in lumbar spine), and neuropsychiatric symptoms (depression). Leukopenia with relative lymphocytosis is common, so this statement is false.	Brucellosis: Undulant fever, sweating, arthralgia, spondylitis, leukopenia with lymphocytosis.					Infections Zoonotic

ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P19, Q157: Which of the following antibiotic is safe in pregnancy?	Ampicillin	Sulphonamides	Streptomycin	Tetracycline		A	Ampicillin	Penicillins (including ampicillin) and cephalosporins are generally considered safe in pregnancy. Sulfonamides (kernicterus risk near term), aminoglycosides (streptomycin - ototoxicity), and tetracyclines (teeth discoloration) should be avoided.	Antibiotics in pregnancy: Safe = Penicillins, Cephalosporins. Avoid = Tetracyclines, Aminoglycosides, Quinolones, Sulfonamides (late).					Pharmacology
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P19, Q158: In a mass population, tuberculosis can be detected by:	Tuberculin test	Sputum AFB	Sputum culture	Mass miniature radiography (MMR)		B	Sputum AFB	For active case finding in a mass population, sputum smear microscopy for Acid-Fast Bacilli (AFB) is a rapid, specific, and cost-effective method. Tuberculin test detects infection, not disease. Culture is gold standard but slow. MMR is less specific.	TB diagnosis: Sputum AFB smear for rapid detection in public health. Culture = gold standard.					Tuberculosis
ريحانة الطبMCQ_Kumar	P19, Q159: HIV is a:	Oncovirus	Retrovirus	Arbovirus	Flavivirus		B	Retrovirus	HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus (family Retroviridae). It contains RNA and uses reverse transcriptase to make DNA.	HIV = Retrovirus (Lentivirus subgroup).					Virology
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q1: During premarital care, the following vaccine/s could be given:	Hepatitis B	Tetanus toxoid	Rubella	all of the above	A & B	D	all of the above	Premarital Care Vaccines typically aim to protect the mother and future child. Hepatitis B, Tetanus Toxoid (to prevent Neonatal Tetanus), and Rubella (to prevent Congenital Rubella Syndrome, with caution regarding pregnancy avoidance for Rubella) are all common recommendations in premarital or preconception care.	Premarital Vaccines: Hepatitis B, Tetanus Toxoid, and Rubella (live vaccine, must avoid pregnancy for a specified period, usually 1-3 months).	Vaccination/EPI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q2: One of the following vaccines is not given to symptomatic HIV children:	HAV	HBV	OPV	DPT	Non of the above	C	OPV	Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated in symptomatic or severely immunosuppressed HIV patients (due to the risk of vaccine-strain infection/disease). The other listed vaccines (HAV, HBV, DPT) are either inactivated/subunit vaccines or toxoids, which are generally safe in HIV patients.	Live Vaccines in HIV: Contraindicated in severely immunosuppressed/symptomatic HIV patients. Examples of live vaccines: OPV, MMR, Varicella.	Vaccination/HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q3: HIV is a:	DNA Pox virus.	RNA Ribovirus.	Single strand RNA Retrovirus.	40 nanometer diameter.	Double strand RNA virus	C	Single strand RNA Retrovirus.	Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a member of the Retroviridae family. Its genetic material is composed of two identical copies of single-stranded RNA (ssRNA), which is reverse-transcribed into DNA upon infection, a hallmark of retroviruses.	HIV Type: Single-stranded RNA Retrovirus.	HIV/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q4: Tetanus toxoid is better given to the pregnant mother in:	In the first trimester	One day before delivery	From 4 to 8 months of pregnancy	Just after delivery		C	From 4 to 8 months of pregnancy	Maternal Tetanus Toxoid (TT) is given to ensure sufficient antibody transfer to the fetus to prevent Neonatal Tetanus. Antibodies cross the placenta best in the second and third trimesters. The dose should be given early enough to allow for an adequate immune response before delivery, typically starting from the second trimester (around 4-8 months)11.	Maternal TT: Given in the second or third trimester (4-8 months) to maximize antibody transfer to the fetus.	Vaccination/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q5: One of the following is not a method of HIV infection:	Feco-oral route.	I.V drug users and shairing needle.	Sexual relations.	Vertical transmission of infected mothers.	Lactation.	A	Feco-oral route.	HIV is primarily transmitted through contact with infected body fluids (blood, semen, pre-seminal fluid, rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, and breast milk). Fecal-oral transmission is not a recognized route for HIV2. Intravenous drug use/sharing needles, sexual relations, mother-to-child transmission (vertical), and lactation are all established routes3.	HIV Transmission: Blood/body fluids, sexual contact, sharing needles, vertical (mother-to-child), and lactation. NOT fecal-oral.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P1, Q6: A newly married female has decided to receive (MMR) vaccine, the doctor advised her to post-pone pregnancy for:	Only one month.	For at least 3 months,	For one year.	Not at all.		B	For at least 3 months,	MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) is a live attenuated vaccine. As a precaution, non-pregnant women receiving the MMR vaccine should be advised to avoid pregnancy for a specified period to minimize the theoretical risk of congenital infection. While current recommendations often suggest 1 month, 3 months is a safe and sometimes cited recommendation4. The crucial point is avoiding pregnancy shortly after administration.	MMR (Live Vaccine): Postpone pregnancy for at least 1 to 3 months after vaccination.	Vaccination/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q7: which one of the following is wrong about AIDS:	HIV equals AIDS	CD4 count less than $200~cell/ml$	Presence of severe opportunistic infections.	kaposi sarcoma could be seen.	Severely ill cachectic patient with fever.	A	HIV equals AIDS	AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is the late stage of HIV infection, characterized by a severely compromised immune system (e.g., CD4 count $< 200~cells/ml$) and the presence of AIDS-defining opportunistic infections or cancers (like Kaposi's sarcoma)5. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS, but having HIV does not equal having AIDS6.	HIV vs. AIDS: HIV is the virus; AIDS is the late, severe stage (CD4 $< 200~cells/ml$ or AIDS-defining illness).	HIV/AIDS				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q8: Expanded program on immunization (EPI) include all of the following steps EXCEPT:	Immunization against the 7 target diseases with mcrease BCG, DPT, Sabin, HBV and Measles vaccines.	Maternal immunization with tetanus toxoid (T.T.).	Immunization of all children against influenza virus.	Reduction of measles cases by 90% and mortalities by 95%.		C	Immunization of all children against influenza virus.	The Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI), as originally established by WHO, focused on routine immunization against major childhood diseases (e.g., BCG, DPT, Sabin/OPV, Measles, and later HBV) 7, maternal Tetanus Toxoid immunization 8, and specific goals like measles reduction9. Influenza virus immunization for all children is a component of some national programs but was not part of the original core EPI steps10.	EPI Core: Targets 6-7 diseases (e.g., DPT, Polio, Measles, TB, sometimes HBV) and maternal TT. Influenza is not a core EPI component.	Vaccination/EPI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q9: Tetanus toxoid (T. T) first dose is best delayed to 20 weeks because if it is given earlier:	May cause congenital anomalies.	May cause abortion,	May cause intrauterine infection.	All of the above.	None of the above.	E	None of the above.	Delaying the Tetanus Toxoid first dose in pregnancy (usually until the start of the second trimester/20 weeks) is not due to safety concerns like congenital anomalies, abortion, or infection11. Tetanus Toxoid is an inactivated vaccine and is safe in pregnancy. The reason for delaying is to ensure optimal maternal antibody response and placental transfer to the fetus before delivery12.	TT Delay (Pregnancy): Not for safety reasons (it's safe). It's delayed to the 2nd/3rd trimester to maximize fetal antibody transfer.	Vaccination/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q10: Target population of the program (EPI):	Children from 0-1 years (Basic vaccines)	Booster doses from one year to school entry	Woman in child bearing period (tetanus toxoid)	All of the above.		D	All of the above.	The Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) targets various groups to achieve its goals13. This includes: Infants (0-1 year) for primary/basic vaccines 14, Older children for booster doses 15, and Women of child-bearing age for Tetanus Toxoid to prevent neonatal tetanus16.	EPI Target Groups: Infants (basic), older children (boosters), and Women of Child-Bearing Age (TT).	Vaccination/EPI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q11: The general objectives of the program are the following except:	To reduce morbidity from the covered diseases	To minimize effort and cost of treatment.	To promote a new healthy generation	To promote geriatric generation.		D	To promote geriatric generation.	The Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) is fundamentally focused on preventing childhood diseases to reduce morbidity and mortality 17, promote healthy new generations 18, and minimize the costs/efforts associated with treating these diseases19. Promoting the geriatric generation is not a primary objective of the childhood immunization program (EPI)20.	EPI Objectives: Focus on reducing childhood morbidity/mortality and promoting healthy young generations. Not geriatric care.	Vaccination/EPI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q12: the WHO established a standardized vaccination schedule for the original EPI which included the following vaccines except:	Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG),	Rota virus vaccine	Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTP),	Oral polio, and Measles.		B	Rota virus vaccine	The original WHO EPI schedule included 6 core vaccines: BCG (Tuberculosis), DTP (Diphtheria-Tetanus-Pertussis), Oral Polio, and Measles21212121. The Rotavirus vaccine was introduced much later and is an addition to the expanded program, but not part of the original standard set22.	Original EPI Vaccines (6): BCG, DTP, Oral Polio, and Measles. Not Rotavirus.	Vaccination/EPI				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P2, Q13: absolute contraindications to vaccination:	Severe illness that needs hospitalization.	Recent receipt of blood	HIV infection is an absolute contraindication to administration of live attenuated vaccines.	Pregnancy		C	HIV infection is an absolute contraindication to administration of live attenuated vaccines.	The most stringent contraindication listed is the administration of live attenuated vaccines (LAVs) to an individual with a severely compromised immune system, such as a symptomatic or severely immunosuppressed patient with HIV infection23. Severe illness (A) 24, recent blood product receipt (B) 25, and pregnancy (D) are typically temporary contraindications or precautions, but generally not absolute contraindications to all vaccines.	Absolute Contraindication: Live vaccines (LAVs) in severely immunosuppressed patients (e.g., symptomatic HIV)26.	Vaccination				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q14: Toxoplasmosis is infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The only known hosts of this organism are domestic cats and their relatives. Infection with T. gondii in humans can occur in various ways. Which of the following is the most common mode of infection in humans?	Blood transfusion	Ingestion of oocysts	Ingestion of tissue cysts	Transplacental transmission		B	Ingestion of oocysts	ملف محمد علاء مختار B والذكاء ... مختار C  Infection with Toxoplasma gondii in humans most commonly occurs through the ingestion of tissue cysts27. This usually happens when humans consume undercooked or raw meat (especially pork, lamb, or venison) that contains these cysts28. While oocysts (from cat feces) are infectious 29, and transplacental and blood transmission can occur, consuming encysted meat is the most common route30.	Toxoplasmosis (Most Common Route): Ingestion of tissue cysts from undercooked meat.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q15: Infection with T. gondii can manifest in many different ways. Which of the following types of toxoplasmosis results from congenital infection that is reactivated in a patient's late teens or 20s?	Acute	Disseminated	CNS	Ocular		D	Ocular	Ocular toxoplasmosis is the most common manifestation resulting from the reactivation of a previously acquired congenital infection31. While the primary infection occurred prenatally, the disease may only become apparent or reactivate later in life, often in the late teens or twenties, leading to chorioretinitis 32.	Congenital Toxo Reactivation: Most commonly presents as Ocular disease (chorioretinitis) later in life33.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q16: What things can you get from a restaurant that will cause you to gain this parasite?	Rotten foods	Uncooked meat	clean water	Unwashed vegetables	B&D	E	B&D	Toxoplasma gondii can be acquired by ingesting tissue cysts in uncooked/raw meat 3434or oocysts contaminating soil/produce, which can be found on unwashed vegetables3535. Both routes are plausible in a restaurant setting.	Toxoplasmosis Sources (Food): Uncooked meat (tissue cysts) and unwashed vegetables (oocysts)36363636.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q17: Toxoplasmosis is diagnosed using an indirect fluorescent antibody (IFA) test or enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for IgG or IgM antibodies. Which of the following results of serologic testing for T. gondii indicates that a patient has a possible acute infection?	IgG is equivocal; IgM is positive	IgG is positive; IgM is equivocal	IgG is positive; IgM is negative			A	IgG is equivocal; IgM is positive	The presence of IgM antibodies generally indicates a recent, or acute infection, as IgM is the first antibody class produced in response to infection37. IgG positivity indicates past or chronic infection38. A positive IgM with equivocal or negative IgG is highly suggestive of a possible acute infection 39.	Acute Toxoplasmosis Serology: Positive IgM (recent infection) with equivocal/negative IgG (early stage)40.	Toxoplasmosis/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q18: If prenatal diagnosis reveals infection in the fetus, the pregnant patient should receive ?	Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine	folinic acid	Spiramycin	A&B		D	A&B	If fetal infection with Toxoplasma gondii is confirmed:    Sulfadiazine + Pyrimethamine = the standard treatment to reduce fetal complications.    Folinic acid is given to prevent bone marrow toxicity from pyrimethamine.      Spiramycin is used only if infection is suspected in the mother but not confirmed in the fetus.	"Confirmed Fetal Toxoplasmosis: Treat with sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine + folinic acid. Maternal Primary Infection (no known fetal transmission): Use spiramycin."",""Infectious Disease/Obstetrics"""					
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q19: The most affected WBC of the immune system with HIV infection is :	CD8 T-lymphocyte	CD4 T-lymphocyte.	Plasma cell	Macrophage.	CD3 T-lymphocyte	B	CD4 T-lymphocyte.	The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has a strong tropism for cells expressing the CD4 receptor. The most significantly affected and destroyed immune cell is the CD4+ T-lymphocyte (Helper T-cell)43. This progressive depletion is the defining feature of immune failure in AIDS.	HIV Target Cell: CD4+ T-lymphocyte.	HIV/Pathogenesis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P3, Q20: Laboratory methods of HIV diagnosis includes all except:	Rapid detection test.	ELISA 3rd generation.	ELISA 4th generation.	Quantiferon gold test.	HIV RNA PCR.	D	Quantiferon gold test.	Methods used for HIV diagnosis and monitoring include Rapid tests 44, ELISA (3rd and 4th generation, detecting antibody and/or antigen) 45, and PCR (detecting HIV RNA, used for confirmation/viral load)46. The QuantiFERON-TB Gold test is a blood test used to diagnose tuberculosis (TB) infection, not HIV47.	HIV Diagnosis: Rapid test, ELISA (Ab/Ag), PCR (RNA). NOT QuantiFERON (used for TB).	HIV/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q1: Risk factors for meningitis include all of the followings except	HIV infection.	Military recruits	Chronic liver disease	College dorm residents		C	Chronic liver disease	Risk factors for Meningitis include conditions or settings that compromise immunity or facilitate transmission. HIV infection is a major risk factor48. Close-quarter living like military recruits 49and college dorms 50 increases the risk of transmissible meningitis (e.g., Neisseria meningitidis). Chronic liver disease is generally a risk factor for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and other systemic infections, but it is not typically listed as a primary, specific risk factor for meningitis transmission or susceptibility in the same way as the others51.	Meningitis Risk Factors: Immunosuppression (HIV) and close-quarter living (military, dorms). NOT chronic liver disease (as a primary, specific risk).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q2: The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, except	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead-end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection	Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease52, meaning it is transmitted from animals to humans. Humans are accidental/dead-end hosts 53 (meaning the infection does not typically spread further from an infected person). The main reservoirs are rodents and other mammals (which excrete the bacteria in urine). Lice are associated with diseases like louse-borne relapsing fever or typhus, but they do not act as reservoirs for Leptospira54.	Leptospirosis: Zoonosis. Man is an accidental/dead-end host. Reservoirs: Rodents/mammals. NOT Lice.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q3: How is leptospirosis transmitted?	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	By mosquito bites	By contact with the infected person			A	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	Leptospirosis is caused by the bacterium Leptospira. It is transmitted to humans through contact with the urine of infected animals (often via water or soil contaminated with that urine)55. The bacteria enter the body through cuts/abrasions in the skin or via mucous membranes (eyes, nose, mouth)56. It is not typically spread by mosquitoes 57or direct person-to-person contact 58.	Leptospirosis Transmission: Contact of abraded skin/mucous membranes with contaminated water/soil (animal urine)59.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q4: Besides the classic triad, what's another sign or symptom that you may find in a patient with bacterial meningitis?	Urinary frequency	Abdominal pain	Constipation	Confusion		D	Confusion	The classic triad of bacterial meningitis is fever, headache, and stiff neck60606060. However, a fourth common and important sign is altered mental status (confusion)616161, which can range from lethargy to coma.	Bacterial Meningitis Triad: Fever, Headache, Stiff Neck. Common 4th Sign: Confusion/Altered Mental Status.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q5: Which form of leptospirosis is known as Weil's disease?	Icteric	Anicteric	Both			A	Icteric	Weil's disease is the term used for the severe, icteric (jaundice-presenting) form of leptospirosis, which often involves hepatic (liver) and renal (kidney) failure, and hemorrhage62. The milder form, which accounts for about 90% of cases, is called anicteric leptospirosis636363.	Weil's Disease: The severe, Icteric (jaundice) form of leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q6: Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is:	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Generalized lymphadenopathy (GLA) is clinically defined as the enlargement of two or more non-contiguous (not next to each other) lymph node groups64. For example, enlarged cervical (neck) nodes and enlarged inguinal (groin) nodes, but not just cervical and supraclavicular nodes on the same side.	Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA): Enlargement of $\ge 2$ non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Infectious Diseases/HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q7: Male patient 50 years old, famer, come to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case?	Myelofibrosis	Egyptian splenomegaly	Hyperthyroidism	syphilis		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	The presentation of a farmer from a region where schistosomiasis is endemic (e.g., Egypt), with massive splenomegaly (25 cm) and complications of portal hypertension like hematemesis (from esophageal varices), strongly points to Egyptian splenomegaly65. This is typically a consequence of Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis (often caused by Schistosoma mansoni), which leads to periportal fibrosis and subsequent portal hypertension, resulting in congestive splenomegaly and varices.	Egyptian Splenomegaly (Farmer, Hematemesis, Massive Splenomegaly): Caused by Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis (portal hypertension, esophageal varices).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P4, Q8: Which of the following parasites is not a cause for aseptic meningitis?	Naegleria	Entamoeba histolytica	Strongyloides stercoralis	Taenia solium		B	Taenia solium	"E. histolytica causes amoebic abscesses, not classic meningitis."",""Infectious Disease/Parasitology"		Meningitis/Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q9: Male patient 29 years old, butcher, presented to OPC by fever, days of fever followed by days without fever, associated with profuse sweating and back pain. His CBC showed mild anemia and leukocytosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?	Typhoid fever	Malaria	Non Hodgkin Lymphoma	Brucellosis		D	Brucellosis	The classic presentation of a person with occupational exposure to livestock/meat (butcher) 70, experiencing an undulating (waves of fever and relative apyrexia) or intermittent fever 71, profuse sweating, and musculoskeletal pain (back pain) is highly suggestive of Brucellosis (Undulant Fever)72. The mild anemia and leukocytosis are non-specific but fit the picture of a chronic infection73.	Brucellosis (Undulant Fever): Risk factor (butcher/livestock exposure), undulating fever (fever days, no-fever days), profuse sweating, and back pain.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q10: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	Prostaglandin F	T-regulator cells	Prostaglandin E2	Cell adhesion molecule		C	Prostaglandin E2	Fever results from the resetting of the hypothalamic set point (the body's temperature regulator) to a higher level. This resetting is mediated by the action of Prostaglandin E2 ($\mathbf{PGE_2}$) on the preoptic nucleus of the anterior hypothalamus74. PGE2 is released in response to pyrogens (e.g., IL-1, TNF-alpha)75.	Hypothalamic Reset (Fever): Caused by Prostaglandin $\mathbf{E_2}$ ($\mathbf{PGE_2}$).	Infectious Diseases/Fever				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q11: In neutropenic fever, absolute count of neutrophils is?	$\le1000$ per mm3	$\le500$ per mm3	$\le850$ per mm3	$>1000$ per mm3		B	$\le500$ per mm3	Neutropenic Fever (or Febrile Neutropenia) is defined as a single oral temperature of $\ge 38.3^\circ \text{C}$ or a temperature of $\ge 38.0^\circ \text{C}$ sustained for over an hour, in a patient with Neutropenia76. Neutropenia is defined as an Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) of $\le 500$ per $\text{mm}^3$ 77, or an ANC that is expected to fall to this level within 48 hours.	Neutropenic Fever ANC: $\mathbf{\le 500}$ per $\mathbf{mm}^3$78.	Infectious Diseases/Hematology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q12: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma is referred to as	Meningitis.	Myelitis.	Encephalitis.	Meningoencephalitis		C	Encephalitis.	Encephalitis is the term for inflammation of the brain parenchyma (the functional tissue of the brain)79. Meningitis is the inflammation of the meninges80. Myelitis is inflammation of the spinal cord81. Meningoencephalitis is inflammation of both the brain and the meninges82.	Encephalitis: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma.	Meningitis/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q13: Male patient 22 years old, presented by fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, weight loss, he has a history of IV drug addiction. What most highly suspected in such case?	TB infection	Meningitis	Acute myeloid leukemia	AIDS		D	AIDS	A young patient 83, with a history of a high-risk behavior for HIV transmission (IV drug addiction) 84, presenting with systemic symptoms including fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, and weight loss (often referred to as 'wasting syndrome' or AIDS-defining symptoms) 85, is highly suspected to have AIDS86. These symptoms reflect the opportunistic infections and immune depletion characteristic of advanced HIV disease.	AIDS (Suspected): IV drug use history, Generalized Lymphadenopathy, fever, diarrhea, and weight loss (wasting syndrome).	HIV/Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q14: Meningitis reflects infection of the	Arachnoid mater and pia mater.	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.	Dura mater and arachnoid mater.	Subarachnoid space and pia mater.		B	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.			Meningitis/Anatomy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q15: Which of the following bacteria is not a cause for bacterial meningitis?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Neisseria meningitidis	Escherichia coli	Haemophilus influenza		C	Escherichia coli	The main classic causes of bacterial meningitis in adults and children include Streptococcus pneumoniae 92, Neisseria meningitidis 93, and Haemophilus influenzae type b94. Escherichia coli 95 is a cause of bacterial meningitis, but predominantly in neonates (along with Group B Streptococcus and Listeria monocytogenes). While E. coli is a cause, it is typically excluded when listing the main causes across all age groups, or if the context is adults/older children. Based on common MCQ patterns, E. coli is often the intended answer to distinguish neonatal causes from others.	Main Bacterial Meningitis Causes: S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae. E. coli is a major cause in Neonates.	Meningitis/Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P5, Q16: Which of the following organisms causes epidemic meningitis cases at military recruits?	Haemophilus influenzae type b	Neisseria meningitidis	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes		B	Neisseria meningitidis	Meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis 96, is highly transmissible via respiratory droplets, especially in crowded, close-quarter settings like military barracks/recruits97. It is the classic cause of epidemic meningitis in these environments.	Epidemic Meningitis (Military/Crowds): Caused by Neisseria meningitidis.	Meningitis/Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q17: Which are the two types of leptospirosis?	Icteric and Anicteric	Edematous and Non edematous	Haemorrhagic and non-haemorhagic	Benign and malignant		A	Icteric and Anicteric	Leptospirosis is broadly classified into two main clinical types 98: Anicteric leptospirosis (the milder, more common form) 99and Icteric leptospirosis (the severe form, also known as Weil's disease)100.	Leptospirosis Types: Icteric (severe/Weil's) and Anicteric (milder/most common).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q18: Aseptic meningitis diagnosed when	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain but detected by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain but not by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain and bacterial cultures		A	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	Aseptic Meningitis is diagnosed when the clinical signs of meningitis are present but routine testing of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows no evidence of bacterial infection, specifically when Gram stain is negative and bacterial cultures show no growth101. This is typically caused by viruses (most commonly) or other non-bacterial pathogens (fungi, parasites, drugs) 102.	Aseptic Meningitis Definition: Clinical signs of meningitis with negative Gram stain and bacterial cultures103.	Meningitis/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q19: The following symptoms and signs are true regarding anicteric leptospirosis except?	Flu Like Symptoms	Nausea and Vomiting	Exudative conjunctivitis	Pharyngitis		C	Exudative conjunctivitis	Anicteric leptospirosis (the milder form) typically presents with non-specific, flu-like symptoms 104, including fever, myalgia, headache, nausea, vomiting 105, and pharyngitis106. A characteristic finding is conjunctival suffusion (redness due to congestion) without pus, which is different from exudative conjunctivitis (pus/discharge), which is not typical for leptospirosis107.	Anicteric Leptospirosis: Flu-like symptoms. NOT Exudative conjunctivitis (Conjunctival suffusion is typical).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q20: Classic symptoms of meningitis usually include...	Backache, hallucinations, indigestion	Rash, inner ear pain, itching	Dry skin, dehydration, cold sore	Fever, headache, stiff neck		D	Fever, headache, stiff neck	The classic triad of meningitis symptoms includes fever, headache, and stiff neck (nuchal rigidity) 108108.	Classic Meningitis Triad: Fever, Headache, Stiff Neck109109109109.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q21: Which of the following signs is not a sign of meningeal irritation?	Nuchal rigidity	Kernig's sign	Brudzinski's sign	Babinski's sign		D	Babinski's sign	The signs of meningeal irritation include Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck) 110, Kernig's sign 111, and Brudzinski's sign112. The Babinski's sign (or plantar reflex) is a neurological sign indicating an abnormality in the corticospinal tract (upper motor neuron lesion), not a specific sign of meningeal irritation113.	Meningeal Irritation Signs: Nuchal Rigidity, Kernig's, Brudzinski's. NOT Babinski's sign (UMN lesion).	Meningitis/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q22: Non-blanching petechiae and cutaneous hemorrhages may be present in meningitis caused by:	Viruses	Parasites	Bacteria	TB		C	Bacteria	The rapid onset of non-blanching petechiae and purpura/cutaneous hemorrhages 114is a critical finding, highly suggestive of meningococcal sepsis/meningitis, which is caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis115.	Petechiae/Hemorrhage in Meningitis: Strongly suggests Bacterial cause (specifically Neisseria meningitidis).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q23: 26 years old female presented with fever, malaise, headache and neck stiffness for the last two days. On examination which cranial nerves can be affected?	I, II, III	III, IV, VI	v, IX, X	VIII, X, XI		B	III, IV, VI	Meningeal inflammation, especially at the base of the brain, can affect the function of the cranial nerves. The most commonly affected cranial nerves in meningitis, leading to signs like ocular palsies or gaze disturbances, are the oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), and abducens (VI) nerves116.	CNs Affected in Meningitis: Most commonly III (Oculomotor), IV (Trochlear), and VI (Abducens).	Meningitis/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P6, Q24: The classic triad of bacterial meningitis includes fever, neck stiffness, and	Paralysis.	Changes in mental status.	Change in gait.	Photophobia		B	Changes in mental status.	The classic triad of bacterial meningitis includes fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status (changes in mental status)117117117. Photophobia (D) 118is also a common symptom, but altered mental status is considered part of the triad, reflecting cerebral involvement 119.	Classic Bacterial Meningitis Triad: Fever, Stiff Neck, and Changes in Mental Status120.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q25: What is the sign in which forced flexion of the neck elicits a reflex flexion of the hips?	Kernig's sign.	Brudzinski's sign.	Chadwick's sign	Babinski's sign		B	Brudzinski's sign.	Brudzinski's sign 121121is a sign of meningeal irritation where passive, forced flexion of the patient's neck causes a reflex flexion of the hips and knees122. Kernig's sign 123involves pain/resistance on extending the knee when the hip is flexed 124.	Brudzinski's Sign: Neck flexion $\to$ Reflex flexion of hips/knees125125125125.	Meningitis/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q26: Which procedure is most likely used to test for meningitis?	Throat culture	Lumbar puncture	Tuberculosis skin test	Urine analysis		B	Lumbar puncture	The definitive diagnostic procedure for meningitis is the Lumbar Puncture (LP)126. This procedure collects Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) for analysis, which confirms the diagnosis and helps determine the causative agent (e.g., bacteria, virus, fungus) 127.	Meningitis Diagnosis (Definitive): Lumbar Puncture for CSF analysis128.	Meningitis/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q27: Which of the following is not an immediate complication of meningitis?	Septic shock	Coma	Seizures	Blindness		D	Blindness	Septic shock 129, coma 130, and seizures 131 are all well-known and potentially immediate, life-threatening complications of severe bacterial meningitis. Blindness (cortical or due to optic nerve damage) 132 can occur, but is more often considered a sequela (long-term complication/residual deficit) rather than an immediate, acute complication like shock or coma.	Immediate Meningitis Complications: Septic shock, Coma, Seizures. Blindness is usually a long-term sequela.	Meningitis/Complications				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q28: Blood culture is positive in meningitis caused by:	Neisseria meningitidis	TB	Aseptic meningitis	Parasites		A	Neisseria meningitidis	Blood cultures are most frequently positive in meningitis caused by Bacterial pathogens that are often associated with concurrent bloodstream infection (septicemia)133. Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcus) is notorious for causing both meningitis and life-threatening meningococcemia, making a positive blood culture very common134. TB, aseptic (viral), and parasitic meningitis are less likely to yield a positive routine blood culture 135.	Positive Blood Culture (Meningitis): Most common with Bacterial causes, especially Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcemia)136.	Meningitis/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q29: Lumbar Puncture needle for CSF analysis is inserted between	L1-L2	L3-L4	L4-L5	L5-S1		C	L4-L5	The spinal cord typically ends at the level of the first or second lumbar vertebra (L1-L2) in adults. To avoid damaging the spinal cord, the Lumbar Puncture (LP) needle is safely inserted below the termination of the cord, usually between the L3-L4 137or L4-L5 138 vertebral interspaces. L4-L5 is the most commonly cited and safest site.	Lumbar Puncture Site: Between L3-L4 139or L4-L5 140 interspaces (below the spinal cord termination).	Meningitis/Anatomy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q30: Which of the following CSF results suggests TB meningitis?	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, normal protein, and normal glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose		C	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	Tuberculous (TB) Meningitis typically shows a CSF profile known as an 'Atypical' pattern: Elevated CSF lymphocytes count (a mononuclear cell predominance) 141, raised protein 142, and low glucose (consumed by the bacteria/inflammation)143. Elevated neutrophils (A) are typical for acute bacterial meningitis.	TB Meningitis CSF: Lymphocytic pleocytosis, High protein, Low glucose.	Meningitis/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q1: Primary prevention refers to	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	Measures taken after occurrence of the disease.	Measures taken after occurrence of complications.	Measures taken to prevent handicapping.		A	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	Primary Prevention consists of measures taken before the disease or health problem occurs, applied to healthy individuals144144144144. The goal is to prevent the onset of disease (e.g., vaccination, health education)145145145145.	Primary Prevention: Before disease onset, applied to Healthy Individuals (e.g., vaccination).	Prevention/Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P7, Q2: Seroprophylaxis is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoide.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera.		B	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Seroprophylaxis involves giving a patient pre-formed antibodies (e.g., immunoglobulin)146. This is a form of Passive Immunity that provides immediate, temporary protection against a disease147.	Seroprophylaxis: Administration of Pre-formed Antibodies (e.g., Ig) for immediate passive immunity.	Prevention/Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q3: Vaccine is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera.		A	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	A Vaccine is an antigenic preparation derived from a pathogenic organism or its products (e.g., toxoid, killed/live attenuated organisms)148. It is administered to stimulate an Active Immune Response against the disease149.	Vaccine: Antigenic preparation (organism, toxoid, etc.) to stimulate active immunity.	Prevention/Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q4: Chemoprophylaxis is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera		C	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	Chemoprophylaxis is the administration of a chemical agent (typically an antimicrobial drug) 150to prevent the development of an infection, usually given just before or immediately after exposure to a pathogen151.	Chemoprophylaxis: Use of Antimicrobial Drugs before or immediately after exposure to prevent infection.	Prevention/Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q5: Community control include the following except:--	Environmental sanitation.	Health education.	Mass immunizatiom.	Disinfection.		D	Disinfection.	Community Control Measures are broad strategies aimed at reducing disease burden in a population. They commonly include Environmental Sanitation 152, Health Education 153, and Mass Immunization campaigns154. Disinfection 155 is a technique for controlling infectious agents on inanimate objects/surfaces, which is usually part of general sanitation/control, but is less of a broad 'Community Control' strategy than the others listed.	Community Control Measures: Environmental Sanitation, Health Education, Mass Immunization. Disinfection is a specific environmental technique.	Prevention/Public Health				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q6: Giving routine iron and folic acid to all pregnant women is a form of:	Primary prevention	Secondary prevention.	Tertiary prevention.	Chemoprophylaxis.		A	Primary prevention	Primary Prevention aims to prevent the onset of disease or injury156. Routine iron and folic acid supplementation is given to healthy pregnant women to prevent nutritional deficiencies (like iron deficiency anemia and neural tube defects), thus it is a form of Primary Prevention157.	Iron/Folic Acid Supplementation (Healthy Pregnant Women): Primary Prevention (prevents deficiency/disease onset).	Prevention				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q7: Adequate treatment of a case is considered as:	Primary prevention for case and contact.	Primary prevention for case and secondary for contact.	Primary prevention for contact.	Secondary prevention of case.	Secondary prevention for case and primary for contact.	D	Secondary prevention of case.			Prevention/Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q8: The following are primary preventive measures EXCEPT:	Vaccination.	Early diagnosis.	Health education.	Proper nutrition.		B	Early diagnosis.	Primary Prevention measures are done before the onset of disease160. Vaccination 161, Health Education 162, and Proper Nutrition 163 all aim to prevent disease acquisition. Early diagnosis 164 (screening) occurs after the onset of the disease (during the preclinical phase) and is therefore a measure of Secondary Prevention165.	Secondary Prevention: Early Diagnosis/Screening. Primary Prevention: Vaccination, Health Education, Proper Nutrition.	Prevention				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q9: An example of secondary prevention is:	Giving iron to pregnant females.	B- Use of seat belts.	C- Influenza vaccine for the elderly.	D-DPT immunization for infant.	E- Detection of asymptomatic cases of diabetes mellitus.	E	Detection of asymptomatic cases of diabetes mellitus.	Secondary Prevention involves measures to detect a disease at an early, asymptomatic stage 166to allow for prompt intervention and limit its progression or complications (e.g., screening tests)167. Detection of asymptomatic cases of diabetes mellitus (screening) is a perfect example168. The others are examples of Primary Prevention 169.	Secondary Prevention: Detection of asymptomatic cases (screening, early diagnosis)170.	Prevention				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P8, Q10: The following are risk factor for candid infection except?	HIV and AIDS	Long term steroids use	HAV	Immunosupressive therapy	Long term antibiotics use	C	HAV	Candidiasis (Candida infection) is often an opportunistic infection. Risk factors involve conditions that compromise the immune system or disrupt normal microbial flora, such as HIV/AIDS 171, immunosuppressive therapy 172, long-term steroid use 173, and long-term antibiotics (disrupting normal flora)174. HAV (Hepatitis A Virus) 175is a cause of acute hepatitis and is not a recognized risk factor for Candida infection176.	Candidiasis Risk Factors: Immunosuppression (HIV, Steroids, IS therapy) and loss of normal flora (Antibiotics). NOT HAV.	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q11: In which of these fungal infections we use maximum tolerated dose of amphotracin B	Candida	Cryptococosis	Asperigillosis	Mucormycosis		D	Mucormycosis	Mucormycosis (caused by fungi of the class Mucorales) is a highly aggressive and rapidly spreading angioinvasive fungal infection with a high mortality rate177. Treatment often requires a multimodal approach, including aggressive surgical debridement and the use of the maximum tolerated dose of intravenous Amphotericin B (or liposomal Amphotericin B) 178.	Maximum Tolerated Dose Amphotericin B: Used for aggressive, high-mortality infections like Mucormycosis179.	Mycology/Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q12: In pnumocyststis pnuomonia 1st line ttt is:	TMP SMX	Pentamedine	Fluconazole	Amphotrscin B		A	TMP SMX	Pneumocystis Pneumonia (PCP), caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii, is a common opportunistic infection, especially in HIV patients with CD4 counts $< 200~cells/\text{ml}$. The drug of choice for both treatment and prophylaxis is Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)180. Pentamidine is a second-line option 181.	Pneumocystis Pneumonia (PCP) Rx: TMP-SMX (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole)182.	Mycology/Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q13: Who of those not at risk of fungal infection	Low birth weight infant	Neutropenic patient	Organ transplantation	Hypertensive patient		D	Hypertensive patient	Individuals at high risk of fungal infection are those with compromised immune systems or other vulnerabilities183. This includes Neutropenic patients (lack of defense cells) 184, Organ transplant recipients (on immunosuppressive drugs) 185, and vulnerable groups like low birth weight infants186. A Hypertensive patient 187 (high blood pressure) is not inherently at increased risk for fungal infections unless they are also immunocompromised.	Fungal Infection Risk Factors: Immunosuppression (Neutropenia, Organ Transplant, HIV) and vulnerable states (LBW infants). NOT Hypertension.	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q14: One of these fungal infections has bad prognosis if associated with covid 19	Cryptococcosis	Candidiasis	Mucormycosis	Histoplasmosis	Asperigillosis	C	Mucormycosis	The fungal infection that has been widely reported to cause a severe and often fatal complication in patients with severe COVID-19, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes and/or on high-dose steroids, is Mucormycosis188. This has been notably observed in India, leading to the term 'Black Fungus'189.	COVID-19 Associated Fungal Infection (Bad Prognosis): Mucormycosis (The 'Black Fungus').	Mycology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q15: As regard salmonella food poisoning all of the following are correct except:	Incubation period from 1 to 6 hour.	Gram-ve bacilli.	Treatment correction of dehydration and antibiotics.	Salmonella is associated mainly with raw meats, poultry and dairy products.	Causing symptoms and signs of gastroenteritis.	A	Incubation period from 1 to 6 hour.	Salmonella food poisoning has an incubation period that is typically longer than 1 to 6 hours190. The usual incubation period is 6 hours to 48 hours (or up to 72 hours). 1-6 hours is characteristic of pre-formed toxin food poisoning (e.g., S. aureus). Salmonella is a Gram-negative bacillus 191, associated with raw meats/poultry 192, causes gastroenteritis 193, and treatment involves rehydration and sometimes antibiotics194.	Salmonella Incubation Period: 6 to 72 hours. NOT 1-6 hours (which is for pre-formed toxin/Staph).	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q16: As regard Neurological signs and symptoms of botulism all the following are correct except:	symmetrical	Ascending	flaccid paralysis	motor and autonomic nerves,	usually beginning with cranial nerves	B	Ascending	The neurological signs of Botulism (caused by Clostridium botulinum toxin) are characterized by symmetrical 195, flaccid paralysis 196involving motor and autonomic nerves 197, typically beginning with the cranial nerves (e.g., blurred vision, dysphagia)198. The pattern of paralysis is characteristically descending (starting from cranial nerves/face and moving down) 199, NOT ascending (which is characteristic of Guillain-Barré Syndrome)200.	Botulism Paralysis: Symmetrical, Flaccid, Descending (starts with cranial nerves). NOT Ascending.	Food Poisoning/Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q17: As regard campylobacter food poisoning the following are correct except:	the most common causes of foodborne illness.	It is present in the gut of a wide range of animals, especially birds.	Outbreaks have been linked to the consumption of undercooked poultry, mince and sausages.	unpasteurized milk not cause campylobacter food poisoning	Pets may also be a source of infection.	D	unpasteurized milk not cause campylobacter food poisoning	Campylobacter food poisoning is a very common foodborne illness 201, with reservoirs in the gut of animals, especially birds202. It is linked to undercooked poultry/meat 203and pets204. Unpasteurized milk is a well-known vehicle for Campylobacter transmission 205, so the statement that it does not cause the disease is incorrect 206.	Campylobacter Source: Undercooked poultry, contaminated water, and unpasteurized milk207.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P9, Q18: As regard staphylococcal food poisoning	Gram negative cocci	Incubation period 72 hours	produce heat labial toxin D-Manifestation simulate gastroenteritis	Manifestation simulate gastroenteritis	the food handler carry the organism in their GUT	D	Manifestation simulate gastroenteritis	Staphylococcal food poisoning is caused by the ingestion of a pre-formed, heat-stable toxin (enterotoxin) produced by Staphylococcus aureus. The correct statement is that the manifestations simulate gastroenteritis (sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhea)208. S. aureus is a Gram-positive coccus209. The incubation period is typically short (1-6 hours)210. The toxin is heat-stable211. The organism is often carried by food handlers on their skin/nose/hands, not primarily in their gut212.	Staph Food Poisoning: Gastroenteritis symptoms from pre-formed, heat-stable toxin. Short incubation ($\mathbf{1-6}$ hours). Gram-positive cocci.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q19: Types of human botulism are all of the following except	Infant botulism	Unclassified	Air-born botulism	Wound botulism	Food-borne botulism	C	Air-born botulism	The main recognized forms of human Botulism are 213: Food-borne (ingestion of pre-formed toxin) 214, Infant (colonization of the gut and toxin production) 215, Wound (toxin production in an infected wound) 216, and sometimes Unclassified 217 or Iatrogenic. Air-born botulism is not a naturally occurring type of human botulism218.	Botulism Types: Food-borne, Infant, Wound. NOT Air-born.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q20: As regard food poisoning the following organisms cancause food poisoning except:	Staphylococcal aurus	Hepatitis B virus.	Clostridium botulenum	Salmonella spp	Hepatitis A virus	B	Hepatitis B virus.	Food poisoning is a general term for illness caused by consuming contaminated food, typically involving gastrointestinal or neurological symptoms. Organisms/toxins that cause this include Staphylococcus aureus (toxin) 219219, Clostridium botulinum (toxin/infection) 220220, Salmonella spp 221, and Hepatitis A virus (foodborne viral illness)222. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) 223is primarily transmitted through blood and sexual contact and is not a cause of food poisoning224.	Food Poisoning Pathogens: S. aureus, C. botulinum, Salmonella, HAV. NOT HBV (bloodborne).	Food Poisoning

C	Intoxication involves food poisoning in which the organism grows in food and releases a heat stable toxin from the cells on pre-formed food as salmonella spp	Food Intoxication is correctly described as consuming a pre-formed toxin in the food225. However, the example given, Salmonella spp 226, typically causes Food Infection (the organism grows in the host after ingestion)227227, not intoxication. S. aureus and C. botulinum toxins are classic examples of intoxication228228228228. The other statements are generally true (Illness from microbe 229, Outbreak definition 230, Salmonella course 231). ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q22: Gonococcal urethritis can be treated by	Ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly for 7 days	Azithromycin 1g daily for 5 days	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of Metronidazole 2 gm.	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of azithromycin 1g.		D	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of azithromycin 1g.	Treatment for uncomplicated Gonococcal urethritis should be a dual therapy regimen to treat Neisseria gonorrhoeae (G-coccus) and often presumptively cover for co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis (Non-gonococcal urethritis, NGU)233. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q23: Non-gonococcal urethritis can be treated by	Oral single dose of azithromycin 500mg once daily for 5 days	Oral single dose of azithromycin 500mg once daily for 5 days plus metronidazole 2 gm daily for 7 days	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily plus metronidazole 2 gm daily	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily		D	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily	The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia trachomatis. First-line treatment is Azithromycin 1g single dose OR Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 7 days. Metronidazole is added if Trichomonas vaginalis is suspected or confirmed. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q24: In urinary tract infections, the most common rout of infection is	Ascending infection.	Lymphatic spread	Direct spread	Hematogenous spread		A	Ascending infection.	The most common route for Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs), especially for cystitis and pyelonephritis caused by E. coli (the most common agent) 238238, is the Ascending Infection route239. Bacteria from the periurethral area colonize the urethra and ascend into the bladder, and sometimes further up to the kidneys 240.	UTI Route: Most common is Ascending Infection241.
