ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q25: The main causative agent of urinary tract infections is	Klebsiella pneumonia	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Escherichia coli		D	Escherichia coli	Escherichia coli ($\mathbf{E. coli}$) is by far the single main causative agent of uncomplicated Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs), responsible for about 75-95% of cases242242. The other bacteria listed are less common causes 243.	Main UTI Cause: Escherichia coli ($\mathbf{E. coli}$)244244.	Infectious Diseases/Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P10, Q26: Which one of the followings is considered to be complicated acute pyelonephritis?	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with sever flank pain	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	Acute pyelonephritis with high fever		C	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	Complicated Acute Pyelonephritis is diagnosed when the infection is associated with an underlying structural or functional abnormality, or with systemic features or complications245. Renal dysfunction 246 is a complication indicating significant compromise and failure of a major organ, thus classifying the pyelonephritis as complicated. High fever (D), high pyuria (A), and severe flank pain (B) are common signs of uncomplicated severe pyelonephritis 247247247247.	Complicated Pyelonephritis: Associated with underlying factors or a severe complication like Renal Dysfunction248.	Infectious Diseases/Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P11, Q27: Which one of the following need treatment at hospital?	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with high leukocytosis	Acute pyelonephritis with fever 39 C		A	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	One of the key indicators for Hospitalization and intravenous (IV) treatment for acute pyelonephritis is the presence of complicating factors or severe illness249. A patient with Diabetes Mellitus (DM) 250has an immunocompromised state and is at higher risk for severe infection, complications (like emphysematous pyelonephritis), and treatment failure, thus requiring hospital admission 251.	Pyelonephritis Hospitalization Indication: Complicating factors like Diabetes Mellitus (DM) 252 or signs of severe sepsis.	Infectious Diseases/Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P11, Q28: Microscopic pyuria defined as pyuria associated with	WBCs more than 10/CM	WBCs more than 50/CM	WBCs more than 100/CM	Positive leukocyte esterase		A	WBCs more than 10/CM	Pyuria is defined as the presence of white blood cells (WBCs) in the urine. Microscopic pyuria is commonly defined as having more than 10 WBCs per cubic millimeter ($/\text{mm}^3$) of uncentrifuged urine253. However, in clinical practice and for some sources, the threshold is often cited as $\ge 5$ or $\ge 10$ WBCs per high-power field (HPF) of centrifuged urine, but from the given options, WBCs more than 10/CM (presumably referring to $/\text{mm}^3$ or a similar microscopic field unit) is the best fit for the definition of pyuria 254.	Pyuria (Microscopic): Generally defined as $\ge 10$ WBCs/High Power Field (HPF) or $/\text{mm}^3$ of uncentrifuged urine255.	Infectious Diseases/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P11, Q29: In patients with urinary tract infections the ultrasonography indicated in	Patients with severe flank pain	Patients with high fever	Patients with high pyuria	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment		D	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment	Imaging, such as ultrasonography, is not routinely recommended for uncomplicated UTIs or pyelonephritis256. It is indicated when there are signs of complications or treatment failure257. The most important indication listed is patients whose condition does not improve after 3 days of appropriate antibiotic treatment 258, suggesting a complication like an abscess or obstruction.	UTI/Pyelonephritis Ultrasound Indication: Failure to improve after 3 days of treatment259.	Infectious Diseases/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P11, Q30: Patients with acute pyelonephritis can be treated by	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	Ciprofloxacin orally for 14 days	Ciprofloxacin, IV for 7 days	Ceftriaxone 1 g IV for 5 days		A	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	For uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis that can be managed as an outpatient (not requiring hospitalization), an appropriate oral regimen includes a fluoroquinolone like Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days260. Ciprofloxacin for 14 days is an older regimen (B), and IV treatment (C and D) is reserved for hospitalized or severely ill patients 261.	Uncomplicated Pyelonephritis Rx (Outpatient): Ciprofloxacin (Oral) for 7 days262.	Infectious Diseases/Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P12, Q1: Tetanus toxoid is better given to the pregnant mother in:	In the first trintester.	One day before delivery.	From 4 to 8 months of pregnancy.	Just after delivery.		C	From 4 to 8 months of pregnancy.	Maternal Tetanus Toxoid (TT) vaccination is most effective when given in the second or third trimester (4 to 8 months)263263263263. This timing ensures maximum antibody production by the mother and efficient placental transfer to the fetus, providing the best protection against neonatal tetanus at birth264264264264.	Maternal TT: Given in the second or third trimester (4-8 months) to maximize fetal antibody transfer.	Vaccination/Pregnancy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P12, Q2: Which of the following parasites may cause keratitis:	Toxoplasma gondi.	Loa loa.	Acanthamoeba.	Demodexfolliculorum.		C	Acanthamoeba.	Acanthamoeba keratitis 265is a rare but severe and painful infection of the cornea (keratitis) caused by the free-living amoeba Acanthamoeba266. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wearers who use contaminated tap water or poor hygiene practices.	Acanthamoeba: Parasitic cause of Keratitis (often associated with contact lenses). ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P12, Q3: How does Ebola spread from human to human?	Spreads through direct contact with blood and bodily fluids.	Spreads through inhaling infected droplets.	Spreads through contaminated water.	Spreads through contaminated skin.		A	Spreads through direct contact with blood and bodily fluids.	Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) is transmitted through direct contact 267with the blood or bodily fluids (urine, saliva, sweat, feces, vomit, breast milk, semen) of a person who is sick with or has died from EVD268. It is not typically spread through the air (aerosol/droplets), water, or casual contact with intact skin 269.	Ebola Transmission: Direct contact with blood and bodily fluids270.	Infectious Diseases/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P12, Q4: Primary prevention refers to:	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	Measures taken after occurrence of the disease.	Measures taken after occurrence of complications.	Measures taken to prevent handicapping.		A	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	Primary Prevention focuses on actions taken before the onset of disease, targeting healthy individuals to prevent them from contracting the disease in the first place271271271271.	Primary Prevention: Before disease onset, applied to Healthy Individuals (e.g., vaccination).	Prevention/Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P12, Q5: Meningitis reflects infection of the:	Arachnoid mater and pia mater.	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.	Dura mater and arachnoid mater.	Subarachnoid space and pia mater.		B	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.	Meningitis is the inflammation of the meninges, which includes the arachnoid mater and pia mater (the leptomeninges)272. Importantly, the inflammation and infection primarily involve the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) 273within the subarachnoid space (the space between the arachnoid and pia mater)274. While A is part of the meninges, B is a more encompassing and correct description of the affected anatomical area 275.	Meningitis Site: Infection of the Arachnoid mater and Subarachnoid space (containing infected CSF)276.	Meningitis/Anatomy				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P13, Q6: A 35 year old man diagnosed with HIV 2 years ago and is stable on antiretroviral therapy. He has a new regular partner and is concerned about transmitting the disease to her. What factor is most likely to increase the risk of transmission?	Circumcision.	Mucosal ulceration.	Low CD4 count	Co infection with genital warts.		B	Mucosal ulceration.	The risk of sexual transmission of HIV is primarily related to the viral load and the integrity of the mucosa. Mucosal ulceration (from any cause, including STIs like Herpes or Syphilis) 277provides a portal of entry for the virus and significantly increases the risk of HIV transmission 278 by exposing the partner to more of the virus and increasing inflammatory cells (targets for HIV). Circumcision (A) actually reduces transmission risk279. Low CD4 count (C) often correlates with high viral load, but mucosal break is a direct physical risk factor 280.	Increased HIV Transmission Risk: Mucosal Ulceration (from STIs or other causes)281, which creates a portal of entry and increases inflammatory cells.	HIV/STIs				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P13, Q7: 18 year old man is bitten by frantic dog whilst taking a gap year in Ecuador. He is worried about rabies and phones for advice. He was not immunised against prior to travelling to Ecuador. What is the most appropriate advice after thorough cleansing of the wound?	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + full course vaccination.	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + oral penicillin for 2 weeks.	human rabies immunoglobulin.	Give full course vaccination.		A	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + full course vaccination.	In a patient with a high-risk exposure (bite by a potentially rabid animal in an endemic area) 282who is not previously vaccinated 283, the correct post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a combination of Passive Immunity (immediate protection with Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIG)) 284and Active Immunity (long-term protection with a full course of the Rabies Vaccine (HDCV/PCEC))285. Wound cleansing is also essential 286.	Rabies PEP (Unvaccinated): HRIG + Full course Rabies Vaccine287.	Infectious Diseases/Vaccination				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P13, Q8: A 25 year old intravenous drug user with chronic HCV becomes pregnant. Approximately what is the chance of the virus being transmittedto her child?	<10%.	10-20%.	20-30%.	30-40%.		A	<10%.	Vertical (mother-to-child) transmission of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) is relatively inefficient compared to HIV or HBV. In the absence of HIV co-infection, the risk of HCV transmission from a chronic HCV-infected mother to her child is generally considered low, typically around 5-10% (or <10%)288. This risk is higher with high maternal viral loads or co-infection with HIV.	HCV Vertical Transmission Risk: Low, generally <10%289.	Hepatitis/STIs				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P13, Q9: A 35 year old man who has recently immigrated from Zimbabwe to the UK presents to the emergency departement with fever, myalgia and headaches. He is suspected to have malaria. Which test is most likely to allow for accurate speciation to the malaria pathogen?	Thick blood film.	Thin blood film.	Quantitative buffy coat analysis.	Blood culture.		B	Thin blood film.	For the diagnosis of Malaria, both thick and thin blood films are typically used290290. The Thick Blood Film (A) is the most sensitive test, used to screen for the presence of parasites291. The Thin Blood Film (B) is used for accurate speciation 292 and determination of the parasitic load, as the morphology of the parasite within the red blood cell is preserved, allowing differentiation between species (e.g., P. falciparum vs. P. vivax).	Malaria Diagnosis: Thick film (screening/sensitivity). Thin film (speciation 293/parasite load).	Parasitology/Diagnosis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P13, Q10: Which of the following is true regarding the Salmonella species?	Rose spots appear in all patients with typhoid.	They are normally presents in the gut as commensals.	They are anaerobic organisms.	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever.		D	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever.	Typhoid fever (caused by Salmonella typhi) is classically associated with a phenomenon called Relative Bradycardia 294, where the pulse rate is lower than expected for the degree of fever295. Rose spots (A) are characteristic but do not appear in all patients296. Salmonella are typically pathogens, not normal commensals (B)297. Salmonella species are facultative anaerobes, not strict anaerobes (C) 298.	Typhoid Fever Sign: Relative Bradycardia (pulse rate low for the level of fever)299.	Infectious Diseases/Typhoid				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P14, Q11: A 34 year old sewage worker presents with 3 days history of low back pain, fever, myalgia, fatigue, jundice, subconjunctival hemorrhage and renal impairment. He has no past medical history and has not been abroad in the last 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Cysticercosis.	Leptospirosis.	Glomerulonephritis.	Hepatitis A.		B	Leptospirosis.	The patient's occupation (sewage worker) 300300exposes him to environments contaminated with animal urine (a key risk factor)301301. The clinical picture of fever, myalgia, headache (flu-like prodrome) 302302, followed by severe systemic disease involving jaundice (liver failure) 303303, renal impairment 304304, and the characteristic sign of subconjunctival hemorrhage 305305is classic for the severe, icteric form of Leptospirosis (Weil's disease) 306306.	Leptospirosis (Weil's Disease): Risk factor (sewage worker/contaminated water) + Fever, Jaundice, Renal Impairment, and Subconjunctival Hemorrhage307307307307.	Leptospirosis

What is the most likely cause?	Sarcoidosis.	Leishmaniasis.	Schistosoma haematobium.	Tuberculosis.		C	Schistosoma haematobium. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P14, Q14: What is the main virulence factor of brucella?	Enterotoxin production	Capsule	Intracellular survival	Endotoxin		D	Endotoxin	Brucella spp. is a Gram-negative bacterium that is a facultative intracellular pathogen318. Its primary virulence mechanism and key to its persistence and chronic infection is its ability to survive and replicate inside host cells (macrophages and monocytes) 319, shielding it from host antibodies and many antibiotics.	Brucella Virulence: Intracellular Survival (in macrophages/monocytes)320.	Infectious Diseases/Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q1: The level of prevention that takes place during the early phases of pathogenesis and includes activities that limit the progression of disease ist	Primary Prevention.	Secondary Prevention.	Tertiary Prevention.	primordial prevention		B	Secondary Prevention.	Secondary Prevention occurs during the early phases of pathogenesis 321 (the preclinical stage), after the disease has started but before overt symptoms. Its goal is to limit the progression of disease 322by detecting it early (screening/early diagnosis) and intervening promptly 323.	Secondary Prevention: Early pathogenesis, aims to limit disease progression (e.g., screening)324.	Prevention/Epidemiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q2: Causes of hypothermia includes the following:	Hyperglycemia.	Adrenal dysfunction.	Thyrotoxic crises	Hyperpituitarism		B	Adrenal dysfunction.	Hypothermia (abnormally low body temperature) can be caused by various endocrine/metabolic dysfunctions that impair the body's thermoregulation. Adrenal dysfunction (e.g., adrenal insufficiency/Addison's disease) 325 is a recognized endocrine cause of hypothermia. Thyrotoxic crisis (C) and Hyperglycemia (A) are typically associated with hyperthermia 326326326326.	Hypothermia Cause: Adrenal Dysfunction (e.g., Adrenal Insufficiency)327. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q3: Chloroquine is not effective in:	Blood schizont of malaria.	Rheumatoid arthritis.	Systemic lupus erythematosus.	Hepatic primary schizont of malaria		D	Hepatic primary schizont of malaria	Chloroquine is highly effective against the blood schizonts (erythrocytic stage) of most Plasmodium species (A) 328and is also used for autoimmune diseases (B, C)329. However, it is not effective against the hepatic (liver) primary schizonts (exo-erythrocytic stage)330, especially for P. vivax and P. ovale, which require drugs like primaquine to prevent relapse.	Chloroquine Action: Effective against blood schizonts. NOT effective against hepatic primary schizonts331.	Infectious Diseases/Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q4: The main causative agent of urinary tract infections is:	Klebsiella pneumonia.	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Escherichia coli.		D	Escherichia coli.	Escherichia coli ($\mathbf{E. coli}$) is the predominant and most frequent cause of uncomplicated Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs) 332332332, accounting for the vast majority of cases.	Main UTI Cause: Escherichia coli ($\mathbf{E. coli}$)333.	Infectious Diseases/Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q5: The characters of stool in giardiasis are:	Pale yellow.	R-Loose	Containing fat and mucus	Frothy		C	Containing fat and mucus	Giardiasis (Giardia lamblia infection) can cause chronic diarrhea and malabsorption (especially of fat), leading to characteristic stools that are often described as loose, bulky, pale, malodorous, and greasy/fatty (containing fat) 334 (steatorrhea), sometimes with mucus335. Pale color (A) and frothy (C) are also sometimes seen but containing fat and mucus is the most descriptive/diagnostic feature 336336336336.	Giardiasis Stool: Loose, Pale, Malodorous, and Greasy/Fatty (containing fat and mucus)337.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P15, Q6: Standard precautions are important in:	Application to skin and mucous membrane.	Isolation with highly infectious diseases.	Protection from infection of healthcare staff only.	Protection from infection of patients only.		A	Application to skin and mucous membrane.	Standard Precautions are a set of infection control practices used universally for all patients 338, regardless of their diagnosis or presumed infection status339. They include practices like hand hygiene and using personal protective equipment (PPE) when contact with blood, all body fluids, non-intact skin, and mucous membranes is anticipated340. Isolation is a component of Transmission-Based Precautions (B) 341.	Standard Precautions: Applied to ALL patients, involves protection from contact with blood/body fluids/non-intact skin/mucous membranes342.	Infectious Diseases/Public Health				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q7: Toxocariasis of the eye is typically presented with which of the following eye signs:	Blepharitis.	Posterior uveitis.	Keratitis	Optic nerve atrophy.		B	Posterior uveitis.	Ocular Toxocariasis (caused by Toxocara canis/cati larvae) most commonly presents as an inflammatory lesion in the posterior part of the eye, often manifesting as a posterior uveitis, retinal granuloma, or endophthalmitis 343.	Ocular Toxocariasis: Typically presents as Posterior Uveitis or retinal granuloma344.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q8: Which of the following groups of viruses is most likely to cause meningitis?	Adenoviruses,	Human papillomaviruses,	Poxviruses.	Enteroviruses.		D	Enteroviruses.	Enteroviruses (especially Coxsackievirus and Echovirus) 345are the most common cause of Aseptic Meningitis (viral meningitis) worldwide346. Adenoviruses (A) and others can cause meningitis, but are much less frequent 347.	Most Common Viral Meningitis Cause: Enteroviruses348.	Meningitis/Virology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q9: Non-blanching petechiae and cutaneous hemorrhages may be present in meningitis caused by:	Viruses	Parasites.	Bacteria	Tuberculosis.		C	Bacteria	The finding of non-blanching petechiae and cutaneous hemorrhages 349is a highly characteristic, though not exclusive, sign of severe sepsis, classically associated with Bacterial Meningitis 350, particularly the fulminant form caused by Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcemia) 351.	Petechiae/Hemorrhage in Meningitis: Strongly suggests Bacterial cause (specifically Neisseria meningitidis)352.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q10: Which one of the following features is least likely to occur in a patient with visceral leishmaniasis?	Massive splenomegaly.	Diarrhoea.	Pancytopenia.	Grey skin.		B	Diarrhoea.	Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) is characterized by Massive Splenomegaly 353, Pancytopenia (due to bone marrow suppression and hypersplenism) 354, and often a darkening of the skin (Grey skin/Kala-azar means 'black fever')355355. Diarrhea 356is a possible but less consistent or defining feature compared to the massive organ enlargement and hematological changes357357357357.	Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) Hallmark: Massive Splenomegaly, Pancytopenia, Grey Skin. Diarrhea is least likely to be a central feature358.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q11: The most consistent pathologic finding in leptospirosis is:	Vasculitis of capillaries.	Endothelial edema	Necrosis.	Lymphocytic infiltration		A	Vasculitis of capillaries.	The primary pathological event in severe Leptospirosis is widespread damage to small blood vessels, leading to vasculitis of capillaries359. This damage (angiitis and subsequent microvascular injury) is responsible for the characteristic hemorrhages (e.g., subconjunctival) and organ dysfunction (renal, hepatic) seen in the disease 360.	Leptospirosis Pathophysiology: Vasculitis of capillaries is the most consistent finding361.	Leptospirosis/Pathology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P16, Q12: All the following statements regarding HIV infection in human is true, EXCEPT?	Monocytes and macrophages are the major reservoirs of the virus.	There are mainly 3 stages of the HIV infection with AIDS being the most severe stage.	The possible symptoms are fever, chills, fatigue, and mouth ulcers in an early stage of infection.	Medicines are available for the complete cure of the chronic stage of the HIV infections.		D	Medicines are available for the complete cure of the chronic stage of the HIV infections.	While highly effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) is available to manage HIV infection and prevent progression to AIDS 362, there is no medicine available for a complete cure363. HIV is currently a lifelong chronic infection. The other statements are generally true: Monocytes/Macrophages serve as reservoirs (A) 364, there are stages (Acute, Chronic/Latent, AIDS) (B) 365, and early infection can present with flu-like symptoms (C) 366.	HIV Treatment: No complete cure367; ART manages the disease (suppresses viral load).	HIV/Treatment				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P17, Q13: Which is FALSE regarding Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia	It is usually only seen when the CD4 count <200.	Prophylaxis should be given in all patients with CD4 count <200,	Chest x-ray characteristically shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates	Once a patient has had it, they are unlikely to get it again.		D	Once a patient has had it, they are unlikely to get it again.	Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia (PCP) is the classic opportunistic infection in HIV, typically occurring when the CD4 count is $\mathbf{< 200~cells/\text{ml}}$ (A)368. Prophylaxis (TMP-SMX) is indicated for all patients with CD4 $< 200$ (B)369. The Chest X-ray often shows characteristic bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates (C)370. However, a history of PCP does not prevent recurrence, and patients should continue prophylaxis (B) to prevent recurrence 371.	PCP False Statement: Recurrence is common; prophylaxis is required even after treatment372.	Mycology/HIV				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page15-31	P17, Q14: A 31-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for history of abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and loose stools, accompanied by progressively increasing fever. On physical examination, temperature is 40°C, blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg, pulse rate is 64/min, and respiration rate is 20/min. BMI is 26. The patient appears sick. There are blanching erythematous macules on the lower chest and upper abdominal wall. The pharynx is erythematous. Abdominal examination reveals tender hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination is normal His CBC shows leucopenia with lymphopenia. Liver profile shows elevated liver enzymes. Two sets of aerobic blood cultures show gram-negative bacilli . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	Brucellosis	Lassa fever	Leptospirosis	Typhoid fever		D	Typhoid fever	The clinical presentation of a progressively increasing (step-ladder) fever 373, Relative Bradycardia (fever $40^\circ \text{C}$ but pulse rate $64/\text{min}$) 374, Rose Spots (blanching erythematous macules) 375, Hepatosplenomegaly 376, Leucopenia with Lymphopenia 377, and growth of Gram-negative bacilli in blood culture 378378378is the classic description of Typhoid Fever 379379379 (Enteric Fever, caused by Salmonella typhi) 380380380.	Typhoid Fever: Step-ladder fever, Relative Bradycardia, Rose Spots, Hepatosplenomegaly, Leucopenia, Gram-negative bacilli on blood culture381381381381381381381381381.	Infectious Diseases/Typhoid

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P15, Q2: The following are true as regarding to schistosoma infection except:	Haematuria or bleeding per rectum may be the presentation.	Diagnosis can be made by finding ova in the urine and/or stool.	Can be complicated by colorectal cancer.	Can lead to portal hypertension.		C	Can be complicated by colorectal cancer.	Schistosomiasis can cause haematuria (S. haematobium) or rectal bleeding (S. mansoni, S. japonicum). Diagnosis is confirmed by finding characteristic ova in stool or urine. Chronic infection with S. mansoni can lead to periportal fibrosis and portal hypertension. While chronic inflammation exists, a strong link to colorectal cancer is not a typical or common complication.	Schistosoma haematobium is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, not colorectal cancer.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P15, Q3: Which of the following parasites is not a cause for aseptic meningitis:	Naegleria.	Entamoeba histolytica.	Strongyloides stercoralis.	Taenia solium.		B	Entamoeba histolytica.	Naegleria fowleri causes primary amebic meningoencephalitis. Strongyloides stercoralis can cause eosinophilic meningitis in hyperinfection syndrome. Taenia solium (cysticercosis) can cause meningitis. Entamoeba histolytica typically causes amoebic liver abscesses and dysentery, not meningitis.	Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic liver abscess, not meningitis. Aseptic meningitis causes include viruses, parasites (e.g., Angiostrongylus), and fungi.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P15, Q4: Which of the following CSF results suggests viral meningitis:	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose.	Elevated CSF lymphocytic count, normal protein, and normal glucose.	Elevated CSF lymphocytic count, raised protein, and low glucose.	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose.		B	Elevated CSF lymphocytic count, normal protein, and normal glucose.	Viral meningitis typically presents with lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose. Bacterial meningitis shows neutrophilic pleocytosis, high protein, and low glucose.	Viral Meningitis CSF: ↑Lymphocytes, Normal Glucose, Normal/Mildly ↑Protein. Bacterial Meningitis CSF: ↑Neutrophils, ↓Glucose, ↑Protein.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P15, Q5: 45 years old male known to be HIV positive presented with fever, malaise, headache and neck stiffness for the last two days. He undergoes lumbar puncture. The CSF contains markedly increased numbers of neutrophils, high protein and low glucose. What is the antibiotic treatment of choice:	Ampicillin plus Cefotaxime.	Ampicillin plus Aminoglycoside.	Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone.	Vancomycin plus Ampicillin plus Ceftriaxone		C	Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone.	The CSF profile (neutrophils, high protein, low glucose) is classic for bacterial meningitis. In an adult, empiric coverage must include S. pneumoniae (possible resistance) and N. meningitidis. Vancomycin covers resistant pneumococci, and ceftriaxone covers susceptible pneumococci and meningococci. Ampicillin is added if Listeria is suspected (neonates, >50 years, immunocompromised). This patient is immunocompromised (HIV), but the presentation is acute (2 days) and Listeria typically has a more subacute presentation. Standard empiric therapy for community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults is Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone.	Empiric treatment for community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults: Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime. Add Ampicillin if Listeria risk factors (age >50, immunocompromised).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	"P16, Q6: The ""first moment"" in the Five Moments for Hand Hygiene occurs when:"	After patient contact/on leaving the point of care.	Before you put on personal protective equipment (i.e. gloves/aprons).	Before patient contact as possible within the patient zone.	Before you start to gather the equipment that you need to take to the patient’s bedside.		C	Before patient contact as possible within the patient zone.	The WHO's Five Moments for Hand Hygiene are: 1. Before touching a patient. 2. Before clean/aseptic procedure. 3. After body fluid exposure risk. 4. After touching a patient. 5. After touching patient surroundings.	WHO 5 Moments: 1. Before patient contact. 2. Before aseptic task. 3. After body fluid exposure. 4. After patient contact. 5. After contact with patient surroundings.	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P16, Q7: Which one of the following is the most likely presentation of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning:	Tenesmus.	Watery diarrhea.	Dysentry.	Severe vomiting.		D	Severe vomiting.	Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning is caused by preformed enterotoxins. It has a very short incubation period (1-6 hours). The rapid onset of severe vomiting and nausea is characteristic, with diarrhea being less prominent. Tenesmus and dysentery (bloody diarrhea) are not typical.	S. aureus food poisoning: Preformed toxin, short incubation (1-6 hrs), prominent VOMITING.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P16, Q8: For a patient undergoing an elective splenectomy, When is the optimal time to give the pneumococcal vaccine:	Four weeks before surgery.	One week before surgery.	Immediately following surgery.	At least one month after surgery.		A	Four weeks before surgery.	The optimal time for vaccination is at least 2 weeks (ideally 4 weeks) before splenectomy to ensure a robust immune response. Vaccination after surgery is less effective.	Vaccines (Pneumococcal, H. influenzae type B, Meningococcal) should be given at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy.	Vaccines				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P16, Q9: A phlebotomist gives herself a needle stick injury whilst taking blood from a patient with HIV infection. What is the chance that she will develop HIV:	0.05%.	0.3%.	5%.	10%.		B	0.3%.	The average risk of HIV transmission after a percutaneous needlestick injury from a confirmed HIV-positive source is approximately 0.3% (or 1 in 333).	Needlestick HIV transmission risk: ~0.3%. For HCV: ~1.8%. For HBV: 6-30% (if HBeAg positive).	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P16, Q10: Which one of the following statements regarding toxoplasmosis is true:	It is a type of flagellate.	Congenital toxoplasmosis results in optic nerve atrophy.	The cat is the only known animal reservoir.	Infection is usually self-limiting.		D	Infection is usually self-limiting.	Toxoplasma gondii is not a flagellate. Congenital toxoplasmosis classically causes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, not primarily optic nerve atrophy. Cats are the definitive host, but many animals (including humans) are intermediate hosts. In immunocompetent individuals, infection is usually asymptomatic or a self-limiting flu-like illness.	Toxoplasmosis: Definitive host = cat. Self-limiting in immunocompetent. Serious in immunocompromised (brain abscess) and congenital infection (classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications).	Parasitology

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P17, Q13: ______ is one of the most virulent food-borne diseases and is one of the reasons why we pasteurize milk.	Psiiticosis.	Listeria monocytopenes.	Streptobacillus moniliformis.	Cryptosporidium parvum.		B	Listeria monocytopenes.	Listeria monocytogenes is a foodborne pathogen found in unpasteurized dairy products, deli meats, and ready-to-eat foods. It is particularly dangerous for pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals, causing sepsis and meningitis. Pasteurization kills it.	Listeria monocytogenes: Risk for pregnant women (causes granulomatosis infantiseptica), neonates, immunocompromised. Grows at refrigerator temperatures. Treated with Ampicillin.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P17, Q14: Diagnosis of trichinosis by:	Detection of larvae in blood in first week.	Detection of larvae in stool in first week.	Detection of larvae in muscle biopsy in first week.	Detection of larvae in CSF in first week.		C	Detection of larvae in muscle biopsy in first week.	In the first week of Trichinella spiralis infection, larvae migrate to and encyst in striated muscle. A muscle biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test during this acute phase. Serology becomes positive later (after 3 weeks).	Trichinella spiralis: Diagnose by muscle biopsy. Larvae encyst in muscle. Causes periorbital edema, myalgia, eosinophilia.	Parasitology

ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P18, Q22: 54year-old neutropenic man undergoing cancer chemotherapy presents with difficult painful swallowing. Human immunodeficiency virus.		C	Candida albicans. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P18, Q23: A baby is born to a mother who is known to have chronic hepatitis B. The mother latest results are as follows: HBsAg Positive, HBeAg Positive. What is the most appropriate strategy to reduce the vertical transmission rate:	Give the newborn hepatitis B vaccine.	Give the newborn hepatitis B immunoglobulin.	Give the newborn hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immunoglobulin.	Give the mother hepatitis B immunoglobulin shortly before birth + the newborn hepatitis B vaccine.		C	Give the newborn hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immunoglobulin.	For infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers (especially HBeAg-positive, indicating high viral load), the recommended strategy is active-passive immunoprophylaxis: Hepatitis B vaccine AND Hepatitis B Immune Globulin (HBIG) given within 12 hours of birth. D	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P19, Q6: Which of the following are the features of enteric fever in the first week	Continued type pyrexia	Pea-soup diarrhoea	Relative tachycardia	Typhoid state		A	Continued type pyrexia	In the first week of enteric fever (typhoid), step-ladder fever (continuous pattern) is characteristic. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P19, Q8: Cyclical periods of pyrexia alternating with a pyrexia is found in all except:	Relapsing fever	Leprosy	Hodgkin's disease	Brucellosis		B	Leprosy	Relapsing fever (Borrelia) has febrile episodes alternating with afebrile periods. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P19, Q9: Cat-scratch disease is characterized by all except:	Positive Hanger-Rose intra-dermal test	Erythema nodosum	Regional lymphadenopathy	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroids		D	Treated by antibiotic and corticosteroids	Cat-scratch disease (Bartonella henselae) causes regional lymphadenopathy. The Hanger-Rose skin test is historical and not used. Erythema nodosum is a rare complication. Treatment is with antibiotics (e.g., Azithromycin) in severe cases; corticosteroids are not routinely used.	Cat-Scratch Disease: Bartonella henselae. Regional lymphadenopathy. Treat severe cases with Azithromycin.	Bacteriology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P20, Q10: Cerebral malaria is:	Treated by oral quinine sulphate	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Associated with signs of meningeal irritation	IV dexamethasone reduces mortality rate		B	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Cerebral malaria is a severe complication of P. falciparum, treated with IV artesunate or quinine. It is a diffuse encephalopathy, not meningitis, so meningeal signs are absent. It often involves multi-organ failure (renal, hepatic, pulmonary). Steroids are not beneficial and can be harmful.	Cerebral Malaria: P. falciparum. Coma, seizures. Can have multi-organ failure. Treat with IV Artesunate. Steroids are contraindicated.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P20, Q11: Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring how many hours after hospital admission?	At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia that occurs 48 hours or more after admission. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP) is a subset occurring 48 hours or more after endotracheal intubation.	HAP Definition: ≥ 48 hours after hospital admission.	Pneumonia				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page32-44	P20, Q12: Which is true in Widal test:	Relapse bears relationship with agglutinin titre	Agglutinin against flagellar antigen is most important	Agglutinins begin to appear after 3rd day of infection	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week		D	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week	The Widal test detects agglutinating antibodies against O (somatic) and H (flagellar) antigens. O antibodies appear earlier and indicate recent infection. H antibodies persist longer. Titers rise during the second and third weeks, peaking around the fifth or sixth week. A single high titer or a four-fold rise in convalescent titers is diagnostic.	Widal Test: O antigen (recent infection), H antigen (past infection/vaccination). Peak titers at 5-6 weeks.	Bacteriology

It causes skin and eye disease, potentially leading to blindness.	Onchocerciasis (River Blindness): Onchocerca volvulus. Transmitted by black flies. Causes dermatitis and blindness.

ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P5, Q7: Which of the following bacteria is not a cause for bacterial meningitis?	Streptococcus pneumonia	Neisseria meningitides	Escherichia coli	Haemophilus influenza		C	Escherichia coli	E. coli is a cause of neonatal meningitis but uncommon in adults; S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae are common.	Adult bacterial meningitis: S. pneumoniae > N. meningitidis > Listeria (risk factors).	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P5, Q8: Which of the following organisms causes epidemic meningitis cases at military recruits?	Haemophilus influenzae type b	Neisseria meningitides	Streptococcus pneumonia	Listeria monocytogenes		B	Neisseria meningitides	N. meningitidis causes epidemics in crowded settings like military barracks and college dormitories.	N. meningitidis → epidemics, petechial rash, Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P5, Q9: Which of the following groups of viruses is most likely to cause meningitis?	Adenoviruses	Human papillomaviruses	Poxviruses	Enteroviruses		D	Enteroviruses	Enteroviruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus) are the most common cause of viral meningitis.	Viral meningitis: enteroviruses most common; also HSV-2, VZV, arboviruses.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q10: Aseptic meningitis diagnosed when ......	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain but not by bacterial cultures	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain but detected by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain and bacterial cultures	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures		D	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	Aseptic meningitis: CSF pleocytosis with negative Gram stain and cultures; often viral cause.	Aseptic meningitis = negative stains/cultures; viral most common.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q11: Classic symptoms of meningitis usually include ......	Backache, hallucinations, indigestion	Rash, inner ear pain, itching	Dry skin, dehydration, cold sore	Fever, headache, stiff neck		D	Fever, headache, stiff neck	The classic triad of meningitis is fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity (stiff neck).	Meningitis triad: fever, headache, nuchal rigidity; not all present.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q12: Classic triad of meningitis requires the followings to be present except:	Fever	Cranial nerve abnormalities	Nuchal rigidity	Altered mental status		B	Cranial nerve abnormalities	The classic triad is fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status; cranial nerve deficits are not part of the triad.	Classic triad: fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status; only 1/3 have all three.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q13: Which of the following signs is not a sign of meningeal irritation?	Nuchal rigidity	Kernig's sign	Babinski's sign	Brudzinski's sign		C	Babinski's sign	Babinski sign indicates upper motor neuron lesion, not meningeal irritation; Kernig and Brudzinski are meningeal signs.	Meningeal signs: Kernig, Brudzinski; Babinski = UMN lesion.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q14: Non-blanching petechiae and cutaneous hemorrhages may be present in meningitis caused by ...	Viruses	Parasites	Bacteria	TB		C	Bacteria	Non-blanching petechiae/purpura suggest bacterial meningitis, especially N. meningitidis (meningococcemia).	Petechial rash → think N. meningitidis; medical emergency.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q15: 26 years old female presented with fever, malaise, headache and neck stiffness for the last two days. On examination which cranial nerves can be affected?	I, II, III	III, IV, VI	V, IX, X	VIII, X, XI		B	III, IV, VI	Cranial nerves III, IV, VI can be affected in meningitis due to increased ICP or inflammation at the base of the brain.	CN III, IV, VI palsies in meningitis; also CN VII, VIII.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P6, Q16: Which procedure is most likely used to test for Meningitis?	Throat culture	Lumbar puncture	Tuberculosis skin test	Urine analysis		B	Lumbar puncture	Lumbar puncture for CSF analysis is key for diagnosing meningitis (cell count, protein, glucose, culture).	LP for CSF analysis → diagnosis of meningitis; imaging first if ↑ICP suspected.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q17: Which of the following is not an immediate complication of meningitis?	Septic shock	Blindness	Coma	Seizures		B	Blindness	Blindness is a potential late complication; immediate complications include shock, coma, seizures, DIC.	Immediate: shock, seizures, coma; late: hearing loss, hydrocephalus, blindness.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q18: The differential diagnoses of Meningitis includes the followings except ……	Encephalitis	Brain Neoplasms	Pneumonia	Stroke Meningitis		C	Pneumonia	Pneumonia is not a direct differential for meningitis; encephalitis, brain tumors, and stroke can mimic symptoms.	Meningitis DDx: encephalitis, SAH, brain abscess, carcinomatous meningitis.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q19: Blood culture is positive in meningitis caused by ….	Neisseria Meningitides	TB	Aseptic meningitis	Parasites		A	Neisseria Meningitides	Blood cultures are often positive in bacterial meningitis, especially N. meningitidis and S. pneumoniae.	Blood culture positive in ~50% bacterial meningitis; LP still needed.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q20: Lumbar Puncture needle for CSF analysis is inserted between ….	L1-L2	L3-L4	L4-L5	L5-S1		C	L4-L5	LP is typically performed at L4-L5 or L3-L4 level to avoid the spinal cord (ends at L1-L2 in adults).	LP at L3-L4 or L4-L5; cord ends at L1-L2.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q21: Which of the following CSF results suggests bacterial meningitis?	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, normal protein, and normal glucose	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose		B	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose	Bacterial meningitis: neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose (CSF:serum glucose <0.4).	Bacterial: high neutrophils, high protein, low glucose; Viral: lymphocytosis, normal glucose.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q22: Which of the following is true about the CSF changes in patients with tuberculous meningitis?	The cell count is often elevated, and the cells are mainly neutrophils	The cell count is normal, and the cells are mainly neutrophils	The cell count is often elevated, and the cells are mainly lymphocytes	The cell count is normal, and the cells are mainly lymphocytes		C	The cell count is often elevated, and the cells are mainly lymphocytes	TB meningitis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, very high protein, low glucose; may show fibrin web.	TB meningitis: lymphocytes, very high protein, low glucose; AFB smear often negative.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P7, Q23: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency with a 1-day history of severe headache, fever, discomfort when looking at the lights and neck stiffness. He is diabetic for 10 years. There is a non-blanching rash observed on his trunk. On examination his temperature is at 39°C.The most likely causative organism is ……	Strongyloides stercoralis	Neisseria Meningitides	Human herpes virus	TB		B	Neisseria Meningitides	Non-blanching rash + meningeal signs = meningococcal meningitis; photophobia and fever are common.	Petechial/purpuric rash + meningitis = N. meningitidis; medical emergency.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q24: 45 years old male known to be HIV positive presented with fever, malaise, headache and neck stiffness for the last two days. He undergoes lumbar puncture. The CSF contains markedly increased numbers of neutrophils, high protein and low glucose. What the antibiotic treatment of choice?	Ampicillin plus Cefotaxime	Ampicillin plus Aminoglycoside	Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone	Vancomycin plus Ampicillin plus Ceftriaxone		C	Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone			Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q1: Sepsis is a serious body wide response to bacteremia or other type of infection plus malfunction or failure of an essential system in the body. Which of the following is always one of the body's responses to sepsis?	Abnormally high or low number of white blood cells	Abnormally high temperature (fever) or low temperature (hypothermia)	Rapid breathing rate	Rapid heart rate		B	Abnormally high temperature (fever) or low temperature (hypothermia)			Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q2: Sepsis is caused by infection with certain types of bacteria. In which of the following locations is an infection leading to septic shock most often acquired?	In schools	In hospitals	From contaminated food in restaurants and cafeterias	In workplaces		B	In hospitals	Hospital-acquired infections are a common cause of sepsis due to resistant organisms and invasive procedures.	Sepsis often hospital-acquired; think nosocomial infections, catheters, ventilators.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q3: Each of the following increases the likelihood of developing an infection that will lead to sepsis EXCEPT:	Being between the ages of 5 and 15 years	Having a disorder that weakens the immune system, such as AIDS or cancer	Having a medical device, such as a catheter or breathing tube, inserted into the body	Using recreational drugs that are injected into the bloodstream		A	Being between the ages of 5 and 15 years	Ages 5-15 have lower sepsis risk; extremes of age (<1, >65) and immunocompromise increase risk.	Sepsis risk: extremes of age, immunocompromise, devices, comorbidities.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q4: Which of the following statement regarding sepsis is not true:	Sepsis is SIRS plus documented infection.	A causative organism is found in 90% of cases.	A high serum lactate is an evidence of poor tissue perfusion.	> 50% of ICU patients develop sepsis during the course of their admission.	The true incidence of sepsis is likely to be lower than estimated.	B	A causative organism is found in 90% of cases.	In sepsis, a causative organism is identified in only about 30-50% of cases, not 90%.	Blood cultures positive in ~30-50% sepsis cases; often no organism identified.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P8, Q5: The following may be required to diagnose SIRS * Positive blood cultures Except:	White cell count <4	Temperature > 38C	PaCO2 > 6.5	Heart Rate > 90 beat/min		C	PaCO2 > 6.5			Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P9, Q6: The following may precipitate severe Sepsis or SIRS	Peritonitis	Massive Transfusion	Pneumonia	Candidcemia	Burns	B	Massive Transfusion	Massive transfusion can cause TRALI or TACO but is not a direct cause of sepsis; infections like peritonitis, pneumonia, candidemia are.	Sepsis triggers: pneumonia, UTI, abdominal infections, bacteremia.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P9, Q7: The following substances are involved in causation of the clinical features of Sepsis Except:	Inducible Nitric Oxide	Interleukin – 6	Acetyl cysteine	Tumor Necrosis Factor		C	Acetyl cysteine	Acetylcysteine is an antioxidant used in acetaminophen overdose, not a mediator of sepsis; TNF-α, IL-6, iNOS are.	Sepsis mediators: TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6, iNOS → vasodilation, hypotension.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P9, Q8: The following features may be present in a patient presenting with severe sepsis Except:	Hypotension	Oliguria	Hypertension	Confusion	Cool peripheries	C	Hypertension	Hypotension, not hypertension, is characteristic of severe sepsis and septic shock.	Severe sepsis: hypotension, oliguria, confusion, cool extremities → septic shock.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P9, Q9: In patients with severe sepsis Except	Administration of antibiotics is time dependent	Vasopressors should be given to those who remain hypotensive despite fluid resuscitation	A central venous oxygen saturation of 80% reliably excludes tissue hypoxia	Management should be in an ICU setting		C	A central venous oxygen saturation of 80% reliably excludes tissue hypoxia	ScvO2 >70% is normal; 80% does not reliably exclude tissue hypoxia in sepsis; lactate clearance is better.	Sepsis management: early antibiotics, fluids, vasopressors if hypotensive, ICU care.	Critical Care				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q1: The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, Except:	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection.		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection.	Leptospirosis is transmitted via contact with water contaminated by urine of infected animals (rodents, livestock), not lice.	Leptospira reservoirs: rodents, dogs, livestock; transmission: contaminated water/soil.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q2: The following symptoms and signs are true regarding anicteric leptospirosis, Except?	Flu Like Symptoms	Nausea And Vomiting	Exudative conjunctivitis	Pharyngitis		C	Exudative conjunctivitis			Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q3: How is leptospirosis transmitted?	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	By mosquito bites	By contact with the infected person			A	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	Leptospira enters through cuts/abraded skin or mucous membranes exposed to contaminated water/soil.	Transmission: contact with contaminated water/soil; not person-to-person.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q4: Which are the two types of leptospirosis?	Icteric and Anicteric	Edematous and Non edematous	Hemorrhagic and non-hemorrhagic	Benign and malignant		A	Icteric and Anicteric	Leptospirosis: anicteric (mild, self-limited) and icteric (severe, Weil's disease with jaundice, AKI).	Leptospirosis: anicteric (90%) and icteric (Weil's disease).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q5: Which form of leptospirosis is known as Weill's disease?	Icteric	Anicteric	Both			A	Icteric	Weil's disease is the severe icteric form with jaundice, AKI, hemorrhage, and high mortality.	Weil's disease = icteric leptospirosis; triad: jaundice, AKI, hemorrhage.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q6: A 44-year-old farmer presents with headache, fever and muscle aches. He initially thought he had a bad cold but his symptoms have got progressively worse over the past week. During the review of systems he reports nausea and a decreased urine output. On examination his temperature is 38.2°C, pulse 102 / min and his chest is clear. Subconjunctival haemorrhages are noted but there is no evidence of jaundice. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Lyme disease	Legionella pneumonia	Listeria	Leptospirosis	E	Leptospirosis	Fever, myalgia, conjunctival hemorrhage, AKI in a farmer suggests leptospirosis (anicteric form).	Leptospirosis: farmer, fever, myalgia, conjunctival hemorrhage, AKI.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P10, Q7: A 34-year-old sewage worker presents with a 3 days history of lower back pain, fever, myalgia, fatigue, jaundice and a subconjunctival haemorrhage. He has no past medical history and has not been abroad in the last 6 months. Na+ : 135 mmol/l - K+ : 5.2 mmol/l - Urea : 10 mmol/l – Creatinine : 180 μmol/l . What is the most likely diagnosis?	Leptospirosis	Cysticercosis	Glomerulonephritis	Hepatitis A	Hepatitis E	A	Leptospirosis	Sewage worker + fever + jaundice + AKI + conjunctival hemorrhage = Weil's disease (icteric leptospirosis).	Weil's disease: jaundice, AKI, hemorrhage, conjunctival suffusion.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q9: A 37-year-old sewer worker presents to the Emergency Department with flu-like symptoms and pyrexia for the past 3 days. Since this morning he has started to develop a headache and signs of meningism are found on examination. Blood tests show: Sodium 145 mmol/l - Potassium 4.7 mmol/l - Urea 10.3 mmol/l - Creatinine 133 µmol/l . What is the antibiotic treatment of choice?	Co-trimoxazole	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	Benzylpenicillin	Erythromycin	D	Benzylpenicillin	Penicillin G is first-line for severe leptospirosis; doxycycline or ceftriaxone are alternatives.	Leptospirosis treatment: penicillin G, doxycycline, ceftriaxone.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q10: A 50-year-old sewage worker presents with a one week history of fever and feeling generally unwell. Which one of the following features would be least consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis?	Meningism	Conjunctival erythema	Productive cough	Decreased urine output	Severe myalgia	C	Productive cough	Leptospirosis causes non-productive cough; productive cough suggests pneumonia, not typical for leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis: dry cough may occur; productive cough not typical.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q1: The intermediate host for Schistosoma mansoni is:	Bulinus snail	Biomphalaria snail	Oncomelania snail	Lymnaea snail		B	Biomphalaria snail	S. mansoni uses Biomphalaria snails; S. haematobium uses Bulinus; S. japonicum uses Oncomelania.	Schistosoma intermediate hosts: mansoni→Biomphalaria, haematobium→Bulinus, japonicum→Oncomelania.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q2: Humans acquire schistosomiasis mainly by:	Ingesting contaminated water	Eating infected fish	Skin penetration by cercariae	Inhalation of spores		C	Skin penetration by cercariae	Cercariae in freshwater penetrate the skin, causing schistosomiasis (swimmer's itch).	Schistosomiasis: cercariae penetrate skin → schistosomula → adults in veins.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q3: The diagnostic form of S. mansoni in stool is:	Egg with terminal spine	Egg with lateral spine	Miracidium	Cercaria		B	Egg with lateral spine	S. mansoni eggs have a lateral spine; S. haematobium has terminal spine; S. japonicum has small lateral knob.	Schistosome eggs: mansoni (lateral spine), haematobium (terminal spine), japonicum (small lateral knob).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P11, Q4: The major pathological lesion in schistosomiasis is caused by:	Adult worms	Cercariae	Eggs trapped in tissues and host immune response	Miracidia		C	Eggs trapped in tissues and host immune response	Eggs lodged in tissues induce granulomatous inflammation and fibrosis (e.g., liver periportal fibrosis).	Schistosomiasis pathology: egg granulomas → fibrosis (pipe-stem fibrosis in liver).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q5: Which test is most useful for detecting active schistosomiasis infection?	Serological test (ELISA)	Microscopic detection of eggs	Skin test	Complement fixation test		B	Microscopic detection of eggs	Egg detection in stool/urine is diagnostic for active infection; serology indicates exposure but not active disease.	Active schistosomiasis: detect eggs in stool (mansoni/japonicum) or urine (haematobium).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q6: Chronic S. Haematobium infection may lead to:	Hepatocellular carcinoma	Bladder carcinoma (squamous cell type)	Colorectal carcinoma	Pancreatic carcinoma		B	Bladder carcinoma (squamous cell type)	Chronic S. haematobium infection causes squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, not transitional cell.	S. haematobium → chronic cystitis → squamous cell bladder cancer.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q7: Which laboratory feature is typical in Hepato-Splenic schistosomiasis?	Elevated serum bilirubin	Elevated transaminases (AST, ALT)	Normal liver enzymes despite massive splenomegaly	Decreased alkaline phosphatase		C	Normal liver enzymes despite massive splenomegaly	In hepato-splenic schistosomiasis, liver synthetic function is preserved; transaminases often normal.	Hepato-splenic schistosomiasis: preserved liver function, normal transaminases, portal hypertension.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q8: Cerebral schistosomiasis is most commonly caused by:	S. haematobium	S. japonicum	S. mansoni	S. mekongi		B	S. japonicum	S. japonicum most commonly causes CNS disease (cerebral granulomas) due to smaller eggs that embolize.	Cerebral schistosomiasis: S. japonicum most common; presents with seizures.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q9: Ultrasound of hepatosplenic schistosomiasis typically shows:	Nodular surface and shrunken liver	Periportal fibrosis with thickened echogenic bands and splenomegaly	Biliary duct dilatation	Diffuse fatty infiltration		B	Periportal fibrosis with thickened echogenic bands and splenomegaly	"Ultrasound shows periportal fibrosis (""pipe-stem"" appearance) and splenomegaly from portal hypertension."	US in schistosomiasis: periportal fibrosis, splenomegaly; liver size normal or increased.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q10: In intestinal schistosomiasis, the typical colonoscopic appearance is:	Aphthous ulcers	Pseudopolyps with granulomas containing eggs	Mucosal atrophy	Thickened folds with bile staining		B	Pseudopolyps with granulomas containing eggs	Colonoscopy shows inflammatory pseudopolyps due to granulomatous reaction to eggs in the bowel wall.	Intestinal schistosomiasis: pseudopolyps on colonoscopy; can cause bloody diarrhea.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P12, Q1: Which is the infective form of the malaria parasite?	Oocyst	Sporozoite	Bradyzoite	Tachyzoite		B	Sporozoite	Sporozoites from mosquito salivary glands infect humans; they travel to liver and initiate infection.	Malaria infective form: sporozoite (from mosquito); diagnostic form: blood stage trophozoites.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q2: Trophozoites, schizonts, and gametocytes of all the malarial parasites are seen in the peripheral blood smear Except;	P. falciparum	P. malariae	P. ovale	P. vivax		A	P. falciparum	P. falciparum usually shows only rings and gametocytes; older stages sequester in microvasculature.	P. falciparum: only rings and gametocytes in peripheral blood; sequestration.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q3: Blackwater fever is a special manifestation of malaria caused by;	P. falciparum	P. malariae	P. ovale	P. vivax		A	P. falciparum	Blackwater fever (massive hemolysis, hemoglobinuria) is associated with P. falciparum infection.	Blackwater fever: P. falciparum; due hemolysis → hemoglobinuria → dark urine.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q4: After sporozoite gain entrance to the human body, it undergoes a developmental cycle first in the liver than in RBC, only after which fever is seen. This incubation period varies be-tween plasmodium species, and has the longest incubation period ...... species.	P. falciparum	P. malariae	P. ovale	P. vivax		B	P. malariae	P. malariae has the longest incubation period (18-40 days or more); P. falciparum 7-14 days, P. vivax 8-17 days.	Longest incubation: P. malariae; can present years after exposure.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q5: All of the following statement(s) regarding Plasmodium falciparum are true, Except ?	causes more severe disease in pregnancy	is associated with recurrent relapses after initial treatment because of liver hypnozoites	is the only malarial parasite causing greater than 20% parasitemia	infection is typically associated with thrombocytopenia	is the only cause of cerebral malaria	B	is associated with recurrent relapses after initial treatment because of liver hypnozoites	P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites; relapse occurs in P. vivax and P. ovale due to hypnozoites.	Hypnozoites: P. vivax and P. ovale; P. falciparum and P. malariae do not.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q6: Mosquitoes is/are the vector in the following disorder(s)	Onchocerciasis	Visceral leishmaniasis	African trypanosomiasis	Bancroftian filariasis		D	Bancroftian filariasis	Wuchereria bancrofti (Bancroftian filariasis) is mosquito-borne; onchocerciasis by blackflies, leishmaniasis by sandflies, African trypanosomiasis by tsetse flies.	Filariasis: W. bancrofti and B. malayi → mosquitoes; Onchocerca → blackflies.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q7: Which of the following statement(s) regarding vivax malaria is (are) true:	may be complicated by anemia	may be complicated by jaundice	in a traveler may present more than six months after exposure	is sensitive to chloroquine	may co-exist with falciparum malaria in the same patient	A,B,C,D,E	All of the above	All options are true for P. vivax; it can cause anemia, jaundice, late relapse (>6 months), is chloroquine-sensitive, and can co-infect with P. falciparum.	P. vivax: chloroquine-sensitive, relapses, Duffy antigen negative resistant.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P13, Q8: Crescent-shaped or banana-shaped gametocytes are seen in infection with:	Plasmodium vivax	Plasmodium falciparum	Plasmodium ovale	Plasmodium malariae		B	Plasmodium falciparum	P. falciparum gametocytes are crescent-shaped; other species have round gametocytes.	P. falciparum: crescent gametocytes; other species: round gametocytes.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q9: Match the following dots with the Plasmodium species in which it is prominently seen.	a. Maurer's dots	b. Schüffner's dots	c. Ziemann's dots	d. James' dots			Schüffner's dots = P. vivax; Maurer's dots = P. falciparum; Ziemann's dots = P. malariae; James' dots = P. ovale	Schüffner's dots: P. vivax/P. ovale; Maurer's dots: P. falciparum; Ziemann's dots: P. malariae.	Parasitology					
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q10: A clinical situation in which the immune system or a therapy failed to eliminate all the Plasmodium spp infected erythrocytes and numbers of Plasmodium spp in RBCs begin to in-crease again with subsequent clinical symptoms is called;	Latency	Re-infection	Relapse	Recrudescence		D	Recrudescence	Recrudescence is recurrence from persistent blood-stage infection (P. falciparum/malariae); relapse is from hypnozoites (P. vivax/ovale).	Recrudescence = blood stages; Relapse = hypnozoites; Reinfection = new bite.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q1: All the following parasites inhibit the large intestine:	Ascaris lumercoids	Sterogyloides stercoralis	Ankylstoma	Enterobius vermicularis		D	Enterobius vermicularis	Enterobius (pinworm) inhabits the cecum and large intestine; Ascaris, Strongyloides, Ancylostoma are small intestine.	Large intestine: Enterobius, Trichuris; Small intestine: Ascaris, Ancylostoma, Strongyloides.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q2: ALL the following tape worms are transmitted via ingestion of improbably cooked meat except:	Tinae solium	Tinae saginata	Diphylobothrium latum			C	Diphylobothrium latum	Diphyllobothrium is from undercooked fish; Taenia solium (pork) and saginata (beef) from meat.	Tapeworms: T. solium (pork), T. saginata (beef), Diphyllobothrium (fish).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q3: All the following parasites can be complicated by acute appendicitis except:	Hymenolepis nana	Tinae saginata	Tinae solium	Ascaris lumbercoids		B	Tinae saginata	T. saginata rarely causes appendicitis; others can obstruct or inflame the appendix.	Appendicitis: Ascaris, Enterobius, Taenia solium, Hymenolepis.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P14, Q4: The following parasite enter the human body via skin:	Enterobius vermicularis	Ankylostoma doudenale	Tinae solium	Ascaris lumercoid		B	Ankylostoma doudenale	Ancylostoma (hookworm) larvae penetrate skin; Enterobius and Taenia via ingestion; Ascaris eggs ingested.	Skin penetration: hookworms (Ancylostoma, Necator), Strongyloides, Schistosomes.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P15, Q1: The characteristic rash seen in typhoid fever is:	Maculopapular rash on palms and soles	Rose spots on the abdomen and chest	Vesicular rash over trunk	Petechial rash over lower limbs		B	Rose spots on the abdomen and chest	Rose spots are faint, pink, blanching macules on trunk in typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi.	Typhoid rash: rose spots (trunk), relative bradycardia, step-ladder fever.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	"P15, Q2: The ""step-ladder"" pattern of fever is characteristic of:"	Typhoid fever	Malaria	Brucellosis	Dengue fever		A	Typhoid fever	Typhoid fever shows step-ladder fever (rising temperature over days); malaria has hectic fever, brucellosis undulant.	Typhoid: step-ladder fever, relative bradycardia, rose spots.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P15, Q3: Which organ is primarily involved in the chronic carrier state of typhoid?	Liver	Gallbladder	Spleen	Kidney		B	Gallbladder	Chronic carriers harbor S. typhi in the gallbladder (especially if gallstones), shedding bacteria in stool.	Typhoid carrier: gallbladder; treated with cholecystectomy if chronic.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P15, Q4: The Widal test detects antibodies against which antigens?	O and H antigens of Salmonella typhi	M and T antigens of Streptococcus	O and K antigens of Vibrio cholera	A and B antigens of E. coli		A	O and H antigens of Salmonella typhi	Widal test detects O (somatic) and H (flagellar) antibodies; limited use due to cross-reactivity and vaccination.	Widal test: anti-O and anti-H antibodies; not reliable in endemic areas.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q5: One of the serious complications of untreated typhoid fever is:	Hepatic failure	Intestinal perforation	Acute glomerulonephritis	Meningitis		B	Intestinal perforation	Typhoid can cause ileal perforation due to necrosis of Peyer's patches in the terminal ileum.	Typhoid complications: ileal perforation, GI hemorrhage, encephalopathy.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q6: The most important laboratory finding in severe cholera is:	Leukocytosis	Hyponatremia and hypokalemia	Hyperglycemia	Elevated liver enzymes		B	Hyponatremia and hypokalemia	Cholera causes isotonic dehydration; stool loss of K+ and HCO3- leads to hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.	Cholera: painless watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, no fever.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q7: The most effective preventive measure against cholera in endemic areas is:	Use of antibiotics	Vaccination and safe water supply	Avoiding raw vegetables	Vitamin supplementation		B	Vaccination and safe water supply	Safe water, sanitation, and oral cholera vaccines are key for prevention; antibiotics are for treatment.	Cholera prevention: safe water, sanitation, vaccines (oral).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q8: The Vibrio cholera is best described as:	Gram-positive coccus	Gram-negative comma-shaped bacillus	Gram-negative cocci	Gram-positive rod		B	Gram-negative comma-shaped bacillus	V. cholerae is a gram-negative, comma-shaped, oxidase-positive bacterium.	V. cholerae: gram-negative comma, oxidase+, single polar flagellum.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q9: The cornerstone of treatment in cholera is:	Antibiotic therapy	Rehydration therapy (oral or IV)	Antispasmodic drugs	Corticosteroids		B	Rehydration therapy (oral or IV)	Oral rehydration solution (ORS) or IV fluids are essential; antibiotics reduce duration but are secondary.	Cholera treatment: rehydration first (ORS/IV), then antibiotics (doxycycline).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q10: The characteristic stool appearance in cholera is described as:	Bloody with mucus	Foul-smelling and greenish	Rice-water stool	Mucoid with pus cells		C	Rice-water stool	Cholera stool is clear, flecked with mucus, like rice-water; massive fluid loss.	Cholera stool: rice-water, isotonic, no blood, no pus.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q1: Symptoms of a heat-related illness include all of the following EXCEPT:	dizziness and disorientation.	thirst and light sweating.	no sweating, but dry, hot skin.	cramps.		B	thirst and light sweating.	Thirst and light sweating are normal responses to heat; the others indicate heat illness (cramps, exhaustion, stroke).	Heat illness: cramps, exhaustion, stroke; dry hot skin = heat stroke.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P16, Q2: The most important factors affecting evaporation when exercising are:	heat and humidity.	duration.	time of day.	intensity.		A	heat and humidity.	High humidity impairs evaporative cooling; heat and humidity are the key environmental factors.	Heat loss: evaporation impaired by high humidity.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q3: Which of the following environments would allow for the best convective cooling?	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	running in the winter wearing a sweat suit, cap, and gloves	running on a track in an enclosed gym	running outside in 80-degree F weather and 80-percent humidity		A	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	Convective cooling is enhanced by air movement (wind) carrying heat away from the body.	Convective cooling: wind; impaired by clothing, still air.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q4: Which of the following groups is the MOST susceptible to heat illness?	the highly fit	the elderly	high school students	those jogging by themselves		B	the elderly	Elderly have reduced thermoregulation, chronic diseases, and medications increasing heat illness risk.	Heat illness risk: elderly, children, chronic disease, drugs (diuretics, anticholinergics).	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q5: The result of evaporation is:	no change in temperature.	warming.	cooling.	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.		D	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.	Evaporation of sweat causes cooling (latent heat of vaporization).	Evaporation → cooling; impaired if humid.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q6: The best way to determine if environmental conditions are imposing a heat load on your body is to:	take your temperature.	weigh yourself before and after exercise to measure water weight loss.	monitor your heart rate.	measure your blood pressure.		C	monitor your heart rate.			Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q7: In order to minimize the possibility of overheating, exercise clothing should be all of the following EXCEPT:	lightweight.	minimal.	dry.	cotton or linen.		C	dry.	Cotton absorbs sweat and reduces evaporation; synthetic wicking fabrics are better for cooling.	Exercise clothing: lightweight, light-colored, wicking fabric; avoid cotton.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q8: Heat acclimatization:	decreases the exercise heart rate.	increases the risk of heat injuries.	needs more research before it should even be considered.	increases body temperature.		A	decreases the exercise heart rate.	Acclimatization improves sweating, cardiovascular stability, and reduces heart rate during heat exposure.	Heat acclimatization: lower HR, higher sweat rate, earlier sweating.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q9: Symptoms of heat exhaustion are:	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	increased blood pressure.	seizures.	hot, red, dry skin.		A	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	Heat exhaustion: sweating, cool/clammy skin, weakness, nausea; heat stroke: hot/dry skin, CNS dysfunction.	Heat exhaustion: sweaty, tired, dizzy; Heat stroke: hot, dry, confused.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P17, Q10: Heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke are similar in all the following ways EXCEPT:	very heavy sweating.	significant loss of water and electrolytes.	high inner core temperature of the body.	increased heat storage in the body.		A	very heavy sweating.	Heat stroke may have absent sweating (anhidrosis); cramps and exhaustion typically have sweating.	Heat stroke may have no sweating; cramps and exhaustion have sweating.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P18, Q11: When exercising in the heat, it is recommended that all of the following be kept in mind EXCEPT:	monitor your heart rate.	keep the exercise session short.	drink plenty of water before, during and after the workout.	take a salt tablet after the workout.		D	take a salt tablet after the workout.	Salt tablets can cause hypernatremia; electrolyte replacement is better through balanced fluids/food.	Hydration: water + electrolytes; avoid salt tablets (can cause hypernatremia).	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P18, Q12: Heat injury can occur when the activity heat load exceeds the body's ability to regulate body temperature. Which of the following is not a common type of heat injury?	heat evaporation	heat cramps	heat exhaustion	heat stroke		A	heat evaporation	Heat evaporation is not a injury; heat cramps, exhaustion, and stroke are the common heat injuries.	"Heat injuries: cramps, exhaustion, stroke; no ""heat evaporation""."	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P18, Q1: In the US, which of the following is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis?	Cytomegalovirus	Herpes simplex	Lymphocytic choriomeningitis	Varicella-zoster		B	Herpes simplex	HSV-1 is the most common cause of sporadic viral encephalitis in the US; often affects temporal lobes. ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P18, Q2: Because prompt identification of the cause of encephalitis via PCR is difficult, treatment should not be withheld pending test results and should consist of which of the following?	Acyclovir	Ganciclovir	Immune globulin	Prednisone		A	Acyclovir	Empiric acyclovir for suspected viral encephalitis covers HSV while awaiting PCR results. ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P20, Q1: Which of the following best defines Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO) in adults?	Fever >38°C for more than 3 days	Fever >38.3°C on several occasions for more than 3 weeks, undiagnosed after 1 week of inpatient evaluation	Fever >39°C for more than 1 week, undiagnosed after 48 hours of investigation	Fever >37.5°C for more than 2 weeks, undiagnosed after outpatient assessment		B	Fever >38.3°C on several occasions for more than 3 weeks, undiagnosed after 1 week of inpatient evaluation	Classic FUO: fever >38.3°C for ≥3 weeks, unknown cause after 1 week of intensive evaluation.	FUO definition: >38.3°C, >3 weeks, unknown after 1 week investigation.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q2: The most common cause of FUO in adults is:	Infection	Neoplasm	Autoimmune disease	Drug fever		A	Infection	Infections are the most common cause of FUO worldwide; then autoimmune diseases and malignancies.	FUO causes: infections > autoimmune > malignancies > other.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q3: Which of the following infections is a well-known cause of FUO?	Influenza	Brucellosis	Viral gastroenteritis	Common cold		B	Brucellosis	Brucellosis causes undulant fever and is a classic cause of FUO; also TB, endocarditis, abscesses.	FUO infections: TB, endocarditis, brucellosis, typhoid, CMV, EBV.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q4: Which malignancy is most commonly associated with FUO? ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q5: Among the following, which autoimmune disease is a frequent cause of FUO? Autoimmune FUO: Still's disease, SLE, granulomatosis, temporal arteritis.	Rheumatology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q6: Which of the following features suggests drug-induced fever as a cause of FUO?	Fever subsides with continued drug use	Associated eosinophilia and rash	Presence of focal infection	Bradycardia is never seen		B	Associated eosinophilia and rash	Drug fever often has eosinophilia, rash, relative bradycardia; fever resolves after stopping the drug.	Drug fever: eosinophilia, rash, no tachycardia, resolves after discontinuation.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q7: The first step in the evaluation of FUO is:	PET-CT scan	Bone marrow biopsy	Detailed history and repeated physical examination	Empirical antibiotic therapy		C	Detailed history and repeated physical examination	History (travel, exposures, medications) and repeated physical exam are crucial first steps in FUO workup.	FUO workup: history, physical, basic labs, then imaging/targeted tests.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P21, Q8: In children, the most common cause of FUO is:	Malignancy	Infection	Rheumatologic disease	Drug fever		B	Infection	Infections are the most common cause of FUO in children, followed by rheumatologic conditions.	Pediatric FUO: infections > connective tissue > malignancies.	Pediatrics				
ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P22, Q9: A 45-year-old man presents with FUO. ESR is high, ferritin markedly elevated, ANA negative, and rash appears during fever spikes.
