ريحانة الطبMCQ of lectures	P23, Q7: 38 years old female farmer, rural village in West Africa, high fever, Fatigue, Severe joint and muscle pain, persistent nausea & vomiting, disoriented and slurred speech - Elevated liver enzymes & heart rate - Hypotension - Wide spread petechiae and ecchymosis - Active bleeding from gums - Congested Conjunctiva & hepatomegaly - Decrease platelet and WBCs count The health care team suspect hemorrhagic fever, what is the most likely mode of transmission for the suspected hemorrhagic fever? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P65, Q1: A 46-year-old woman presents 3 days after returning from a safari holiday in Tanzania. She complains of fever, chills, myalgia and malaise which started 2 days ago and now complains of daytime somnolence and night time insomnia. Her husband also reports she has been acting strangely. She says she took malarone as antimalarial prophylaxis and had all the recommended vaccines before travelling. A HIV test was negative. On examination her temperature is 38.5°C, heart rate 90/min, blood pressure 118/90 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Cerebral malaria	Human African Trypanosomiasis	Yellow fever	Tuberculosis meningitis	Bacterial meningitis	B	Human African Trypanosomiasis	Sleep-wake cycle reversal and behavioral changes are classic for African trypanosomiasis. Malaria prophylaxis makes cerebral malaria unlikely.	Sleep-wake reversal = African trypanosomiasis; tsetse fly vector.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P65, Q2: A 43-year-old Asian man presents with headache and neck stiffness. CT brain is normal and a lumbar puncture is performed with the following results: Serum glucose 4.7 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture reveals: Opening pressure 15 cmCSF, Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 3.3 mmol/l, Protein 0.7 g/l, White cells 100 / mm³ (70% lymphocytes). What is the most likely diagnosis?	Bacterial meningitis	Viral meningitis	Tuberculous meningitis	Normal CSF result	Cryptococcal meningitis	B	Viral meningitis	CSF shows lymphocytosis with glucose >50% of serum level, characteristic of viral meningitis. TB meningitis typically has low glucose.	Viral meningitis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P66, Q3: Which one of the following organisms causes lymphogranuloma venereum? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P66, Q4: A 39-year-old female who has recently emigrated from sub-Saharan Africa is screened for tuberculosis. She reports being fit and well with no past medical history and has never had a BCG vaccination. Her chest x-ray is normal so she has a Mantoux test which is positive. An interferon gamma test is also performed which is positive. A HIV test is requested which is negative. What treatment would you recommend?	3 months of isoniazid (with pyridoxine) and rifampicin OR 6 months of isoniazid (with pyridoxine)	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol for 6 months	Observe	Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol for 2 months then step down to rifampicin and isoniazid for 4 months	3 months of pyrazinamide and isoniazid OR 6 months of pyrazinamide	A	3 months of isoniazid (with pyridoxine) and rifampicin OR 6 months of isoniazid (with pyridoxine)	Positive Mantoux and IGRA with normal CXR indicates latent TB. Treatment is 3 months of isoniazid + rifampicin or 6 months of isoniazid.	Latent TB: 3HR or 6H; Active TB: 2HRZE/4HR.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P67, Q5: A 28-year-old medical student presents to the infectious diseases ward with fevers, lethargy and a productive cough that has been ongoing for two weeks. He has recently returned to the UK following an elective period spent volunteering in refugee camps overseas. He has no significant past medical history. Prior to his travel, the patient received all appropriate vaccinations and received the BCG vaccine prior to starting his studies 4 years ago. White Cell Count 13 x10^9/l, C-reactive Protein 240 mg/L, Na+ 137 mmol/L, Chest X-ray Left upper zone consolidation, Sputum appearances Mucopurulent with streaks of blood. What is the most likely causative organism for the patient's pneumonia?	Staphylococcus aureus	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophila	C	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Upper zone consolidation in a high-risk setting (refugee camp) suggests TB. BCG offers limited protection against pulmonary TB.	TB: upper lobe consolidation, cavitation; BCG protects against extrapulmonary TB.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P68, Q6: A 42-year-old dentist is reviewed in the medical clinic complaining of persistent lethargy. Routine bloods show abnormal liver function tests so a hepatitis screen is sent. The results are shown below: Anti-HAV IgG negative, HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc negative, Anti-HCV positive. What do these results most likely demonstrate?	Hepatitis B infection	Hepatitis C infection	Previous vaccination to hepatitis B and C	Hepatitis C infection with previous hepatitis B vaccination	Hepatitis B and C infection	D	Hepatitis C infection with previous hepatitis B vaccination	Anti-HBs positive with negative anti-HBc indicates vaccination, not infection. Anti-HCV positive suggests hepatitis C infection.	Hepatitis B vaccination: anti-HBs +, anti-HBc -; Hepatitis C: anti-HCV +.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P69, Q7: Infection with Schistosoma haematobium is most strongly associated with:	Transitional cell bladder cancer	Lung cancer	Hepatoma	Vulval carcinoma	Squamous cell bladder cancer	E	Squamous cell bladder cancer	Chronic S. haematobium infection causes squamous metaplasia and increases risk of squamous cell bladder cancer.	S. haematobium → squamous cell bladder cancer; S. mansoni/japonicum → liver fibrosis.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P69, Q8: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent amantadine?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Protease inhibitor	Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	D	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Amantadine blocks the M2 ion channel of influenza A, preventing viral uncoating inside host cells.	Amantadine: inhibits uncoating of influenza A; also used in Parkinson's.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P70, Q9: A 23-year-old medical student is seen in a genitourinary medicine clinic for a painless lesion on the glans of his penis. He describes a 2-week history of the lesion that started as a small erythematous papule and has now progressed to ulceration. This was associated with fevers, sweats and general malaise. He has returned from his elective in the Caribbean and admits to an episode of unprotected sex with a local resident. On examination there was a 1x2cm painless ulcer on the glans of his penis. You note groove sign with lymphadenopathy above and below the left inguinal ligament only. What organism is cause of the patients presentation?	Treponema pallidum	Chlamydia trachomatis	Haemophilus ducreyi	Klebsiella	Gonorrhoea	B	Chlamydia trachomatis	Painless ulcer + groove sign (lymph nodes above and below inguinal ligament) = lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.	LGV: painless ulcer → painful lymphadenopathy + groove sign; treat with doxycycline.	Sexually Transmitted Infections				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P70, Q10: Which of the following anti-retroviral drugs is a known inducer of cytochrome P450?	Nevirapine	Ritonavir	Saquinavir	Neffinavir	Zidovudine	A	Nevirapine	Nevirapine (NNRTI) induces cytochrome P450; protease inhibitors generally inhibit it.	NNRTIs: nevirapine induces CYP450; PIs inhibit CYP450.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P71, Q11: A 43-year-old sheep farmer presents with a lesion on his right hand. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P71, Q12: A 29-year-old Russian man who has recently arrived into the country presents with fever and feeling generally unwell. Dengue fever	Typhoid	Paratyphoid	Actinomycosis	Diphtheria	E	Diphtheria	Grey pseudomembrane on tonsils + cervical lymphadenopathy = diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae).	Diphtheria: grey pseudomembrane, bull neck, myocarditis/neuropathy.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P72, Q13: A 54 year old female is admitted with a severe pneumonia following a holiday in Turkey. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the probable diagnosis? Legionella: hyponatremia, confusion; diagnosis = urinary antigen.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P72, Q14: You are speaking to the partner of a 28-year-old man who has recently been admitted with pyrexia and neck stiffness. The results of initial investigations are shown below: Serum glucose 5.0 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture: Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 1.2 mmol/l, Protein 1.8 g/l, White cells 450 / mm³ (85% polymorphs), Microscopy Gram-negative diplococci. The partner is 27-years-old and has no past medical history of note other than depression for which she takes fluoxetine. She has had a full course of immunisations including a course of MenC vaccines whilst at university 8 years ago. What is the most appropriate next step to reduce her chance of developing meningitis?	No further action is required	MenC booster dose	Oral ciprofloxacin + MenC booster dose	Oral ciprofloxacin	Oral rifampicin	D	Oral ciprofloxacin	Close contacts of meningococcal meningitis should receive chemoprophylaxis; ciprofloxacin is first-line. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P73, Q15: A 35-year-old man is reviewed in clinic having been diagnosed with HIV two years ago and is stable on anti-retroviral therapy. He has a new regular partner and is concerned about transmitting the disease to him. What factor is most likely to increase the risk of transmission?	Circumcision	Low CD4 count	Co-infection with genital warts	Diabetes	Mucosal ulceration	E	Mucosal ulceration	Mucosal breaks increase HIV transmission risk; viral load is more important than CD4 count. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P74, Q16: A 48 year old farmer attends the emergency department 7 days after cutting his arm from falling on barbed wire in his field. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P74, Q17: A 25-year-old woman is admitted to a local hospital whilst travelling in north India. She takes no regular medication other than malaria prophylaxis (chloroquine). On examination her pulse is 96/min, blood pressure 102/66 mmHg. Jaundiced sclera, along with some bruising on her arms is noted. Her partner states that she also seems confused. Bloods show: Bilirubin 102 µmol/l, ALP 256 u/l, ALT 1024 u/l, VGT 563 u/l, Albumin 35 g/l, INR 2.4. What is the most likely cause of her deterioration? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P75, Q18: A 23-year-old solider who returned from a tour of Afghanistan 2 months ago presents with a large painless ulcer on the back of his hand. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P75, Q19: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department with an evolving purpuric rash, pyrexia and confusion. Urinary antigen	Blood PCR for meningococcus	Blood culture	CT head	Lumbar puncture	B	Blood PCR for meningococcus	After antibiotics, blood cultures may be negative; PCR has >90% sensitivity for meningococcal detection. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P76, Q20: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department complaining of a widespread erythematous rash. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P77, Q21: You attend a meeting with the hospital management. The use of personal protective equipment for staff including gloves and aprons	Hand hygiene	Screening patients for MRSA on admission	Cohort nursing	Limiting the number of visitors	B	Hand hygiene	Hand hygiene is the most effective measure to prevent MRSA transmission in healthcare settings.	MRSA prevention: hand hygiene > screening > isolation.	Infection Control				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P77, Q22: A patient with a severe headache, nausea and vomiting comes to the emergency department. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P78, Q23: A health care assistant sustains a needlestick injury whilst taking blood from a patient who is known to be HIV positive. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P78, Q24: A 44-year-old farmer presents with headache, fever and muscle aches. On examination his temperature is 38.2°C, pulse 102 / min and his chest is clear. Subconjunctival haemorrhages are noted but there is no evidence of jaundice. What is the most likely diagnosis? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P79, Q26: A patient is prescribed zanamivir (Relenza) for suspected influenza. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P80, Q27: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department 4 weeks after returning from a two-week business trip to India. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P80, Q28: A 29-year-old man with HIV is admitted with shortness of breath. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 65-81 (MRCP1)	P81, Q29: A 12-year-old boy who had a splenectomy following a road traffic accident is reviewed in clinic. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P82, Q30: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent amantadine? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P83, Q32: A tearful 35-year-old pregnant lady reports that her husband has recently told her has chlamydia. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P84, Q33: Which one of the following is true regarding linezolid?	Active against both MRSA and VRE (Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococcus)	Bactericidal in action	No activity against GISA (Glycopeptide Intermediate Staphylococcus aureus)	Adverse effects include raised platelet count	Inhibits RNA synthesis	A	Active against both MRSA and VRE (Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococcus)	Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis and is bacteriostatic. It has excellent Gram-positive coverage including MRSA, VRE, and GISA.	Linezolid → MRSA, VRE, GISA coverage. Side effect: thrombocytopenia.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P84, Q34: A 40-year-old woman who is known to be HIV positive is admitted to the Emergency Department following a seizure. Her partner reports that she has been having headaches, night sweats and a poor appetite for the past four weeks. Blood tests and a CT head are arranged: CD4 89 u/l, CT head Single homogenously-enhancing lesion in the right parietal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Primary CNS lymphoma	Tuberculosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcus	Toxoplasmosis	A	Primary CNS lymphoma	Although toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of brain lesions in HIV patients, around 80% involve multiple lesions. A single homogeneously-enhancing lesion with constitutional symptoms is more suggestive of primary CNS lymphoma.	Single homogenous lesion + HIV → Primary CNS lymphoma. Multiple ring-enhancing → Toxoplasmosis.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P86, Q35: A 31-year-old woman who is 26 weeks pregnant presents with a rash. The rash is located just under her axilla and has been getting progressively larger since it first appeared five days. She also reports feeling 'flu-like' and having some joint pains. She has recently returned from a weekend away in Hampshire. Her pregnancy is uncomplicated to date. On examination a large erythematous rash is noted. In the middle a central punctum is seen. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate treatment? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P87, Q36: A 28-year-old student is admitted out of hours to the infectious diseases ward with suspected malaria following a backpacking trip around South East Asia. Thick film shows parasite burden of 1.5%, thin film shows non-falciparum malaria - looks like Plasmodium knowlesi. Which of the following attributes make Plasmodium knowlesi infections particularly dangerous?	Cytoadherence	Hypnozoite formation	Short erythrocytic replication stage	Resistance to treatment	Slow growth leading to late presentation	C	Short erythrocytic replication stage	P. knowlesi has the shortest erythrocytic cycle (24 hours), leading to very high parasite counts rapidly. Severe parasitemia is defined as >1% for P. knowlesi versus >2% for other species.	P. knowlesi → 24-hour cycle → rapid parasite increase. Severe if >1%.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P88, Q37: A 23-year-old male presents with a purulent urethral discharge. A sample of the discharge is shown to be a Gram negative diplococcus. Oral ciprofloxacin for 7 days	Oral penicillin V for 7 days	Oral doxycycline for 7 days	Oral azithromycin stat dose	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	E	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	Gram-negative diplococcus indicates gonorrhea. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P89, Q38: Which one of the following statements regarding toxoplasmosis is true?	It is a type of flagellate	Congenital toxoplasmosis results in optic nerve atrophy	Ceftriaxone should be used initially in patients with HIV-associated toxoplasmosis	The cat is the only known animal reservoir	Infection is usually self-limiting	E	Infection is usually self-limiting	Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoa with the cat as the main reservoir. Most infections are asymptomatic or self-limiting. Treatment (pyrimethamine plus sulfadiazine) is reserved for severe or immunosuppressed cases.	Toxoplasmosis → Usually self-limiting. Treat severe/immunocompromised cases.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P90, Q39: A 72-year-old woman who is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and heart failure is reviewed. What is the most appropriate next line antibiotic?	Co-amoxiclav	Erythromycin	Clindamycin	Vancomycin	Gentamicin	C	Clindamycin	Many local protocols suggest oral clindamycin in patients who have failed to respond to flucloxacillin for cellulitis. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P90, Q40: A 52-year-old man with a history of alcohol dependence is admitted with fever and feeling generally unwell. An admission chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right upper lobe with early cavitation. What is the most likely causative organism?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophilia	Staphylococcus aureus	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	D	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Klebsiella pneumoniae is classically associated with pneumonia in alcoholics, typically presenting with upper lobe consolidation and cavitation.	Alcoholic + pneumonia with cavitation → Klebsiella.	Respiratory Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P91, Q41: A 31-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a headache. She has had 'flu' like symptoms for the past three days with the headache developing gradually yesterday. The headache is described as being 'all over' and is worse on looking at bright light or when bending her neck. On examination her temperature is 38.2º, pulse 96/min and blood pressure 116/78 mmHg. There is neck stiffness present but no focal neurological signs. On close inspection you notice a number of petechiae on her torso. She has been cannulated and bloods (including cultures) have been taken. What is the most appropriate next step?	IV cefotaxime	Arrange a CT head	Perform a lumbar puncture	IV dexamethasone	Intramuscular benzypenicillin	A	IV cefotaxime	This patient has meningococcal meningitis (petechial rash, meningism, fever). She needs immediate IV antibiotics. Modern PCR diagnostics mean lumbar puncture should not delay life-saving treatment.	Suspected meningococcal meningitis → IV antibiotics immediately (cefotaxime/ceftriaxone).	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P91, Q42: A 30-year-old man returns from a cheese and wine tasting holiday in Portugal. On questioning, he tells you about all the unpasteurised cheese he tried. He comes to the GP complaining of feeling very unwell with fluctuating temperatures, pain in his joints and muscles that is transient and has noticed a peculiar 'wet hay' smell when he sweats. What is the most likely causative organism?	Yersinia pestis	Brucella melitensis	Wuchereria bancrofti	Bartonella henselae	Plasmodium falciparum	B	Brucella melitensis	Brucellosis presents with fluctuating fever, transient arthralgia/myalgia, and hyperhidrosis with characteristic 'wet hay' smell. History of unpasteurized dairy products is key. Treat with doxycycline plus streptomycin.	Unpasteurized dairy + fluctuating fever + 'wet hay' smell → Brucellosis.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P92, Q43: A 32-year-old HIV positive man presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen leg. He has a history of poor adherence with his medication and is currently not taking antiretrovirals; his most recent blood tests from a year previously show a detectable viral load. On examination, there are multiple purplish nodules in the skin overlying the popliteal fossa. What is the most likely underlying viral cause for his pathology?	Ebstein Barr Virus	Human Herpes Virus 8	Human Papilloma Virus	Hepatitis B	Human T-Lymphotrophic Virus	B	Human Herpes Virus 8	This is Kaposi's sarcoma caused by HHV-8 in HIV-positive individuals. It presents as purplish skin nodules and is an AIDS-defining illness.	Kaposi's sarcoma → HHV-8 in HIV patients. AIDS-defining illness.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P92, Q44: A 26-year-old man returns to the genito-urinary medicine clinic. He is a known intravenous drug user. Five days ago he was seen with a urethral discharge. A swab taken in the clinic showed a Gram-negative diplococcus and treatment with IM ceftriaxone was given. Unfortunately his symptoms have not resolved. What is the most likely explanation?	Gonorrhoea-resistant to ceftriaxone	Co-existent Candida infection	HIV infection	Co-existent syphilis infection	Co-existent Chlamydia infection	E	Co-existent Chlamydia infection	Co-existent Chlamydia infection is extremely common in patients with gonorrhea. This is why dual therapy (ceftriaxone plus azithromycin) is now recommended for gonorrhea treatment.	Gonorrhea treatment failure → Think co-existent Chlamydia.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P93, Q45: A 58-year-old caucasian male originally from the United Kingdom now living in East Africa has returned to the UK on holiday. He has become unwell in the last two days, complaining of a headache, rigors, vomiting, fever, abdominal pain and passing little amounts of dark red urine. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice and anaemia. Urinalysis reveals blood only and microscopy showed no red cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Leptospirosis	Acute viral hepatitis	Pyelonephritis	Schistosomiasis	Blackwater fever	E	Blackwater fever	Blackwater fever is a rare, potentially fatal malaria complication caused by massive intravascular hemolysis resulting in hemoglobinuria (dark red/black urine), anemia, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Urinalysis shows blood without red cells.	Blackwater fever → Massive hemolysis in malaria. Dark urine, no RBCs on microscopy.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P94, Q46: A 22-year-old female presents with an offensive vaginal discharge. History and examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. What is the most appropriate initial management?	Oral azithromycin	Topical hydrocortisone	Oral metronidazole	Clotrimazole pessary	Advice regarding hygiene and cotton underwear	C	Oral metronidazole	Bacterial vaginosis is treated with oral metronidazole for 5-7 days with a 70-80% initial cure rate. Topical metronidazole or clindamycin are alternatives.	Bacterial vaginosis → Oral metronidazole 5-7 days.	Gynecology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P95, Q47: Which one of the following is the most common cause of visceral larva migrans?	Cryptococcus neoformans	Strongyloides stercoralis	Visceral leishmaniasis	Toxocara canis	Giardiasis	D	Toxocara canis	Toxocara canis is commonly acquired by ingesting eggs from soil contaminated by dog feces and is the most common cause of visceral larva migrans. It may also cause eye granulomas and liver/lung involvement.	Visceral larva migrans → Toxocara canis (dog feces).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P95, Q48: A 34-year-old postman attends the Emergency Department following a dog bite to his right hand. What is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy?	Metronidazole + amoxicillin	Erythromycin	Co-amoxiclav	Metronidazole	Flucloxacillin + penicillin	C	Co-amoxiclav	Animal bites are polymicrobial with Pasteurella multocida being most common. Co-amoxiclav is the recommended treatment. If penicillin-allergic, use doxycycline plus metronidazole.	Animal bite → Co-amoxiclav first-line.	Emergency Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P96, Q49: A 35-year-old homosexual man is referred to the local genitourinary clinic following the development of a solitary painless penile ulcer associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. He has recently developed rectal pain and tenesmus. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Herpes simplex infection	Syphilis	Granuloma inguinale	Chancroid	Lymphogranuloma venereum	E	Lymphogranuloma venereum	Lymphogranuloma venereum presents in three stages: small painless pustule/ulcer, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, then proctocolitis. This fits the clinical picture described.	LGV → Painless ulcer + painful nodes + proctocolitis.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P96, Q50: An 18-year-old male who has recently undergone chemotherapy for leukaemia presents with fever, cough, haemoptysis and shortness of breath not responsive to antibiotics. He underwent a chest CT which revealed a 'halo' sign suggestive of invasive aspergillosis. What immune response component is the first line of action against aspergillosis?	Cytokines	Neutrophils	Eosinophils	Basophils	Macrophages	E	Macrophages	Macrophages are the first-line immune response against aspergillosis, helping recruit neutrophils. Patients with deficiencies in macrophages and neutrophils are prone to aspergillosis.	Aspergillosis defense → Macrophages first, then neutrophils. Treat with voriconazole.	Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P97, Q51: A 24-year-old patient presents to the Emergency Department with watery diarrhoea. He returned from holiday in Tanzania yesterday. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely to be responsible for this presentation?	Enterotoxigenic E. coli	Non-typhoidal Salmonella	Campylobacter spp	Vibrio cholerae	Giardia lamblia	A	Enterotoxigenic E. coli	Worldwide, enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea, though there is geographical variation (Campylobacter more common in South East Asia).	Traveler's diarrhea → ETEC most common worldwide.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P98, Q52: A 24-year-old heterosexual man presents to GUM with a history of dysuria, urethral irritation and milky discharge from the urethra. Urethral microscopy reveals >10 polynuclear lymphocytes per field but no gonorrhoea is seen and urine dip is normal. He did a home test 3 days ago when his symptoms started and Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea NAATs were negative. His last sexual encounter was 3 weeks ago. You make a clinical diagnosis of non specific urethritis (NSU). What is the most appropriate action to take?	Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	Reassure the patient; his symptoms will resolve spontaneously	Tell the patient to repeat his Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea tests in 2 weeks' time	Start oral aciclovir	Refer to urology for their assessment and opinion	A	Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	Non-specific urethritis with pus cells on urethral swab requires treatment with doxycycline or azithromycin. The 2-week window period means the home test is likely accurate, but treatment shouldn't be delayed.	NSU → Treat with doxycycline 7 days or azithromycin.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P98, Q53: A man presents with severe vomiting. He reports not being able to keep fluids down for the past 12 hours. You suspect a diagnosis of gastroenteritis and on discussing possible causes he mentions reheating curry with rice the night before. What is the most likely causative organism?	Escherichia coli	Campylobacter	Salmonella	Shigella	Bacillus cereus	E	Bacillus cereus	Bacillus cereus infection most commonly results from reheated rice. It produces heat-stable toxins that cause rapid-onset vomiting.	Reheated rice → Bacillus cereus gastroenteritis.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P99, Q54: A 24-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department with breathing difficulties and confusion three weeks after returning from a holiday in Cambodia. His partner says he has had 'the flu' for the past two weeks. A blood film is positive for malarial parasites and a chest x-ray and arterial blood gases suggest acute respiratory distress syndrome. A diagnosis of severe falciparum malaria is suspected. What is the treatment of choice?	Intravenous artesunate	Intravenous clindamycin + oral artemether-lumefantrine	Intravenous artemether-lumefantrine	Oral atovaquone-proguanil	Intravenous quinine	A	Intravenous artesunate	WHO now recommends intravenous artesunate over IV quinine for severe falciparum malaria due to better outcomes.	Severe falciparum malaria → IV artesunate (not quinine).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P99, Q55: A 23-year-old man develops watery diarrhoea 5 days after arriving in Mexico. Which one of the following is the most likely responsible organism?	Salmonella	Shigella	Campylobacter	Escherichia coli	Bacillus cereus	D	Escherichia coli	E. coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea worldwide.	Traveler's diarrhea → E. coli most common.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P99, Q56: A 42-year-old female presents to the Emergency Department. She is known to be an intravenous drug user and sometimes practices skin popping. She has multiple sores and wounds. She is complaining of double vision, difficulty swallowing, slurred speech and weakness of the arm muscles. Her arms are weak and floppy. You suspect that a bacterial toxin is causing her symptoms. What is the mechanism of action of the most likely toxin?	Chloride channel blocker	Inhibition of the release of acetylcholine at synapses	Inhibition of the release of glycine and gamma-amino butyric acid at synapses	Sodium channel blocker	Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor blocker	B	Inhibition of the release of acetylcholine at synapses	Wound botulism presents with descending flaccid paralysis and cranial nerve signs. Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting acetylcholine release at synapses. IV drug users practicing skin popping are at higher risk.	Botulinum toxin → Blocks ACh release → flaccid paralysis.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P100, Q57: A 19-year-old man presents asking for advice. His girlfriend has recently been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. He is worried he may have 'caught it'. What is the recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for close contacts such as this man?	Oral co-amoxiclav	Oral phenoxymethylpenicillin	Oral rifampicin	Oral erythromycin	Intramuscular cefotaxime	C	Oral rifampicin	BNF recommends twice-daily rifampicin for two days based on patient weight for meningococcal prophylaxis. Ciprofloxacin is an alternative per recent guidelines.	Meningococcal contact prophylaxis → Rifampicin or ciprofloxacin.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P100, Q58: A 34-year-old lady presents to the GP with worsening nausea and fatigue over a 2 week period. On examination, there is a yellow tinge to the sclera of her eyes. She lives in a remote fishing village and consumes a diet high in seafood. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She does not report any weight loss or other constitutional features. Her LFTs show: Bilirubin 20 μmol/l, ALP 160 u/l, ALT 550 u/l. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?	Gilbert's syndrome	Pancreatic adenocarcinoma	Hepatitis B	Hepatitis C	Hepatitis E	E	Hepatitis E	Hepatitis E is associated with fecal-oral spread, commonly from shellfish and pork. Blood results show elevated bilirubin and significant transaminitis. No constitutional symptoms make cancer unlikely.	High seafood diet + hepatitis picture → Hepatitis E (fecal-oral).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P101, Q59: You review a 14-year-old boy who has recently emigrated from Russia. He was involved in car accident two years ago and underwent an emergency splenectomy. Following this he takes penicillin V on a daily basis. He is unsure of his vaccination history. Which organism is he particularly susceptible to?	Staphylococcus aureus	HIV	Haemophilus influenzae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	C	Haemophilus influenzae	Penicillin V protects against Streptococcus pneumoniae but not Haemophilus influenzae due to beta-lactamase production by the organism. Post-splenectomy patients need additional vaccination.	Post-splenectomy + penicillin V → Still vulnerable to H. influenzae (beta-lactamase).	Hematology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P101, Q60: A 34-year-old man from Swaziland presents to the emergency department with a 3 day history of fever, shortness of breath and a dry cough. His past medical history includes tuberculosis and HIV and his most recent CD4 count is 150. On examination: heart rate 100/min, respiratory rate 28/min, oxygen saturation 98% on air at rest, dropping to 80% on walking. Temperature is 38.5ºC. On auscultation, his chest is clear. How would you treat this man?	IV cefotaxime	Oral ciprofloxacin	IV tazocin	Oral rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol	Oral co-trimoxazole	E	Oral co-trimoxazole	Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) in HIV patient with low CD4. Classically presents with fever, dyspnea, dry cough, exercise-induced desaturation, and few chest signs. Treat with co-trimoxazole or IV pentamidine if severe.	PCP → CD4 <200 + dry cough + exercise desaturation + clear chest. Treat: co-trimoxazole.	Respiratory Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P102, Q61: A 27-year-old bisexual man presents to your GUM clinic with a 7-day history of rectal discharge, pain on passing stools and tenesmus. On examination, he has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and proctoscopy reveals red mucosa with yellow discharge and some shallow ulcers. Which one of the following organisms is most likely to be causative?	Enterococcus coli	Treponema pallidum	Haemophilus ducreyi	Neisseria gonorrhoea	Chlamydia trachomatis	E	Chlamydia trachomatis	The presence of ulcers and significant rectal symptoms in a sexually active man suggests lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), caused by specific serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis. LGV proctocolitis should be considered in sexually active patients with these symptoms.	LGV proctocolitis → Chlamydia trachomatis (specific serovars).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P102, Q62: A 56-year-old diabetic man was admitted with pyrexia and rigors secondary to an infected diabetic foot ulcer and commenced on IV Flucloxacillin. The wound swab grew methicillin resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) and he was commenced on an alternative IV antibiotic. Within an hour of administration the patient developed an itchy, erythematous maculopapular rash, which became diffuse covering >80% of his body surface area. He also began to complain of hearing loss in his right ear. What antibiotic is likely to have been prescribed?	Teicoplanin	Co-Amoxiclav	Clindamycin	Vancomycin	Cefuroxime	D	Vancomycin	Vancomycin causes red man syndrome (non-IgE mediated mast cell degranulation), ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. Red man syndrome presents with flushing/maculopapular rash, more common with rapid infusion. Treat with antihistamines.	Vancomycin side effects → Red man syndrome, ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P103, Q63: A 44-year-old homosexual man presents to your GUM clinic with a 3-day history of diarrhoea. He has no history of recent foreign travel and is normally fit and well. His abdomen is soft, non tender and he has normal observations. His last sexual encounter was 2 weeks ago. Tests for Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoea, HIV and Syphilis are negative. A stool sample is sent for culture and grows Shigella. What is the most suitable management plan?	Start loperamide and review in 48 hours	Admit to the local infectious diseases unit for IV Metronidazole	Reassure the patient this is a commensal bacteria unlikely to be the cause of their symptoms	Advise the patient to increase their fluid intake and seek medical attention if they become unwell, or develop bloody diarrhoea	Inform Public Health England	D	Advise the patient to increase their fluid intake and seek medical attention if they become unwell, or develop bloody diarrhoea	Shigella infection is usually self-limiting and doesn't require antibiotics unless severe disease, immunocompromised, or bloody diarrhea develops. Antimotility drugs not recommended in infective diarrhea.	Shigella → Usually self-limiting. Antibiotics only if severe/bloody/immunocompromised.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P103, Q64: You are working in the Emergency Department and you see a 22-year-old man with an itchy erythematous rash across his back, shoulders and backs of his arms. The rash appeared yesterday after he started taking an antibiotic, having been unwell for 10 days with general malaise and a sore throat. Which antibiotic is most likely to be the cause?	Flucloxacillin	Phenoxymethylpenicillin	Amoxicillin	Ciprofloxacin	Co-amoxiclav	C	Amoxicillin	Patient likely has infectious mononucleosis (EBV). Amoxicillin commonly produces widespread erythematous rash in patients with EBV infection and should not be prescribed for sore throats. Use penicillin V instead for bacterial tonsillitis.	Amoxicillin + EBV/infectious mononucleosis → Widespread rash.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 82-98 (MRCP2)	P104, Q65: A previously well 68-year-old woman is reviewed on the acute medical ward. She has recently been commenced on methotrexate for newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis. During your review, she complains of dysuria and urinary frequency. She is otherwise systemically well, with no fever or loin tenderness. Urinalysis results show: Leucocytes +++, Nitrites Positive, Blood Trace. Which antibiotics should be used to treat this patient's urinary tract infection?	Amoxicillin + Gentamicin	Trimethoprim	Ciprofloxacin	Co-trimoxazole	Nitrofurantoin	E	Nitrofurantoin	Trimethoprim and co-trimoxazole should be avoided in patients on methotrexate. Both inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, causing cumulative folic acid antagonism leading to life-threatening myelosuppression when combined.	Methotrexate + trimethoprim/co-trimoxazole → Myelosuppression. Use nitrofurantoin instead.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P099, Q66: A 33-year-old man who is HIV positive is admitted to the Emergency Department with confusion and drowsiness. He has been complaining of headaches for a number of days. On examination heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure 104/78 mmHg and temperature is 37.2ºC. He is confused giving a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 14. There is no photophobia or neck stiffness. His infectious diseases consultant reports that he is prescribed highly active antiretroviral treatment (HAART) but his compliance is poor and he often misses clinic appointments. A CT brain is requested: CT brain (with contrast): Multiple hypodense regions predominantly in the basal ganglia which show ring enhancement. Minimal surrounding oedema. No mass effect. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcal infection	Cerebral toxoplasmosis	CMV encephalitis	Tuberculosis	C	Cerebral toxoplasmosis	HIV with multiple ring-enhancing lesions indicates toxoplasmosis, the most common neurological infection in HIV (up to 10% of patients).	HIV + multiple ring-enhancing lesions → Toxoplasmosis.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P099, Q67: A patient with HIV is reviewed. Which one of the following is an example of a nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors?	Zidovudine	Indinavir	Ritonavir	Ribavirin	Efavirenz	A	Zidovudine	Zidovudine (AZT) is a NRTI. Rule of thumb: NRTIs end in 'ine', PIs end in 'vir', NNRTIs include nevirapine and efavirenz.	NRTIs end in 'ine' → Zidovudine is a NRTI.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P100, Q68: A 43-year-old woman who is a recent immigrant from Mozambique is referred to the dermatology outpatient clinic. She has developed a number of hypopigmented, oval shaped lesions on her body which are associated with reduced sensation. These are mainly located on the extensor surfaces of her limbs. She has no past medical history of note other than suffering from malaria as a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?	HIV	Chagas disease	Pityriasis versicolor	Tuberculosis	Leprosy	E	Leprosy	Leprosy presents with hypopigmented skin patches with sensory loss, typically on buttocks, face, and extensor limb surfaces. Treated with rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine.	Hypopigmented patches + sensory loss → Leprosy.	Dermatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P100, Q69: A 37-year-old woman who is being treated as an inpatient for Mycoplasma pneumonia is reviewed. Unfortunately she is unable to tolerate clarithromycin due to severe nausea. What is the most suitable alternative antibiotic?	Linezolid	Cefaclor	Ciprofloxacin	Co-amoxiclav	Doxycycline	E	Doxycycline	Mycoplasma pneumonia is typically treated with macrolides (erythromycin/clarithromycin). If intolerant, doxycycline is the alternative.	Mycoplasma pneumonia intolerant to macrolides → Doxycycline.	Respiratory Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P101, Q70: A nurse in a GUM clinic asks you to look at a rectal gram-stained slide for a symptomatic patient she has just seen. It shows pinkish/red stained intracellular diplococci. What is the most likely organism?	Neisseria Meningitidis	Probable contaminant/commensal organism	Chlamydia trachomatis	Escherichia coli	Neisseria gonorrhoea	E	Neisseria gonorrhoea	Gram-negative (pinkish/red) intracellular diplococci indicate Neisseria gonorrhoea. Chlamydia cannot be diagnosed on gram staining.	Gram-negative intracellular diplococci → Gonorrhea.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P102, Q71: A 77-year-old female presents with a non-healing ulcer on her right foot. Blood cultures grow MRSA. Which antibiotic would you consider in addition to vancomycin?	Flucloxacillin	Ceftazidime	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	Rifampicin	E	Rifampicin	For MRSA infections, rifampicin is often added to vancomycin for synergy, particularly in severe or persistent infections.	MRSA treatment → Vancomycin + rifampicin.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P102, Q72: A 34-year-old man from Zimbabwe is admitted with abdominal pain to the Emergency Department. An abdominal x-ray reveals urinary bladder calcification. What is the most likely cause?	Schistosoma mansoni	Sarcoidosis	Leishmaniasis	Tuberculosis	Schistosoma haematobium	E	Schistosoma haematobium	Schistosoma haematobium causes hematuria and is the most common cause of bladder calcification worldwide.	Bladder calcification + endemic area → Schistosoma haematobium.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P103, Q73: A 34-year-old man with a past history of HIV infection presents to the Emergency Department with watery diarrhoea. Cryptosporidium infection is confirmed on ZN staining. What is the most suitable management?	Metronidazole	Sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine	Supportive therapy	Rifampicin + ethambutol + clarithromycin	Co-trimoxazole	C	Supportive therapy	Cryptosporidium is the most common infective cause of diarrhea in HIV. Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain shows red cysts. Supportive therapy is the mainstay of treatment.	Cryptosporidium in HIV → Supportive therapy (difficult to treat).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P103, Q74: You are phoned for advice. The parents of a 19-year-old man have just been messaged by their son who is currently backpacking in Thailand. Earlier in the day he was bitten by a dog whilst staying in a rural community. Prior to travelling, he received vaccination against rabies as he was going to be visiting many rural areas. What is the most appropriate advice?	He should increase his fluid intake by around 1L a day as a precaution	He should be protected given the previous vaccination but should monitor for any changes in salivation over the next 72 hours	He should see a local doctor to request antibiotic therapy	He should urgently seek local medical attention for consideration of booster vaccination + antibiotic therapy	He should take the next flight home so he can be observed for any symptoms of rabies	D	He should urgently seek local medical attention for consideration of booster vaccination + antibiotic therapy	Even with prior rabies vaccination, booster doses are needed after a dog bite in high-risk areas. Rabies is nearly always fatal if untreated. Urgent local medical attention is essential.	Dog bite in endemic area + prior vaccine → Still need booster urgently.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P105, Q75: A 32-year-old oil worker presents by ambulance to the Emergency Department following his return from Angola. His wife reports that over the past 24 hours, the patient has become progressively more drowsy with fevers ongoing for the past 5 days. Initial investigations show: Hb 78 g/l, Platelets 90 × 109/l, WBC 20 × 109/l, K+ 5.6 mmol/l, Urea 15 mmol/l, Creatinine 190 μmol/l, Bilirubin 70 μmol/l. Malarial Films show P. falciparum species seen, 12% parasitaemia. Given this patient's condition, what treatment(s) should be commenced?	Chloroquine	Artesunate and exchange transfusion	Artesunate	Doxycycline	Quinine + Doxycycline	B	Artesunate and exchange transfusion	Severe falciparum malaria with parasitemia >10% requires IV artesunate plus consideration of exchange transfusion.	Severe malaria with parasitemia >10% → IV artesunate + exchange transfusion.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P106, Q76: A 39-year-old man returns from a two week business trip to Kenya. Four weeks after his return he presents complaining of malaise, headaches and night sweats. On examination there is a symmetrical erythematous macular rash over his trunk and limbs associated with cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Typhoid fever	Tuberculosis	Dengue fever	Schistosomiasis	Acute HIV infection	E	Acute HIV infection	HIV seroconversion presents 3-12 weeks after infection with flu-like illness, maculopapular rash, and lymphadenopathy. Consider STIs in businessmen returning from trips abroad.	Businessman + travel + maculopapular rash + lymphadenopathy → HIV seroconversion.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P107, Q77: A 20-year-old woman was admitted overnight with suspected meningitis. You are asked to review the initial microscopy results from the lumbar puncture. The lab tells you the culture is growing gram negative diplococci. What is the most likely organism?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes	Escherichia coli	Haemophilus influenzae	Neisseria meningitidis	E	Neisseria meningitidis	In this age group (6-60 years), Neisseria meningitidis and Streptococcus pneumoniae are most common. N. meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus.	Meningitis age 6-60 + gram-negative diplococcus → N. meningitidis.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P108, Q78: A 19-year-old man presents with dysuria associated with a watery discharge from his urethral meatus. A urethral swab shows non-specific urethritis and urine is sent for Chlamydia/gonococcus. What is the most appropriate antibiotic to use?	Erythromycin	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	Cefixime	Azithromycin	E	Azithromycin	Non-specific urethritis most likely indicates Chlamydia. SIGN guidelines recommend azithromycin first-line due to better compliance versus 7-day doxycycline.	Non-specific urethritis → Azithromycin (or doxycycline).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P109, Q79: Which of the following anti-retroviral drugs is most characteristically associated with nephrolithiasis?	Zidovudine	Didanosine	Indinavir	Ritonavir	Nevirapine	C	Indinavir	Indinavir, a protease inhibitor, is characteristically associated with nephrolithiasis (kidney stones).	Indinavir → Nephrolithiasis risk.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P109, Q80: A 55-year-old business man presents with a 15 day history of watery, non-bloody diarrhoea associated with anorexia and abdominal bloating. His symptoms started 4 days after returning from a trip to Pakistan. On examination he is apyrexial with dry mucous membranes but normal skin turgor. Given the likely organism, what is the most appropriate treatment?	Hydroxychloroquine	Aciclovir	Benzylpenicillin	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	E	Metronidazole	Length of illness (15 days) plus bloating and watery diarrhea suggest Giardiasis. Treat with metronidazole.	Prolonged watery diarrhea + bloating → Giardiasis → Metronidazole.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P110, Q81: A 12-year-old girl is prescribed oseltamivir for suspected influenza. What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir?	Inhibits RNA polymerase	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	Neuraminidase inhibitor	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Protease inhibitor	C	Neuraminidase inhibitor	Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) is a neuraminidase inhibitor used to treat influenza.	Oseltamivir → Neuraminidase inhibitor for influenza.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P110, Q82: You are an F2 working in general practice. Last week you saw a 17-year-old female with acne vulgaris which is causing her significant distress and started her on tetracycline. She has come back to see you today complaining about a side effect. Which side effect is she most likely to be experiencing?	Headache	Red rash on her face and neck	Dizziness	Dry lips and tongue	Ringing in her ears	B	Red rash on her face and neck	Tetracyclines commonly cause photosensitive skin rash appearing as red rash on sun-exposed areas. Other side effects include tooth discoloration in neonates if given to pregnant women.	Tetracyclines → Photosensitive skin rash.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P111, Q83: A 23-year-old student returns from India and develops a febrile illness. Following investigation he is diagnosed as having Plasmodium vivax malaria. This area is known to harbour chloroquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium vivax. What is the most appropriate initial management to treat the acute infection?	Primaquine	Atovaquone-proguanil	Quinine	Doxycycline	Artemether-lumefantrine	E	Artemether-lumefantrine	For chloroquine-resistant non-falciparum malaria, WHO recommends artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) such as artemether-lumefantrine.	Chloroquine-resistant P. vivax → ACT (artemether-lumefantrine).	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P111, Q84: A 24-year-old woman who is 18 weeks pregnant presents to the Emergency Department. Earlier on in the morning she came into contact with a child who has chickenpox. She is unsure if she had the condition herself as a child. What is the most appropriate action?	Advise her to present within 24 hours of the rash developing for consideration of IV aciclovir	Reassure her that there is no risk of fetal complications at this point in pregnancy	Give varicella immunoglobulin	Check varicella antibodies	Prescribe oral aciclovir	D	Check varicella antibodies	If any doubt about previous chickenpox, maternal blood should be urgently checked for varicella antibodies. If not immune, give VZIG as soon as possible.	Chickenpox exposure in pregnancy → First check varicella antibodies.	Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P112, Q85: A 31-year-old woman who is known to be HIV positive presents following a positive pregnancy test. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. The last CD4 count was 420 × 106/l and she does not take any antiretroviral therapy. What is the most appropriate management with regards to antiretroviral therapy?	Check CD4 at 12 weeks and initiate antiretroviral therapy if CD4 count is less than 350 × 106/l	Do not give antiretroviral therapy	Start antiretroviral therapy at 20-32 weeks	Start antiretroviral therapy at 10-12 weeks	Start antiretroviral therapy immediately	E	Start antiretroviral therapy immediately	Following 2015 BHIVA guidelines, all HIV-positive patients should start HAART immediately upon diagnosis, regardless of pregnancy status or CD4 count.	HIV in pregnancy → Start HAART immediately (reduces vertical transmission to 2%).	Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P113, Q86: A 30-year-old man comes for review. He lives with a woman who has recently been diagnosed with having tuberculosis. The man was born in the UK, has no past medical history of note and is currently asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate test to check for latent tuberculosis?	Heaf test	Mantoux test	Sputum culture	Chest x-ray	Interferon-gamma blood test	B	Mantoux test	Mantoux test is the main screening technique for latent TB in the UK. Interferon-gamma test is used in specific situations. Heaf test is no longer used.	TB screening in contacts → Mantoux test (0.1ml PPD intradermal).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P114, Q87: A 19-year-old man presents with an annular rash, pyrexia and polyarthralgia to the Emergency Department. He has just returned from the New Forest and remembers being bitten by a tick. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy?	Ciprofloxacin	Amoxicillin	Metronidazole	Doxycycline	Ceftriaxone	D	Doxycycline	Early Lyme disease is treated with doxycycline. Ceftriaxone is used for disseminated disease.	Early Lyme disease → Doxycycline.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P115, Q88: Following a recent holiday to South America, a 19-year-old woman returned home and within a month developed a swelling around the right cheek with increased fatigue and diarrhoea. Diagnostic thick and thin blood films identified the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Which medication can be used to treat her condition during the acute phase of the disease?	Riluzole	Benznidazole	Praziquantel	Miltefosine	Chloroquine	B	Benznidazole	Benznidazole is used in the acute phase of Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi infection).	Chagas disease (T. cruzi) → Benznidazole.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P115, Q89: A prison GP is bitten by a patient who is known to have hepatitis B. The GP has a documented full history of hepatitis B vaccination and was known to be a responder. What is the most appropriate action to reduce the chance of contracting hepatitis B?	Admit for intravenous interferon	Give hepatitis B immune globulin	Give hepatitis B immune globulin + hepatitis B vaccine booster	Give hepatitis B vaccine booster	Give oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	D	Give hepatitis B vaccine booster	Previously vaccinated known responder exposed to Hep B needs only a vaccine booster.	Previous Hep B responder + exposure → Booster only.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P116, Q90: A 30-year-old HIV positive man attends your travel clinic asking for your advice on holiday vaccinations. He is taking anti-retroviral therapy and his most recent CD4 count is 200 cells/mm³. He is otherwise well and has no other medical conditions. Which of the following vaccines are contraindicated in this man?	Rabies	Meningitis ACWY	Japanese encephalitis	Tuberculosis (BCG)	Hepatitis B	D	Tuberculosis (BCG)	Live attenuated vaccines like BCG are contraindicated in all HIV-positive patients. Others include yellow fever, oral polio, intranasal influenza, varicella, and MMR.	Live vaccines (BCG, yellow fever, MMR, oral polio) → Contraindicated in HIV.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P117, Q91: A 31-year-old female presents to the genitourinary medicine clinic due to four fleshy, protuberant lesions on her vulva which are slightly pigmented. She has recently started a relationship with a new partner. What is the most appropriate initial management?	Oral aciclovir	Topical podophyllum	Topical salicylic acid	Topical aciclovir	Electrocautery	B	Topical podophyllum	Multiple, non-keratinized genital warts are treated with topical podophyllum. Solitary, keratinized warts respond better to cryotherapy.	Multiple non-keratinized warts → Topical podophyllum. Solitary keratinized → Cryotherapy.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P118, Q92: A 26-year-old man presents to your sexual health clinic with a history of swollen inguinal lymph nodes and fever 1 month after he had receptive anal intercourse with a casual male partner. He tells you his last HIV test was 2 months previously and this is the only sexual contact he has had in the last 6 months. What is the most appropriate course of action to determine his HIV status?	Advise the patient it is too early to test for HIV; ask him to return in 2 weeks and then at 3 months	Request a combined antigen (P24) and antibody test	Ask the patient to return in 2 months for an RNA PCR test	Perform a bedside 'Point of Care' antibody only test and reassure the patient if this is normal	Take a full blood count for CD4 count	B	Request a combined antigen (P24) and antibody test	Combined p24/Antibody test has a 4-week window period and is most appropriate in clinical practice. Bedside antibody-only test may not be accurate for recent exposure <6 weeks.	HIV testing after recent exposure → Combined p24/antibody test (4-week window).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P118, Q93: A 25-year-old man returns from a gap-year in Central and South America and presents with a 2 month history of an ulcerating lesion on his lower lip. Examination of his nasal and oral mucosae reveals widespread involvement. What is the likely cause?	Leishmania brasiliensis	Leishmania mexicana	Trypanosoma cruzi	Basal cell carcinoma	Leishmania donovani	A	Leishmania brasiliensis	Primary skin lesion with mucosal involvement is characteristic of Leishmania brasiliensis (mucocutaneous leishmaniasis).	Mucocutaneous ulceration after S. America travel → L. brasiliensis.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P119, Q94: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed as having primary syphilis. Six hours after receiving his first injection of benzylpenicillin he complains of feeling generally unwell. On examination he appears flushed. His blood pressure is 94/62 mmHg, pulse 96/min and temperature 37.9º. These symptoms settle after around four hours. Which one of the following is most likely to explain this finding?	Arunan-Leadbetter reaction	Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction	Concurrent infectious mononucleosis infection	Allergic reaction to benzylpenicillin	Undiagnosed tertiary syphilis	B	Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction	Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction presents with fever, rash, and tachycardia after first dose of antibiotic for syphilis. Due to release of endotoxins following bacterial death, typically occurs within few hours.	Syphilis treatment → Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (fever, rash within hours).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P119, Q95: A 34-year-old man presents with a widespread maculopapular rash and mouth ulcers. Two months ago he presented to the local GUM clinic after developing a painless penile ulcer. At the time he was noted to have inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible?	Lymphogranuloma venereum	Herpes simplex virus type 2	Mycoplasma genitalium	Haemophilus ducreyi	Treponema pallidum	E	Treponema pallidum	Secondary syphilis occurs 6-10 weeks after primary infection with painless chancre. Features include systemic symptoms, rash on trunk/palms/soles, and buccal ulcers.	Painless ulcer → then maculopapular rash + mouth ulcers → Secondary syphilis.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P120, Q96: Which one of the following statements best describes the prevention and treatment of hepatitis C?	No vaccine is available and treatment is only successful in around 10-15% of patients	No vaccine and no treatment is available	A vaccine is available and treatment is successful in around 50% of patients	A vaccine is available but no treatment has been shown to be effective	No vaccine is available but treatment is successful in the majority of patients	E	No vaccine is available but treatment is successful in the majority of patients	Hepatitis C has no vaccine but treatment (direct-acting antivirals) is successful in the majority of patients.	Hepatitis C → No vaccine but treatment effective.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P120, Q97: A 31-year-old female with no past medical history of note is admitted to hospital with dyspnoea and fever. She has recently returned from holiday in Turkey. A clinical diagnosis of pneumonia is made. On examination she is noted to have an ulcerated lesion on her upper lip consistent with reactivation of herpes simplex. Which organism is most associated with this examination finding?	Legionella pneumophilia	Staphylococcus aureus	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis carinii	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Streptococcus pneumoniae commonly causes reactivation of herpes simplex virus resulting in cold sores. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P121, Q98: A phlebotomist gives herself a needlestick injury whilst taking blood from a patient who is known to be hepatitis B positive. The phlebotomist has just started her job and is in the process of being immunised for hepatitis B but has only had one dose to date. What is the most appropriate action to minimise her risk of contracting hepatitis B from the needle?	No action needed, complete hepatitis B vaccination course as normal	Give oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	Give an accelerated course of the hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immune globulin	Give hepatitis B immune globulin + oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	Give hepatitis B immune globulin	C	Give an accelerated course of the hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immune globulin	Incomplete vaccination + Hep B exposure requires accelerated vaccine course plus hepatitis B immune globulin for immediate protection.	Incomplete Hep B vaccine + exposure → Accelerated vaccine + HBIG.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P121, Q99: A 25-year-old student with an anaphylactic allergy to egg protein is planning to travel in South East Asia. MMR and some rabies vaccines use egg embryos but egg protein content is not clinically significant.	Egg allergy → Yellow fever vaccine contraindicated.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P122, Q100: A 35-year-old male presents with a facial droop. On neurological examination, a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion is localised. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P122, Q101: A 23-year-old man has a Mantoux test prior to receiving the BCG vaccine. He develops a 12 mm indurated lesion on his forearm. Interleukin-8	Interferon-γ	Interferon-β	Interferon-α	Interleukin-10	B	Interferon-γ	Tuberculin skin tests are type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reactions, largely mediated by interferon-γ secreted by Th1 cells which stimulates macrophage activity. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P122, Q102: A 24-year-old woman presents due to an itchy vulva and pain during sex. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P123, Q103: You are counselling a 26-year-old man who has recently had a positive HIV test. His most recent CD4 count is 650 cells/mm^3. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P124, Q104: A 64-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a cough, fever, diarrhoea and myalgia. The cough is non-productive and has been getting gradually worse since she returned from holiday in Spain one week ago. Her husband is concerned because over the past 24 hours she has become more drowsy and febrile. On examination pulse is 76/min, blood pressure 104/62 mmHg, oxygen saturations are 94% on room air and temperature is 38.4ºC. Bilateral coarse crackles are heard in the chest. Initial blood tests show: Na+ 131 mmol/l, ALT 64 u/l. A chest x-ray shows patchy consolidation in the left lower zone with an associated pleural effusion. What is the most likely causative organism?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophila	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Staphylococcus aureus	C	Legionella pneumophila	Features suggesting Legionella include recent foreign travel, flu-like symptoms, hyponatremia, deranged LFTs, and pleural effusion. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P125, Q105: You are reviewing a 31-year-old man in the liver clinic. He is currently on triple therapy for hepatitis C. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P125, Q106: A 74-year-old woman has a chest x-ray organised by her GP due to a chronic cough. Aspergilloma → High Aspergillus precipitins on serology.	Respiratory Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P126, Q107: Which one of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus pyogenes infection?	Rheumatic fever	Scarlet fever	Cellulitis	Type 2 necrotizing fasciitis	Pneumonia	E	Pneumonia	Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) causes erysipelas, impetigo, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and scarlet fever but rarely causes pneumonia.	S. pyogenes → Rarely causes pneumonia.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P126, Q108: A 34-year-old HIV positive man is being treated for Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia with co-trimoxazole. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P127, Q109: A 24-year-old man attends your GUM clinic for results of his recent tests. He frequently engages in unprotected sex with multiple partners. You note he had a mildly raised Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test at 1:8. He did however have a negative EIA and TPPA test. You suspect it could be a false positive test result. Which of the following would be useful at determining a cause?	HIV test	Rheumatoid factor	Serum electrophoresis	Varicella serology	Mycoplasma serology	A	HIV test	False positive VDRL/RPR occurs with SLE, TB, malaria, HIV, and antiphospholipid syndrome. HIV testing is appropriate given the patient's risk factors.	False positive VDRL → Think SLE, TB, malaria, HIV.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P128, Q110: Which one of the following is least associated with a false negative tuberculin skin test? Severe renal failure may cause false negative but CKD stage 3 would not.	False negative Mantoux → Miliary TB, sarcoidosis, HIV, lymphoma.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P128, Q111: A 87 year old lady presents to the Emergency Department with a two day history of new confusion. Her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, blood pressure 95/45 mmHg and temperature 38.4ºC. You suspect urinary sepsis and after taking urine and blood cultures you start appropriate treatment with intravenous fluids and broad spectrum antibiotics. Later that day the microbiology lab phones to inform you the microscopy of the urine sample shows Gram positive cocci in clusters. What is the likely organism in this case?	Escherichia coli	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Enterococcus faecalis	Staphylococcus aureus	C	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Gram-positive cocci in clusters from urine is most likely S. saprophyticus. S. aureus rarely causes UTIs. E. coli and Klebsiella are gram-negative bacilli.	UTI + gram-positive cocci in clusters → S. saprophyticus.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P129, Q112: A 17-year-old man attends the local sexual health clinic. He has developed a large, keratinised genital wart on the shaft of his penis. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P129, Q113: The most appropriate treatment for cutaneous larva migrans is:	Thiabendazole	Sulfadoxine	Pyrimethamine	Metronidazole	Dapsone	A	Thiabendazole	Cutaneous larva migrans (caused by Ancylostoma braziliense) is treated with thiabendazole or albendazole.
