ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P129, Q114: Which one of the following features is least likely to occur in a patient with visceral leishmaniasis?	Massive splenomegaly	Diarrhoea	Pyrexia	Pancytopaenia	Grey skin	B	Diarrhoea	Visceral leishmaniasis commonly presents with pyrexia, massive splenomegaly, weight loss, night sweats, pancytopenia (from hypersplenism), and grey skin. Diarrhea is not typical.	Visceral leishmaniasis → Fever + massive splenomegaly + pancytopenia, NOT diarrhea.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P130, Q115: Which one of the following organisms causes erysipelas?	Staphylococcus aureus	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Staphylococcus epidermidis	Streptococcus pyogenes	Streptococcus viridans	D	Streptococcus pyogenes	Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep), which also causes impetigo, cellulitis, and necrotizing fasciitis.	Erysipelas → Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep).	Dermatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P130, Q116: A 24-year-old student returns from a gap year in Malawi complaining of visible haematuria, dysuria and urinary frequency. She says she felt well throughout her trip but experienced an itchy rash on her legs a few hours after swimming in Lake Malawi which has now resolved. Her blood results show: Hb 98 g/l, Eosinophils 0.5 × 109/l. How would you treat her?	Albendazole	Trimethoprim	Prednisolone	Doxycycline	Praziquantel	E	Praziquantel	Swimming in Lake Malawi + hematuria + eosinophilia + initial itch suggests Schistosoma haematobium. Treat with praziquantel.	Swimming endemic area + hematuria + eosinophilia → Schistosomiasis → Praziquantel.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P131, Q117: Which one of the following vaccines uses a protein that attaches to the polysaccharide outer coat to make the pathogen more immunogenic?	Rabies	Yellow fever	Oral polio	Measles	Meningococcus	E	Meningococcus	Conjugate vaccines link poorly immunogenic bacterial polysaccharide outer coats to proteins. Examples include pneumococcus, Haemophilus, and meningococcus.	Conjugate vaccine → Meningococcus, pneumococcus, Haemophilus.	Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P131, Q118: A 50-year-old man is admitted with sepsis of unknown origin. He has had three sets of blood cultures taken. The microbiology laboratory phone the ward with some preliminary results about a bacterium growing from the first set of cultures. Which of the following findings would make you concerned that the bacterium isolated is Staph aureus?	Bacteria seen in diplococci pairs	Poor uptake of gram stain	Coagulase test positive	Rapid growth on MacConkey agar	Haemolysis on blood agar	C	Coagulase test positive	Coagulase test differentiates Staphylococcus species. Staph aureus is coagulase positive and highly pathogenic. Coagulase-negative species are usually less pathogenic commensals.	Coagulase positive → Staph aureus (pathogenic).	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P132, Q119: A 31-year-old man who is known to be HIV positive presents with dyspnoea and a dry cough. He is currently homeless and has not been attending his outpatient appointments or taking antiretroviral medication. Clinical examination reveals a respiratory rate of 24/min. Chest auscultation is unremarkable with only scattered crackles. His oxygen saturation is 96% on room air but this falls rapidly after walking the length of the ward. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate first-line treatment?	Fluconazole	Co-trimoxazole	Erythromycin	Ganciclovir	Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine	B	Co-trimoxazole	HIV patient with dry cough, clear chest, and exercise-induced desaturation suggests PCP. First-line treatment is co-trimoxazole.	HIV + dry cough + exercise desaturation → PCP → Co-trimoxazole.	Respiratory Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P132, Q120: A 33-year-old man is admitted due to profuse diarrhoea. He has a history of HIV infection and Cryptosporidium diarrhoea is suspected. What investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?	Blood cultures	Sigmoidoscopy with biopsy	Abdominal x-ray	Acid-fast staining of stool sample	Cryptosporidium PCR of stool sample	D	Acid-fast staining of stool sample	Modified Ziehl-Neelsen (acid-fast) stain of stool reveals characteristic red cysts of Cryptosporidium. PCR is mainly a research tool.	Cryptosporidium diagnosis → Acid-fast stain shows red cysts.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 99-118 (MRCP3)	P133, Q121: What percentage of patients who contract the hepatitis C virus will become chronically infected?	30-35%	55-85%	90-95%	5-10%	15-20%	B	55-85%	55-85% of patients who contract hepatitis C become chronically infected. Only 30% develop acute symptoms after exposure.	Hepatitis C → 55-85% become chronically infected.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P1, Q122: A 31-year-old woman with a three year history of ulcerative colitis is started on azathioprine to help prevent relapses. Which one of the following vaccines must be avoided whilst she is on this treatment?	Yellow fever	Rabies	Pertussis	Diphtheria	Tetanus	A	Yellow fever	Live attenuated vaccines (e.g., Yellow fever, MMR, BCG) are contraindicated in immunocompromised patients, including those on azathioprine.	Live vaccines are contraindicated in immunosuppression.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P2, Q123: A 42-year-old businessman presents to General Practice after returning from a trip to Thailand, 4 weeks ago, with an ulcer on his penis. He has a prior history of treated syphilis. On examination, you note a non-painful chance on the shaft of the penis. There is no penile discharge and no lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following tests are more likely to reflect a repeat infection with treponema pallidum?	Enzyme immunoassay	Treponema pallidum haemagglutination assay	Rapid plasma reagin	Chemiluminescence immunoassay	Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay	C	Rapid plasma reagin	Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) is a non-treponemal (cardiolipin) test that becomes negative after treatment; a positive result in a previously treated patient suggests reinfection.	Non-treponemal tests (RPR, VDRL) become negative post-treatment; treponemal tests remain positive for life.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P3, Q124: A 57-year-old female presents with headache and fever to the Emergency Department. On examination neck stiffness is noted along with a positive Kernig’s sign. A lumbar puncture is performed and reported as follows: CSF culture Gram positive bacilli. What is the most likely causative organism?	Cryptococcus	Haemophilus influenzae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	E. coli	Listeria monocytogenes	E	Listeria monocytogenes	Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive rod that causes meningitis, particularly in neonates, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals.	Gram-positive rods in CSF: think Listeria.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P3, Q125: A 27-year-old woman develops fever and lymph node swelling after being scratched by her cat. Which one of the organisms is responsible for cat scratch disease?	Bordetella pertussis	Moraxella catarrhalis	Bartonella henselae	Francisella tularensis	Yersinia enterocolitica	C	Bartonella henselae	Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae, a Gram-negative rod transmitted via cat scratches or bites.	Cat scratch → Bartonella henselae.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P4, Q126: A 20-year-old student presents to the Emergency Department three weeks after being scratched by their pet kitten on their left arm. There is a crusted papule at the site of the scratch and painful left axillary lymphadenopathy. Which is the most likely causative organism?	Bartonella	Coxiella	Brucella	Mycoplasma	Yersinia	A	Bartonella	Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease, characterized by a papule at the inoculation site and regional lymphadenopathy after a cat scratch.	Kitten scratch + lymphadenopathy = Bartonella henselae.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P4, Q127: A 34-year-old female with a background of HIV present with progressive weakness in her lower limbs. She also states that she is finding it difficult to walk up the stairs and is becoming generally clumsy. She is known to be non compliant with her anti-retroviral therapy. She had no other systemic symptoms such as weight loss and no other past medical history. On examination, one notes power is normal in both upper and lower limbs. However, one notes bilateral dysmetria in the upper limbs and lower limbs. She had an MRI which showed some white matter lesions bilaterally in the parietal lobes. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Cerebral vasculitis	Cerebral metastasis	Multiple sclerosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Toxoplasmosis	D	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating disease caused by JC virus in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV with low CD4), presenting with subacute neurological deficits and white matter lesions on MRI.	HIV + white matter lesions → PML (JC virus).	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P6, Q128: A 74-year-old female presents with headache and neck stiffness to the Emergency Department. Following a lumbar puncture the patient was started on IV ceftriaxone. CSF culture grows Listeria monocytogenes. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Add IV amoxicillin	Change to IV amoxicillin + gentamicin	Add IV ciprofloxacin	Add IV co-amoxiclav	Continue IV ceftriaxone as monotherapy	B	Change to IV amoxicillin + gentamicin	Listeria meningitis is treated with IV amoxicillin/ampicillin plus gentamicin; cephalosporins like ceftriaxone are ineffective against Listeria.	Listeria meningitis: Ampicillin + Gentamicin.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P7, Q129: A 31-year-old woman presents as she has noted an offensive, fishy vaginal discharge. She describes a grey, watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Trichomonas vaginalis	Candida	Chlamydia	Bacterial vaginosis	Physiological discharge	D	Bacterial vaginosis	Bacterial vaginosis presents with a thin, grey, homogenous, fishy-smelling discharge due to overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria and a rise in vaginal pH.	Fishy discharge + clue cells = Bacterial vaginosis.	Gynecology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P8, Q130: An 18-year-old man is bitten by a frantic dog whilst taking a gap year in Ecuador. He is worried about rabies and phones for advice. He was not immunised against prior to travelling to Ecuador. What is the most appropriate advice after thorough cleansing of the wound?	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + full course of vaccination	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + oral penicillin for the next 2 weeks	Advise low risk but take oral co-amoxiclav for the dog bite	Give human rabies immunoglobulin	Give full course of vaccination	A	Give human rabies immunoglobulin + full course of vaccination	For unimmunized individuals with a potential rabies exposure, post-exposure prophylaxis includes human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) and a full course of rabies vaccination.	Rabies PEP: HRIG + vaccine for unimmunized.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P8, Q131: A middle-aged man is diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. What type of virus family is associated with this malignancy?	Reovirus	Herpesvirus	Parvovirus	Adenovirus	Hepadnaviridae	B	Herpesvirus	Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which is a member of the Herpesviridae family.	EBV (Herpesvirus) → Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma.	Oncology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P9, Q132: A 28-year-old man who has recently emigrated from Nigeria presents with a penile ulcer. Examination of the testes was unremarkable but tender inguinal lymphadenopathy was noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Chancroid	Lymphogranuloma venereum	Syphilis	Herpes simplex infection	Granuloma inguinale	A	Chancroid	Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as a painful genital ulcer with a ragged, undermined edge and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.	Painful ulcer + tender nodes = Chancroid (H. ducreyi).	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P9, Q133: A 29-year-old man presents with a nine day history of watery diarrhoea that developed one week after returning from India. Amoebiasis	Giardiasis	Campylobacter	Shigella	Salmonella	B	Giardiasis	Giardiasis causes prolonged, non-bloody, watery diarrhea, often with bloating and flatulence, after a 1-2 week incubation period following travel to endemic areas.	Prolonged watery diarrhea post-travel → Giardia.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P10, Q134: A 63-year-old man presents to the acute receiving ward with a two-week history of a cough, fever, night sweats, weight loss and diarrhoea. He has tender hepatomegaly on examination. His past medical history includes HIV and his recent CD4 count is less than 50. A blood culture reveals mycobacterium avium complex. What is the treatment for this condition?	Rifampicin + Ethambutol	Pentamidine	Rifampicin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide	Rifampicin + Ethambutol + Clarithromycin	Rifampicin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol	D	Rifampicin + Ethambutol + Clarithromycin	Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) in HIV patients with low CD4 counts is treated with a regimen including clarithromycin and ethambutol, often with rifampicin or rifabutin added for severe disease.	MAC treatment: Clarithromycin + Ethambutol ± Rifampicin.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P10, Q135: A 28-year-old student is admitted out of hours to the infectious diseases ward with suspected malaria following a backpacking trip around South East Asia. Malarial films are as follows: Thick film: Parasite burden of 1.5%; Thin film: Non-falciparum malaria - Looks like Plasmodium knowlesi. On admission, the patient is systemically well with observations at follows: HR 90bpm, BP 123/75 mmHg, RR 16 breaths per minute, Oxygen Sats 97% on air, Temp 36.4°. Although being relatively well on first admission, you are called to review her overnight a few hours later, due to her condition worsening. You arrive to find her observations as follows: HR 110bpm, BP 105/65 mmHg, RR 25 breaths per minute, Oxygen Sats 93% on air, Temp 38.4°. Which of the following attributes make Plasmodium knowlesi infections particularly dangerous?	Cytoadherence	Hypnozoite formation	Short erythrocytic replication stage	Resistance to treatment	Slow growth leading to late presentation	C	Short erythrocytic replication stage	Plasmodium knowlesi has a 24-hour erythrocytic cycle, leading to rapid increases in parasite burden and potential for severe disease.	P. knowlesi: 24-hour cycle → rapid parasite increase.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P11, Q136: What is the first line treatment in hydatid disease?	Metronidazole	Ciprofloxacin	Itraconazole	Albendazole	Sodium stibogluconate	D	Albendazole	Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is treated with albendazole, often combined with surgical intervention for cyst management.	Hydatid disease → Albendazole.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P12, Q137: A 30-year-old man has just returned to the UK after visiting Kenya. He did not take any anti-malarials during his visit and received multiple mosquito bites. He is pyrexial but stable at present. Malaria is confirmed with a rapid antigen test. You are waiting for the rest of his test results. Which of the following findings would suggest that he should be treated as having severe malaria? Severe malaria: Parasitaemia >2%.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P12, Q138: A 30-year-old man comes for review. He returned from a holiday in Egypt yesterday. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P13, Q139: A 19-year-old female returns from Ghana. She presents with pyrexia (40°C). She complains of bloody stools preceding this. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P14, Q140: A 19-year-old man presents 3 days after returning from a backpacking trip across Brazil. On examination he has a petechial rash on his limbs. He has no focal neurology and no signs of meningism. Hb 100 g/l, Platelets 80 * 10°/l, WBC 4.0 * 10°/l, Eosinophils 0.4 * 10°/l. Dengue: Fever + rash + thrombocytopenia.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P15, Q141: Which one of the following features is not associated with Lyme disease? Lyme: Erythema migrans, not marginatum.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P15, Q142: A 25-year-old man with a history of epilepsy presents for advice regarding malarial prophylaxis. What is the most appropriate medication to prevent him developing malaria?	Quinine	Atovaquone + proguanil	Mefloquine	Primaquine	Pyrimethamine + sulfadoxine	B	Atovaquone + proguanil	Atovaquone-proguanil (Malarone) is recommended for chloroquine-resistant areas and is safe in epilepsy, unlike mefloquine which is contraindicated.	Malaria prophylaxis in epilepsy: Avoid Mefloquine; use Atovaquone-proguanil or Doxycycline.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P16, Q143: A 33-year-old primigravida woman presents to her GP at 22 weeks gestation with a 2-day history of painful shallow ulcers on the labia and vagina; she has had one prior outbreak of herpes 2 years previously with a viral swab performed at that time positive for HSV2. She is otherwise well and her 20-week scan was normal. She is concerned about how HSV may affect her pregnancy and whether it will be safe for her to deliver vaginally. What should you advise her?	There is high risk of blood borne neonatal transmission of HSV regardless of treatment	All antiviral medications normally used in herpes are teratogenic and should be avoided	Ibuprofen and salt water bathing are recommended for analgesia	Most women with outbreaks of recurrent HSV during pregnancy are recommended to deliver by elective caesarean section	Suppressive treatment with aciclovir from 36 weeks gestation may be considered	E	Suppressive treatment with aciclovir from 36 weeks gestation may be considered	Suppressive aciclovir from 36 weeks reduces viral shedding and the risk of neonatal transmission; it is considered safe in pregnancy.	Recurrent genital herpes in pregnancy: Suppressive aciclovir from 36 weeks; vaginal delivery is usually safe.	Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P16, Q144: A 39-year-old man with HIV is admitted due to shortness of breath. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 119-135 (MRCP4)	P17, Q145: A 67-year-old man is referred to the respiratory clinic. Lung abscess	Invasive aspergillosis	Aspergilloma	Reactivation of primary tuberculosis	Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis	C	Aspergilloma	An aspergilloma (fungus ball) often develops in pre-existing lung cavities (e.g., from prior TB), causing cough, weight loss, and haemoptysis, with positive Aspergillus precipitin antibodies.	Aspergilloma: Fungus ball in old cavity (e.g., post-TB) + haemoptysis.	Respiratory				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P1, Q146: A 47-year-old lady is referred by her GP with a two day history of fever and headache. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P1, Q147: For a patient undergoing an elective splenectomy, when is the optimal time to give the pneumococcal vaccine?	Four weeks before surgery	One week before surgery	Immediately following surgery	Two weeks after surgery	At least one month after surgery	A	Four weeks before surgery	Pneumococcal vaccine should be given at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy to ensure adequate immune response prior to surgery. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P2, Q148: Which one of the following is a Gram positive coccus? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P3, Q149: A 41-year-old female presents with 3 day history of a dry cough and shortness of breath. This was preceded by flu-like symptoms. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P3, Q150: Which one of the following tests is most likely to remain positive in a patient with syphilis despite treatment? Syphilis: Treponemal tests remain positive; non-treponemal tests correlate with disease activity.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P3, Q151: Which of the following is true regarding the Salmonella species?	Rose spots appear in all patients with typhoid	They are normally present in the gut as commensals	They are anaerobic organisms	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever	Salmonella typhi can be categorised into type A, B and C	D	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever	Relative bradycardia (pulse-temperature dissociation) is a classic feature of enteric fever (typhoid). Rose spots occur in only about 40% of patients.	Typhoid: Relative bradycardia, rose spots (40%), constipation more common than diarrhea.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P3, Q152: A 28-year-old female returns from a country that is known to have Zika virus transmission. In view of the possibility of Zika virus, how long should she wait before attempting conception?	2 months	4 months	6 months	8 months	10 months	C	6 months	WHO recommends using barrier methods for 6 months after returning from a Zika-endemic area due to the risk of sexual transmission and potential fetal complications.	Zika: Wait 6 months before attempting conception post-exposure.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P4, Q153: Which one of the following best describes the action of aciclovir? ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P5, Q154: A 45-year-old male presents with yellow discolouration of his nails. On examination he has thickened yellow toe nails. ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P6, Q155: A newly qualified staff nurse at the local hospital undergoes vaccination against hepatitis B. The following results are obtained three months after completion of the primary course: Anti-HBs: 10 - 100 mIU/ml. Reference: An antibody level of >100 mIU/ml indicates a good immune response with protective immunity. What is the most appropriate course of action?	Repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of hepatitis B vaccine	Repeat anti-HBs level in three months time	Give a course of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) + one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Do a HIV test	D	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	An anti-HBs level of 10-100 mIU/ml indicates a suboptimal response. A single booster dose is recommended; no further testing is needed if immunocompetent.	Hep B vaccine: Suboptimal response (10-100 mIU/ml) → give one booster dose.	Immunology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P7, Q156: A 35-year-old man who has recently immigrated from Zimbabwe to the UK presents to the emergency department with fever, myalgia and headaches. He is suspected to have malaria. Which test is most likely to allow for accurate speciation of the malarial pathogen?	Thick blood film	Thin blood film	Quantitative buffy coat analysis	Blood cultures	Point of care malaria test	B	Thin blood film	Thin blood films allow for better visualization of parasite morphology and are used for speciation, while thick films are more sensitive for detecting parasitemia.	Malaria: Thick film for detection, thin film for speciation.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P8, Q157: A 27-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant presents with 'cystitis'. She describes a two day history of dysuria, suprapubic pains and frequency. There has been no vaginal bleeding. Urine dipstick is positive for leucocytes and nitrites. Her temperature is 37.6°C. What is the most appropriate management?	Oral nitrofurantoin	Await the midstream specimen of urine (MSU) result	Oral trimethoprim	Oral ciprofloxacin	Topical clotrimazole	A	Oral nitrofurantoin	Pregnant women with symptomatic UTI should be treated promptly. Nitrofurantoin is safe; trimethoprim (folate antagonist) is avoided in first trimester; ciprofloxacin is contraindicated.	UTI in pregnancy: Nitrofurantoin safe; avoid trimethoprim (1st tri) and quinolones.	Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P8, Q158: A 45-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department due to severe pain in the perineal area over the past 6 hours. IV antibiotics + surgical debridement	IV antibiotics	IV corticosteroids	Plasma exchange	Urgent microscopy of wound swab	A	IV antibiotics + surgical debridement	Necrotizing fasciitis is a surgical emergency. Urgent surgical debridement is critical, along with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.	Necrotizing fasciitis: Surgical debridement is key + IV antibiotics.	Surgery				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P9, Q159: An 82-year-old gentleman admitted with back pain to a medical ward for a magnetic resonance imaging of his spine has a background of prostate cancer under surveillance and a long-term catheter inserted a few weeks ago by urology. A midstream specimen of urine was positive for extended spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) (>100.000 colonies). He claims he has no dysuria and urine in catheter bag looks clear and there are no signs of hematuria. He is also afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Hb 111 g/l, Platelets 236 * 10^9/l, WBC 6.8 * 10^9/l, Na+ 143 mmol/l, K+ 5.1 mmol/l, Urea 6.2 mmol/l, Creatinine 102 μmol/l, CRP 7.8 mg/l. What would be the next step to manage his bacteriuria?	This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	Commence nitrofurantoin 100 mg four times a day for 3 days	Commence one stat dose of gentamicin intravenously and if no response contact microbiology	Check sensitivities first and commence antibiotics regardless of clinic	Remove catheter immediately and contact urology	A	This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	Asymptomatic bacteriuria in a catheterized patient should not be treated except in pregnancy, children <5, or immunocompromised patients, to avoid antibiotic resistance.	Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Do not treat (except pregnancy, children <5, immunocompromised).	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P9, Q160: A 20-year-old man who presented with persistent diarrhoea and abdominal bloating after returning from a gap year in Africa is diagnosed as having strongyloidiasis. How would the Strongyloides stercoralis organism initially entered his body?	Sexual transmission	Faecal oral route	Penetrated the skin	Respiratory droplet route	Mosquito vector	C	Penetrated the skin	Strongyloides stercoralis larvae in soil penetrate the skin (e.g., soles of feet), enter the bloodstream, and migrate to the lungs and then the gut.	Strongyloides: Larvae penetrate skin → autoinfection possible.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P10, Q161: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a productive cough of green sputum and occasional bloody specks. On examination his temperature is 38.3°C, respiratory rate 23/min, heart rate 100/min and there is left basal coarse crackles with a small cold sore above his lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Streptococcal pneumonia	Viral pneumonia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Klebsiella pneumonia	Legionella pneumonia	A	Streptococcal pneumonia	Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Cold sores can be triggered by systemic illness like pneumonia.	CAP: S. pneumoniae most common; cold sore can be associated.	Respiratory				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P10, Q162: A 35-year-old man returns from a two week holiday in Italy. He has a 10 day history of rectal bleeding associated with lower back pain. On examination there is a painful swelling of his right knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Gonococcal septicaemia	Amoebiasis	Crohn's disease	Tuberculosis	Ulcerative colitis	A	Gonococcal septicaemia	Disseminated gonococcal infection can cause proctitis (rectal pain/bleeding) and septic arthritis (knee swelling), often in young adults.	DGI: Triad of tenosynovitis, migratory polyarthritis, dermatitis; can cause proctitis and septic arthritis.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P11, Q163: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent ribavirin?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Protease inhibitor	Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	E	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	Ribavirin is a guanosine analog that inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase and interferes with viral mRNA capping.	Ribavirin: Guanosine analog → inhibits mRNA capping.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P11, Q164: A 33-year-old woman who was diagnosed as having HIV-1 two years ago is reviewed in clinic. She is fit and well currently and has no symptoms of note. The only medication she takes is the occasional paracetamol for tension headaches. Her latest blood tests are as follows: CD4 325 * 10^6/l. What is the most appropriate action with regard with to anti-retroviral therapy?	Wait until the CD4 count is below 200 * 10^6/l	Wait until the CD4 count is above 350 * 10^6/l	Wait until the CD4 count is below 250 * 10^6/l	Start antiretroviral therapy now	Wait until the CD4 count is below 300 * 10^6/l	D	Start antiretroviral therapy now	Current guidelines recommend starting antiretroviral therapy immediately upon HIV diagnosis, regardless of CD4 count, to reduce transmission and improve outcomes.	HIV: Start ART immediately upon diagnosis (irrespective of CD4).	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P12, Q165: A 56-year-old farmer presents with a painless black eschar on his cheek with surrounding swelling and mild fever. The eschar started initially as an itchy boil-like lesion which became enlarged. In the last week, he had been visiting rural farms in the Turkey to help with agriculture work. What diagnosis would need to be considered first?	Necrotic ulcer	Anthrax	Cellulitis	Necrotising spider bite	Scrub typhus	B	Anthrax	Cutaneous anthrax presents as a painless black eschar (malignant pustule) with surrounding edema, often in farmers or handlers of infected animals.	Anthrax: Painless black eschar + edema; farmers at risk.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P12, Q166: You review a 45-year-old woman who has been admitted feeling generally unwell. Four months ago she had a renal transplant and has since been taking a combination of ciclosporin and mycophenolate for immunosuppression. For the past three days she has had fever, dyspnoea and a dry cough. A chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Graft-versus host disease	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	Cell mediated acute transplant rejection	Mycophenolate pneumonitis	Cryptococcus neoformans pneumonia	B	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	CMV pneumonitis is a common opportunistic infection in transplant recipients, typically occurring weeks to months post-transplant, presenting with fever, dry cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates.	Post-transplant pneumonitis: Think CMV.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P13, Q167: A 17-year-old girl presents with a sore throat. On examination she has inflamed tonsils covered in white patches. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy and a low grade pyrexia are also present. Which one of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible?	Streptococcus viridans	Streptococcus agalactiae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Staphylococcus aureus	Streptococcus pyogenes	E	Streptococcus pyogenes	Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) is the most common cause of bacterial pharyngitis/tonsillitis, presenting with exudates, fever, and tender lymphadenopathy.	Strep throat: S. pyogenes (Group A) → exudative tonsillitis + tender nodes.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P14, Q168: A 27-year-old man who has recently moved to the UK from Uganda presents complaining of fatigue and purple skin lesions all over his body. On examination he has multiple raised purple lesions on his trunk and arms. You also notice some smaller purple lesions in his mouth. He has recently started taking acyclovir for herpes zoster infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Dermatofibroma	Kaposi's sarcoma	Drug reaction to acyclovir	Psoriasis	Haemangioma	B	Kaposi's sarcoma	Kaposi's sarcoma, caused by HHV-8, presents with purple papules/plaques on skin and mucosa, often in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV).	Purple skin/mucosal lesions in young adult → Kaposi's sarcoma (think HIV).	Dermatology				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P14, Q169: A 34-year-old sewage worker presents with a 3 days history of lower back pain, fever, myalgia, fatigue, jaundice and a subconjunctival haemorrhage. He has no past medical history and has not been abroad in the last 6 months. Na+ 135 mmol/l, K+ 5.2 mmol/l, Urea 10 mmol/l, Creatinine 180 μmol/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Leptospirosis	Cysticercosis	Glomerulonephritis	Hepatitis A	Hepatitis E	A	Leptospirosis	Leptospirosis (Weil's disease) presents with fever, myalgia, jaundice, renal impairment, and subconjunctival hemorrhage; common in sewage workers exposed to rat urine.	Sewage worker + hepatorenal failure + conjunctival hemorrhage = Leptospirosis.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبMA MCQ Infections::Page 136-150 (MRCP5)	P15, Q170: A 34-year-old male returns from india and upon arriving home is diagnosed with pneumonia that is resistant to multiple antibiotics, in particular to imipenem. What is the likely virulence factor which caused the pneumonia?	D-alanyl-D-lactate variation leading to loss of affinity	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	Presence of MexAB-OprM efflux pumps	Alteration to the penicillin binding protein 2	Reduced permeability & ribosomal modification	B	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1 (NDM-1) is a carbapenemase enzyme that confers resistance to carbapenems (e.g., imipenem) and is prevalent in India.	Carbapenem resistance in India → NDM-1.	Microbiology

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P1, Q1: Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring how many hours after hospital admission?	At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring 48 hours or more after hospital admission that was not present at the time of admission.	HAP = Pneumonia occurring ≥48 hours after hospital admission.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P1, Q2: Drug of choice in Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia?	Cefoperazone	Zidovudine	Aztreonamo	Pentamidine isethionate		D	Pentamidine isethionate	Pentamidine isethionate is an alternative drug of choice for *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP, formerly *P. carinii*) for patients who cannot tolerate the first-line drug, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).	PCP first-line treatment is TMP-SMX; Pentamidine is an alternative, especially for severe cases or intolerance.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P1, Q3: One of the following bundle has been shown to reduce ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) rates:	elevate the head of the bed to between 90 and 120 degrees.	"daily \sedation\"" and intubation"""	daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	no prophylaxis for peptic ulcer is needed.	early ambulation to prevent anti-deep venous thrombosis.	C	daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	VAP bundles include elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees, daily sedation interruption, and daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	VAP Bundle: Head elevation (30-45°), Sedation breaks, PUD/DVT prophylaxis, and Oral care.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P1, Q4: 12 patients presented to a local emergency department with similar symptoms of severe nausea, profuse vomiting, and severe abdominal cramps. A few patients reported diarrhea. The patients report that they were all present at a lunch party two hours ago. The dishes were served from slow cookers, and the food handlers did not wear gloves. None of the patients were found to be febrile. The patients were treated with supportive care and hydration. Within 24 hours, all the patients had resolution of their symptoms. What is the most likely cause of this disease outbreak?	Salmonella infection.	Norovirus infection	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	C. perfringens infection.		C	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	The very short incubation period (2 hours), profuse vomiting, lack of fever, and rapid recovery (within 24 hours) are classic features of food poisoning caused by *Staphylococcus aureus* preformed toxin.	Very short incubation (1-6 hours) + prominent vomiting + no fever = *S. aureus* toxin.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P3, Q5: The primary preventive strategy for community acquired pneumonia is :	Antibiotic therapy	Good hand hygiene	Adherence to healthy lifestyle behaviors	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.		D	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.	Immunization is the most effective primary preventive strategy against Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP), targeting the most common pathogens like *Streptococcus pneumoniae* and influenza virus.	Primary prevention for CAP relies heavily on vaccination (Pneumococcal and Flu).	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P3, Q6: The single most useful clinical sign of severity of pneumonia in a person without underlying lung disease is?	Respiratory rate > 30/minute	Pulse rate 100/minute	Hypothermia	Postural fall of SBP > 10 mm Hg		A	Respiratory rate > 30/minute	A high respiratory rate (>30 breaths/min) is a key component of the CURB-65 severity score for pneumonia and is the most useful sign of severe respiratory compromise.	Severe Pneumonia = CURB-65 criteria. RR > 30/min is a major component.	Respiratory Infections

At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring 48 hours or more after hospital admission.	HAP definition requires onset ≥48 hours post-admission.	Respiratory Infections

CAP most common cause: *Streptococcus pneumoniae*.	Respiratory Infections

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P4, Q10: The single most useful clinical sign of severity of pneumonia in a person without underlying lung disease is?	Respiratory rate > 30/minute	Pulse rate > 100/minute	Hypothermia	Postural fall of SBP > 10 mm Hg		A	Respiratory rate > 30/minute	A respiratory rate greater than 30 breaths/min indicates significant respiratory distress and is a criterion for severe pneumonia according to the CURB-65 scale.	Tachypnea (RR > 30) is the most sensitive sign of severe pneumonia and respiratory distress.	Respiratory Infections

HAP time cutoff is 48 hours.	Respiratory Infections

Macrolides (Erythromycin/Azithromycin) or Fluoroquinolones are first-line for Legionella.	Respiratory Infections

PCP alternative: Pentamidine.	Respiratory Infections

PCP first line: TMP-SMX.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P5, Q15: A 29-year-old man with HIV is admitted with shortness of breath. He has recently emigrated from South Africa and has only just started taking anti-retroviral medication. Auscultation of his chest is unremarkable although chest xray shows bilateral pulmonary interstitial shadowing. What is the investigation of choice?	Bronchoalveolar lavage	CT thorax	Transbronchial biopsy	Sputum culture	Blood culture	A	Bronchoalveolar lavage	The clinical presentation (HIV, SOB, new ART) and CXR (bilateral interstitial shadowing) are highly suggestive of *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP). Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is the most sensitive and specific method to obtain samples for definitive diagnosis.	PCP diagnosis in HIV + bilateral interstitial shadowing → BAL for stain/PCR.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P5, Q16: A 12-year-old boy who had a splenectomy following a roadtraffic accident is reviewed in clinic. He had his full immunisation course as a child and was given a repeat pneumococcal vaccination 5 days following surgery. What is the most appropriate ongoing management?	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + lifelong penicillin V.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + penicillin V for 2 years.	Lifelong penicillin V.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + penicillin V for 2 years.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + lifelong penicillin V.	E	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + lifelong penicillin V.	Post-splenectomy patients are highly susceptible to encapsulated organisms (Pneumococcus, Haemophilus, Meningococcus). Management includes lifelong prophylactic penicillin V, annual influenza vaccine, and boosters for encapsulated bacterial vaccines (Pneumococcal, Hib, MenC).	Asplenic patients need lifelong Penicillin V prophylaxis, annual flu vaccine, and boosters for encapsulated bacteria.	Preventive Medicine				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P6, Q17: A 52-year-old man with a history of alcohol dependence is admitted with fever and feeling generally unwell. An admission chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right upper lobe with early cavitation. What is the most likely causative organism?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophilia	Staphylococcus aureus	Klebsiella pneumoniae	Mycoplasma pneumonia	D	Klebsiella pneumoniae	*Klebsiella pneumoniae* often affects those with chronic alcohol misuse and is classically associated with severe, necrotizing pneumonia, frequently involving the upper lobes and causing cavitation (lung abscess formation).	Right Upper Lobe Pneumonia + Alcoholism + Cavitation = *Klebsiella pneumoniae*.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P6, Q18: You review a 14-year-old boy who has recently emigrated from Russia. He was involved in car accident two years ago and underwent an emergency splenectomy. Following this he takes penicillin V on a daily basis. He is unsure of his vaccination history. Which organism is he particularly susceptible to?	Staphylococcus aureus	HIV	Haemophilus influenzae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	D	Streptococcus pneumoniae	An asplenic patient is highly susceptible to severe infection by encapsulated bacteria, with Streptococcus pneumoniae being the most common and dangerous cause of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).	Asplenia significantly increases susceptibility to encapsulated organisms: S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, N. meningitidis.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P6, Q19: A 34-year-old man from Swaziland presents the the emergency department with a 3 day history of fever, shortness of breath and a dry cough. His past medical history ncludes tuberculosis and HIV and his most recent CD4 count is 150. On examination: heart rate 100/min, blood pressure 110/80mmHg, respiratory rate 28/min, oxygen saturation 98% on air at rest, dropping to 80% on walking. His temperature is 38.5ºC. On auscultation, his chest is clear. How would you treat this man?	IV cefotaxime	Oral ciprofloxacin	IV tazocin	Oral rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol	Oral co-trimoxazole	E	Oral co-trimoxazole	The presentation (HIV, CD4 < 200, dry cough, desaturation on exertion) is highly suggestive of *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP), for which co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the first-line treatment.	CD4 < 200 + PCP symptoms (esp. desaturation on exertion) = Treat with Co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P7, Q20: A 37-year-old woman who is being treated as an inpatient for Mycoplasma pneumonia is reviewed. Unfortunately she is unable to tolerate clarithromycin due to severe nausea. What is the most suitable alternative antibiotic?	Linezolid	Cefaclor	Ciprofloxacin	Co-amoxiclav	Doxycycline	E	Doxycycline	*Mycoplasma pneumoniae* is an atypical bacterium lacking a cell wall, making beta-lactams (like cefaclor or co-amoxiclav) ineffective. Doxycycline (a tetracycline) is a suitable alternative to macrolides (like clarithromycin) for atypical pneumonias.	Atypical pneumonia (Mycoplasma/Chlamydia) requires Macrolides, Tetracyclines (Doxycycline), or Fluoroquinolones.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P7, Q21: A 31-year-old female with no past medical history of note is admitted to hospital with dyspnoea and fever. She has recently returned from holiday in Turkey. A clinical diagnosis of pneumonia is made. On examination she is noted to have an ulcerated lesion on her upper lip consistent with reactivation of herpes simplex. Which organism is most associated with this examination finding?	Legionella pneumophilia	Staphylococcus aureus	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis carinii	Mycoplasma pneumonia	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumonia caused by *Streptococcus pneumoniae* is classically associated with the reactivation of herpes simplex virus (HSV) on the lips (herpes labialis).	Herpes labialis (cold sore) in pneumonia suggests *Streptococcus pneumoniae*.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P7, Q22: Which one of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus pyogenes infection?	Rheumatic fever	Scarlet fever	Cellulitis	Type 2 necrotizing fasciitis	Pneumonia	E	Pneumonia	*Streptococcus pyogenes* (Group A Strep) is primarily associated with pharyngitis (strep throat), skin infections (cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis), and post-infectious syndromes (rheumatic fever, scarlet fever). It is an uncommon cause of pneumonia.	*S. pyogenes* is common for pharyngitis and skin infection (Cellulitis/NF), but rare for pneumonia.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P8, Q23: A 39-year-old man with HIV is admitted due to shortness of breath. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia is suspected. What type of staining should be applied to the bronchoalveolar lavage to demonstrate the organism?	Rubeanic acid	Silver stain	Pearl's stain	Rose Bengal	Congo red	B	Silver stain	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* (formerly *P. carinii*) cysts are typically detected using various silver stains, such as the Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain, on specimens obtained via bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).	PCP diagnosis: GMS (Silver) stain on BAL fluid.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P8, Q24: A 47-year-old lady is referred by her GP with a two day history of fever and headache. She is normally fit and well and has no past medical history of note. On examination you note nuchal rigidity. Investigations show the following: Serum glucose 4.9 mmol/l, Lumbar puncture reveals: Opening pressure 14 cmCSF, Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 1.7 mmol/l, Protein 1.9 g/l, White cells 900/mm3 (90% polymorphs). What is the most likely infective agent?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	coli	Listeria monocytogenes	Enterovirus	Streptococcus pyogenes	A	Streptococcus pneumoniae	The CSF picture (high WCC with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, high protein, and cloudy appearance) is classic for acute bacterial meningitis. In a previously healthy adult, the most common cause is Streptococcus pneumoniae.	Bacterial meningitis is typically neutrophilic, hypoglycorrhachic (low glucose), and hyperproteinemic (high protein). S. pneumoniae is the most common cause in adults.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P9, Q25: For a patient undergoing an elective splenectomy, when is the optimal time to give the pneumococcal vaccine?	Four weeks before surgery	One week before surgery	Immediately following surgery	Two weeks after surgery	At least one month after surgery	A	Four weeks before surgery	Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (like pneumococcus) should be completed at least two weeks before elective splenectomy, ideally four weeks prior, to allow for an optimal and effective antibody response.	Vaccination (especially pneumococcal) should be given 2-4 weeks *before* elective splenectomy for maximal immune response.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P9, Q26: A 41-year-old female presents with 3 day history of a dry cough and shortness of breath. This was preceded by flu-like symptoms. On examination there is a symmetrical, erythematous rash with 'target' lesions over the whole body. What is the likely organism causing the symptoms?	Pseudomonas	Staphylococcus aureus	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Chlamydia pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophilia	C	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	*Mycoplasma pneumoniae* causes 'atypical' pneumonia, often preceded by flu-like symptoms, and is strongly associated with extrapulmonary manifestations like erythema multiforme (rash with target lesions).	Atypical Pneumonia + Erythema Multiforme (Target Lesions) = *Mycoplasma pneumoniae*.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P9, Q27: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a productive cough of green sputum and occasional bloody specks. On examination his temperature is 38.3ºC, respiratory rate 23/min, heart rate 100/min and there is left basal coarse crackles with a small cold sore above his lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Streptococcal pneumonia	Viral pneumonia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Klebsiella pneumonia	Legionella pneumonia	A	Streptococcal pneumonia	The combination of fever, productive cough (purulent sputum), and the presence of a cold sore (herpes labialis) strongly suggests classic bacterial pneumonia caused by *Streptococcus pneumoniae*.	Pneumonia + Herpes Labialis (Cold Sore) = *Streptococcus pneumoniae* (Pneumococcus).	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P10, Q28: You review a 45-year-old woman who has been admitted feeling generally unwell. Four months ago she had a renal transplant and has since been taking a combination of ciclosporin and mycophenolate for immunosuppression. For the past three days she has had fever, dyspnoea and a dry cough. A chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Graft-versus host disease	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	Cell mediated acute transplant rejection	Mycophenolate pneumonitis	Cryptococcus neoformans pneumonia	B	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	*Cytomegalovirus* (CMV) pneumonitis is a common and serious opportunistic infection in solid organ transplant recipients (especially lung and renal) occurring typically 1-6 months post-transplant, presenting with fever, dry cough, dyspnoea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on CXR.	Post-transplant (1-6 months) + Fever + Dry Cough + Bilateral Interstitial Infiltrates = CMV Pneumonitis.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P10, Q29: A 34-year-old male returns from india and upon arriving home is diagnosed with pneumonia that is resistant to multiple antibiotics, in particular to imipenem. What is the likely virulence factor which caused the pneumonia?	D-alanyl-D-lactate variation leading to loss of affinity	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	Presence of MexAB-OprM efflux pumps	Alteration to the penicillin binding protein 2	Reduced permeability & ribosomal modification	B	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1 (NDM-1) is an enzyme that confers resistance to nearly all beta-lactam antibiotics, including carbapenems like imipenem. Its spread has been prominently linked to travel in the Indian subcontinent.	Resistance to Carbapenems (Imipenem) in a traveler from India = NDM-1.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P10, Q30: Which one of the following statements is true regarding Listeria monocytogenes?	Multiplies rapidly at high temperatures	The organism is resistant to ampicillin	It is a Gram negative bacillus	It is diagnosed by the presence of urinary antigen	May cause ataxia	E	May cause ataxia	*Listeria monocytogenes* can cause rhombencephalitis (brainstem encephalitis), which often presents with fever, cranial nerve palsies, and cerebellar symptoms, including ataxia. It is a Gram-positive bacillus, usually sensitive to ampicillin.	*Listeria* causes rhombencephalitis, which classically presents with CN palsies and ataxia.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P11, Q31: Which one of the following is a Gram negative coccus?	Haemophilus influenzae	Moraxella catarrhalis	Enterococcus faecalis	Listeria monocytogenes	Campylobacter jejuni	B	Moraxella catarrhalis	*Moraxella catarrhalis* is a Gram-negative diplococcus, often resembling a bean shape. *Haemophilus* and *Campylobacter* are Gram-negative bacilli, while *Enterococcus* and *Listeria* are Gram-positive organisms.	*Moraxella* and *Neisseria* are the main Gram-negative cocci (diplococci).	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P11, Q32: A 31-year-old man is admitted to hospital with a 4 day history of fever and dyspnoea. He is known to be HIV positive but poorly compliant with his antiretroviral therapy (ART). Bloods taken during a clinic visit two weeks ago show the following: CD4 180 cells/μ l. On examination today his pulse is 102/min, oxygen saturations 97% on room air with a temperature of 38.1ºC. He has coarse crackles on the right side of his chest. A chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right mid zone. Moraxella catarrhalis What is the most likely causative organism?	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Cryptococcus neoformans	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis jirovecii	Histoplasma capsulatum	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	In HIV patients with CD4 counts above 100-200, **common community-acquired pathogens**, such as *Streptococcus pneumoniae*, remain the most frequent causes of typical lobar pneumonia, often presenting with consolidation. PCP typically presents with bilateral interstitial infiltrates and a CD4 count < 200.	HIV patients with CD4 > 200 are still most susceptible to common CAP pathogens, like *S. pneumoniae*.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P11, Q33: A 55-year-old man is referred to the medical admissions unit. He recently returned from a holiday in Italy and has failed to respond to a course of co-amoxiclav for a suspected lower respiratory tract infection. Chest x-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. Bloods are as follows: Na+ 122 mmol/l, K+ 4.3 mmol/l, Urea 8.4 mmol/l, Creatinine 130 μmol/l. What is the likely diagnosis?	Goodpasture's syndrome	Legionella pneumonia	Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia	Pulmonary eosinophilia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	B	Legionella pneumonia	The triad of atypical pneumonia (failure to respond to beta-lactam, bilateral infiltrates), hyponatraemia (low Na+), and acute kidney injury (raised urea/creatinine) is highly suggestive of Legionella pneumophila infection.	Legionella: Atypical pneumonia + hyponatraemia + deranged LFTs/AKI.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P12, Q34: A 69-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by ambulance, with a few days history of increasing shortness of breath, fever and a productive cough. On review, you find: HR 105 bpm, Oxygen saturation 90% on air, BP 100/65 mmHg, Temp 38.9°C, Respiratory Rate 32 breaths per minute, Chest X-ray right mid-zone cavity with surrounding consolidation. He reports that he and his wife both caught a 'bad cold' from their grandchildren about a month ago. What is the most likely cause for this gentleman's symptoms?	Lung cancer	Klebsiella pneumoniae infection	Staphylococcus aureus infection	Pulmonary tuberculosis	Streptococcus pneumoniae infection	C	Staphylococcus aureus infection	The presentation features a preceding viral illness (cold from grandchildren) followed by severe necrotizing pneumonia (cavity on CXR, severe vital signs (low BP, high RR, low Sats)). This is characteristic of secondary bacterial pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus (often MRSA in HAP, but can follow influenza in CAP).	Post-viral pneumonia (especially influenza) with rapid severe course and cavitation/necrosis suggests secondary S. aureus infection.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P13, Q35: A 28-year-old male presents with shortness of breath, dry cough and fever for one week. Prior to this, he had been generally unwell for several months complaining of weight loss, fatigue, generalised lymphadenopathy and myalgia. He admits to using intravenous drugs in the past. Observations reveal O2 sats 88% on air, heart rate 112 bpm, blood pressure 124/85mmHg, respiratory rate 24/min and temperature 37.8ºC. His chest is clear and heart sounds are normal. On mobilising his O2 sats drop to 75% on air and he is acutely short of breath. Chest x-ray shows bilateral perihilar shadowing. Arterial blood gas on 5 litres of oxygen shows: PH 7.41, PaO2 8.9 kPa, PaCO2 3.6 kPa. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?	Amoxicillin and clarithromycin	Co-trimoxazole	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	Doxycycline	Oseltamivir	C	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	The presentation (IVDU, chronic illness, dry cough, fever, hypoxia, bilateral interstitial CXR, marked desaturation on exertion) is classic for **Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)** in an HIV patient. For severe PCP (PaO2  35 mmHg), the treatment is high-dose co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX) PLUS **adjunctive corticosteroids (prednisolone)**.	Severe PCP (PaO2 < 9.3 kPa) treatment is TMP-SMX + Steroids (Prednisolone).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P13, Q36: A 28-year-old man who is immunosuppressed secondary to HIV infection is admitted to hospital with dyspnoea and a dry cough. His chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial pulmonary infiltrates and he is started on co-trimoxazole empirically. The following morning he complains of a sudden worsening of his dyspnoea associated with left-sided chest pain. Which complication is most likely to have developed?	Empyema	Pulmonary embolism	Acute respiratory distress syndrome	Pericarditis	Pneumothorax	E	Pneumothorax	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP) is associated with the development of pulmonary cysts (pneumatoceles) which can rupture, leading to a spontaneous pneumothorax, presenting as sudden chest pain and worsening dyspnoea.	Spontaneous pneumothorax is a common complication in HIV patients with PCP.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P14, Q37: A 39-year-old man presents with shortness of breath following one week of flu-like symptoms. He also has a nonproductive cough but no chest pain. A chest x-ray shows bilateral consolidation and examination reveals erythematous lesions on his limbs and trunk. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to be diagnostic?	Cold agglutins	Sputum culture	Urinary antigen for Legionella	Serology for Mycoplasma	Blood culture	D	Serology for Mycoplasma	This presentation (flu-like prodrome, dry cough, bilateral infiltrates, erythema multiforme/lesions) is classic for **Mycoplasma pneumonia**. Serology (for IgM or a four-fold rise in IgG titer) is the most common diagnostic method, as culture is difficult. Cold agglutinins are a less specific but associated finding.	Atypical pneumonia + Extrapulmonary signs (rash) suggests Mycoplasma; Serology is the primary diagnostic method.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P14, Q38: A 44-year-old man who is known to be HIV positive presents with shortness-of-breath. Which one of the following features is most characteristic of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia?	Usually occurs when the CD4 count is 200-300/mm^3	Absence of fever	Productive cough	Oxygen saturations usually improve after short period of exertion	Normal chest auscultation	E	Normal chest auscultation	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP) typically causes significant pulmonary symptoms and CXR findings (bilateral interstitial shadowing) but often presents with a **disproportionately normal chest auscultation**. It is most common with CD4 counts < 200.	PCP classic sign: Severe respiratory symptoms and CXR changes, but clear or nearly normal chest auscultation.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P15, Q1: Release of which of the following results in fever?	Interleukin (IL) 8	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor	Interleukin (IL) 1	Tumor necrosis factor		C	Interleukin (IL) 1	Fever is primarily caused by **pyrogenic cytokines** (endogenous pyrogens) acting on the hypothalamus. The main ones are Interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-α).	Key Pyrogens: IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P15, Q2: In neutropenic fever, absolute count of neutrophils is?	<= 1000 per mm3	<= 500 per mm3	<= 850 per mm3	> 1000 per mm3		B	<= 500 per mm3	Neutropenia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of less than $500~cells/mm^3$. Fever in this setting is termed febrile neutropenia, which requires urgent empirical antibiotics.	Absolute Neutropenia = ANC < 500 cells/mm^3.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P15, Q3: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitaris	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) causes severe **hyperthermia** (high fever) due to a loss of central thermoregulation. The other conditions (panhypopituitarism, myxoedema coma, and circulatory failure) can all lead to hypothermia.	NMS causes hyperthermia (high fever), not hypothermia.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P15, Q4: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	Prostaglandin F	T-regulator cells	Prostaglandin E2	Cell adhesion molecule		C	Prostaglandin E2	Pyrogenic cytokines (IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α) stimulate the release of **Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)** in the hypothalamus, which acts to raise the thermoregulatory set-point, causing fever.	PGE2 is the final mediator that raises the hypothalamic set-point to cause fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P15, Q5: Each attack of FMF usually lasts for:	6 hours to 2 days	12 hours to 3 days	24 hours to 7 days	3 days to 10 days		A	6 hours to 2 days	Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) attacks are typically characterized by recurrent, self-limiting episodes of fever and serositis lasting from 6 hours to 2-3 days, though the range given in the source options is 6 hours to 2 days.	FMF attacks are short-lived, self-resolving, and last less than 3 days.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P16, Q6: Which is not a cause of aseptic fever	Crush injury	SLE	AIDS	Pontine haemorrhage		D	Pontine haemorrhage	Pontine hemorrhage is a cause of **central fever** (non-infectious hyperthermia due to direct hypothalamic damage), but it is a cause of fever (pyrexia). Aseptic fever refers to fever without infection; a pontine hemorrhage is a CNS cause of fever, not an aseptic cause. *Correction based on standard medical knowledge: Pontine hemorrhage causes hyperthermia, not hypothermia, but this is a central fever, which is non-infectious, or 'aseptic'. Crush injury, SLE, and AIDS are also non-infectious causes of fever (aseptic fever). The question is likely looking for a cause of fever/hyperthermia that is *not* typically classified under the common categories of aseptic fever or simply asking which one causes hyperthermia/fever. However, a massive pontine hemorrhage usually causes **hyperpyrexia** due to loss of heat control, not the other way around. Based on the options, this seems to be the least common association with 'aseptic fever' in the context of the others. Let's assume the question is flawed and select the most common non-infectious causes. Let's choose AIDS (due to associated infections). Let's re-read the options and typical causes. Aseptic fever causes are: Drug reaction, Malignancy, Trauma (Crush Injury), Autoimmune (SLE), CNS (Pontine Hemorrhage). The question is likely flawed, but Pontine Hemorrhage is a unique cause of central hyperthermia and is a direct neurological cause unlike the others.	Pontine hemorrhage causes central hyperthermia due to hypothalamic damage. Crush injury and SLE cause aseptic fever via cytokine release.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P16, Q7: A 30 years man from Australia returned from a business trip to Indonesia 6d ago presenting with complaints of fever, joint and muscle ache and headache, in particular behind the eye for the past 2 days. This presentation is characteristic of Dengue fever.	Fever + Retro-orbital headache + Travel to endemic area = Dengue fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P16, Q8: Release of which of the following results in fever? IL-8 is a chemokine and G-CSF promotes neutrophil production.	IL-1 is a primary pyrogenic cytokine that causes fever.	Fever

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P17, Q10: Cyclical periods of pyrexia alternating with a pyrexia is found in all except	Relapsing fever	Leprosy	Hodgkin's disease	Brucellosis		B	Leprosy	Cyclical fever (e.g., Pell-Ebstein fever in Hodgkin's disease, undulant fever in Brucellosis, or recurrent spirochete infection in Relapsing Fever) is a feature of the other options, but not typical for leprosy, which is a chronic condition.	Cyclical fevers are common in Hodgkin's (Pel-Ebstein), Brucellosis (Undulant), and Relapsing fever (Borrelia), but not Leprosy.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P17, Q11: Faget's sign (relative bradycardia) is first described in	Typhoid fever	Yellow fever	Acute rheumatic fever	Brucellosis		B	Yellow fever	Faget's sign is the paradoxical finding of bradycardia (slow heart rate) despite the presence of fever. While classically associated with Yellow fever, it is also seen in Typhoid fever, Brucellosis, and others.	Faget's sign (Bradycardia with fever) is characteristic of Yellow fever, Typhoid, and Brucellosis.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P17, Q12: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitarism	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) causes severe **hyperthermia** (high fever) due to impaired heat dissipation and increased heat production, not hypothermia.	NMS causes hyperthermia.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P17, Q13: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	1- Prostaglandin F	2- T-regulator cells	3- Prostaglandin E2	4- Cell adhesion molecule		3	Prostaglandin E2	Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is the molecule that directly acts on the hypothalamus to raise the thermoregulatory set-point, thereby causing fever.
