ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P112, Q6: Which one of the followings is considered to be complicated acute pyelonephritis?	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with sever flank pain	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	Acute pyelonephritis with high fever		C	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	**Complicated acute pyelonephritis** refers to infection in a patient with underlying structural, functional, or metabolic abnormalities. The presence of **renal dysfunction** (e.g., elevated creatinine, impaired GFR) indicates a complication or underlying compromise, classifying it as complicated.	Pyelonephritis with structural/functional abnormality (e.g., renal dysfunction) is Complicated Pyelonephritis.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P112, Q7: Which one of the following need treatment at hospital?	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with high leukocytosis	Acute pyelonephritis with fever 39 C		A	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	Acute Pyelonephritis requires hospital admission and IV antibiotics if there are signs of severe sepsis, inability to tolerate oral intake, or the presence of complicating factors. **Diabetes Mellitus (DM)** is a complicating factor that often mandates inpatient treatment due to increased risk of complications (e.g., emphysematous pyelonephritis) and treatment failure.	Acute Pyelonephritis in a diabetic patient often requires hospital admission for IV antibiotics.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P112, Q8: Microscopic pyuria defined as pyuria associated with	WBCs more than 10/CM	WBCs more than 50/CM	WBCs more than 100/CM	Positive leukocyte esterase		A	WBCs more than 10/CM	**Microscopic pyuria** is generally defined as the presence of $\ge 10$ leukocytes (white blood cells) per cubic millimeter (or per high-power field, depending on the standard used) in a urine sample.	Pyuria is defined as $\ge 10$ WBCs/CM (or per HPF).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P112, Q9: In patients with urinary tract infections the ultrasonography indicated in	Patients with severe flank pain	Patients with high fever	Patients with high pyuria	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment		D	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment	Imaging (e.g., Ultrasound or CT) is generally not required for uncomplicated UTIs/pyelonephritis. It is indicated if there is suspicion of complicated infection, such as recurrent episodes, haematuria, evidence of obstruction (e.g., stones), or most importantly, **failure to clinically improve after 72 hours (3 days) of appropriate antibiotic therapy**.	Imaging (US/CT) for UTI is mainly indicated for non-improving symptoms after 72 hours of treatment.	Clinical Testing				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P113, Q10: Patients with acute pyelonephritis can be treated by	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	Ciprofloxacin orally for 14 days	Ciprofloxacin, IV for 7 days	Ceftriaxone 1 g IV for 5 days		A	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	Uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis can often be treated effectively with an oral Fluoroquinolone (e.g., Ciprofloxacin or Levofloxacin) for a duration of **7 days**. More severe or complicated cases may require IV therapy and longer durations.	Oral Ciprofloxacin for 7 days is a standard regimen for uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P113, Q11: Infection with Schistosoma haematobium is most strongly associated with:	A. Transitional cell bladder cancer	B. Lung cancer	C. Hepatoma	D. Vulval carcinoma	E. Squamous cell bladder cancer	E	Squamous cell bladder cancer	Chronic infection and inflammation of the bladder wall caused by **Schistosoma haematobium** (urinary schistosomiasis) is a major risk factor for the development of **Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Bladder**, a relatively rare form of bladder cancer otherwise.	*S. haematobium* causes chronic bladder inflammation, a risk factor for Squamous Cell Bladder Cancer.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P113, Q12: A 54 year old female is admitted with a severe pneumonia following a holiday in Turkey. Bloods reveal both hyponatraemia and deranged liver function tests. A chest xray shows patchy alveolar infiltrates with consolidation in the right lower lobe. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the probable diagnosis?	A. Sputum culture	B. Urinary antigen	C. Blood cultures	D. Bone marrow aspirate	E. Lumbar puncture	B	Urinary antigen	The presentation (severe pneumonia, hyponatremia, deranged LFTs, travel history) is highly suggestive of **Legionella pneumonia**. The most reliable and rapid non-invasive test for *Legionella pneumophila* serogroup 1 (the most common cause) is the **Urinary Antigen Test**.	Pneumonia + Hyponatremia + Travel = Legionella. Test of choice is Urinary Antigen.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P113, Q13: A 23-year-old male presents with a purulent urethral discharge. A sample of the discharge is shown to be a Gram negative diplococcus. What is the most appropriate antimicrobial therapy?	Oral ciprofloxacin for 7 days	Oral penicillin V for 7 days	Oral doxycycline for 7 days	Oral azithromycin stat dose	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	E	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	The finding of a Gram-negative diplococcus in urethral discharge is diagnostic of **Gonococcal Urethritis** (*Neisseria gonorrhoeae*). The recommended first-line treatment is **dual therapy**: a single IM dose of **Ceftriaxone** (for *N. gonorrhoeae*) plus a single oral dose of **Azithromycin** (to cover co-infection with *C. trachomatis*).	Gonococcal Urethritis: Ceftriaxone IM + Azithromycin PO dual therapy.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P114, Q14: A 22-year-old female presents with an offensive vaginal discharge. History and examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. What is the most appropriate initial management?	Oral azithromycin	Topical hydrocortisone	Oral metronidazole	Clotrimazole pessary	Advice regarding hygiene and cotton underwear	C	Oral metronidazole	**Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)**, characterized by an offensive/fishy odor and thin, watery discharge, is caused by an overgrowth of *Gardnerella vaginalis* and other anaerobes. The first-line treatment is a 7-day course of **Oral Metronidazole** (or topical Metronidazole/Clindamycin).	First-line treatment for Bacterial Vaginosis is Oral Metronidazole.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P114, Q15: A 24-year-old heterosexual man presents to GUM with a history of dysuria, urethral irritation and milky discharge from the urethra. Urethral microscopy reveals >10 polynuclear lymphocytes per field but no gonorrhoea is seen and urine dip is normal. He did a home test 3 days ago when his symptoms started and Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea NAATs were negative. His last sexual encounter was 3 weeks ago. You make a clinical diagnosis of non specific urethritis (NSU). What is the most appropriate action to take?	Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	Reassure the patient; his symptoms will resolve spontaneously	Tell the patient to repeat his Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea tests in 2 weeks' time.	Start oral aciclovir	Refer to urology for their assessment and opinion	A	Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	The clinical diagnosis of Non-Specific Urethritis (NSU) (urethral discharge + microscopic evidence of inflammation/PMNs) warrants **empiric treatment** even with negative initial NAATs (false negatives are possible, and the cause is often non-chlamydial). **Doxycycline for 7 days** is one of the two main first-line regimens for NGU/NSU.	Clinical NSU should be treated empirically with Doxycycline for 7 days or single-dose Azithromycin.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P114, Q16: A nurse in a GUM clinic asks you to look at a rectal gramstained slide for a symptomatic patient she has just seen. It shows pinkish/red stained intracellular diplococci. What is the most likely organism?	A. Neisseria Meningitidis	B. Probable contaminant/commensal organism	C. Chlamydia trachomatis	D. Escherichia coli	E. Neisseria gonorrhea	E	Neisseria gonorrhea	**Gram-negative (pink/red) intracellular diplococci** seen on a Gram stain of an endocervical, urethral, or rectal specimen are considered diagnostic for **Neisseria gonorrhoeae** infection.	Gram-negative intracellular diplococci from a genital/rectal swab = *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P115, Q17: A 34-year-old man from Zimbabwe is admitted with abdominal pain to the Emergency Department. An abdominal x-ray reveals urinary bladder calcification. What is the most likely cause?	A. Schistosoma mansoni	B. Sarcoidosis	C. Leishmaniasis	D. Tuberculosis	E. Schistosoma haematobium	E	Schistosoma haematobium	**Urinary bladder calcification** (a late complication of chronic inflammation) in a patient from an endemic area (Zimbabwe/Africa) is the hallmark finding for chronic infection with **Schistosoma haematobium** (Urinary Schistosomiasis).	Bladder Calcification + African Travel = Chronic *Schistosoma haematobium* infection.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P115, Q18: A 24-year-old woman presents due to an itchy vulva and pain during sex. She also mentions a green, offensive vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Candida	B. Bacterial vaginosis	C. Gonorrhoea	D. Trichomonas vaginalis	E. Chlamydia	D	Trichomonas vaginalis	The classic presentation of **Trichomoniasis** (*Trichomonas vaginalis*) is a highly characteristic **green/yellow, frothy, offensive vaginal discharge**, often accompanied by vulval itching (pruritus) and dyspareunia (painful sex).	Green, frothy, offensive discharge + Pruritus = *Trichomonas vaginalis*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P115, Q19: A 24-year-old student returns from a gap year in Malawi complaining of visible haematuria, dysuria and urinary frequency. She says she felt well throughout her trip but experienced an itchy rash on her legs a few hours after swimming in Lake Malawi which has now resolved. Her blood results show: Hb 98 g/l, Eosinophils 0.5 * 109/l. How would you treat her?	Albendazole	Trimethoprim	Prednisolone	Doxycycline	Praziquantel	E	Praziquantel	The history (swimming in Lake Malawi), initial itchy rash (swimmer's itch), and current presentation (haematuria, dysuria) with laboratory **Eosinophilia** are classic for active infection with **Schistosoma haematobium** (urinary schistosomiasis). The treatment of choice for schistosomiasis is a single or dual dose of **Praziquantel**.	Schistosomiasis (haematuria, eosinophilia, fresh-water exposure) is treated with Praziquantel.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P116, Q20: A 31-year-old woman presents as she has noted an offensive, fishy vaginal discharge. She describes a grey, watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Trichomonas vaginalis	B. Candida	C. Chlamydia	D. Bacterial vaginosis	E. Physiological discharge	D	Bacterial vaginosis	The classic presentation of **Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)** is a thin, homogenous **grey or white vaginal discharge** with a characteristic **'fishy' odor** (due to volatile amines).	Grey, watery, fishy-smelling discharge = Bacterial Vaginosis.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P116, Q21: A 27-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant presents with 'cystitis'. She describes a two day history of dysuria, suprapubic pains and frequency. Urine dipstick is positive for leucocytes and nitrites. Her temperature is 37.6ºC. What is the most appropriate management?	Oral nitrofurantoin	Await the midstream specimen of urine (MSU) result	Oral trimethoprim	Oral ciprofloxacin	Topical clotrimazole	A	Oral nitrofurantoin	A UTI (cystitis) in a pregnant woman should be treated immediately due to the high risk of progression to pyelonephritis and obstetric complications. **Nitrofurantoin** is a safe first-line oral antibiotic for cystitis in the first two trimesters of pregnancy. Trimethoprim is generally avoided in the first trimester.	First-line treatment for cystitis in early pregnancy is oral Nitrofurantoin.	Pharmacology/Obstetrics				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P117, Q22: An 82-year-old gentleman admitted with back pain to a medical ward for a magnetic resonance imaging of his spine has a background of prostate cancer under surveillance and a long-term catheter inserted a few weeks ago by urology. A midstream specimen of urine was positive for extended spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) (>100,000 colonies). He claims he has no dysuria and urine in catheter bag looks clear and there is no sign of haematuria. He is also afebrile and hemodynamically stable. What would be the next step to manage his bacteriuria?	This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	Commence nitrofurantoin 100 mg four times a day for 3 days	Commence one stat dose of gentamicin intravenously and if no response contact microbiology	Check sensitivities first and commence antibiotics regardless of clinic	Remove catheter immediately and contact urology	A	This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	This patient has **Asymptomatic Bacteriuria (ABU)**, which is common in patients with long-term indwelling urinary catheters and should **NOT** be treated with antibiotics unless the patient becomes symptomatic (fever, dysuria, systemic signs). Treating ABU increases the risk of selecting for resistant organisms (like the ESBL *E. coli*).	Asymptomatic Bacteriuria in catheterized patients should NOT be treated with antibiotics.	Infectious Diseases/Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P118, Q22: A 35-year-old man returns from a two week holiday in Italy. He has a 10 day history of rectal bleeding associated with lower back pain. On examination there is a painful swelling of his right knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Gonococcal septicaemia	B. Amoebiasis	C. Crohn's disease	D. Tuberculosis	E. Ulcerative colitis	C	Crohn's disease	The combination of gastrointestinal symptoms (**rectal bleeding**) and the presence of **extraintestinal manifestations** (**arthritis/painful knee swelling**) suggests an Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) like Crohn's disease or Ulcerative Colitis. The travel history to Italy is a distractor, and an acute infection is less likely to cause a 10-day course of rectal bleeding and arthritis.	Rectal Bleeding + Extraintestinal Manifestation (Arthritis) = Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's/UC).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P118, Q23: A 30-year-old woman presents with a white, malodorous vaginal discharge. There is no associated itch or dyspareunia. A diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is suspected. Overgrowth of which one of the following organisms is most likely to cause this presentation?	A. Lactobacilli	B. Trichomonas	C. Candida	D. Mycoplasma hominis	E. Gardnerella	E	Gardnerella	**Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)** is characterized by a reduction in protective *Lactobacilli* and an overgrowth of various anaerobic bacteria, predominantly **Gardnerella vaginalis**, which is responsible for the characteristic fishy odor and grey discharge.	Bacterial Vaginosis is caused by overgrowth of *Gardnerella vaginalis* and other anaerobes.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P118, Q24: An 18-year-old male is admitted with fever, headache and neck stiffness. He receives IV ceftriaxone. A lumbar puncture and culture of his cerebrospinal fluid reveal that the pathogenic organism is Neisseria meningitides. What is the appearance of this bacterium on gram staining?	A. Gram-positive cocci	B. Gram-negative cocci	C. Gram-positive rod	D. Gram-negative rod	E. Poorly staining organism	B	Gram-negative cocci	**Neisseria meningitidis** is a classic encapsulated, non-motile, oxidase-positive bacterium that is classified as a **Gram-negative diplococcus (cocci)**.	*Neisseria meningitidis* is a Gram-negative diplococcus.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P119, Q25: A 19-year-old woman is reviewed in the genitourinary medicine clinic. She presented with vaginal discharge and dysuria. Microscopy of an endocervical swab showed a Gram-negative coccus that was later identified as Neisseria gonorrhoea. This is her third episode of gonorrhoea in the past two years. What is the most likely complication from repeated infection?	A. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome	B. Cervical cancer	C. Arthropathy	D. Infertility	E. Uterine abscess	D	Infertility	Repeated episodes of **Gonococcal infection** (and Chlamydia) in women cause chronic, ascending infection that leads to **Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)**. PID causes scarring of the fallopian tubes, which is the most common cause of tubal-factor **infertility** and ectopic pregnancy.	Recurrent Gonorrhea/Chlamydia most commonly leads to Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) and subsequent Infertility.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P119, Q26: A 38-year-old man presents to the genitourinary clinic with multiple, painless genital ulcers. A diagnosis of granuloma inguinale is made. What is the causative organism?	A. Klebsiella granulomatis	B. Chlamydia	C. Herpes simplex virus	D. Treponema pallidum	E. Haemophilus ducreyi	A	Klebsiella granulomatis	**Granuloma Inguinale** (Donovanosis) is a rare, chronic, sexually transmitted infection characterized by progressive, painless, beefy-red ulcers. It is caused by the bacterium **Klebsiella granulomatis** (formerly *Calymmatobacterium granulomatis*).	Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) is caused by *Klebsiella granulomatis*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P119, Q27: A 25-year-old sexually active woman presents with dysuria and urgency. A urine dipstick is positive for leukocytes and nitrites. Urine culture and gram staining reveal a grampositive organism in clusters that is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely causative organism?	A. Escherichia coli	B. Staphylococcus aureus	C. Staphylococcus saprophyticus	D. Proteus mirabilis	E. Klebsiella	C	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	The patient has a UTI (dysuria/urgency + positive dipstick). In young, sexually active women, the second most common cause of UTI (after *E. coli*) is **Staphylococcus saprophyticus**, which is a **Gram-positive coccus** that is typically **coagulase-negative**. *S. aureus* is coagulase-positive.	UTI in young sexually active woman + Coagulase-negative Gram-positive cocci = *Staphylococcus saprophyticus*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P120, Q2: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. He states that the symptoms are worse with eating, and that his abdominal pain has been increasing over the past three to four months. He reports a history of travel to endemic area with parasites five months ago. After that he developed a cough associated with mild shortness of breath which he attributed to a viral respiratory infection, as it resolved shortly thereafter. His physical examination is significant for moderate periumbilical tenderness. His laboratory results are significant for an eosinophil count of 20 percent. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed small bowel dilation proximal to a whirlpool-like mass in the mid-jejunum causing intestinal obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Clonorchis sinensis	B. Ascaris lumbricoides	C. Trichuris trichiura	D. Cystoisospora belli	E. Taenia saginata	B	Ascaris lumbricoides	The key findings are a history of travel (endemic exposure), the migration/pulmonary phase (**cough/SOB**), **high eosinophilia** (20%), and the presence of a mass (worm bolus) in the small bowel causing **intestinal obstruction** (whirlpool sign/dilation). This clinical picture is characteristic of heavy infection with the roundworm **Ascaris lumbricoides**.	Small Bowel Obstruction + Eosinophilia + Cough phase + Endemic area = *Ascaris lumbricoides* infection.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P121, Q3: A 24 years old male coming to you complaining of epigastic discomfort and vomiting ,You requested testing for H.pylori which was positive .In addition to PPI .Choose the most suitable antimicrobials	A- Ceftriaxone	B- Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	C- Azithromycin	D- Doxycyclin		B	Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	The standard triple therapy for **Helicobacter pylori** infection is a Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI) plus two antibiotics: usually **Clarithromycin and Amoxicillin** (or Metronidazole if penicillin-allergic) for 10-14 days.	*H. pylori* first-line treatment is PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin (Triple Therapy).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P121, Q4: Which of the following statements regarding Clostridium difficile associated disease relapses is true?	A. A first recurrence does not imply greater risk of further recurrences.	B. Most recurrences are due to antibiotic resistance.	C. Recurrent C. difficile–associated disease has been associated with a higher risk of colon cancer.	D. Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	E. Testing for clearance of C. difficile is warranted after treating recurrences.	D	Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	Recurrent *C. difficile* infection (CDI) is a significant clinical problem, with a risk of further relapse. Each subsequent recurrence is associated with an **increased risk of serious complications**, including toxic megacolon and death. Testing for clearance (E) is generally not recommended.	Recurrent *C. difficile* infection significantly increases the risk of severe complications and subsequent relapses.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P121, Q5: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Ascaris lumbricoides infection except:	asymptomatic carriage	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	non-productive cough and pleurisy with eosinophilia	right upper quadrant pain and fever	small-bowel obstruction	B	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	*Ascaris lumbricoides* infection presents in two phases: asymptomatic carriage (A) or the pulmonary/migratory phase (Löffler syndrome: cough, eosinophilia, C), followed by the intestinal phase, which can cause obstruction (E) or biliary/pancreatic symptoms (RUQ pain, D). The symptoms listed in B (meningism) are characteristic of **meningitis/encephalitis**, not typical *Ascaris* manifestations.	*Ascaris* infection involves pulmonary migration (Löffler syndrome) and intestinal symptoms (obstruction), but not CNS infection/meningism.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P121, Q6: Refering to the last question, one month after receiving a 14-day course of the antimicrobials, you prescribed for Helicobacter pylori. He still has mild dyspepsia and pain after meals. What is the appropriate next step in management?	Empirical long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy	Endoscopy with biopsy to rule out gastric adenocarcinoma	Second-line therapy for H. pylori with omeprazole, bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole	Urea breath test	H. pylori serology testing	D	Urea breath test	Since the patient was treated for *H. pylori*, the first step in managing persistent symptoms is to confirm the eradication of the bacterium. The non-invasive **Urea Breath Test (UBT)** is the preferred method for assessing eradication success 4 weeks after antibiotic therapy.	Test-of-Cure for *H. pylori* (4 weeks post-treatment): Urea Breath Test (UBT) or Fecal Antigen Test (FAT).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P122, Q7: All of the following diseases can cause huge splenomegaly except:	A-HCV infection	B- Biharziasis	C-Thalassemia	D-Malaria		A	HCV infection	Huge (massive) splenomegaly is common in chronic hemolytic anemias (Thalassemia), chronic protozoal infections (Malaria), and hepatic diseases causing portal hypertension (*Schistosomiasis*, historically called Bilharziasis). **Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) infection** typically causes chronic liver disease/cirrhosis, but **not** massive splenomegaly unless associated with portal hypertension.	Massive splenomegaly is associated with hemolysis, severe malaria, and Schistosomiasis, but not typically chronic HCV infection alone.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P122, Q8: A 31-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 5-day history of abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and loose stools, accompanied by progressively increasing fever. He also has a moderate headache and a rash. On physical examination, temperature is 40 °C , pulse rate is 64/min, normal blood pressure and respiratory rate. There are blanching erythematous macules on the lower chest and upper abdominal wall. Abdominal examination reveals tender hepatosplenomegaly. His CBC shows leucopenia with lymphopenia. Two sets of aerobic blood cultures show gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	Brucellosis	Lassa fever	Leptospirosis	Typhoid fever		D	Typhoid fever	The presentation (high fever, gastrointestinal symptoms, headache), the characteristic findings of **relative bradycardia** (Temp 40°C, Pulse 64/min), **rose spots** (blanching erythematous macules), **leukopenia/lymphopenia**, and positive blood culture for Gram-negative bacilli are all classic for **Typhoid Fever** (*Salmonella typhi*).	Typhoid Fever: High fever + Relative Bradycardia + Rose Spots + Leukopenia + Positive blood culture for Gram-negative bacilli.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P123, Q9: Male patient 50 years old, farmer, came to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case is	a. Myelofibrosis	b. Egyptian splenomegaly	c. Syphilis	d. Hyperthyroidism		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	The context of massive splenomegaly ($\ge 25~cm$), portal hypertension signs (**hematemesis from esophageal varices**), and the high-risk occupation/endemic area implies chronic **Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis** (Bilharziasis), which is historically termed **Egyptian Splenomegaly**.	Massive Splenomegaly + Variceal Bleeding in a Farmer = Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis ('Egyptian Splenomegaly').	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P123, Q10: Which is not a recognised complication of acute shigellosis	a. Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome	B. Reiter's syndrome	c. Liver abscess	d. Endotoxic shock		C	Liver abscess	Acute Shigellosis can lead to severe systemic disease, including Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS), post-infectious Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's syndrome), and shock. **Liver abscess** is not a typical complication of *Shigella* but is associated with amebiasis (*Entamoeba histolytica*).	Liver abscess is associated with Amoebiasis, not a recognized complication of Shigellosis.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P123, Q11: A 53-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for fever. He underwent elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery 2 days ago. urinary catheter was inserted in the operating room. On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C. He has mild suprapubic tenderness but no costovertebral angle or flank tenderness. Urine analysis reveals 10 to 20 leukocytes/hpf. Urine culture reveals> 400 colonies gram-negative rods. Chest radiograph shows no infiltrate. In addition to removing the urinary catheter, which of the following is the most appropriate management?	wait antimicrobial sensitivity before beginning antimicrobial therapy	Begin antimicrobial therapy now	Repeat urinalysis and urine culture in 24 hours	Provide no additional treatment		A	wait antimicrobial sensitivity before beginning antimicrobial therapy	The patient has signs of a Urinary Tract Infection (suprapubic tenderness, pyuria, positive culture), but the fever is only moderate (38.4°C), and he is otherwise stable without systemic signs of sepsis (normal BP, Pulse, RR). A short course of antibiotics is warranted, but since he is stable and the organism is a Gram-negative rod (often *E. coli* or *Klebsiella*), it is generally safe to **await the antibiotic sensitivities** before initiating therapy (especially to ensure targeted treatment). The catheter should be removed immediately.	In a stable patient with a non-severe hospital-acquired UTI, it is appropriate to await culture sensitivities for targeted treatment.	Infectious Diseases/Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P124, Q12: Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is	a. Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	b. Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	c. Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	d. Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	**Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA)** is defined as the enlargement of lymph nodes in **two or more non-contiguous** (non-adjacent) lymph node regions.	GLA = Enlargement of lymph nodes in $\ge 2$ non-contiguous areas.	Infectious Diseases

Pseudomonas mallei		C	Brucella abortus	**Malta Fever** is the alternative name for **Brucellosis**, caused by species of the genus *Brucella*, including *B. abortus*.	Malta Fever is Brucellosis (*Brucella* species).	Brucellosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections MA Summary	P124, Q14: In the developed world, seroprevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection is currently	A. Decreasing	B. increasing	C. staying the same	D. unknown		A	Decreasing	Due to improved sanitation, better hygiene, and increased use of antibiotics, the prevalence and acquisition rate (and thus seroprevalence) of *Helicobacter pylori* infection have been **decreasing** significantly in developed countries over the past few decades.	*H. pylori* prevalence is decreasing in developed nations due to improved sanitation/antibiotics. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P1, Q1: Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring how many hours after hospital admission?	At least 12 hours	At least 24 hours	At least 36 hours	At least 48 hours		D	At least 48 hours	Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia occurring 48 hours or more after hospital admission that was not present at the time of admission. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P1, Q3: One of the following bundle has been shown to reduce ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) rates:	elevate the head of the bed to between 90 and 120 degrees.	"daily \sedation\"" and intubation"""	daily oral care with chlorhexidine.	no prophylaxis for peptic ulcer is needed.	early ambulation to prevent anti-deep venous thrombosis. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P1, Q4: 12 patients presented to a local emergency department with similar symptoms of severe nausea, profuse vomiting, and severe abdominal cramps. A few patients reported diarrhea. The patients report that they were all present at a lunch party two hours ago. The dishes were served from slow cookers, and the food handlers did not wear gloves. What is the most likely cause of this disease outbreak?	Salmonella infection.	Norovirus infection	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	C. perfringens infection.		C	S. aureus preformed ingestion toxin	The very short incubation period (2 hours), profuse vomiting, lack of fever, and rapid recovery (within 24 hours) are classic features of food poisoning caused by *Staphylococcus aureus* preformed toxin.	Very short incubation (1-6 hours) + prominent vomiting + no fever = *S. aureus* toxin.	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P3, Q5: The primary preventive strategy for community acquired pneumonia is :	Antibiotic therapy	Good hand hygiene	Adherence to healthy lifestyle behaviors	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.		D	Immunization with pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.	Immunization is the most effective primary preventive strategy against Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP), targeting the most common pathogens like *Streptococcus pneumoniae* and influenza virus.	Primary prevention for CAP relies heavily on vaccination (Pneumococcal and Flu).	Respiratory Infections

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P5, Q15: A 29-year-old man with HIV is admitted with shortness of breath. Auscultation of his chest is unremarkable although chest xray shows bilateral pulmonary interstitial shadowing. What is the investigation of choice?	Bronchoalveolar lavage	CT thorax	Transbronchial biopsy	Sputum culture	Blood culture	A	Bronchoalveolar lavage	The clinical presentation (HIV, SOB, new ART) and CXR (bilateral interstitial shadowing) are highly suggestive of *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP). Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is the most sensitive and specific method to obtain samples for definitive diagnosis.	PCP diagnosis in HIV + bilateral interstitial shadowing → BAL for stain/PCR. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P5, Q16: A 12-year-old boy who had a splenectomy following a road traffic accident is reviewed in clinic. He had his full immunisation course as a child and was given a repeat pneumococcal vaccination 5 days following surgery. What is the most appropriate ongoing management?	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + lifelong penicillin V.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + penicillin V for 2 years.	Lifelong penicillin V.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + penicillin V for 2 years.	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + lifelong penicillin V.	E	Booster dose of Hib and MenC vaccine + annual influenza vaccination + lifelong penicillin V.	Asplenic patients are at high risk of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI), primarily from encapsulated organisms like *S. pneumoniae* and *H. influenzae*. Management includes appropriate vaccinations and lifelong antibiotic prophylaxis, usually penicillin V, plus annual flu shots.	Asplenia management: Vaccinations (Pneumo, Men, Hib) + Lifelong Penicillin V + Annual Flu Shot.	Infectious Diseases

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P6, Q19: A 34-year-old man from Swaziland presents the the emergency department with a 3 day history of fever, shortness of breath and a dry cough. His past medical history ncludes tuberculosis and HIV and his most recent CD4 count is 150. On examination: heart rate 100/min, blood pressure 110/80mmHg, respiratory rate 28/min, oxygen saturation 98% on air at rest, dropping to 80% on walking. His temperature is 38.5ºC. On auscultation, his chest is clear. How would you treat this man?	IV cefotaxime	Oral ciprofloxacin	IV tazocin	Oral rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol	Oral co-trimoxazole	E	Oral co-trimoxazole	The presentation (HIV, CD4 < 200, dry cough, desaturation on exertion) is highly suggestive of *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP), for which co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the first-line treatment. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P7, Q20: A 37-year-old woman who is being treated as an inpatient for Mycoplasma pneumonia is reviewed. Unfortunately she is unable to tolerate clarithromycin due to severe nausea. What is the most suitable alternative antibiotic?	Linezolid	Cefaclor	Ciprofloxacin	Co-amoxiclav	Doxycycline	E	Doxycycline	*Mycoplasma pneumoniae* is an atypical bacterium lacking a cell wall, making beta-lactams (like cefaclor or co-amoxiclav) ineffective. Doxycycline (a tetracycline) is a suitable alternative to macrolides (like clarithromycin) for atypical pneumonias.	Atypical pneumonia (Mycoplasma/Chlamydia) requires Macrolides, Tetracyclines (Doxycycline), or Fluoroquinolones.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P7, Q21: A 31-year-old female with no past medical history of note is admitted to hospital with dyspnoea and fever. On examination she is noted to have an ulcerated lesion on her upper lip consistent with reactivation of herpes simplex. Which organism is most associated with this examination finding?	Legionella pneumophilia	Staphylococcus aureus	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis carinii	Mycoplasma pneumonia	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumonia caused by *Streptococcus pneumoniae* is classically associated with the reactivation of herpes simplex virus (HSV) on the lips (herpes labialis). ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P7, Q22: Which one of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus pyogenes infection?	Rheumatic fever	Scarlet fever	Cellulitis	Type 2 necrotizing fasciitis	Pneumonia	E	Pneumonia	*Streptococcus pyogenes* (Group A Strep) is primarily associated with pharyngitis (strep throat), skin infections (cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis), and post-infectious syndromes (rheumatic fever, scarlet fever). It is an uncommon cause of pneumonia.	*S. pyogenes* is common for pharyngitis and skin infection (Cellulitis/NF), but rare for pneumonia.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P8, Q23: A 39-year-old man with HIV is admitted due to shortness of breath. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia is suspected. What type of staining should be applied to the bronchoalveolar lavage to demonstrate the organism?	Rubeanic acid	Silver stain	Pearl's stain	Rose Bengal	Congo red	B	Silver stain	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* (formerly *P. carinii*) cysts are typically detected using various silver stains, such as the Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain, on specimens obtained via bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).	PCP diagnosis: GMS (Silver) stain on BAL fluid.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P8, Q24: A 47-year-old lady is referred by her GP with a two day history of fever and headache. She is normally fit and well and has no past medical history of note. On examination you note nuchal rigidity. Investigations show the following: Serum glucose 4.9 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture reveals: Opening pressure 14 cmCSF, Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 1.7 mmol/l, Protein 1.9 g/l, White cells 900/mm^3 (90% polymorphs). What is the most likely infective agent?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	E. coli	Listeria monocytogenes	Enterovirus	Streptococcus pyogenes	A	Streptococcus pneumoniae	The CSF analysis shows a classic picture of **bacterial meningitis**: high neutrophils (>50%), high protein, and very low glucose (CSF:Serum glucose ratio <0.4). *Streptococcus pneumoniae* is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults.	Bacterial Meningitis CSF: High Neutrophils, Low Glucose, High Protein. Most common cause in adults is *S. pneumoniae*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P9, Q25: For a patient undergoing an elective splenectomy, when is the optimal time to give the pneumococcal vaccine?	Four weeks before surgery	One week before surgery	Immediately following surgery	Two weeks after surgery	At least one month after surgery	A	Four weeks before surgery	Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (like pneumococcus) should be completed at least two weeks before elective splenectomy, ideally four weeks prior, to allow for an optimal and effective antibody response.	Vaccination (especially pneumococcal) should be given 2-4 weeks *before* elective splenectomy for maximal immune response.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P9, Q26: A 41-year-old female presents with 3 day history of a dry cough and shortness of breath. This was preceded by flu-like symptoms. On examination there is a symmetrical, erythematous rash with 'target' lesions over the whole body. What is the likely organism causing the symptoms?	Pseudomonas	Staphylococcus aureus	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	Chlamydia pneumoniae	Legionella pneumophilia	C	Mycoplasma pneumoniae	*Mycoplasma pneumoniae* causes 'atypical' pneumonia, often preceded by flu-like symptoms, and is strongly associated with extrapulmonary manifestations like erythema multiforme (rash with target lesions).	Atypical Pneumonia + Erythema Multiforme (Target Lesions) = *Mycoplasma pneumoniae*.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P9, Q27: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a productive cough of green sputum and occasional bloody specks. On examination his temperature is 38.3ºC, respiratory rate 23/min, heart rate 100/min and there is left basal coarse crackles with a small cold sore above his lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Streptococcal pneumonia	Viral pneumonia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Klebsiella pneumonia	Legionella pneumonia	A	Streptococcal pneumonia	The combination of fever, productive cough (purulent sputum), and the presence of a cold sore (herpes labialis) strongly suggests classic bacterial pneumonia caused by *Streptococcus pneumoniae*.	Pneumonia + Herpes Labialis (Cold Sore) = *Streptococcus pneumoniae* (Pneumococcus).	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P10, Q28: You review a 45-year-old woman who has been admitted feeling generally unwell. Four months ago she had a renal transplant and has since been taking a combination of ciclosporin and mycophenolate for immunosuppression. For the past three days she has had fever, dyspnoea and a dry cough. A chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Graft-versus host disease	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	Cell mediated acute transplant rejection	Mycophenolate pneumonitis	Cryptococcus neoformans pneumonia	B	Cytomegalovirus pneumonitis	*Cytomegalovirus* (CMV) pneumonitis is a common and serious opportunistic infection in solid organ transplant recipients (especially lung and renal) occurring typically 1-6 months post-transplant, presenting with fever, dry cough, dyspnoea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on CXR.	Post-transplant (1-6 months) + Fever + Dry Cough + Bilateral Interstitial Infiltrates = CMV Pneumonitis.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P10, Q29: A 34-year-old male returns from india and upon arriving home is diagnosed with pneumonia that is resistant to multiple antibiotics, in particular to imipenem. What is the likely virulence factor which caused the pneumonia?	D-alanyl-D-lactate variation leading to loss of affinity	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	Presence of MexAB-OprM efflux pumps	Alteration to the penicillin binding protein 2	Reduced permeability & ribosomal modification	B	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1	New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1 (NDM-1) is an enzyme that confers resistance to nearly all beta-lactam antibiotics, including carbapenems like imipenem. Its spread has been prominently linked to travel in the Indian subcontinent.	Resistance to Carbapenems (Imipenem) in a traveler from India = NDM-1.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P10, Q30: Which one of the following statements is true regarding Listeria monocytogenes?	Multiplies rapidly at high temperatures	The organism is resistant to ampicillin	It is a Gram negative bacillus	It is diagnosed by the presence of urinary antigen	May cause ataxia	E	May cause ataxia	*Listeria monocytogenes* can cause rhombencephalitis (brainstem encephalitis), which often presents with fever, cranial nerve palsies, and cerebellar symptoms, including ataxia. It is a Gram-positive bacillus, usually sensitive to ampicillin.	*Listeria* causes rhombencephalitis, which classically presents with CN palsies and ataxia.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P11, Q31: Which one of the following is a Gram negative coccus?	Haemophilus influenzae	Moraxella catarrhalis	Enterococcus faecalis	Listeria monocytogenes	Campylobacter jejuni	B	Moraxella catarrhalis	*Moraxella catarrhalis* is a Gram-negative diplococcus, often resembling a bean shape. *Haemophilus* and *Campylobacter* are Gram-negative bacilli, while *Enterococcus* and *Listeria* are Gram-positive organisms.	*Moraxella* and *Neisseria* are the main Gram-negative cocci (diplococci).	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P11, Q32: A 31-year-old man is admitted to hospital with a 4 day history of fever and dyspnoea. He is known to be HIV positive but poorly compliant with his antiretroviral therapy (ART). Bloods taken during a clinic visit two weeks ago show the following: CD4 180 cells/μ l. On examination today his pulse is 102/min, oxygen saturations 97% on room air with a temperature of 38.1ºC. He has coarse crackles on the right side of his chest. A chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right mid zone. Moraxella catarrhalis What is the most likely causative organism?	Mycobacterium tuberculosis	Cryptococcus neoformans	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Pneumocystis jirovecii	Histoplasma capsulatum	C	Streptococcus pneumoniae	In HIV patients with CD4 counts above 100-200, **common community-acquired pathogens**, such as *Streptococcus pneumoniae*, remain the most frequent causes of typical lobar pneumonia, often presenting with consolidation. PCP typically presents with bilateral interstitial infiltrates and a CD4 count < 200.	HIV patients with CD4 > 200 are still most susceptible to common CAP pathogens, like *S. pneumoniae*.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P11, Q33: A 55-year-old man is referred to the medical admissions unit. He recently returned from a holiday in Italy and has failed to respond to a course of co-amoxiclav for a suspected lower respiratory tract infection. Chest x-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. Bloods are as follows: Na+ 122 mmol/l. K+ 4.3 mmol/l, Urea 8.4 mmol/l, Creatinine 130 μmol/l. What is the likely diagnosis?	Goodpasture's syndrome	Legionella pneumonia	Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia	Pulmonary eosinophilia	Mycoplasma pneumonia	B	Legionella pneumonia	The triad of **hyponatremia** (Na+ 122 mmol/l), **pneumonia** (bilateral infiltrates, failure to respond to beta-lactam), and **travel history** (Italy) is highly characteristic of *Legionella pneumophila* infection.	Pneumonia + Hyponatremia + Travel (or water exposure) + Failure of beta-lactam = Legionella.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P12, Q34: A 69-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by ambulance, with a few days history of increasing shortness of breath, fever and a productive cough. On review, you find: HR 105 bpm, Oxygen saturation 90% on air, BP 100/65 mmHg, Temp 38.9°C, Respiratory Rate 32 breaths per minute, Chest X-ray Right mid-zone cavity with surrounding consolidation. The patient is started on oxygen, antibiotics and IV fluids and his observations improve to the point where taking a history is easier. He reports that he normally keeps fit and has no other long-term health conditions, but that he has been more tired for the past few weeks. He explains further that he and his wife both caught a 'bad cold' from their grandchildren about a month ago. What is the most likely cause for this gentleman's symptoms?	Lung cancer	Klebsiella pneumoniae infection	Staphylococcus aureus infection	Pulmonary tuberculosis	Streptococcus pneumoniae infection	C	Staphylococcus aureus infection	The patient has severe pneumonia (tachycardia, hypoxia, hypotension, tachypnea), and the CXR shows **cavitation** (*lung abscess*). The history of a preceding **viral illness** (cold from grandchildren) strongly suggests **secondary bacterial pneumonia**, for which *Staphylococcus aureus* is a common and destructive cause, often presenting with cavitation.	Severe pneumonia + Cavitation + Preceding viral illness = *Staphylococcus aureus*.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P13, Q35: A 28-year-old male presents with shortness of breath, dry cough and fever for one week. Prior to this, he had been generally unwell for several months complaining of weight loss, fatigue, generalised lymphadenopathy and myalgia. He admits to using intravenous drugs in the past. Observations reveal O2 sats 88% on air, heart rate 112 bpm, blood pressure 124/85mmHg, respiratory rate 24/min and temperature 37.8ºC. His chest is clear and heart sounds are normal. On mobilising his O2 sats drop to 75% on air and he is acutely short of breath. Chest x-ray shows bilateral perihilar shadowing. Arterial blood gas on 5 litres of oxygen shows: PH 7.41, PaO2 8.9 kPa, PaCO2 3.6 kPa. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?	Amoxicillin and clarithromycin	Co-trimoxazole	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	Doxycycline	Oseltamivir	C	Co-trimoxazole and prednisolone	The presentation (IVDU, chronic illness, dry cough, fever, hypoxia, bilateral interstitial CXR, marked desaturation on exertion) is classic for **Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)** in an HIV patient. For severe PCP (PaO2  35 mmHg), the treatment is high-dose co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX) PLUS **adjunctive corticosteroids (prednisolone)**.	Severe PCP (PaO2 < 9.3 kPa) treatment is TMP-SMX + Steroids (Prednisolone).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P13, Q36: A 28-year-old man who is immunosuppressed secondary to HIV infection is admitted to hospital with dyspnoea and a dry cough. His chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial pulmonary infiltrates and he is started on co-trimoxazole empirically. The following morning he complains of a sudden worsening of his dyspnoea associated with left-sided chest pain. Which complication is most likely to have developed?	Empyema	Pulmonary embolism	Acute respiratory distress syndrome	Pericarditis	Pneumothorax	E	Pneumothorax	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP) is associated with the development of pulmonary cysts (pneumatoceles) which can rupture, leading to a spontaneous pneumothorax, presenting as sudden chest pain and worsening dyspnoea.	Spontaneous pneumothorax is a common complication in HIV patients with PCP.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P14, Q37: A 39-year-old man presents with shortness of breath following one week of flu-like symptoms. He also has a nonproductive cough but no chest pain. A chest x-ray shows bilateral consolidation and examination reveals erythematous lesions on his limbs and trunk. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to be diagnostic?	Cold agglutins	Sputum culture	Urinary antigen for Legionella	Serology for Mycoplasma	Blood culture	D	Serology for Mycoplasma	This presentation (flu-like prodrome, dry cough, bilateral infiltrates, erythema multiforme/lesions) is classic for **Mycoplasma pneumonia**. Serology (for IgM or a four-fold rise in IgG titer) is the most common diagnostic method, as culture is difficult. Cold agglutinins are a less specific but associated finding.	Atypical pneumonia + Extrapulmonary signs (rash) suggests Mycoplasma; Serology is the primary diagnostic method.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P14, Q38: A 44-year-old man who is known to be HIV positive presents with shortness-of-breath. Which one of the following features is most characteristic of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia?	Usually occurs when the CD4 count is 200-300/mm^3	Absence of fever	Productive cough	Oxygen saturations usually improve after short period of exertion	Normal chest auscultation	E	Normal chest auscultation	*Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP) typically causes significant pulmonary symptoms and CXR findings (bilateral interstitial shadowing) but often presents with a **disproportionately normal chest auscultation**. It is most common with CD4 counts < 200.	PCP classic sign: Severe respiratory symptoms and CXR changes, but clear or nearly normal chest auscultation.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P15, Q1: Release of which of the following results in fever?	Interleukin (IL) 8	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor	Interleukin (IL) 1	Tumor necrosis factor		C	Interleukin (IL) 1	Fever is primarily caused by **pyrogenic cytokines** (endogenous pyrogens) acting on the hypothalamus. The main ones are Interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-α).	Key Pyrogens: IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P15, Q2: In neutropenic fever, absolute count of neutrophils is?	<= 1000 per mm3	<= 500 per mm3	<= 850 per mm3	> 1000 per mm3		B	<= 500 per mm3	Neutropenia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of less than $500~cells/mm^3$. Fever in this setting is termed febrile neutropenia, which requires urgent empirical antibiotics.	Absolute Neutropenia = ANC < 500 cells/mm^3.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P15, Q3: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitaris	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) causes severe **hyperthermia** (high fever) due to a loss of central thermoregulation. The other conditions (panhypopituitarism, myxoedema coma, and circulatory failure) can all lead to hypothermia.	NMS causes hyperthermia (high fever), not hypothermia.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P15, Q4: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	Prostaglandin F	T-regulator cells	Prostaglandin E2	Cell adhesion molecule		C	Prostaglandin E2	Pyrogenic cytokines (IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α) stimulate the release of **Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)** in the hypothalamus, which acts to raise the thermoregulatory set-point, causing fever.	PGE2 is the final mediator that raises the hypothalamic set-point to cause fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P15, Q5: Each attack of FMF usually lasts for:	6 hours to 2 days	12 hours to 3 days	24 hours to 7 days	3 days to 10 days		B	12 hours to 3 days			Fever

ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P16, Q7: A 30 years man from Australia returned from a business trip to Indonesia 6d ago presenting with complaints of fever, joint and muscle ache and headache, in particular behind the eye for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis	Malaria	Chicken pox	TB	Lyme's disease	Dengue	E	Dengue	The patient presents with fever, myalgia, joint ache, and a classic symptom of **retro-orbital headache** (behind the eye) after returning from an endemic area (Indonesia). This presentation is characteristic of Dengue fever.	Fever + Retro-orbital headache + Travel to endemic area = Dengue fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P16, Q8: Release of which of the following results in fever?	Interleukin (IL) 1	Interleukin (IL) 8	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor	All of the above		A	Interleukin (IL) 1	Fever is primarily mediated by pyrogenic cytokines (endogenous pyrogens) like Interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and TNF-α, which act on the hypothalamus. IL-8 is a chemokine and G-CSF promotes neutrophil production.	IL-1 is a primary pyrogenic cytokine that causes fever.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q9: Rat-bite fever is caused by the organism	Spirillum minus	A gram-positive cocci	Yersinia multocida	Treponema pertenue		A	Spirillum minus	Rat-bite fever is caused by either *Spirillum minus* (causing Sodoku, often with lymphadenopathy and a rash) or *Streptobacillus moniliformis* (causing Haverhill fever, often with polyarthritis).	Rat-bite fever is caused by *Spirillum minus* or *Streptobacillus moniliformis*.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q10: Cyclical periods of pyrexia alternating with a pyrexia is found in all except	Relapsing fever	Leprosy	Hodgkin's disease	Brucellosis		B	Leprosy	Cyclical fever (e.g., Pell-Ebstein fever in Hodgkin's disease, undulant fever in Brucellosis, or recurrent spirochete infection in Relapsing Fever) is a feature of the other options, but not typical for leprosy, which is a chronic condition.	Cyclical fevers are common in Hodgkin's (Pel-Ebstein), Brucellosis (Undulant), and Relapsing fever (Borrelia), but not Leprosy.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q11: Faget's sign (relative bradycardia) is first described in	Typhoid fever	Yellow fever	Acute rheumatic fever	Brucellosis		B	Yellow fever	Faget's sign is the paradoxical finding of bradycardia (slow heart rate) despite the presence of fever. While classically associated with Yellow fever, it is also seen in Typhoid fever, Brucellosis, and others.	Faget's sign (Bradycardia with fever) is characteristic of Yellow fever, Typhoid, and Brucellosis.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q12: Which of the following does not produce hypothermia	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Panhypopituitarism	Peripheral circulatory failure	Myxoedema coma		A	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome	Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) causes severe **hyperthermia** (high fever) due to impaired heat dissipation and increased heat production, not hypothermia.	NMS causes hyperthermia.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q13: Which one of the following causes hypothalamic reset?	1- Prostaglandin F	2- T-regulator cells	3- Prostaglandin E2	4- Cell adhesion molecule		C	3- Prostaglandin E2	Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is the molecule that directly acts on the hypothalamus to raise the thermoregulatory set-point, thereby causing fever.	PGE2 is the direct trigger for the hypothalamic set-point reset.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P17, Q14: In neutropenic fever, absolute count of neutrophils is?	1- <= 1000 per mm3	2- <= 500 per mm3	3- <= 850 per mm3	4- > 1000 per mm3		B	<= 500 per mm3	Neutropenia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) below $500~cells/mm^3$ or an ANC below $1000~cells/mm^3$ with an anticipated decline to $500~cells/mm^3$. The typical threshold for febrile neutropenia requiring aggressive management is ANC $\le 500~cells/mm^3$.	Febrile Neutropenia definition uses ANC $\le 500~cells/mm^3$.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P18, Q15: A 58-year-old caucasian male originally from the United Kingdom (UK) now living in East Africa has returned to the UK on holiday. He has become unwell in the last two days, complaining of a headache, rigors, vomiting, fever, abdominal pain and passing little amounts of dark red urine. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice and anaemia. Urinalysis reveals blood only and microscopy showed no red cells. Of the following options, what is the most likely diagnosis?	Leptospirosis	Acute viral hepatitis	Pyelonephritis	Schistosomiasis	Blackwater fever	E	Blackwater fever	The presentation of fever, rigors, vomiting, dark red urine (hemoglobinuria), jaundice, and anemia in a patient with exposure in an endemic area (East Africa) is characteristic of **Blackwater fever**, a severe complication of *Plasmodium falciparum* malaria caused by massive intravascular hemolysis.	Blackwater Fever = Severe hemolysis/hemoglobinuria + Malaria (often Falciparum).	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P18, Q16: A 31-year-old woman with a three year history of ulcerative colitis is started on azathioprine to help prevent relapses. Which one of the following vaccines must be avoided whilst she is on this treatment?	Yellow fever	Rabies	Pertussis	Diphtheria	Tetanus	A	Yellow fever	Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant. **Live attenuated vaccines** (like Yellow fever, MMR, Varicella, BCG) are generally contraindicated in immunosuppressed individuals due to the risk of uncontrolled infection from the vaccine strain. Rabies, Pertussis, Diphtheria, and Tetanus are inactivated (non-live) vaccines.	Immunosuppression (Azathioprine) is a contraindication for Live Vaccines (e.g., Yellow Fever).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P18, Q17: A 45-year-old female presents to the Emergency Department three days after returning from Thailand complaining of severe muscle ache, fever and headache. On examination she has a widespread maculopapular rash. Results show: Malaria film: negative, Hb 16.2*10^9 g/dl, Plt 96*10^9/l, WBC 2.4*10^9/l, ALT 146 iu/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Hepatitis A	Japanese encephalitis	Rheumatic fever	Malaria	Dengue fever	E	Dengue fever	The combination of fever, severe muscle ache, maculopapular rash, and laboratory findings of **thrombocytopenia** (Plt 96) and **leukopenia** (WBC 2.4) in a patient returning from Thailand is highly suggestive of Dengue fever.	Travel + Fever + Myalgia + Maculopapular Rash + Thrombocytopenia/Leukopenia = Dengue.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P19, Q18: 24-year-old male attends the clinic for a yellow fever vaccine before travelling to South America. He has no past medical history and takes no regular medicines. He states that he also had a varicella zoster vaccination a few weeks ago. What is the minimum interval required between the last vaccination?	1 week	2 weeks	3 weeks	4 weeks	1 year	D	4 weeks	Two or more **live attenuated parenteral vaccines** (like Yellow Fever and Varicella Zoster) given at the same time or less than 4 weeks apart may interfere with the immune response of both. If not given simultaneously, they should be separated by at least 4 weeks (28 days).	Simultaneous or wait 4 weeks between two live parenteral vaccines.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P19, Q19: Symptoms of a heat-related illness include all of the following EXCEPT:	dizziness and disorientation.	thirst and light sweating.	no sweating, but dry, hot skin.	cramps.		B	thirst and light sweating.			Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P20, Q20: The most important factors affecting evaporation when exercising are:	heat and humidity.	duration.	time of day.	intensity.		A	heat and humidity.	Evaporation (sweating) is the most effective mechanism for heat loss during exercise, but its efficiency is drastically reduced by **high ambient temperature** and, crucially, **high humidity**, which limits the saturation capacity of the air.	Evaporation effectiveness is inversely proportional to humidity and heat.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P20, Q21: Which of the following environments would allow for the best convective cooling?	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	running in the winter wearing a sweat suit, cap, and gloves	running on a track in an enclosed gym	running outside in 80-degree F weather and 80-percent humidity		A	running outside with a cool, light wind blowing	Convective cooling (convection) is the transfer of heat away from the body by the movement of air or water across the skin surface. A cool, light wind provides the best scenario for maximizing this heat transfer mechanism.	Convective cooling is enhanced by movement of a cooler medium (wind/water) across the skin.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P20, Q22: Which of the following groups is the MOST susceptible to heat illness?	the highly fit	the elderly	high school students	those jogging by themselves		B	the elderly	The elderly are the most susceptible group due to age-related changes, including a blunted thirst mechanism, decreased sweat gland function, and compromised cardiovascular and renal function.	The elderly and infants/young children are the most vulnerable groups to heat illness.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P20, Q23: The result of evaporation is:	no change in temperature.	warming.	cooling.	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.		D	either cooling or warming, depending on the humidity.	AI solves it ===C  Evaporation (of sweat) requires heat energy (the latent heat of vaporization) to turn liquid into vapor, and this energy is drawn from the skin surface, resulting in a cooling effect on the body.	Evaporation (of sweat) is the body's main mechanism for cooling in hot environments.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P20, Q24: The best way to determine if environmental conditions are imposing a heat load on your body is to:	take your temperature.	weigh yourself before and after exercise to measure water weight loss.	monitor your heart rate.	measure your blood pressure.		C	monitor your heart rate.			Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P21, Q25: In order to minimize the possibility of overheating, exercise clothing should be all of the following EXCEPT:	lightweight.	minimal.	dry.	cotton or linen.		C	dry.	AI solves it ===D Cotton and linen hold moisture (sweat) near the skin, reducing the efficiency of evaporative cooling. Clothing should be lightweight, minimal, and preferably made of synthetic materials that wick moisture away.	Avoid cotton clothing for exercise in the heat, as it retains moisture and reduces evaporative cooling.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P21, Q26: Heat acclimatization:	decreases the exercise heart rate.	increases the risk of heat injuries.	needs more research before it should even be considered.	increases body temperature.		A	decreases the exercise heart rate.	Heat acclimatization is a process of physiological adaptations that allows the body to cope better with heat stress. Key adaptations include an increase in plasma volume, a reduction in resting and exercise heart rate (improved cardiac efficiency), and earlier/higher sweat rates.	Heat acclimatization improves cardiovascular stability and efficiency (e.g., lower HR) during exercise in heat.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P21, Q27: Symptoms of heat exhaustion are:	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	increased blood pressure.	seizures.	hot, red, dry skin.		A	profuse sweating and clammy skin.	Heat exhaustion is characterized by symptoms of dehydration and circulatory stress, including profuse sweating, cold/clammy skin, weakness, and faintness. Hot, red, dry skin and seizures are signs of the more severe condition, heat stroke.	Heat Exhaustion = Profuse sweating + Clammy skin + Core temperature < 40°C.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P21, Q28: Heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke are similar in all the following ways EXCEPT:	very heavy sweating.	significant loss of water and electrolytes.	high inner core temperature of the body.	increased heat storage in the body.		A	very heavy sweating.	Heat stroke is the most severe condition and often involves a cessation of sweating (anhidrosis) leading to hot, dry skin. Heavy sweating (diaphoresis) is characteristic of heat cramps and heat exhaustion.	Heavy sweating is usually absent in Heat Stroke, distinguishing it from heat cramps and exhaustion.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q29: When exercising in the heat, it is recommended that all of the following be kept in mind EXCEPT:	monitor your heart rate.	keep the exercise session short.	drink plenty of water before, during and after the workout.	take a salt tablet after the workout.		D	take a salt tablet after the workout.	Salt tablets are generally not necessary and can be dangerous as they may exacerbate dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. Hydration with water or sports drinks containing small amounts of electrolytes is the appropriate strategy.	Salt tablets are not recommended; water or sports drinks are sufficient for rehydration and electrolyte balance.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q30: Heat injury can occur when the activity heat load exceeds the body's ability to regulate body temperature. Which of the following is not a common type of heat injury?	heat evaporation	heat cramps	heat exhaustion	heat stroke		A	heat evaporation	Heat evaporation is a **mechanism of heat loss**, not a type of heat injury. Heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke are clinical syndromes resulting from excessive heat load.	Heat evaporation is a physiologic mechanism, not a clinical heat injury syndrome.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q1: Rate of transmission of HCV after needle stick injury is:	1%	0.3%	3%	30%		C	3%	The estimated risk of transmission of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) after a percutaneous exposure (e.g., needle-stick injury) to HCV-positive blood is approximately 1.8% to 3%.	HCV transmission risk from a needle-stick is approximately 3%.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q2: Chronic hepatitis is considered when duration of more than:	3 months	4 months	5 months	6 months		D	6 months	Chronic hepatitis is defined as inflammation and necrosis of the liver persisting for more than **6 months**.	Chronic Hepatitis = Liver inflammation persisting for > 6 months.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q3: Which of the following is not a RNA virus?	Hepatitis A virus	Hepatitis B virus	Hepatitis C virus	Hepatitis D virus		B	Hepatitis B virus	Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a **DNA virus** (specifically, a partially double-stranded circular DNA virus), while Hepatitis A, C, D, and E are all RNA viruses.	Hepatitis B (HBV) is a DNA virus; all other common hepatitis viruses (A, C, D, E) are RNA viruses.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P22, Q4: A 42-year-old dentist is reviewed in the medical clinic complaining of persistent lethargy. Routine bloods show abnormal liver function tests so a hepatitis screen is sent. The results are shown below: Anti-HAV IgG negative, HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc negative, Anti-HCV positive. What do these results most likely demonstrate?	Hepatitis B infection	Hepatitis C infection	Previous vaccination to hepatitis B and C	Hepatitis C infection with previous hepatitis B vaccination	Hepatitis B and C infection	D	Hepatitis C infection with previous hepatitis B vaccination	The results indicate: **Anti-HBs positive** (protection/immunity) AND **Anti-HBc negative** (no prior natural infection) = **Hepatitis B vaccination**. **Anti-HCV positive** = **Hepatitis C infection** (past or present).	Hepatitis B Status: Anti-HBs (+) and Anti-HBc (-) = Vaccination. Anti-HCV (+) = HCV infection.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P23, Q5: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent amantadine?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Protease inhibitor	Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	D	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Amantadine and its derivative, rimantadine, are M2 ion channel inhibitors that prevent the acidification of the viral core, thereby blocking the **uncoating** of the Influenza A virus once it is inside the cell.	Amantadine/Rimantadine block the M2 ion channel, preventing Influenza A virus uncoating.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P23, Q6: A 25-year-old woman is admitted to a local hospital whilst travelling in north India. She is 26 weeks pregnant with her first child and the pregnancy has been uneventful to date. For the past 3-4 days she has been feeling generally unwell with fever, lethargy and vomiting. She takes no regular medication other than malaria prophylaxis (chloroquine). On examination her pulse is 96/min blood pressure 102/66 mmHg. Jaundiced sclera, along with some bruising on her arms is noted. Her partner states that she also seems confused. Bloods show the following: Bilirubin 102 μmol/l, ALP 256 u/l, ALT 1024 u/l, YGT 563 u/l, Albumin 35 g/l, INR 2.4. What is the most likely cause of her deterioration?	Hepatitis A	Hepatitis B	Hepatitis E	Malaria	Amoebiasis	C	Hepatitis E	Infection with **Hepatitis E Virus (HEV)**, which is endemic in India and typically spread via the fecal-oral route, carries a significantly increased risk of severe illness and **fulminant hepatic failure** in **pregnant women**. The elevated INR (2.4) and confusion suggest liver failure.	Hepatitis E is highly dangerous, causing fulminant liver failure, especially in pregnant women.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P24, Q7: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent amantadine?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Protease inhibitor	Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	D	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Amantadine prevents the release of the Influenza A viral nucleic acid into the host cell cytoplasm by blocking the M2 ion channel (viral uncoating).	Amantadine blocks viral uncoating (M2 ion channel).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P24, Q8: A 34-year-old lady presents to the GP with worsening nausea and fatigue over a 2 week period. On examination, there is a yellow tinge to the sclera of her eyes. She lives in a remote fishing village and consumes a diet high in seafood. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She does not report any weight loss or other constitutional features. Her LFTs are as follows: Bilirubin 20 μmol/l, ALP 160 u/l, ALT 550 u/l, YGT 30 u/l, Albumin 35 g/l. Other routine blood results are within normal limits. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?	Gilbert's syndrome	Pancreatic adenocarcinoma	Hepatitis B	Hepatitis C	Hepatitis E	E	Hepatitis E	The clinical picture (acute hepatitis-like illness: nausea, fatigue, jaundice, high ALT, normal GGT/ALP) and the risk factor of living in an area with poor sanitation/consuming contaminated food (often water or seafood in endemic regions) is suggestive of **Hepatitis E Virus (HEV)** infection (fecal-oral transmission).	Acute hepatitis picture (High ALT, near-normal ALP/GGT) in a high-risk area (poor sanitation/seafood) = Hepatitis E or A.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P25, Q9: A prison GP is bitten by a patient who is known to have hepatitis B. The GP has a documented full history of hepatitis B vaccination and was known to be a responder. What is the most appropriate action to reduce the chance of contracting hepatitis B?	Admit for intravenous interferon	Give hepatitis B immune globulin	Give hepatitis B immune globulin + hepatitis B vaccine booster	Give hepatitis B vaccine booster	Give oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	D	Give hepatitis B vaccine booster			Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P25, Q10: Which one of the following statements best describes the prevention and treatment of hepatitis C?	No vaccine is available and treatment is only successful in around 10-15% of patients	No vaccine and no treatment is available	A vaccine is available and treatment is successful in around 50% of patients	A vaccine is available but no treatment has been shown to be effective	No vaccine is available but treatment is successful in the majority of patients	E	No vaccine is available but treatment is successful in the majority of patients	There is currently **no vaccine** available for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV). However, modern direct-acting antiviral (DAA) therapies have achieved cure rates (sustained virologic response) of well over 95% in the majority of patients.	HCV: No vaccine, but modern DAAs cure >95% of patients.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P26, Q11: A phlebotomist gives herself a needlestick injury whilst taking blood from a patient who is known to be hepatitis B positive. The phlebotomist has just started her job and is in the process of being immunised for hepatitis B but has only had one dose to date. What is the most appropriate action to minimise her risk of contracting hepatitis B from the needle?	No action needed, complete hepatitis B vaccination course as normal	Give oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	Give an accelerated course of the hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immune globulin	Give hepatitis B immune globulin + oral ribavirin for 4 weeks	Give hepatitis B immune globulin	C	Give an accelerated course of the hepatitis B vaccine + hepatitis B immune globulin	For a non-responder or person with incomplete vaccination against Hepatitis B, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) includes administration of both **Hepatitis B Immune Globulin (HBIG)** (for immediate passive immunity) and an **accelerated course of the Hepatitis B vaccine** (for active long-term immunity).	HBV PEP for non-immune/incomplete vaccine: HBIG + Accelerated Vaccine Course.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P26, Q12: You are reviewing a 31-year-old man in the liver clinic. He is currently on triple therapy for hepatitis C. What is the best way to assess his response to treatment?	Alanine transaminase level	Anti-HCV antibodies	Viral load	Prothrombin time	Hepatitis C genotype	C	Viral load	The most direct and accurate way to assess the response to Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) treatment is by measuring the **HCV RNA viral load** (quantification of the virus), aiming for a Sustained Virologic Response (SVR), which is an undetectable viral load 12 weeks after completing treatment. Anti-HCV antibodies may remain positive for life.	HCV treatment response is monitored by measuring the HCV RNA Viral Load.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P26, Q13: What percentage of patients who contract the hepatitis C virus will become chronically infected?	A. 30-35%	B. 55-85%	C. 90-95%	D. 5-10%	E. 15-20%	B	55-85%	The majority of people (about 55-85%) who contract Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) will fail to clear the virus spontaneously and will progress to chronic infection.	HCV infection has a high rate (55-85%) of progression to chronic disease.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P27, Q14: A 19-year-old man presents 3 days after returning from a backpacking trip across Brazil. He complains of a sudden onset fever, headache, joint pains and rash all over his body. He has no existing health conditions and is not on any medication. On examination he has a petechial rash on his limbs. He has no focal neurology and no signs of meningism. Hb 100 g/l, Platelets 80*10^9/l, WBC 4.0*10^9/l, Eosinophils 0.4*10^9/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Viral hepatitis	Chagas disease	Dengue fever	Malaria	Bacterial meningitis	C	Dengue fever	The presentation of high fever, myalgia/arthralgia (joint pains), rash (petechial), and the lab findings of **leukopenia** and **thrombocytopenia** in a traveler returning from Brazil is characteristic of Dengue fever.	Travel + Fever + Arthralgia + Rash + Thrombocytopenia = Dengue.	Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P27, Q15: A newly qualified staff nurse at the local hospital undergoes vaccination against hepatitis B. The following results are obtained three months after completion of the primary course: Result Anti-HBs: 10-100 mlU/ml. Reference An antibody level of > 100 mlU/ml indicates a good immune response with protective immunity. What is the most appropriate course of action?	Repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of hepatitis B vaccine	Repeat anti-HBs level in three months time	Give a course of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) + one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Do a HIV test	D	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	An Anti-HBs level between 10 and 100 mIU/mL is considered a poor response (but still possibly protective). The appropriate next step is to give **one booster dose** of the vaccine, and then re-check the Anti-HBs level 1-2 months later.	Anti-HBs 10-100 mIU/mL (Poor Responder) → Give one booster dose, then re-check titer.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P28, Q16: What is the mechanism of action of the antiviral agent ribavirin?	Inhibits DNA polymerase	Inhibits uncoating of virus in the cell	Protease inhibitor	Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	E	Interferes with the capping of viral mRNA	Ribavirin is a guanosine analogue used to treat Hepatitis C and RSV. Its mechanism is complex, but it interferes with RNA metabolism and inhibits viral RNA polymerase, often described as interfering with the capping of viral mRNA.	Ribavirin is a guanosine analogue that inhibits viral RNA synthesis (e.g., mRNA capping).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P28, Q17: Which one of the following statements regarding hepatitis B is correct?
