Ribavirin is the treatment of choice for chronic hepatitis	All patient immunised against hepatitis B require an anti-HBs check to assess their response to the vaccine	10-15% of adults fail to respond or respond poorly to 3 doses of the vaccine	The vaccine is of the live-attenuated type	An anti-HBs level of 20 mlU/ml indicates an adequate response to the vaccine	C	10-15% of adults fail to respond or respond poorly to 3 doses of the vaccine	Approximately 5-15% of healthy adults will be non-responders (Anti-HBs < 10 mIU/mL) or poor responders (Anti-HBs 10-100 mIU/mL) to the standard 3-dose vaccine course. The vaccine is inactivated, not live. An adequate response is defined as Anti-HBs $\ge 100~mIU/mL$.	HBV vaccine failure/poor response rate is approximately 10-15% in adults.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P28, Q18: A 25-year-old intravenous drug user with chronic hepatitis C becomes pregnant. Approximately what is the chance of the virus being transmitted to her child?	A. <10%	B. 10-20%	C. 20-30%	D. 30-40%	E. 40-50%	A	<10%	Vertical (mother-to-child) transmission of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) is relatively inefficient, occurring in approximately 5% of cases. The risk is higher if the mother is co-infected with HIV.	HCV vertical transmission risk is low, typically < 10%.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P29, Q19: A 19-year-old medical student undergoes primary immunisation against hepatitis B. His post immunisation bloods are reported as follows: Anti-HBs < 10 mlU/ml.	Give one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	Do a HIV test	Test for current or past hepatitis B + repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of vaccine	Give two further doses of hepatitis B vaccine	Give a course of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) + one further dose of hepatitis B vaccine	C	Test for current or past hepatitis B + repeat course (i.e. 3 doses) of vaccine	A non-responder (Anti-HBs < 10 mIU/mL) to the primary 3-dose course should first be tested for current (HBsAg) or past (Anti-HBc) Hepatitis B infection. If negative, they should receive a complete repeat 3-dose course of the vaccine.	Non-responder (<10 mIU/mL) to HBV vaccine: Check HBsAg/Anti-HBc, then give a full repeat 3-dose course.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P29, Q20: A patient who was an intravenous drug user in the 1990s asks for a hepatitis C test. What is the most appropriate action?	Refer him for pre-test counselling to discuss the pros and cons of testing	Advise him that no accurate test is currently available but that he should undertake normal precautions	Arrange an anti-HCV antibody test	Arrange a HCV RNA test	Refer him to gastroenterology for a liver biopsy	C	Arrange an anti-HCV antibody test	The initial screening test for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) is the **Anti-HCV antibody test**, which identifies individuals who have been exposed to the virus. If positive, an HCV RNA test is then needed to determine if active infection is present.	HCV screening test is the Anti-HCV antibody test.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q1: The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, except	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection	Leptospirosis is a zoonosis (transmitted from animals to humans) and man is an accidental host. The primary reservoir is the urine of infected animals (especially rodents, dogs, and livestock). Lice are associated with other diseases (like typhus, relapsing fever) but not leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis is spread by the urine of infected animals (rodents) in contaminated water/soil, not lice.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q2: The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, except	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead-end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection	Leptospirosis is a zoonosis, and humans are accidental hosts. The bacteria (*Leptospira*) are shed in the urine of reservoir hosts (e.g., rodents, dogs), and transmission occurs through contact with contaminated water or soil. Lice are not reservoirs.	Reservoirs of Leptospirosis are infected animals (urine), not lice.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q3: How is leptospirosis transmitted?	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	By mosquito bites	By contact with the infected person			A	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	Leptospirosis is acquired when abraded skin or mucous membranes (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth) come into contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals.	Leptospirosis is transmitted via contact with contaminated water (infected animal urine).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q4: Which form of leptospirosis is known as Weil's disease?	Icteric	Anicteric	Both			A	Icteric	Weil's disease (or Icteric leptospirosis) is the severe form of leptospirosis, characterized by jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage. The milder form is anicteric leptospirosis.	Weil's Disease = Icteric (severe) form of leptospirosis (Jaundice, Renal Failure).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q5: Which are the two types of leptospirosis?	Icteric and Anicteric	Edematous and Non edematous	Haemorrhagic and non-haemorhagic	Benign and malignant		A	Icteric and Anicteric	Leptospirosis is clinically classified into two main syndromes: the milder, more common form, **anicteric leptospirosis**, and the more severe form with jaundice, **icteric leptospirosis** (Weil's disease).	Leptospirosis is classified into a mild (anicteric) form and a severe (icteric/Weil's) form.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P30, Q6: The following symptoms and signs are true regarding anicteric leptospirosis except?	Flu Like Symptoms	Nausea and Vomiting	Exudative conjunctivitis	Pharyngitis		C	Exudative conjunctivitis	Anicteric leptospirosis is the mild form, presenting with non-specific flu-like symptoms. **Exudative conjunctivitis** (pus/discharge) is typically seen in bacterial conjunctivitis; leptospirosis causes a characteristic **suffused (red/injected) conjunctivitis** that is non-exudative.	Leptospirosis causes suffused (non-exudative) conjunctivitis, not exudative.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P31, Q7: A 44-year-old farmer presents with headache, fever and muscle aches. He initially thought he had a bad cold but his symptoms have got progressively worse over the past week. During the review of systems he reports nausea and a decreased urine output. On examination his temperature is 38.2ºC, pulse 102/min and his chest is clear. Subconjunctival haemorrhages are noted but there is no evidence of jaundice. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Mycoplasma pneumonia	Lyme disease	Legionella pneumonia	Listeria	Leptospirosis	E	Leptospirosis	The key features are fever, myalgia, exposure risk (farmer), and the classic findings of **decreased urine output (renal involvement)** and **subconjunctival hemorrhages** without jaundice (anicteric form). This combination is highly suggestive of Leptospirosis.	Fever + Myalgia + Farmer/Rodent exposure + Renal involvement (Low UO) + Subconjunctival Hemorrhage = Leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P31, Q8: A 34-year-old sewage worker presents with a 3 days history of lower back pain, fever, myalgia, fatigue, jaundice and a subconjunctival haemorrhage. He has no past medical history and has not been abroad in the last 6 months. Na+ 135 mmol/l, K+ 5.2 mmol/l, Urea 10 mmol/l, Creatinine 180 μmol/l. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Leptospirosis	Cysticercosis	Glomerulonephritis	Hepatitis A	Hepatitis E	A	Leptospirosis	The classic triad for the severe form of leptospirosis (Weil's disease) is fever, jaundice, and renal failure/dysfunction (Creatinine 180 $\mu mol/l$). The high-risk occupation (**sewage worker**) and the presence of **subconjunctival hemorrhage** make Leptospirosis the most likely diagnosis.	Sewage worker + Fever + Jaundice + Renal Dysfunction + Subconjunctival Hemorrhage = Leptospirosis (Weil's Disease).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P32, Q9: A 37-year-old sewer worker presents to the Emergency Department with flu-like symptoms and pyrexia for the past 3 days. Since this morning he has started to develop a headache and signs of meningism are found on examination. Blood tests show: Sodium 145 mmol/l, Potassium 4.7 mmol/l, Urea 10.3 mmol/l, Creatinine 133 μmol/l. What is the antibiotic treatment of choice?	Co-trimoxazole	Ciprofloxacin	Metronidazole	Benzylpenicillin	Erythromycin	D	Benzylpenicillin	The presentation (sewer worker, flu-like symptoms, fever, meningism) is suggestive of Leptospirosis (which can cause aseptic meningitis). The treatment of choice for severe Leptospirosis is high-dose IV **Penicillin G (Benzylpenicillin)** or Ceftriaxone. Doxycycline is used for milder cases.	Severe Leptospirosis (Weil's or Meningitis) treatment of choice: High-dose IV Penicillin G (Benzylpenicillin) or Ceftriaxone.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P32, Q10: A 50-year-old sewage worker presents with a one week history of fever and feeling generally unwell. Which one of the following features would be least consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis?	Meningism	Conjunctival erythema	Productive cough	Decreased urine output	Severe myalgia	C	Productive cough	A **productive cough** is characteristic of typical pneumonia, not Leptospirosis, which is usually associated with a non-specific 'flu-like' illness, severe myalgia, conjunctival suffusion/erythema, renal/hepatic failure (decreased urine output), and sometimes aseptic meningitis (meningism).	Productive cough is *least* typical for the flu-like presentation of Leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P32, Q11: The following statements are true regarding leptospirosis, except:	It is zoonosis	Man is the dead-end host	Man is an accidental host	Lice act as reservoirs of infection		D	Lice act as reservoirs of infection	Leptospirosis is a zoonosis, and humans are accidental hosts. The infectious agent is transmitted through the urine of reservoir hosts (e.g., rodents) in water or soil, not through lice.	Leptospirosis is spread by animal urine in water, not by lice.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P33, Q12: The following symptoms and signs are true regarding anicteric leptospirosis except?	Flu Like Symptoms	Nausea And Vomiting	Exudative conjunctivitis	Pharyngitis		C	Exudative conjunctivitis	Anicteric leptospirosis is the milder form presenting with non-specific flu-like symptoms. **Conjunctival suffusion/erythema** is typical, but it is **non-exudative** (no pus/discharge). Exudative conjunctivitis is generally seen in bacterial infections.	Leptospirosis causes non-exudative conjunctival suffusion.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P33, Q13: How is leptospirosis transmitted?	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	By mosquito bites	By contact with the infected person			A	Exposure of mucous membranes or abraded skin to the contaminated water	Leptospirosis is transmitted through contact of abraded skin or mucous membranes with water or soil contaminated by infected animal urine.	Transmission of Leptospirosis is through contact with contaminated water/soil.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P33, Q14: Which are the two types of leptospirosis?	Icteric and Anicteric	Edematous and Non edematous	Haemorrhagic and non-haemorhagic	Benign and malignant		A	Icteric and Anicteric	Leptospirosis is clinically divided into the mild, anicteric form and the severe form, icteric leptospirosis (Weil's disease).	Leptospirosis types are Anicteric (mild) and Icteric (severe/Weil's).	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P33, Q15: Which form of leptospirosis is known as Weil's disease?	Icteric	Anicteric	Both			A	Icteric	Weil's disease refers specifically to the severe form of leptospirosis, which includes jaundice (icterus), renal failure, and hemorrhage.	Weil's Disease = Icteric Leptospirosis.	Leptospirosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P33, Q1: Acyclovir is an antiviral drug that is usually used in treatment of......	Hepatitis C virus	Herpes Zoster virus	Hepatitis B virus	Human immunodeficiency virus	Cytomegalovirus	B	Herpes Zoster virus	Acyclovir is a nucleoside analogue primarily used for treating infections caused by the herpes group of DNA viruses, which includes Herpes Zoster (shingles), Herpes Simplex, and Varicella.	Acyclovir is the first-line treatment for Herpes family viruses (HSV, VZV).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P34, Q2: One of the following is not a method of HIV infection:	Feco-oral route.	I.V drug users and shairing needle	Sexual relations.	Vertical transmission of infected mothers.	Lactation	A	Feco-oral route.	HIV is transmitted through body fluids, primarily blood, semen, vaginal secretions, and breast milk. It is **not** transmitted via the fecal-oral route, which is typical for some enteric pathogens.	HIV is not transmitted via the fecal-oral route.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P34, Q3: The most affected WBC of the immune system with HIV infection is :	CD8 T- lymphocyte	CD4 T- lymphocyte.	Plasma cell	Macrophage.	CD3 T- lymphocyte	B	CD4 T- lymphocyte.	The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) specifically targets and destroys **CD4+ T-lymphocytes**, which are essential for coordinating the immune response. The decline in the CD4 count is the hallmark of HIV progression to AIDS.	HIV targets the CD4 T-lymphocyte, leading to immunosuppression.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P34, Q4: Worldwide, the most common mode of infection with HIV is?	Homosexual transmission	Heterosexual transmission	Blood and blood products	Infected mothers to infants		B	Heterosexual transmission	Globally, the vast majority of HIV infections are transmitted through **heterosexual sexual contact**. The dominant mode of transmission varies by region.	Worldwide, the most common mode of HIV transmission is heterosexual contact.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P34, Q5: Which is not a cause of aseptic fever	Crush injury	SLE	AIDS	Pontine haemorrhage		C	AIDS			Fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P35, Q6: Male patient 22 years old, presented by fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, weight loss, he has a history of IV drug addiction. What most highly suspected in such case?	TB infection	Meningitis	Acute myeloid leukemia	AIDS		D	AIDS	The combination of the patient's age, high-risk behavior (**IV drug addiction**), and the prolonged, non-specific systemic symptoms (**fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, weight loss**) is highly suggestive of symptomatic HIV infection progressing to **AIDS**.	IV drug use + Constitutional symptoms (Fever, Weight Loss, LAD) = Suspect AIDS.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P35, Q7: One of the following vaccines is not given to symptomatic HIV children:	HAV	HBV	OPV	DPT	Non of the above	C	OPV	**Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)** is a **live attenuated vaccine** and is generally contraindicated in symptomatic or severely immunosuppressed HIV patients (children and adults) due to the risk of vaccine-associated paralytic polio or disseminated infection. HAV, HBV, and DPT are inactivated or non-live vaccines.	Live vaccines (like OPV) are contraindicated in symptomatic/immunosuppressed HIV patients.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P35, Q8: HIV is a:	DNA Pox virus.	RNA Ribovirus.	Single strand RNA Retrovirus.	40 nanometer diameter.	Double strand RNA virus	C	Single strand RNA Retrovirus.	The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is classified as a **retrovirus** because it uses the enzyme reverse transcriptase to copy its RNA genome into DNA. It contains a single-stranded RNA genome.	HIV is a single-stranded RNA retrovirus.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P35, Q9: One of the following is not a method of HIV infection:	Feco-oral route.	I.V drug users and shairing needle.	Sexual relations.	Vertical transmission of infected mothers.	Lactation.	A	Feco-oral route.	HIV is transmitted through body fluids (blood, semen, breast milk) and is not transmitted by the fecal-oral route.	HIV is not transmitted through the gastrointestinal/fecal-oral route.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P35, Q10: which one of the following is wrong about AIDS:	HIV equals AIDS	CD4 count less than 200 cell/ml.	Presence of severe opportunistic infections.	kaposi sarcoma could be seen.	Severely ill cachectic patient with fever.	A	HIV equals AIDS	**HIV infection does not equal AIDS**; AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is the late-stage of HIV infection defined by a CD4 count below $200~cells/\mu l$ or the presence of an AIDS-defining illness (e.g., Kaposi's sarcoma, PCP, certain opportunistic infections).	AIDS is defined by CD4 < 200 or an AIDS-defining illness, not synonymous with HIV infection.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P36, Q11: The most affected WBC of the immune system with HIV infection is	CD8 T- lymphocyte	CD4 T-lymphocyte.	Plasma cell	Macrophage.	CD3 T-lymphocyte	B	CD4 T-lymphocyte.	HIV targets the **CD4 T-lymphocyte** by binding to the CD4 receptor, leading to the progressive destruction of this crucial cell type and resulting in immunodeficiency.	The primary target of HIV is the CD4 T-lymphocyte.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P36, Q12: Laboratory methods of HIV diagnosis includes all except:	Rapid detection test.	ELISA 3rd generation.	ELISA 4th generation.	Quantiferon gold test.	HIV RNA PCR.	D	Quantiferon gold test.	The QuantiFERON-TB Gold test is an interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) used for the diagnosis of **tuberculosis (TB) infection**, not HIV. The other tests are standard methods for HIV diagnosis or monitoring.	QuantiFERON-Gold test is used for Tuberculosis (TB) diagnosis, not HIV.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P36, Q13: Male patient 22 years old, presented by fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, weight loss, he has a history of IV drug addiction. What most highly suspected in such case?	1- TB infection	2- Meningitis	3- Acute myeloid leukemia	4- AIDS		C	AIDS	The combination of the high-risk behavior (IV drug use) and the constellation of prolonged constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, generalized lymphadenopathy, diarrhea) is characteristic of the late, symptomatic stage of HIV infection, or AIDS.	IVDU + Wasting Syndrome (Fever, Weight Loss, Diarrhea) = Suspect AIDS.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P36, Q14: Which of the following anti-retroviral drugs is a known inducer of cytochrome P450?	Nevirapine	Ritonavir	Saquinavir	Nelfinavir	Zidovudine	A	Nevirapine	**Nevirapine** (a Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor - NNRTI) is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzyme system, which is important for drug-drug interaction considerations. Ritonavir, Saquinavir, and Nelfinavir are protease inhibitors (PIs) and are typically P450 inhibitors.	Nevirapine (NNRTI) is a CYP450 enzyme inducer.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P37, Q15: A 35-year-old man is reviewed in clinic having been diagnosed with HIV two years ago and is stable on antiretroviral therapy. He has a new regular partner and is concerned about transmitting the disease to him. What factor is most likely to increase the risk of transmission?	Circumcision	Low CD4 count	Co-infection with genital warts	Diabetes	Mucosal ulceration	E	Mucosal ulceration	The risk of sexual transmission of HIV is significantly increased by the presence of factors that compromise the mucosal barrier, such as active **genital ulcers** (mucosal ulceration), which provide a direct portal of entry for the virus.	Mucosal ulcers (e.g., from an STI) increase the risk of HIV transmission by providing a viral entry point.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P37, Q16: A health care assistant sustains a needlestick injury whilst taking blood from a patient who is known to be HIV positive. Following thorough washing of the wound what is the most appropriate management?	HIV test of health care worker in 3 months to determine treatment	Immediate p24 HIV test of health care worker to determine treatment	Oral antiretroviral therapy for 4 weeks	Oral antiretroviral therapy for 3 months	Intravenous zidovudine	C	Oral antiretroviral therapy for 4 weeks	For a significant occupational exposure to HIV (Needlestick from a known positive source), the standard Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) is a **3-drug oral antiretroviral regimen for 4 weeks** (28 days), initiated as soon as possible, ideally within 1-2 hours.	HIV Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) is a 3-drug ART regimen for 4 weeks.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P37, Q17: A 40-year-old woman who is known to be HIV positive is admitted to the Emergency Department following a seizure. Her partner reports that she has been having headaches, night sweats and a poor appetite for the past four weeks. Blood tests and a CT head are arranged: CD4 89 u/l, CT head Single homogenously-enhancing lesion in the right parietal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Primary CNS lymphoma	Tuberculosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcus	Toxoplasmosis	A	Primary CNS lymphoma	In an HIV patient with a low CD4 count (89), a single, homogeneously-enhancing brain lesion is highly suggestive of **Primary Central Nervous System Lymphoma (PCNSL)**. Toxoplasmosis typically presents with *multiple* ring-enhancing lesions.	HIV + CD4 < 100 + Single, homogeneously-enhancing brain lesion = Primary CNS Lymphoma.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P38, Q18: A 32-year-old HIV positive man presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen leg. He has a history of poor adherence with his medication and is currently not taking antiretrovirals; his most recent blood tests from a year previously show a detectable viral load. On examination, there are multiple purplish nodules in the skin overlying the popliteal fossa. What is the most likely underlying viral cause for his pathology?	Ebstein Barr Virus	Human Herpes Virus 8	Human Papilloma Virus	Hepatitis B	Human T-Lymphotrophic Virus	B	Human Herpes Virus 8	The multiple purplish skin nodules/plaques are characteristic of **Kaposi's Sarcoma (KS)**, an AIDS-defining cancer. Kaposi's Sarcoma is caused by co-infection with **Human Herpes Virus 8 (HHV-8)**, particularly in individuals with severe immunosuppression (detectable viral load, poor adherence).	Kaposi's Sarcoma (Purplish nodules) is caused by Human Herpes Virus 8 (HHV-8) in HIV patients.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P38, Q19: A patient with HIV is reviewed. Which one of the following is an example of a nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors?	Zidovudine	Indinavir	Ritonavir	Ribavirin	Efavirenz	A	Zidovudine	**Zidovudine (AZT)** is a Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI), a class of drugs that acts as a false substrate to inhibit the reverse transcription of the viral RNA into DNA. Indinavir/Ritonavir are Protease Inhibitors (PIs), and Efavirenz is a Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NNRTI).	Zidovudine is a classic example of an NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P39, Q20: A 34-year-old man with a past history of HIV infection presents to  the Emergency Department with watery diarrhoea. Cryptosporidium  infection is confirmed on ZN staining. What is the most suitable  management?	Metronidazole	Sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine	Supportive therapy	Rifampicin + ethambutol + clarithromycin	Co-trimoxazole	C	Supportive therapy	**Cryptosporidium** infection in an HIV patient typically causes prolonged, watery diarrhea. The primary treatment for this condition is to re-establish immune function with **Antiretroviral Therapy (ART)**; specific antimicrobial therapy (nitazoxanide or paromomycin) is often not necessary or effective, making **supportive therapy** (rehydration, ART optimization) the most crucial management step.	Cryptosporidium diarrhea in HIV: Primary management is Supportive Therapy + Optimizing ART.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P39, Q21: A 39-year-old man returns from a two week business trip to Kenya. Four weeks after his return he presents complaining of malaise, headaches and night sweats. On examination there is a symmetrical erythematous macular rash over his trunk and limbs associated with cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Typhoid fever	Tuberculosis	Dengue fever	Schistosomiasis	Acute HIV infection	E	Acute HIV infection	The constellation of symptoms (**fever, malaise, headaches, rash, and generalized lymphadenopathy**) occurring 2-6 weeks after a high-risk exposure (travel/sexual contact not explicitly mentioned but implied by the context of a GUM-style question) is the classic presentation of **Acute HIV Seroconversion Syndrome**.	Fever + Rash + Lymphadenopathy 2-6 weeks post-exposure = Acute HIV Seroconversion Syndrome.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P39, Q22: Which of the following anti-retroviral drugs is most characteristically associated with nephrolithiasis?	Zidovudine	Didanosine	Indinavir	Ritonavir	Nevirapine	C	Indinavir	**Indinavir** (a Protease Inhibitor) is famously associated with the adverse effect of **nephrolithiasis** (kidney stones) and crystal-induced nephropathy due to the poor solubility of the drug in urine.	Indinavir (PI) is associated with kidney stones (nephrolithiasis).	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P40, Q23: A 31-year-old woman who is known to be HIV positive presents following a positive pregnancy test. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. The last CD4 count was 420*10^6/l and she does not take any antiretroviral therapy. What is the most appropriate management with regards to antiretroviral therapy?	Check CD4 at 12 weeks and initiate antiretroviral therapy if CD4 count is less than 350*10^6/l	Do not give antiretroviral therapy	Start antiretroviral therapy at 20-32 weeks	Start antiretroviral therapy at 10-12 weeks	Start antiretroviral therapy immediately	E	Start antiretroviral therapy immediately			HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P40, Q24: A 26-year-old man presents to your sexual health clinic with a history of swollen inguinal lymph nodes and fever 1 month after he had receptive anal intercourse with a casual male partner. He tells you his last HIV test was 2 months previously and this is the only sexual contact he has had in the last 6 months. What is the most appropriate course of action to determine his HIV status?	Advise the patient it is too early to test for HIV; ask him to return in 2 weeks and then at 3 months	Request a combined antigen (P24) and antibody test	Ask the patient to return in 2 months for an RNA PCR test	Perform a bedside 'Point of Care' antibody only test and reassure the patient if this is normal	Take a full blood count for CD4 count	B	Request a combined antigen (P24) and antibody test	The symptoms are consistent with **Acute HIV Seroconversion Syndrome** (fever, lymphadenopathy) 1 month post-exposure. The modern **4th generation combined test** detects both p24 antigen (which is detectable early, at 2-6 weeks) and HIV antibodies, making it the most appropriate and sensitive test at this timeframe.	4th Generation HIV test (p24 Ag + Ab) is the test of choice for acute seroconversion illness (1 month post-exposure).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P41, Q25: A 34-year-old HIV positive man is being treated for Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia with co-trimoxazole. Arterial blood gases show a pO2 of 8.2 kPa. What drug should be added to treatment?	Meropenem	Chloramphenicol	Steroids	Nebulised fluconazole	Magnesium sulphate	C	Steroids	In patients with moderate-to-severe *Pneumocystis jirovecii* pneumonia (PCP), defined by a PaO2 $\le 9.3~kPa$ (or alveolar-arterial gradient $> 35~mmHg$), the addition of **adjunctive corticosteroids (steroids)** to co-trimoxazole is critical to reduce mortality and morbidity.	PCP + PaO2 $\le$ 9.3 kPa = Add Steroids to Co-trimoxazole.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P41, Q26: A 24-year-old man attends your GUM clinic for results of his recent tests. He frequently engages in unprotected sex with multiple partners. You note he had a mildly raised Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test at 1:8. He did however have a negative EIA and TPPA test. You suspect it could be a false positive test result. Which of the following would be useful at determining a cause?	HIV test	Rheumatoid factor	Serum electrophoresis	Varicella serology	Mycoplasma serology	A	HIV test	VDRL and RPR are non-treponemal tests for syphilis that can produce **false positives** due to other acute or chronic conditions. Conditions that commonly cause false-positive VDRL include HIV infection, autoimmune disorders (like SLE), and certain infections/vaccinations, making an HIV test a prudent next step.	False Positive VDRL/RPR → Test for conditions like HIV or SLE.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P41, Q27: A 31-year-old man who is known to be HIV positive presents with dyspnoea and a dry cough. He is currently homeless and has not been attending his outpatient appointments or taking antiretroviral medication. Clinical examination reveals a respiratory rate of 24 / min. Chest auscultation is unremarkable with only scattered crackles. His oxygen saturation is 96% on room air but this falls rapidly after walking the length of the ward. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate first-line treatment?	Fluconazole	Co-trimoxazole	Erythromycin	Ganciclovir	Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine	B	Co-trimoxazole	The presentation (HIV, non-adherence, dry cough, dyspnoea, bilateral lung disease implied by desaturation on exertion, and relatively clear auscultation) is classic for **Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)**. The first-line treatment is high-dose **Co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX)**.	PCP first-line treatment is Co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P42, Q28: A 33-year-old man is admitted due to profuse diarrhoea. He has a history of HIV infection and Cryptosporidium diarrhoea is suspected. What investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?	Blood cultures	Sigmoidoscopy with biopsy	Abdominal x-ray	Acid-fast staining of stool sample	Cryptosporidium PCR of stool sample	D	Acid-fast staining of stool sample	The standard and rapid method for diagnosing **Cryptosporidium** infection, an opportunistic pathogen causing profuse diarrhea in HIV patients, is the demonstration of the oocysts in a stool sample using **modified acid-fast staining** (e.g., ZN staining).	*Cryptosporidium* oocysts are detected using modified Acid-Fast Staining of stool.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P42, Q29: A 34-year old female with a background of HIV present with progressive weakness in her lower limbs. She also states that she is finding it difficult to walk up the stairs and is becoming generally clumsy. She is known to be non compliant with her anti-retroviral therapy. She had no other systemic symptoms such as weight loss and no other past medical history. On examination, one notes power is normal in both upper and ower limbs. However, one notes bilateral dysmetria in the upper limbs and lower limbs. She had an MRI which showed some white matter lesions bilaterally in the parietal lobes. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Cerebral vasculitis	Cerebral metastasis	Multiple sclerosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Toxoplasmosis	D	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	The presentation of **progressive neurological deficits** (weakness, clumsiness, dysmetria) without headache/fever/seizures in a non-compliant HIV patient, coupled with characteristic **non-enhancing, multifocal white matter lesions** on MRI (especially in the parietal lobes), is classic for **Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)**, caused by the JC virus.	Progressive Focal Neuro Deficits + Non-enhancing White Matter Lesions (MRI) + HIV = PML.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P43, Q30: A 63-year-old man presents to the acute receiving ward with a two-week history of a cough, fever, night sweats, weight loss and diarrhoea. He has tender hepatomegaly on examination. His past medical history includes HIV and his recent CD4 count is less than 50. A blood culture reveals mycobacterium avium complex. What is the treatment for this condition?	Rifampicin + Ethambutol	Pentamidine	Rifampicin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide	Rifampicin + Ethambutol + Clarithromycin	Rifampicin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol	D	Rifampicin + Ethambutol + Clarithromycin	The diagnosis is **Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC)** infection, an opportunistic infection in severe HIV (CD4 < 50). The standard treatment for disseminated MAC involves a combination of at least two drugs, typically a macrolide (**Clarithromycin** or Azithromycin) plus **Ethambutol** (and often Rifampicin/Rifabutin).	Disseminated MAC (CD4 < 50) treatment: Macrolide (Clarithromycin) + Ethambutol + Rifabutin/Rifampicin.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P43, Q31: A 33-year-old woman who was diagnosed as having HIV-1 two years ago is reviewed in clinic. She is fit and well currently and has no symptoms of note. The only medication she takes is the occasional paracetamol for tension headaches. Her latest blood tests are as follows: CD4 325*10^6/l. What is the most appropriate action with regard with to anti-retroviral therapy?	Wait until the CD4 count is below 200*10^6/l	Wait until the CD4 count is above 350*10^6/l	Wait until the CD4 count is below 250*10^6/l	Start antiretroviral therapy now	Wait until the CD4 count is below 300*10^6/l	D	Start antiretroviral therapy now	Current guidelines recommend starting Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) for **all HIV-positive patients**, regardless of CD4 count, to preserve immune function, prevent opportunistic infections, and prevent transmission.	Current HIV guidelines recommend starting ART for all patients regardless of CD4 count.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P43, Q32: A 27-year-old man who has recently moved to the UK from Uganda presents complaining of fatigue and purple skin lesions all over his body. On examination he has multiple raised purple lesions on his trunk and arms. You also notice some smaller purple lesions in his mouth. He has recently started taking acyclovir for herpes zoster infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Dermatofibroma	Kaposi's sarcoma	Drug reaction to acyclovir	Psoriasis	Haemangioma	B	Kaposi's sarcoma	The appearance of **multiple, raised, purple-to-brown cutaneous and oral lesions** in a young patient who has recently emigrated from an endemic region and is likely immunosuppressed (based on the Herpes Zoster history) is classic for **Kaposi's Sarcoma (KS)**, an AIDS-defining illness.	Purple cutaneous/mucosal nodules in an HIV-risk patient = Kaposi's Sarcoma.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P44, Q33: A 22-year-old woman who is an immigrant from Malawi presents for review as she thinks she is pregnant. This is confirmed with a positive pregnancy test. She is known to be HIV positive. Which one of the following should NOT be part of the management plan to ensure an optimal outcome?	Oral zidovudine for the newborn until 6 weeks of age	Maternal antiretroviral therapy	Encourage breast feeding	Intrapartum zidovudine infusion	Elective caesarean section	C	Encourage breast feeding	In high-income countries, **breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated** for HIV-positive mothers to prevent vertical transmission via breast milk, even if the mother is on ART. However, in low-income settings where clean water/formula is unavailable, WHO guidelines may recommend exclusive ART-covered breastfeeding. Given the UK setting implied by the GUM-style question, this is the least appropriate advice.	In most developed nations, breastfeeding is contraindicated for HIV-positive mothers due to vertical transmission risk.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P44, Q34: A 44-year-old man who is known to have HIV is admitted to the Emergency Department following a seizure. He has been taking antiretroviral therapy for the past two years. A CT scan (without contrast) shows a solitary lesion in the basal ganglia. What is the most effective method to help differentiate between lymphoma and toxoplasmosis?	MR spectroscopy	CT with contrast	Thallium SPECT	Peripheral blood film	Lumbar puncture	C	Thallium SPECT	**Thallium Single-Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT)** scanning is highly effective in differentiating Primary Central Nervous System Lymphoma (PCNSL) from Cerebral Toxoplasmosis. PCNSL lesions are typically Thallium-avid (high uptake), whereas Toxoplasmosis lesions show low Thallium uptake.	Thallium SPECT helps differentiate PCNSL (high uptake) from Toxoplasmosis (low uptake) in HIV patients.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P45, Q35: A 27-year-old male presents with malaise, pyrexia, lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. The Monospot test is negative. Given a history of high-risk sexual behaviour you are asked to exclude a HIV seroconversion illness. What is the most appropriate investigation?	Antibodies to HIV-2	gp120 polymerase chain reaction	p24 antigen test	CCR5 polymerase chain reaction	Antibodies to HIV-1	C	p24 antigen test	The patient has symptoms suggestive of Acute HIV Seroconversion Syndrome. At this early stage (2-6 weeks post-exposure), the **p24 antigen** (a core protein of the virus) is usually detectable before HIV antibodies are generated, making it the most appropriate specific investigation for early diagnosis. Modern tests typically combine p24 antigen and antibody detection.	The p24 antigen is the earliest and most specific serological marker for Acute HIV infection.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P45, Q36: A 38-year-old HIV-positive woman who is 38 weeks into her first pregnancy comes to the obstetric clinic for review. She has been compliant with medication and her viral load has been consistently <50 copies. She would like to have a vaginal delivery and is keen to breastfeed after the birth.What would you advise her regarding breastfeeding?	She can breastfeed regardless of the viral load	Breastfeeding is not recommended	She can breastfeed as long as the baby is on the neonatal antiretroviral therapy	She can breastfeed to a maximum of approximately 100ml a day	She can breastfeed as long as the viral load remains at <50 copies	B	Breastfeeding is not recommended	In developed countries, even with an undetectable viral load (like <50 copies) and maternal/neonatal ART, breastfeeding is **not recommended** for HIV-positive mothers due to the residual, albeit small, risk of HIV transmission via breast milk.	Breastfeeding is contraindicated in HIV-positive mothers in resource-rich settings, regardless of viral load.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P45, Q37: A 31-year-old man from Russia who is known to be HIV positive presents with purple plaques on his skin. Which of the following viruses is thought to be the cause of Kaposi's sarcoma?	HTLV-1	HIV-2	HHV-8	CMV	HPV-8	C	HHV-8	Kaposi's Sarcoma (KS) is an angioproliferative tumor commonly seen in immunosuppressed patients (especially those with AIDS). It is caused by the **Human Herpes Virus 8 (HHV-8)**, also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).	Kaposi's Sarcoma is caused by Human Herpes Virus 8 (HHV-8).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P46, Q38: A 57-year-old businessman presents to the emergency department with fevers, myalgia and headache which have been ongoing for the past 10 days. He also reports that he has noticed the beginnings of a rash on his face and trunk, which you would describe as maculopapular. He has no significant past medical history, and recently returned from a trip to Bangkok three weeks ago, where he admits to having intercourse with a local sex worker. He cannot remember if he used protection. Otherwise he made sure to take appropriate precautions with malarial prophylaxis and pretravel vaccines. Which of the following tests would be most likely to give a diagnosis in this history?	Malarial films	HIV antibody test	CD4 count	P24 antigen	Dengue serology	D	P24 antigen	The presentation (fever, myalgia, headache, maculopapular rash) and timing (3 weeks post-exposure) are highly suggestive of **Acute HIV Seroconversion Syndrome**. At 3 weeks, the **p24 antigen** is typically detectable, making it the most reliable early serological marker for diagnosis.	3 weeks post-exposure + Acute Retroviral Syndrome symptoms = Test for p24 antigen (part of the 4th generation HIV test).	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P46, Q39: A 34-year-old man is diagnosed as being HIV positive. He was born and brought up in the United Kingdom and is currently fit and well with no past medical history. At what point should anti-retroviral therapy be started?	At the time of diagnosis	CD4 < 200*10^6/l	CD4 < 250*10^6/l	CD4 < 300*10^6/l	CD4 < 350*10^6/l	A	At the time of diagnosis	Current guidelines universally recommend that Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) should be offered and initiated for all HIV-positive individuals, **regardless of their CD4 count**, to maximize health benefits and prevent transmission.	ART should be started for all HIV patients at the time of diagnosis, regardless of CD4 count.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P47, Q40: A 28-year-old nurse on your ward receives a needle stick injury after taking blood from a known HIV positive patient. You give her first aid treatment and send bloods for an initial HIV test. She asks you about post exposure prophylaxis. What would you advise?	Tenofovir, repeat HIV test in 12 weeks	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavir/ritonavir) repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	Nevirapine, repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavr/ritonavir), repeat HIV test in 12 week	Tenofovir, repeat HIV test in 4 weeks	B	Combination antiretrovirals (Tenofovir, emtricitabine and lopinavir/ritonavir) repeat HIV test in 4 weeks			HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P47, Q41: A 34-year-old man from West Africa is admitted due to confusion associated with left-sided weakness and ataxia. He is known to be HIV positive but is not on anti-retroviral treatment. The following results are obtained: CD4 43 u/l, CT head Low attenuation diffusely. No mass effect or enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Toxoplasmosis	Tuberculosis	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcus	Cerebral lymphoma	C	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	The presentation (profound immunosuppression with CD4 < 50, progressive focal neurological deficits - weakness, ataxia) and the CT finding of **diffuse low attenuation (non-enhancing white matter lesions)** are highly characteristic of **Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)** caused by the JC virus.	HIV + CD4 < 50 + Progressive Focal Neuro Deficits + Non-enhancing White Matter Lesions (CT/MRI) = PML.	HIV				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P47, Q1: A 7-year school-boy has been dx with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	In the event of a confirmed case of meningococcal meningitis in a school, **chemoprophylaxis** (usually with Rifampicin, Ciprofloxacin, or Ceftriaxone) is recommended for **close contacts**, which typically includes household members and others in frequent close contact (like classmates/daycare contacts). The entire class and family would be considered close contacts.	Meningococcal Prophylaxis: Give Rifampicin (or Ciprofloxacin/Ceftriaxone) to close contacts (household, daycare, deep-kissing).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P48, Q2: Which of the following CSF results suggests TB meningitis?	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, normal protein, and normal glucose	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose		C	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose	**Tuberculous (TB) meningitis** is characterized by a high number of white cells with a **lymphocytic predominance** (initially may be mixed), **raised protein**, and a significantly **low glucose** level.	TB Meningitis CSF: Lymphocytic Pleocytosis, High Protein, Low Glucose.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P48, Q3: Regarding primary amoebic meningoencephalitis, which is false	Almost invariably fatal	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Caused by Naegleria fowleri	Acquired by swimming in fresh warm water		B	Dehydroemetine is drug of choice	Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) is caused by *Naegleria fowleri* and is acquired by swimming in warm freshwater. It is almost invariably fatal. The drug of choice is high-dose IV and intrathecal **Amphotericin B**, often combined with Miltefosine. Dehydroemetine is for amebiasis.	PAM is caused by *Naegleria fowleri*, acquired via warm freshwater; Amphotericin B is the treatment, not Dehydroemetine.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P48, Q4: Which of the following organisms causes epidemic meningitis cases at military recruits?	Haemophilus influenzae type b	Neisseria meningitidis	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes		B	Neisseria meningitidis	**Neisseria meningitidis** (Meningococcus) is the classic cause of **epidemic meningitis** (outbreaks) in close-contact settings such as military barracks, college dormitories, and crowded institutions.	Outbreaks of meningitis in close quarters (barracks/dorms) are typically caused by *Neisseria meningitidis*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P48, Q5: A 10 years old child comes to the clinic complaining of fever of 2 days duration, sore throat and fatigue. He reports that there is painful swelling in his neck. His CBC shows lymphocytosis with many atypical cells. What is the appropriate treatment of this patient?	Symptomatic treatment	corticosteroid	Broad spectrum antibiotic	acyclovir		A	Symptomatic treatment	The presentation (fever, sore throat, painful neck swelling, lymphocytosis with atypical cells) is classic for **Infectious Mononucleosis**, most commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). Since this is a viral illness and usually self-limiting, the treatment is supportive/symptomatic.	Infectious Mononucleosis (EBV) is treated with symptomatic and supportive care.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P50, Q6: A 7-year school boy has been dx with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	In an outbreak scenario, **chemoprophylaxis** (like Rifampicin) should be given to all close contacts of the case, including household members and potentially the entire class/daycare group, to eradicate nasopharyngeal colonization.	Meningococcal Prophylaxis (Rifampicin) is for all close contacts (family, class, etc.).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P50, Q7: Meningitis reflects infection of the	Arachnoid mater and pia mater.	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.	Dura mater and arachnoid mater.	Subarachnoid space and pia mater.		A	Arachnoid mater and subarachnoid space.			Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P50, Q8: Which of the following bacteria is not a cause for bacterial meningitis?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Neisseria meningitidis	Escherichia coli	Haemophilus influenza		C	Escherichia coli	***Correction: E. coli is a common cause of neonatal meningitis.*** The most common causes of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults are *S. pneumoniae* and *N. meningitidis*. *H. influenzae* is a cause, especially in unvaccinated children. *E. coli* is a major cause in **neonates** but is an uncommon cause in healthy adults. Assuming the question refers to the most common adult causes, *E. coli* is the least likely (or *Listeria* should have been an option). Since the question is general, and *E. coli* is a major cause in newborns, the question is likely flawed. Based on typical adult/child questions, *E. coli* is the least common contextually in this group. Let's assume the question meant to exclude a major cause in all ages. *E. coli* is a key cause in neonates. Let's assume the question is asking which is least likely in the *general* population. The best option is **D** (H. influenzae) if the population is fully vaccinated. Given the source, I will select the one that is a pathogen, but less frequent in adults, which is the most likely intent of a flawed question. I will select **C**.	*E. coli* is a major cause in neonates, but less common in adults compared to *S. pneumoniae* and *N. meningitidis*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P50, Q9: Which of the following organisms causes epidemic meningitis cases at military recruits?	Haemophilus influenzae type b	Neisseria meningitidis	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes		B	Neisseria meningitidis	*Neisseria meningitidis* is the main organism responsible for large-scale outbreaks and epidemics of meningitis, particularly in areas of close living like military camps or dormitories.	Epidemic Meningitis in close quarters = *Neisseria meningitidis*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P50, Q10: Aseptic meningitis diagnosed when	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain but detected by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain but not by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain and bacterial cultures		A	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	**Aseptic meningitis** is a clinical syndrome of meningeal inflammation (headache, fever, neck stiffness) with pleocytosis in the CSF, but for which routine stains (Gram stain) and bacterial cultures fail to identify a bacterial pathogen. It is most commonly caused by viruses (e.g., Enterovirus).	Aseptic Meningitis = Clinical signs + CSF changes, but no growth on routine bacterial culture/Gram stain.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P51, Q11: Aseptic meningitis diagnosed when	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain but detected by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain but not by bacterial cultures	Organisms demonstrated by gram stain and bacterial cultures		A	No organisms demonstrated by gram stain or bacterial cultures	Aseptic meningitis is diagnosed when clinical symptoms and CSF pleocytosis are present, but **no bacterial pathogen can be identified** by routine Gram stain or culture.	Aseptic Meningitis is diagnosed by the absence of organisms on routine bacterial stain/culture.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P51, Q12: Classic symptoms of meningitis usually include...	Backache, hallucinations, indigestion	Rash, inner ear pain, itching	Dry skin, dehydration, cold sore	Fever, headache, stiff neck		D	Fever, headache, stiff neck	The classic clinical triad for meningitis (though not always present) is **fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)**. Confusion and photophobia are also very common.	Meningitis Classic Triad: Fever, Headache, Stiff Neck.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P51, Q13: A 43-year-old Asian man presents with headache and neck stiffness. CT brain is normal and a lumbar puncture is performed with the following results; Serum glucose 4.7 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture reveals: Opening pressure 15 cmCSF, Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 3.3 mmol/l, Protein 0.7 g/l, White cells 100/mm^3 (70% lymphocytes). What is the most likely diagnosis?	Bacterial meningitis	Viral meningitis	Tuberculous meningitis	Normal CSF result	Cryptococcal meningitis	B	Viral meningitis	The CSF profile shows a **lymphocytic predominance** (70% lymphocytes) and a **mildly low to normal glucose** (CSF/Serum ratio 3.3/4.7 = 0.7) and **mildly raised protein** (0.7 g/l). This is highly characteristic of **Viral Meningitis** (or partially treated bacterial meningitis, but viral is most likely given the mildness). TB meningitis typically has a much lower glucose and higher protein.	CSF: Lymphocytic Pleocytosis + Normal/Mildly Low Glucose + Mildly Raised Protein = Viral Meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P52, Q14: You are speaking to the partner of a 28-year-old man who has recently been admitted with pyrexia and neck stiffness. The results of initial investigations are shown below: Serum glucose 5.0 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture: Appearance Cloudy, Glucose 1.2 mmol/l, Protein 1.8 g/l, White cells 450/mm^3 (85% polymorphs), Microscopy Gram-negative diplococci. No other results concerning the serotype of the organism are available. The partner is 27-years-old and has no past medical history of note other than depression for which she takes fluoxetine. She has had a full course of immunisations including a course of MenC vaccines whilst at university 8 years ago. What is the most appropriate next step to reduce her chance of developing meningitis?	No further action is required	MenC booster dose	Oral ciprofloxacin + MenC booster dose	Oral ciprofloxacin	Oral rifampicin	D	Oral ciprofloxacin	The patient has meningitis caused by Gram-negative diplococci, which is highly likely to be **Neisseria meningitidis**. The partner is a close contact and requires **chemoprophylaxis** to prevent secondary spread. **Ciprofloxacin (single oral dose)** or Rifampicin (multiple doses) are standard prophylaxis options. The MenC vaccine given 8 years ago may not cover the specific serotype, and chemoprophylaxis is the priority.	Close contact of Meningococcal Meningitis needs Chemoprophylaxis (Ciprofloxacin or Rifampicin) urgently.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P52, Q15: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department with an evolving purpuric rash, pyrexia and confusion. His GP had given him intramuscular benzylpenicillin in the surgery and dialled 999. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?	Urinary antigen	Blood PCR for meningococcus	Blood culture	CT head	Lumbar puncture	B	Blood PCR for meningococcus	The presentation (pyrexia, confusion, purpuric rash) is classic for **meningococcemia/meningitis**. Since the patient was pre-treated with penicillin, **blood cultures** are likely to be falsely negative. **PCR for *Neisseria meningitidis* on a blood sample** is the most sensitive and reliable test for confirming the diagnosis after antibiotic pretreatment.	Antibiotic pre-treatment makes Blood PCR the most reliable test for Meningococcal infection.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P53, Q16: A patient with a severe headache, nausea and vomiting comes to the emergency department. Examination reveals neck stiffness and a positive Kernig's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed and the CSF is purulent. She is urgently started on ceftriaxone. Which class of antibiotics does ceftriaxone belong to?	Macrolides	Tetracyclines	Aminoglycosides	Beta-lactams	Lincosamides	D	Beta-lactams	**Ceftriaxone** is a third-generation cephalosporin, which belongs to the larger class of antibiotics known as **beta-lactams** (which includes penicillins and carbapenems).	Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, belonging to the Beta-lactam class.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P53, Q17: A 31-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a headache. She has had 'flu' like symptoms for the past three days with the headache developing gradually yesterday. The headache is described as being 'all over' and is worse on looking at bright light or when bending her neck. On examination her temperature is 38.2º, pulse 96 / min and blood pressure 116/78 mmHg. There is neck stiffness present but no focal neurological signs. On close inspection you notice a number of petechiae on her torso. She has been cannulated and bloods (including cultures) have been taken. What is the most appropriate next step?	IV cefotaxime	Arrange a CT head	Perform a lumbar puncture	IV dexamethasone	Intramuscular benzypenicillin	A	IV cefotaxime	The patient presents with classic signs of **meningitis** (fever, headache, neck stiffness, photophobia) and is hypotensive/unstable. The presence of **petechiae** strongly suggests meningococcemia, which is a life-threatening emergency. The next step, after taking bloods, is immediate administration of **IV empiric antibiotics** (e.g., Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime). A CT is not necessary if there are no signs of raised ICP/focal deficit and is a delay to treatment.	Meningitis + Petechial Rash = Meningococcemia. Give IV empiric antibiotics STAT (Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P54, Q18: A 20-year-old woman was admitted overnight with suspected meningitis. You are asked to review the initial microscopy results from the lumbar puncture. The lab tells you the culture is growing gram negative diplococci. What is the most likely organism?	Streptococcus pneumoniae	Listeria monocytogenes	Escherichia coli	Haemophilus influenzae	Neisseria meningitides	E	Neisseria meningitides	The organism that grows as a **Gram-negative diplococcus** and is a common cause of meningitis in young adults (like a 20-year-old) is **Neisseria meningitidis**.	Gram-negative diplococci in CSF of a young adult = *Neisseria meningitidis*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P54, Q19: Which one of the following vaccines uses a protein that attaches to the polysaccharide outer coat to make the pathogen more immunogenic?	Rabies	Yellow fever	Oral polio	Measles	Meningococcus	E	Meningococcus	This describes a **conjugate vaccine**, where a weak antigen (the polysaccharide capsule of the bacterium, like *N. meningitidis* or *S. pneumoniae*) is chemically linked (conjugated) to a strong protein carrier, enhancing immunogenicity, especially in young children. The MenC and Pneumococcal vaccines are examples.	Conjugate vaccines link a polysaccharide to a protein to enhance the immune response.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P54, Q20: A 57-year-old female presents with headache and fever to the Emergency Department. On examination neck stiffness is noted along with a positive Kernig's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed and reported as follows: CSF culture; Gram positive bacilli. What is the most likely causative organism?	Cryptococcus	Haemophilus influenzae	Streptococcus pneumoniae	E. coli	Listeria monocytogenes	E	Listeria monocytogenes	**Listeria monocytogenes** is one of the few organisms that presents as a **Gram-positive bacillus (rod)** in the CSF and causes meningitis, particularly in immunosuppressed, elderly, or pregnant patients. *S. pneumoniae* is a Gram-positive coccus.	Meningitis with Gram-positive bacilli in CSF = *Listeria monocytogenes*.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P55, Q21: A 74-year-old female presents with headache and neck stiffness to the Emergency Department. Following a lumbar puncture the patient was started on IV ceftriaxone. CSF culture grows Listeria monocytogenes. What is the most appropriate treatment?	Add IV amoxicillin	Change to IV amoxicillin + gentamicin	Add IV ciprofloxacin	Add IV co-amoxiclav	Continue IV ceftriaxone as monotherapy	B	Change to IV amoxicillin + gentamicin	The definitive treatment for **Listeria meningitis** is high-dose IV **Ampicillin or Amoxicillin**, often combined with an **Aminoglycoside (Gentamicin)** for synergistic killing, as *Listeria* is intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.	Listeria meningitis treatment is Ampicillin/Amoxicillin + Gentamicin, as it is resistant to Cephalosporins.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P55, Q22: A 7-year-old boy is admitted to hospital after presenting with fever, headache and neck stiffness. A diagnosis of pneumococcal meningitis is made. There are no other reports of meningitis in the local area over the past 4 weeks. How should the close contacts of this boy be managed?	No action is needed	Pneumococcal vaccine booster	Oral amoxicillin	Oral amoxicillin + pneumococcal vaccine booster	Oral ciprofloxacin	A	No action is needed	**Pneumococcal meningitis** (caused by *Streptococcus pneumoniae*) is generally a sporadic disease, and secondary transmission to close contacts is very rare. Therefore, unlike meningococcal meningitis, **routine chemoprophylaxis is not recommended** for close contacts.	Prophylaxis is NOT recommended for close contacts of Pneumococcal Meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P56, Q23: A 28-year-old man from Zimbabwe presents to the emergency department with a 2 week history of fever, cough, headache, vomiting and neck stiffness. He is known to be HIV positive and is on treatment. His most recent CD4 count was 450 cells/mm^3. On examination he has no focal neurological signs but appears drowsy and confused. You suspect meningitis and perform and lumbar puncture. The results show: Opening pressure 25mm H20, Appearance cloudy, White cells 200 cells/mm^3, Cells 90% lymphocytes, CSF protein 3 g/L, CSF glucose 1.1 mmol/L, Blood glucose 6.8 mm/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Meningococcal meningitis	TB meningitis	Cryptococcal meningitis	Partially treated bacterial meningitis	Herpes simplex meningitis	B	TB meningitis	The CSF profile (lymphocytic predominance, very high protein (3 g/L), and very low glucose (1.1 mmol/L, ratio 0.16)) is classic for **Tuberculous (TB) meningitis**. Although the patient's CD4 is relatively high (450), the patient is from an endemic area (Zimbabwe), and this profile is highly suggestive of TB.	CSF: Lymphocytic Pleocytosis + Very High Protein + Very Low Glucose = TB Meningitis (even with higher CD4 count).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P56, Q24: A 31-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a headache. She has had 'flu' like symptoms for the past three days with the headache developing gradually yesterday. The headache is described as being 'all over' and is worse on looking at bright light or when bending her neck. On examination her temperature is 38.2º, pulse 96 / min and blood pressure 116/78 mmHg. here is neck stiffness present but no focal neurological signs. On close inspection you notice a number of petechiae on her torso. She has been cannulated and bloods (including cultures) have been taken. What is the most appropriate next step?	IV cefotaxime	Arrange a CT head	Perform a lumbar puncture	IV dexamethasone	Intramuscular benzypenicillin	A	IV cefotaxime	The presence of **petechiae/purpura** in a patient with signs of meningitis strongly suggests fulminant **meningococcemia**, which is a medical emergency. The priority is immediate administration of high-dose IV empiric antibiotics (e.g., Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone) after blood cultures are drawn.	Meningitis + Petechial Rash = Give IV antibiotics (Cefotaxime/Ceftriaxone) STAT.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P57, Q1: Most reliable clue to poor tissue perfusion in septic shock is	Hyponatremia Hypochloremia	High level of blood lactate	Hypochloremia	Low level of HCO3		B	High level of blood lactate	**Lactate** is a direct and reliable biomarker of **tissue hypoperfusion** and anaerobic metabolism, which occurs when oxygen delivery is inadequate to meet demand (shock). A high blood lactate level is a critical indicator of severe sepsis and septic shock.	High Blood Lactate is the most reliable marker for tissue hypoperfusion/anaerobic metabolism in shock.	Septic Shock				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P57, Q2: Most reliable clue to poor tissue perfusion in septic shock is	Hyponatraemia	High level of blood lactate	Hypochloraemia	Low level of HCO3		B	High level of blood lactate	Elevated **blood lactate** is the most crucial biochemical marker for assessing and monitoring the severity of tissue hypoperfusion in septic shock.	Lactate is the key parameter for assessing perfusion status in septic shock.	Septic Shock				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P58, Q1: Which of the following is false regarding Widal test:	Titre of O-antigen above 1:640 is often very significant in enteric fever	Antibiotic therapy may depress the agglutination titres	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	An agglutination reaction		C	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	The statement that is **false** is C. In vaccinated individuals, the **H-antigen titre** is often raised and persists for years, while the O-antigen titre is not affected. The Widal test is an agglutination reaction used to detect antibodies against *Salmonella typhi* O and H antigens.	Vaccination against Typhoid raises H-titre (Flagellar antigen) for years, but the O-titre (Somatic antigen) indicates active infection.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P58, Q2: Micobacterial flora of Gl tract does not contain	Bacteroides fragilis	Clostridium perfringens	Pseudomonas	Klebsiella ozaenae		D	Klebsiella ozaenae			Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P58, Q3: Which of the following are the features of enteric fever in the first week	Continued type pyrexia	Pea-soup diarrhoea	Relative tachycardia	Typhoid state		A	Continued type pyrexia	Enteric (Typhoid) fever in the first week is typically characterized by a **gradually rising, step-ladder pattern of fever** that becomes a **continued (sustained) pyrexia**. Relative bradycardia and abdominal symptoms (like pea-soup diarrhea) or 'typhoid state' are more prominent in the second and third weeks.	First week of Typhoid: Step-ladder fever progressing to continued pyrexia.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P58, Q4: Which is true in Widal test	Relapse bears relationship with agglutinin titre	Agglutinin against flagellar antigen is most important	Agglutinins begin to appear after 3rd day of infection	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week		D	Agglutinins reach a peak titre during the fifth or sixth week	Antibodies (agglutinins) against the *Salmonella typhi* antigens begin to appear after the first week of infection, rise during the second and third weeks, and typically reach their **peak titre during the fifth or sixth week** of the illness.	Widal test antibodies peak around the 5th or 6th week of illness.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P58, Q5: Treatment of choice in chronic carrier of enteric fever is	Cholecystectomy	Quinolones	Ceftriaxone	Furazolidone		A	Cholecystectomy	A chronic carrier of *Salmonella typhi* is often asymptomatic but harbors the organism, typically in the **gallbladder**. The most definitive treatment for refractory chronic carriers is often **cholecystectomy** (gallbladder removal), alongside prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., Quinolones).	Chronic Typhoid Carriers harbor bacteria in the Gallbladder, making Cholecystectomy the definitive treatment.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P59, Q6: Which of the following is not seen in typhoid state	Flapping tremor	Coma vigil	Subsultus terulinum	Carphology		A	Flapping tremor	The **Typhoid State** is characterized by a severe, delirious, or stuporous state (Coma vigil, Subsultus tendinum/terulinum - muscular twitching, Carphology - aimless plucking at clothes/bedsheets). A **flapping tremor (asterixis)** is more typical of hepatic encephalopathy or uremia, not the central nervous system involvement of severe typhoid fever.	Flapping tremor (Asterixis) suggests Hepatic Encephalopathy, not Typhoid State.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P59, Q7: Which of the following is false regarding Widal test	An agglutination reaction	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	Titre of O-antigen above 1:640 is often very significant in enteric fever	Antibiotic therapy may depress the agglutination titres		B	In vaccinated subjects, the O-titre disappears in time but H-agglutinins present for years	This statement is **false**. In vaccinated subjects, the H-agglutinin (against the flagellar antigen) typically persists for years, while the O-agglutinin (against the somatic antigen) is not produced or disappears quickly. The O-titre is what is often significant in acute infection.	Vaccination raises the H-titre; the acute infection is typically indicated by a rising O-titre.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P59, Q8: Which of the following is true regarding the Salmonella species?	Rose spots appear in all patients with typhoid	They are normally present in the gut as commensals	They are anaerobic organisms	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever	Salmonella typhi can be categorised into type A, B and C	D	A relative bradycardia is often seen in typhoid fever	**Relative bradycardia** (Faget's sign), a slow pulse rate despite a high fever, is a classic, though not universal, sign of Typhoid fever. Rose spots are present in a minority of patients. *Salmonella* are facultative anaerobes and are considered pathogens, not commensals. *S. typhi* is not categorized into A, B, and C.	Faget's sign (relative bradycardia) is a characteristic finding in Typhoid fever.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P60, Q1: Mefloquine is used for prophylaxis against malaria 	One day before travelling to endemic area	3 days before travelling	2 days before travelling	One week before travelling		D	One week before travelling	Mefloquine prophylaxis must be started **at least 1-2 weeks (or 10 days to 2 weeks)** before travel to ensure therapeutic blood levels and to allow for the possibility of adverse effects before travel. It is continued weekly during the trip and for 4 weeks after.	Mefloquine prophylaxis begins 1-2 weeks before travel.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P60, Q2: 5-A 19-year-old man plans on traveling to Nigeria. He comes to clinic interested in travel advice and any vaccinations he may need. He has no medical history and takes no medicines. In addition to DEET and mosquito netting, which of the following recommendations would be important for prophylaxis against malaria?	Tetracyclin	Mefloquine	Primaquin	Atovaquone		B	Mefloquine	Nigeria is an area with high prevalence of chloroquine-resistant *P. falciparum*. **Mefloquine** is one of the commonly recommended first-line prophylactic agents for this region, alongside Atovaquone/Proguanil or Doxycycline.	Mefloquine is a first-line prophylaxis option for travel to chloroquine-resistant areas like Nigeria.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P60, Q3: Cinchonism is a possible side effect for:	Primaquin	Mefloquine	Proguanil	Quinine		D	Quinine	**Cinchonism** is a syndrome of symptoms (tinnitus, headache, nausea, visual disturbance) that is a known side effect of the cinchona alkaloids, primarily **Quinine**, and to a lesser extent, the related drug Mefloquine.	Cinchonism is the classic side effect syndrome of Quinine therapy.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P60, Q4: Cinchonism is a possible side effect for:	Primaquin	Proguanil	Chloroquine	Mefloquine	Quinine	E	Quinine	Cinchonism is the collection of adverse effects (tinnitus, headache, nausea, visual changes) associated with the cinchona alkaloids, most notably **Quinine**.	Quinine and Mefloquine can cause Cinchonism.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P61, Q5: Cerebral malaria is :	Treated by oral quinine sulphate	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	Associated with signs of meningeal irritation	IV dexamethasone reduces mortality rate		B	Often complicated by multi-organ failure	**Cerebral malaria** is the most severe manifestation of *P. falciparum* infection and is a life-threatening medical emergency. It is considered **severe malaria**, which is often complicated by end-organ damage, including acute kidney injury, severe anemia, and multi-organ failure. Corticosteroids like dexamethasone are **contraindicated**.	Cerebral Malaria is a severe form of *P. falciparum* that leads to multi-organ failure. Steroids are contraindicated.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P61, Q6: Malaria can affect	One million case per year	More than million per year	Less than one million			B	More than million per year	Malaria affects millions of people globally each year (estimated to be over 200 million cases per year), a number much greater than one million.	Malaria affects millions of people globally each year.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P61, Q7: The most dangerous type of malaria is	Vivax	P.malaria	Falciparum	Ovale		C	Falciparum	**Plasmodium falciparum** is the species responsible for the vast majority of severe malaria cases and malaria-related deaths, including cerebral malaria, due to its ability to infect all stages of red blood cells and cause cytoadherence.	*Plasmodium falciparum* causes the most severe and life-threatening form of malaria.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P61, Q8: The infective stage of malaria is	Ring stage	Trophozite	Sporozoites	Merozoites		C	Sporozoites	The **sporozoite** is the form of the malaria parasite that is injected into the human host's bloodstream by the infected *Anopheles* mosquito.	The infective stage transmitted by the mosquito is the Sporozoite.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P61, Q9: Cerebral malaria can be caused by	P.vivax	P.malaria	P.ovale	P.falciparum		D	P.falciparum	**Cerebral malaria** is a specific and life-threatening complication of severe malaria, caused almost exclusively by infection with **Plasmodium falciparum**.	Cerebral Malaria is caused by *Plasmodium falciparum*.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q10: Sexual cycle of malaria	Inside liver cells	Inside R.B.C	In the W.B.C	Gut of mosquito		D	Gut of mosquito	The sexual cycle of the malaria parasite, involving the fusion of male and female gametes to form a zygote, occurs in the **midgut of the *Anopheles* mosquito**. The asexual cycle (schizogony) occurs in humans.	The sexual cycle of *Plasmodium* occurs in the gut of the mosquito.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q11: Complicated malaria can develop in	Children	Pregnant female	Both			C	Both	Complicated (severe) malaria, including cerebral malaria, severe anemia, and multi-organ failure, is more likely to develop in high-risk groups such as **young children** (especially under 5), **pregnant women**, and non-immune travelers.	Children and pregnant women are the most vulnerable groups for complicated (severe) malaria.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q12: Malaria can be transmitted by	Sand fly	Male anopheles mosquito	Female anopheles mosquito			C	Female anopheles mosquito	Malaria is transmitted solely through the bite of an infected **female *Anopheles* mosquito**, as the females are the only ones that take a blood meal for egg development.	Malaria is transmitted by the bite of the female *Anopheles* mosquito.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q13: Uncomplicated falciparum can be treated	Chloroquine	Chloroquine + primaquine	ACTs therapy			C	ACTs therapy	Due to widespread drug resistance, the first-line treatment for **uncomplicated *P. falciparum* malaria** is typically an **Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT)**, such as Artemether-Lumefantrine. Chloroquine is generally ineffective against *P. falciparum*.	First-line treatment for uncomplicated *P. falciparum* is Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT).	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q14: Sickle cell patient are	More liable to malaria	Less liable to malaria	Has no role			B	Less liable to malaria	Individuals who are heterozygous for the sickle cell trait (Sickle cell carriers) are partially protected against severe and fatal **Plasmodium falciparum malaria**, meaning they are **less liable** to complicated disease.	Sickle cell trait confers protection against severe *P. falciparum* malaria.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P62, Q15: Which type of bite represents a potential medical emergency in an asplenic patient	Cat bite	Dog bite	Fish bite	Human bite		B	Dog bite	An asplenic patient is highly susceptible to overwhelming infection by encapsulated organisms. **Dog and cat bites** carry a high risk of infection with *Capnocytophaga canimorsus*, a Gram-negative bacillus that can cause fulminant sepsis, especially in asplenic patients, making it a medical emergency.	Dog and cat bites carry a high risk of *Capnocytophaga canimorsus* sepsis in asplenic patients.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P63, Q16: Mefloquinine is used for prophylaxis against malaria	One day before travelling to endemic area	2 days before travelling	3 days before travelling	One week before travelling		D	One week before travelling	Mefloquine prophylaxis must be started 1 to 2 weeks before travel to ensure steady-state blood levels are achieved and to screen for any potential severe central nervous system side effects before entering a malaria-endemic area.	Mefloquine prophylaxis begins 1-2 weeks before travel.	Malaria				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P63, Q17: Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	**Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA)** is defined as the enlargement of lymph nodes in **two or more non-contiguous** (non-adjacent) lymph node regions, often a sign of systemic disease like HIV, Tuberculosis, or lymphoma.	GLA = Enlarged nodes in 2 or more non-contiguous areas.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P63, Q18: Male patient 50 years old, farmer, came to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case is	Myelofibrosis	Egyptian splenomegaly	Hyperthyroidism	syphilis		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	The combination of **massive splenomegaly** (25 cm), signs of portal hypertension (**hematemesis from esophageal varices**), and the location/occupation (farmer) suggests **Schistosomiasis-related portal hypertension and hepatosplenic disease**, historically termed **Egyptian splenomegaly** (due to *S. mansoni*).	Massive Splenomegaly + Variceal Bleeding + Endemic area (Egypt) = Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis ('Egyptian Splenomegaly').	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P63, Q19: A 28-year-old student is admitted out of hours to the infectious diseases ward with suspected malaria following a backpacking trip around South East Asia.
