ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P84, Q1: Woolsorter's disease is	Plague	Legionnaires' disease	Anthrax	Klebsiella-induced pneumonia	Anthrax	C	Anthrax	**Woolsorter's disease** is the historical name for the **pulmonary (inhalation) form of Anthrax**, caused by inhaling spores of *Bacillus anthracis* (a Gram-positive rod). It was named after the wool and hide industry workers who inhaled the spores during their work.	Woolsorter's disease is Inhalation Anthrax.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P84, Q2: Woolsorter's disease is	Plague	Legionnaires' disease	Klebsiella-induced pneumonia	Anthrax		D	Anthrax	Woolsorter's disease is the historical term for **inhalation anthrax**, caused by inhaling *Bacillus anthracis* spores, often associated with handling animal products like wool.	Woolsorter's disease = Inhalation Anthrax.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P84, Q3: A man presents with severe vomiting. He reports not being able to keep fluids down for the past 12 hours. You suspect a diagnosis of gastroenteritis and on discussing possible causes he mentions reheating curry with rice the night before. What is the most likely causative organism?	Escherichia coli	Campylobacter	Salmonella	Shigella	Bacillus cereus	E	Bacillus cereus	The combination of **severe vomiting** and the specific food history of **reheated rice** is highly suggestive of the **emetic-type food poisoning** caused by the pre-formed toxin of **Bacillus cereus**. This toxin-mediated illness has a very short incubation period (1-5 hours).	Vomiting + Reheated Rice = *Bacillus cereus* (emetic type).	Food Poisoning				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P84, Q4: A 56-year-old farmer presents with a painless black eschar on his cheek with surrounding swelling and mild fever. The eschar started initially as an itchy boil-like lesion which became enlarged. In the last week, he had been visiting rural farms in the Turkey to help with agriculture work. What diagnosis would need to be considered first?	Necrotic ulcer	Anthrax	Cellulitis	Necrotising spider bite	Scrub typhus	B	Anthrax	The classic presentation of a **painless black eschar** with surrounding non-pitting edema (**malignant pustule**) in a patient with occupational exposure to livestock/animal products (**farmer**) is highly suggestive of **Cutaneous Anthrax** (*Bacillus anthracis*).	Painless Black Eschar + Farmer/Animal Contact = Cutaneous Anthrax.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P86, Q1: Which of the following is false in hydatid disease of liver	Caused by larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus	Diagnostic aspiration may produce anaphylaxis	Casoni's test is positive in all	Albendazole therapy is most efficacious		C	Casoni's test is positive in all	The Casoni's test (a delayed hypersensitivity skin test) is an older method for diagnosing hydatid disease. The statement that it is **positive in all** cases is **false**; serology and imaging are the gold standards. Hydatid disease is caused by the larval stage of *E. granulosus* (A). Rupture/aspiration can cause anaphylaxis (B). Albendazole is the treatment (D).	Casoni's skin test is an outdated and unreliable test for Hydatid Disease.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P87, Q1: The main pathogenic organism in non-gonococcal urethritisis	Ureaplasma urealyticum	Chalmydia trachomatis	Trichomoniasis	Herpes simplex		B	Chalmydia trachomatis	**Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU)** is defined as urethritis not caused by *N. gonorrhoeae*. The single most common cause of NGU is **Chlamydia trachomatis**. *Ureaplasma urealyticum* is the second most common cause.	The most common cause of Non-Gonococcal Urethritis (NGU) is *Chlamydia trachomatis*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P88, Q1: A 7-year school-boy has been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. What is the advice for schoolmates and staff?	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	Rifampicin for the whole school and family	Meningococcal vaccine for the family	Benzylpenicillin	IV cefotaxime	A	Rifampicin for the whole class and family	In the case of meningococcal meningitis, **chemoprophylaxis** (using Rifampicin, Ciprofloxacin, or Ceftriaxone) is recommended for all close contacts, which includes both the household and individuals who share close space (like the entire class) to eradicate the organism's carriage.	Meningococcal Prophylaxis (Rifampicin) is for all close contacts (family, classmates, etc.).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P88, Q2: A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by friends for confusion and altered mental status. They state that many colleagues have upper respiratory tract infections. He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. His physical examination is notable for confusion, fever, and a rigid neck. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination reveals a white blood cell count of 1800 cells/μL with 98% neutrophils, glucose of 1.9 mmol/L (35 mg/dL), and protein of 1.0 g/L (100 mg/dL). What is the most probable diagnosis:	a- Bacterial meningitis	b- Viral meningitis	c- Viral encephalitis	d- Tubercoulus meningitis		A	Bacterial meningitis	The CSF profile shows a **very high white cell count** ($\ge 1000~cells/\mu L$), a dominant **neutrophilic pleocytosis** ($\ge 80\%$ polymorphs), **low glucose** (CSF:Serum glucose ratio $\le 0.4$), and **high protein** ($>0.5~g/L$). This constellation of findings is diagnostic of **Bacterial Meningitis**.	CSF: High WBCs + High Neutrophils + Low Glucose + High Protein = Bacterial Meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P88, Q3: A 23-year-old previously healthy female letter carrier works in an area in which the presence of rabid foxes have been documented. She is bitten by a bat, which then flies away. Initial examination reveals a clean break in the skin in the right upper forearm. She has no history of receiving treatment for rabies and is unsure about vaccination against tetanus. The physician should:	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution and administer tetanus toxoid	cleans the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, and administer human rabies immune globulin intramuscularly	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, administer human rabies immune globulin IM, and administer human diploid cell vaccine	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution and administer human diploid cell vaccine	D	clean the wound with a 20% soap solution, administer tetanus toxoid, administer human rabies immune globulin IM, and administer human diploid cell vaccine	A bat bite, even a seemingly minor one, is considered a definitive high-risk exposure for **Rabies** and requires full post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP): **Wound cleaning**, **Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG)** (for passive immunity), and a course of **Rabies Vaccine** (active immunity). Tetanus prophylaxis is also required as indicated by the patient's uncertain status.	Rabies PEP (High Risk): Wound care + RIG + Active Vaccine Series + Tetanus.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P89, Q4: Referring to the last question: Which of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate as initial therapy?	Ampicillin plus vancomycin	Ampicillin plus gentamycin	Cefotaxime plus vancomycin	Cefotaxime plus doxycyclin		C	Cefotaxime plus vancomycin	The prior question (Q2) described a patient with CSF findings highly suggestive of **Bacterial Meningitis** in a college-aged individual (high risk for *S. pneumoniae* and *N. meningitidis*). The current empiric antibiotic regimen for community-acquired bacterial meningitis includes a third-generation cephalosporin (**Cefotaxime/Ceftriaxone**) to cover *N. meningitidis* and other Gram-negatives, PLUS **Vancomycin** to cover highly drug-resistant *S. pneumoniae*.	Empiric Meningitis Treatment: 3rd Gen Cephalosporin (Cefotaxime) + Vancomycin (to cover DRSP).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P89, Q5: The best score in Glasgow coma scale is	A-10	B-15	C-20	D-22	E-12	B	15	The **Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)** is scored from 3 (deep coma/death) to 15 (fully conscious). Therefore, the best possible score, indicating full consciousness, is **15**.	GCS range is 3 to 15; 15 is the highest (best) score.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P89, Q6: The patient is considered comatose when Glasgow coma scale less than or equal to	a-3	b-10	C-8	d-5	e-12	C	8	A patient is generally considered to be in a **coma** and unable to protect their airway when their Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is **8 or less**. This is often written as GCS $\le 8$, 'intubate 8'.	GCS $\le 8$ is the clinical definition of coma (and often the trigger for intubation).	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P90, Q7: The best score in Glasgow coma scale is	a-10	b-15	C-20	d-22	e-18	B	15	The maximum possible score on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is **15**, indicating full consciousness.	GCS max score is 15.	Neurology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P90, Q8: Which of the following causing bacterial meningitis?	Cryptococcus neoformans.	Toxoplasmosis.	Malignant malaria.	Neisseria meningitides.	Negleria fowleri.	D	Neisseria meningitides.	**Neisseria meningitidis** is one of the classic bacterial pathogens causing bacterial meningitis. The other options are fungal (*Cryptococcus*), parasitic (*Toxoplasmosis*, *Naegleria*), or protozoan (*Malaria*), causing non-bacterial (aseptic) or other types of CNS infection.	*Neisseria meningitidis* is a key cause of bacterial meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P90, Q9: Which of the following causing a septic meningitis?	H. influenza B.	Neisseria meningitides.	Strept. Pneumonia.	Staph. aureus.	Cryptococcus neoformans.	E	Cryptococcus neoformans.	**Aseptic meningitis** refers to meningitis without a bacterial cause found on routine culture/stain. This is commonly caused by viruses but can also be caused by fungi, such as **Cryptococcus neoformans**, which causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV). The other options are bacterial causes.	Fungal meningitis (*Cryptococcus*) is a cause of aseptic meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P90, Q10: Which of the following is correct about CSF examination in bacterial meningitis?	Low Tension < 180 mm H20.	Turbid aspect.	High lymphocytes.	High protein 50-100 mg/dl.	Glucose > 40 mg/dl.	B	Turbid aspect.	In bacterial meningitis, the CSF is typically cloudy or **turbid** due to the very high white cell count, predominantly neutrophils. The opening pressure is high, protein is very high ($>100~mg/dl$), glucose is low (often $<40~mg/dl$), and the cell count is very high (mostly neutrophils).	Bacterial Meningitis CSF is Turbid (cloudy) due to massive cell count.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P91, Q11: Which of the following is incorrect about CSF examination in viral meningitis?	Low Tension < 180 mm H20.	Turbid aspect.	High lymphocytes.	High protein 50-100 mg/dl.	Glucose > 40 mg/dl.	B	Turbid aspect.	The statement that the CSF has a **turbid aspect** is generally **incorrect** for typical viral meningitis. Viral meningitis typically has a lower cell count (lymphocytic pleocytosis) and relatively normal glucose/protein, resulting in a CSF that is typically **clear**.	Viral Meningitis CSF is usually clear, not turbid.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P91, Q12: Risk factors for meningitis include all of the followings except	HIV infection.	Military recruits	Chronic liver disease	College dorm residents		C	Chronic liver disease	High-risk settings (Military recruits, College dorms) and immunosuppressed states (HIV) are significant risk factors for bacterial meningitis (*N. meningitidis*, *S. pneumoniae*). While chronic liver disease causes some immune dysfunction, it is generally **less of a direct risk factor** for typical community-acquired bacterial meningitis than the others.	Chronic Liver Disease is the least common/direct risk factor for typical meningitis among these options.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P91, Q13: Besides the classic triad, what's another sign or symptom that you may find in a patient with bacterial meningitis?	Urinary frequency	Abdominal pain	Constipation	Confusion		D	Confusion	The classic triad is fever, headache, and stiff neck. However, the presence of an **altered mental status/confusion** is a fourth major and common finding, and a key indicator of severe disease/encephalitis.	Altered Mental Status (Confusion) is a common sign of meningitis/meningoencephalitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P91, Q14: Which of the following parasites is not a cause for aseptic meningitis?	Naegleria	Entamoeba histolytica	Strongyloides stercoralis	Taenia solium		B	Entamoeba histolytica			Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P91, Q15: Which of the following signs is not a sign of meningeal irritation?	Nuchal rigidity	Kernig's sign	Brudzinski's sign	Babinski's sign		D	Babinski's sign	The signs of meningeal irritation are **Nuchal rigidity** (stiff neck), **Kernig's sign**, and **Brudzinski's sign**. **Babinski's sign** (extensor plantar response) is a pathological reflex indicative of an upper motor neuron (pyramidal tract) lesion.	Babinski's sign indicates an Upper Motor Neuron lesion, not meningeal irritation.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P92, Q16: Non-blanching petechiae and cutaneous hemorrhages may be present in meningitis caused by:	Viruses	Parasites	Bacteria	TB		C	Bacteria	The classic cause of a non-blanching **petechial or purpuric rash** in the setting of meningitis is **meningococcemia**, which is a systemic infection caused by the bacterium *Neisseria meningitidis*.	Petechial/Purpuric rash + Meningitis = Meningococcemia (*Neisseria meningitidis*), a bacterial cause.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P92, Q17: 26 years old female presented with fever, malaise, headache and neck stiffness for the last two days. On examination which cranial nerves can be affected?	I, II, III	III, IV, VI	V, IX, X	VIII, X, XI		B	III, IV, VI	Cranial nerve palsies, particularly involving the **oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), and abducens (VI) nerves** (the eye movement nerves), are common complications of bacterial meningitis due to inflammation or increased intracranial pressure affecting the nerves at the base of the brain.	Cranial Nerves III, IV, and VI (eye movement) are commonly affected in bacterial meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P92, Q18: The classic triad of bacterial meningitis includes fever, neck stiffness, and	Paralysis.	Changes in mental status.	Change in gait.	Photophobia		B	Changes in mental status.	The classic triad of bacterial meningitis is **Fever, Nuchal Rigidity (Stiff Neck), and Altered Mental Status (Changes in mental status/Confusion)**. Photophobia is a common symptom but not always included in the formal triad.	Bacterial Meningitis Triad: Fever, Stiff Neck, Altered Mental Status.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P92, Q19: What is the sign in which forced flexion of the neck elicits a reflex flexion of the hips?	Kernig's sign.	Brudzinski's sign.	Chadwick's sign	Babinski's sign		B	Brudzinski's sign.	**Brudzinski's sign** is a physical sign of meningeal irritation where passive flexion of the patient's neck causes an involuntary flexion of the hip and knee joints. Kernig's sign is resistance/pain on knee extension.	Brudzinski's sign: Neck flexion causes hip/knee flexion.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P92, Q20: Which procedure is most likely used to test for meningitis?	Throat culture	Lumbar puncture	Tuberculosis skin test	Urine analysis		B	Lumbar puncture	A **Lumbar Puncture (LP)** is the definitive diagnostic procedure for meningitis, as it allows for the collection and analysis of the Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF), which reveals the cellular, chemical, and microbiological nature of the infection.	Lumbar Puncture (LP) is the definitive diagnostic test for meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P93, Q21: Which of the following is not an immediate complication of meningitis?	Septic shock	Coma	Seizures	Blindness		D	Blindness	**Septic shock, coma, and seizures** are all immediate, acute, and life-threatening complications that can develop rapidly with severe bacterial meningitis. **Blindness** (cranial nerve palsies, endophthalmitis) is a potential long-term sequela or complication, but not typically an immediate complication at presentation.	Blindness is a late complication/sequela, not an immediate complication of meningitis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P93, Q22: Blood culture is positive in meningitis caused by:	Neisseria meningitidis	TB	Aseptic meningitis	Parasites		A	Neisseria meningitidis	Blood cultures are frequently positive in patients with **Bacterial Meningitis**, especially those caused by organisms that typically cause bacteremia/sepsis, such as **Neisseria meningitidis** and *Streptococcus pneumoniae*. Blood cultures are usually negative in aseptic meningitis, TB meningitis, and parasitic causes.	Blood Cultures are most often positive in Bacterial Meningitis (especially Meningococcus).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P93, Q23: Lumbar Puncture needle for CSF analysis is inserted between	L1-L2	L3-L4	L4-L5	L5-S1		C	L4-L5	In adults, the spinal cord typically terminates at the L1-L2 level (and lower in children). To safely perform a Lumbar Puncture (LP), the needle is inserted below the end of the spinal cord, typically between the **L3-L4** or **L4-L5** vertebral interspaces, with L4-L5 being the most common/preferred site.	LP is safely performed at the L3/L4 or L4/L5 interspace (below the spinal cord terminus).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P93, Q24: Which of the following CSF results suggests TB meningitis?	Elevated CSF neutrophil count, raised protein, and low glucose.	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, normal protein, and normal glucose.	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose.	No CSF cell count, normal protein, and normal glucose.		C	Elevated CSF lymphocytes count, raised protein, and low glucose.	**Tuberculous Meningitis** classically produces a CSF profile with a **lymphocytic predominance**, a **high protein** concentration, and a **very low glucose** level.	TB Meningitis CSF: Lymphocytic Pleocytosis, High Protein, Very Low Glucose.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P93, Q25: A 19-year-old man presents asking for advice. His girlfriend has recently been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. He is worried he may have 'caught it'. What is the recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for close contacts such as this man?	Oral co-amoxiclav	Oral phenoxymethylpenicillin	Oral rifampicin	Oral erythromycin	Intramuscular cefotaxime	C	Oral rifampicin	Close contacts of a patient with meningococcal meningitis require urgent **chemoprophylaxis** to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage. Recommended oral options include a short course of **Rifampicin** or a single dose of Ciprofloxacin.	Close contacts of meningococcal cases require Rifampicin or Ciprofloxacin prophylaxis.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P94, Q26: A 19-year-old student is brought to the Emergency Department by friends due to a severe headache and drowsiness. On examination he has a widespread purpuric rash. Meningococcal infection is strongly suspected but he is known to be penicillin allergic (previous anaphylaxis). What is the antibiotic of choice?	Chloramphenicol	Meropenem	Teicoplanin	Erythromycin	Ciprofloxacin	A	Chloramphenicol	In a patient with suspected **meningococcemia/meningitis** who has a history of **anaphylaxis to penicillin** (and thus all beta-lactams like Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime), the antibiotic of choice is often **Chloramphenicol**, as it achieves high CSF concentrations and is effective against *N. meningitidis*.	Meningococcal Meningitis + Penicillin Anaphylaxis = Treat with Chloramphenicol.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P94, Q27: A 19-year-old man presents with a 12-hour history of a headache and fever. On examination, you elicit neck stiffness, photophobia and a positive Kernig's sign. He scores 15 on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)and there has been no change in behaviour and there is no evidence of raised intracranial pressure. He is haemodynamically stable and there is no rash. Blood cultures are taken and a lumbar puncture is performed. You decide to treat empirically for bacterial meningitis and prescribe intravenous cefotaxime every 6 hours. Which of the following is most appropriate in addition to intravenous cefotaxime?	Give intravenous aciclovir	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose and continue every 6 hours	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose only	Await the cerebrospinal fluid results and prescribe intravenous dexamethasone only if Streptococcus pneumoniae is isolated	Give intravenous amoxicillin	B	Give intravenous dexamethasone with the first antibiotic dose and continue every 6 hours	For adults with suspected or confirmed **bacterial meningitis** (especially pneumococcal), **adjunctive Dexamethasone** should be given just *prior* to or *concurrently* with the first dose of antibiotics to reduce cerebral inflammation and hearing loss. It is continued every 6 hours for 2-4 days.	Dexamethasone is given with the first dose of antibiotics for adult bacterial meningitis (Pneumococcal/Meningococcal).	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P95, Q28: A 19-year-old man presents with a two-day history of a diffuse headache and sore throat. He is pyrexial at 37.8°C and is reluctant to have a fundoscopy due to photophobia. A lumbar puncture is performed: Serum glucose 5.9 mmol/l. Lumbar puncture reveals: Appearance Clear, Glucose 4.1 mmol/l, Protein 0.3 g/l, White cells 2/mm^3 lymphocytes 0/mm^3 polymorphs. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Guillain-Barre syndrome	Viral meningitis	Bacterial meningitis	Cerebral malaria	Normal CSF result	E	Normal CSF result	The CSF findings (Clear appearance, very low cell count (2/mm^3), normal glucose (ratio $\approx 0.7$), and normal protein ($<0.45~g/L$)) are all within the normal reference range for Cerebrospinal Fluid. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is a **Normal CSF result**; his symptoms are likely due to a systemic viral illness.	Normal CSF: Clear, low/no cells, normal protein/glucose.	Meningitis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P95, Q1: Giving routine iron and folic acid to all pregnant women is a form of:	A- Primary prevention	B. Secondary prevention.	C-Tertiary prevention.	D-Chemoprophylaxis.		A	Primary prevention	**Primary prevention** aims to prevent disease or injury before it ever occurs. Giving supplements (like iron and folic acid) to a healthy population (all pregnant women) is a form of primary prevention aimed at preventing iron-deficiency anemia and neural tube defects.	Primary Prevention: Intervening *before* disease onset (e.g., universal vaccination, healthy diet, supplements).	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P96, Q2: A newly married female has decided to receive (MMR) vaccine, the doctor advised her to post-pone pregnancy for:	Only one month	For at least 3 months	For one year.	Not at all.		B	For at least 3 months			Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P96, Q3: the WHO established a standardized vaccination schedule for the original EPI which included the following vaccines except:	Bacillus - Calmette Guérin (BCG)	Rota virus vaccine	Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTP	Oral polio, and Measles		B	Rota virus vaccine	The World Health Organization (WHO) Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI), established in 1974, originally targeted six diseases using **BCG, DPT (Diphtheria-Tetanus-Pertussis), Oral Polio, and Measles** vaccines. Rotavirus vaccine was added later.	Original WHO EPI vaccines included BCG, DPT, OPV, and Measles, not Rotavirus.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P96, Q4: SARS is described as a zoonotic virus - what does this mean?	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	They cause pandemics	Hepatitis B virus	Such viruses are confined to animals	D.They do not cause disease in human	A	They emerge from animals to cross the species barrier infrequently	***The provided answer text does not match the standard definition.*** A **zoonotic virus** is one that naturally exists in animal populations and can be transmitted from animals to humans (e.g., SARS, MERS, Avian Flu). The most accurate definition from the choices is not C or D. Let's assume the question meant to say 'They are transmitted from animals to humans'. Since I must pick one: I'll choose A as it's the closest, emphasizing the cross-species barrier.	Zoonotic virus: Transmitted from animals to humans.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P96, Q5: The chain of infection has five main components. the habitat (animals, human or environment) in which the agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies is known as	the reservoir of the infectious agent	the portal of exit.	portal of entry	mode of transmission of the infectious agent e. the susceptible host to the infectious agent		A	the reservoir of the infectious agent	The **reservoir** is the long-term habitat or ecological niche where an infectious agent normally lives, grows, and multiplies, and from which it can infect a susceptible host.	Reservoir: The natural habitat where the pathogen lives, grows, and multiplies.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P97, Q6: During premarital care, the following vaccine/s could be given:	Hepatitis B	Tetanus toxoid	Rubella	all of the above	A & B	D	all of the above	**Premarital counseling/care** often includes screening and offering vaccines for infections that could affect the partner or future offspring, such as Hepatitis B (sexual/blood transmission), Tetanus Toxoid (for women of child-bearing age), and Rubella (due to teratogenicity in pregnancy).	Premarital vaccines often include HBV, Tetanus, and Rubella (if non-immune and not pregnant).	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P97, Q7: Expanded program on immunization (EPI) include all of the following steps EXCEPT:	Immunization against the 7 target diseases with mcrease BCG, DPT, Sabin, HBV and Measles vaccines.	Maternal immunization with tetanus toxoid (T.T.).	Immunization of all children against influenza virus.	Reduction of measles cases by 90% and mortalities by 95%.		C	Immunization of all children against influenza virus.	The EPI focuses on core childhood and maternal vaccines. **Routine immunization of all children against influenza virus** is typically a strategy beyond the original and core EPI program, although it may be adopted nationally.	Routine influenza vaccination for all children is generally not a core component of the global EPI program.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P97, Q8: Tetanus toxoid (T. T) first dose is best delayed to 20 weeks because if it is given earlier:	May cause congenital anomalies.	May cause abortion,	May cause intrauterine infection.	All of the above.	None of the above.	E	None of the above.	Tetanus Toxoid is an **inactivated (non-live) vaccine** and is safe throughout pregnancy. The recommendation to delay the first dose until after 20 weeks is generally to maximize the passive antibody transfer to the fetus and avoid the period of maximal organogenesis and risk perception, but it **does not cause** congenital anomalies or abortion.	Tetanus Toxoid is safe in pregnancy and does not cause congenital harm or abortion.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P97, Q9: Target population of the program (EPI):	Children from 0-1 years (Basic vaccines)	Booster doses from one year to school entry	Woman in child bearing period (tetanus toxoid)	All of the above.		D	All of the above.	The Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) targets the entire population at risk of the covered diseases. This includes **infants and children** (basic and booster doses) and **women of childbearing age** (for maternal/neonatal tetanus protection).	EPI targets infants, children, and women of childbearing age.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P98, Q10: The general objectives of the program are the following except:	To reduce morbidity from the covered diseases	To minimize effort and cost of treatment.	To promote a new healthy generation	To promote geriatric generation.		D	To promote geriatric generation.	The objectives of the EPI focus on controlling vaccine-preventable diseases in **mothers and children**. While general health initiatives target all ages, the core EPI objectives do not specifically focus on the **geriatric population**.	The EPI focuses on maternal and child health, not specifically the geriatric population.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P98, Q11: the WHO established a standardized vaccination schedule for the original EPI which included the following vaccines except:	Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG),	Rota virus vaccine	Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTP),	Oral polio, and Measles.		B	Rota virus vaccine	The initial six vaccines included in the Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) were BCG, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Polio, and Measles. The **Rotavirus vaccine** was introduced later as an optional or supplemental vaccine.	Rotavirus vaccine was not part of the original core EPI schedule.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P98, Q12: absolute contraindications to vaccination:	Severe illness that needs hospitalization.	Recent receipt of blood.	HIV infection is an absolute contraindication to administration of live attenuated vaccines.	Pregnancy.		C	HIV infection is an absolute contraindication to administration of live attenuated vaccines.			Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P98, Q13: If prenatal diagnosis reveals infection in the fetus, the pregnant patient should receive ?	Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine	folinic acid	Spiramycin	A&B		D	A&B	This question is asking about the management of **congenital toxoplasmosis** where fetal infection is confirmed. The treatment for this is typically a regimen of **Pyrimethamine, Sulfadiazine, and Folinic Acid** (A&B), as this regimen crosses the placenta to treat the fetus. Spiramycin is used earlier in pregnancy if maternal infection is confirmed but fetal infection is not yet known.	Confirmed fetal Toxoplasmosis is treated with Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Folinic Acid.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P98, Q14: Primary prevention refers to	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	Measures taken after occurrence of the disease.	Measures taken after occurrence of complications.	Measures taken to prevent handicapping.		A	Measures carried out for healthy individuals.	**Primary prevention** is defined as actions taken to preclude the development of a disease or injury (e.g., vaccination, health education). It is applied to **healthy individuals** or populations to promote health and prevent disease occurrence.	Primary prevention targets healthy people to prevent the onset of disease.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P99, Q15: Seroprophylaxis is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoide.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera.		B	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	**Seroprophylaxis** is the administration of **pre-formed antibodies** (e.g., Immune Globulins) to provide immediate, temporary, passive immunity against a specific pathogen.	Seroprophylaxis = Giving pre-formed antibodies (passive immunity).	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P99, Q16: Vaccine is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera.		A	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	A **Vaccine** is an **antigenic preparation** (inactivated or attenuated organisms, or toxoids) administered to a recipient to stimulate an active, protective immune response against a specific pathogen.	Vaccine = Antigenic preparation to stimulate active immunity.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P99, Q17: Chemoprophylaxis is:-	Antigenic preparations in the form of organisms or toxoid.	Already formed antibodies to induce Humoral or Cellular immunity.	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	System of preserving vaccines, toxoid, and sera		C	Antimicrobial drugs given just before or immediately after exposure.	**Chemoprophylaxis** is the administration of **antimicrobial drugs** (chemicals) to prevent the development or progression of an infection, usually given just before or immediately after known or likely exposure (e.g., malaria prophylaxis, meningococcal prophylaxis).	Chemoprophylaxis = Giving antibiotics/drugs to prevent infection post-exposure.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P99, Q18: Community control include the following except:--	Environmental sanitation.	Health education.	Mass immunizatiom.	Disinfection.		D	Disinfection.	Community control measures are broad public health activities aimed at reducing the burden of disease in a community, such as **Environmental Sanitation**, **Health Education**, and **Mass Immunization**. **Disinfection** is typically a specific action taken on surfaces, less a broad public health control strategy than the others.	Disinfection is a specific action, not a broad community-level control measure like Health Education or Mass Immunization.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P99, Q19: Giving routine iron and folic acid to all pregnant women is a form of:	A- Primary prevention	B- Secondary prevention.	C- Tertiary prevention.	D- Chemoprophylaxis.		A	Primary prevention	Administering iron and folic acid to healthy pregnant women is a preventative measure applied to a healthy group, intended to prevent the occurrence of nutritional deficiency diseases. This is the definition of **Primary Prevention**.	Universal administration of supplements to healthy populations is a Primary Prevention strategy.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P100, Q20: Adequate treatment of a case is considered as:	A- Primary prevention for case and contact.	B- Primary prevention for case and secondary for contact.	C- Primary prevention for contact.	D- Secondary prevention of case.	E- Secondary prevention for case and primary for contact.	D	D- Secondary prevention of case.			Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P100, Q21: The following are primary preventive measures EXCEPT:	Vaccination.	Early diagnosis.	Health education.	Proper nutrition.		B	Early diagnosis.	**Primary prevention** aims to prevent the onset of disease (e.g., Vaccination, Health Education, Nutrition). **Early diagnosis** (Screening) is a measure taken to detect disease at an asymptomatic, early stage, which is the definition of **Secondary Prevention**.	Early Diagnosis (Screening) is Secondary Prevention, not Primary Prevention.	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P100, Q22: An example of secondary prevention is:	A- Giving iron to pregnant females.	B- B- Use of seat belts.	C- Influenza vaccine for the elderly.	D-D- DPT immunization for infant.	E- Detection of asymptomatic cases of diabetes mellitus.	E	Detection of asymptomatic cases of diabetes mellitus.	**Secondary prevention** aims to detect disease early and intervene to stop or slow its progression (Screening). **Detection of asymptomatic cases** (screening) is the classic example of secondary prevention. The others are examples of primary prevention (preventing the initial onset).	Secondary Prevention involves screening/early diagnosis (e.g., detecting asymptomatic DM).	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P100, Q23: You attend a meeting with the hospital management. There is currently an increased incidence of MRSA septicaemia in the hospital and a strategy is being drawn up to tackle this. What is the most effective single step to reduce the incidence of MRSA?	The use of personal protective equipment for staff including gloves and aprons	Hand hygiene	Screening patients for MRSA on admission	Cohort nursing	Limiting the number of visitors	B	Hand hygiene	The single most effective and fundamental measure for controlling the spread of all nosocomial infections, including MRSA, is strict adherence to **Hand Hygiene** practices by all healthcare workers.	Hand Hygiene is the single most effective way to prevent nosocomial infection (e.g., MRSA).	Community Health				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P100, Q24: Which one of the following is true regarding linezolid?	Active against both MRSA and VRE (Vancomycin Resistant Enterococcus)	Bactericidal in action	No activity against GISA (Glycopeptide Intermediate Staphylococcus aureus	Adverse effects include raised platelet count	Inhibits RNA synthesis	A	Active against both MRSA and VRE (Vancomycin Resistant Enterococcus)	**Linezolid** (an Oxazolidinone) is a broad-spectrum Gram-positive agent that is effective against many multidrug-resistant organisms, including both **MRSA** and **Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococci (VRE)**. It is typically bacteriostatic and can cause thrombocytopenia (low platelets).	Linezolid is highly effective against both MRSA and VRE.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P101, Q1: Cysticercosis is the larval stage of	Taenia solium	Hyrnenolepiasis n.ana	Taenia saginata	Ancylostoma duodenale		A	Taenia solium	**Cysticercosis** is the infection caused by the larval stage (*Cysticercus cellulosae*) of the tapeworm **Taenia solium** (the pork tapeworm), acquired by ingesting the tapeworm eggs.	Cysticercosis is the larval infection of *Taenia solium*.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P101, Q2: Toxoplasmosis is infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The only known hosts of this organism are domestic cats and their relatives. Infection with T. gondii in humans can occur in various ways. Which of the following is the most common mode of infection in humans?	Blood transfusion	Ingestion of oocysts	Ingestion of tissue cysts	Transplacental transmission		B	Ingestion of oocysts			Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P101, Q3: Retinochroiditis is caused by eye infection with:	a-Loa-loa	b-Onchocerca volvulous	c-Demodex folliculorum	d-Toxoplasma gondi	e-Toxocara cani	D	Toxoplasma gondi	**Retinochoroiditis** is a classic and common manifestation of **ocular toxoplasmosis**, often resulting from the reactivation of a congenital *Toxoplasma gondii* infection.	Ocular Toxoplasmosis typically presents as Retinochoroiditis.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P102, Q4: Improper contact lens -care practices may lead to	River blindness	Acanthamoeba keratitis	African eye worm	Ocular toxocariasis	Ocular toxoplasmosis	B	Acanthamoeba keratitis	**Acanthamoeba keratitis** is a severe and painful infection of the cornea caused by the amoeba *Acanthamoeba*. The main risk factor for this infection is improper contact lens hygiene, particularly using tap water or homemade solutions.	Acanthamoeba Keratitis is strongly associated with poor contact lens hygiene (especially water exposure).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P102, Q5: Retinochroiditis is caused by eye infection with	a-Loa-loa	b-Onchocerca volvulous	c) -Demodex folliculorum	d-Toxoplasma gondi	e-Toxocara cani	D	Toxoplasma gondi	**Retinochoroiditis** is the most common ocular manifestation of **Toxoplasmosis**, often due to the parasite encysting in the retina and reactivating.	Retinochoroiditis is a classic feature of Ocular Toxoplasmosis.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P102, Q6: River blindness' is due to	A. Toxoplasmosis	B. Trichinasis	C. Onchocerciasis	D. Cysticerosis		C	Onchocerciasis	**River Blindness** is the common name for the chronic disease **Onchocerciasis**, which is caused by the parasitic worm *Onchocerca volvulus* and transmitted by blackflies that breed near fast-flowing rivers.	River Blindness = Onchocerciasis (*Onchocerca volvulus*).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P102, Q7: Toxoplasmosis is infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The only known hosts of this organism are domestic cats and their relatives. Infection with T. gondii in humans can occur in various ways. Which of the following is the most common mode of infection in humans?	A. Blood transfusion	B. Ingestion of oocysts	C. Ingestion of tissue cysts	D. Transplacental transmission		B	B. Ingestion of oocysts	The most common route of transmission for *Toxoplasma gondii* in humans is the consumption of raw or undercooked meat containing **tissue cysts** (bradyzoites).	Eating undercooked meat with tissue cysts is the most frequent way humans contract Toxoplasmosis.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P102, Q8: Infection with T. gondii can manifest in many different ways. Which of the following types of toxoplasmosis results from congenital infection that is reactivated in a patient’s late teens or 20s?	A. Acute	B. Disseminated	C. CNS	D. Ocular		D	Ocular	**Ocular Toxoplasmosis** (retinochoroiditis) is a common clinical syndrome that is often the result of a flare-up (reactivation) of cysts that had been dormant in the retina since a **congenital infection** acquired *in utero*.	Ocular Toxoplasmosis is the most common reactivation site from a congenital infection.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P103, Q9: What things can you get from a restaurant that will cause you to gain this parasite?	Rotten foods	Uncooked meat	clean water	Unwashed vegetables	B&D	E	B&D	Infection with *Toxoplasma gondii* occurs from consuming **tissue cysts** in undercooked meat (B) or **oocysts** from environmental contamination, which can be found on unwashed fruits and **vegetables** (D).	Toxoplasma is acquired from undercooked meat (tissue cysts) or unwashed produce (oocysts).	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P103, Q10: Toxoplasmosis is diagnosed using an indirect fluorescent antibody (IFA) test or enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for IgG or IgM antibodies. Which of the following results of serologic testing for T. gondii indicates that a patient has a possible acute infection?	A. IgG is equivocal; IgM is positive	B. IgG is positive; IgM is equivocal	C. IgG is positive; IgM is negative			A	A. IgG is equivocal; IgM is positive	Acute Toxoplasmosis: IgM Positive (or rising titre) + IgG Negative/Equivocal.	The presence of **IgM antibodies** is indicative of a **recent/acute infection** with *Toxoplasma gondii*, as IgM is produced early and disappears quickly. IgG indicates past infection (or immunity). The combination of positive IgM and equivocal IgG is consistent with the early stage of acute infection.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P103, Q11: Which one of the following statements regarding toxoplasmosis is true?	A. It is a type of flagellate	B. Congenital toxoplasmosis results in optic nerve atrophy	C. Ceftriaxone should be used initially in patients with HIVassociated toxoplasmosis	D. The cat is the only known animal reservoir	E. Infection is usually self-limiting	E	Infection is usually self-limiting	Infection with *Toxoplasma gondii* is typically **asymptomatic and self-limiting** in immunocompetent individuals (E). It is a sporozoan (A is false), causes retinochoroiditis, not optic atrophy (B is false), the treatment is pyrimethamine/sulfadiazine (C is false), and cats are the definitive host, but many other animals can be intermediate hosts (D is false).	Toxoplasmosis is generally a self-limiting, flu-like illness in immunocompetent individuals.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P104, Q12: Which one of the following is the most common cause of visceral larva migrans?	Cryptococcus neoformans	Strongyloides stercoralis	Visceral leishmaniasis	Toxocara canis	Giardiasis	D	Toxocara canis	**Visceral Larva Migrans (VLM)** is a syndrome caused by the migration of nematode larvae (most commonly the dog roundworm, **Toxocara canis**) through the viscera of humans, who are accidental hosts.	Visceral Larva Migrans is most commonly caused by *Toxocara canis* (dog roundworm).	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P104, Q13: A 33-year-old man who is HIV positive is admitted to the Emergency Department with confusion and drowsiness. He has been complaining of headaches for a number of days. On examination heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure 104/78 mmHg and temperature is 37.2ºC. He is confused giving a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 14. There is no photophobia or neck stiffness. His infectious diseases consultant reports that he is prescribed highly active antiretroviral treatment (HAART) but his compliance is poor and he often misses clinic appointments. A CT brain is requested: CT brain (with contrast): Multiple hypodense regions predominantly in the basal ganglia which show ring enhancement. Minimal surrounding oedema. No mass effect. What is the most likely diagnosis?	Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy	Cryptococcal infection	Cerebral toxoplasmosis	CMV encephalitis	Tuberculosis	C	Cerebral toxoplasmosis	The combination of the immunocompromised status (HIV, poor compliance), the classic location (**basal ganglia**), and the characteristic appearance of **multiple ring-enhancing lesions** on CT/MRI is highly suggestive of **Cerebral Toxoplasmosis**.	HIV + Basal Ganglia Lesions + Multiple Ring-Enhancing Lesions = Cerebral Toxoplasmosis.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P104, Q14: A 29-year-old HIV positive man is admitted with right-sided hemiplegia. For the past four days he has been complaining of headache and flu-like symptoms. CT scan shows multiple ring enhancing lesions. A diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. What is the most suitable management?	Artemether and lumefantrine	Co-trimoxazole	Supportive treatment	Pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine	Metronidazole and gentamicin	D	Pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine	The treatment of choice for suspected or confirmed **Cerebral Toxoplasmosis** is the combination of **Pyrimethamine and Sulfadiazine**, with the addition of Folinic Acid to prevent bone marrow suppression from Pyrimethamine.	Cerebral Toxoplasmosis treatment: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P105, Q15: Toxoplasmosis is infection with Toxoplasma gondii. The only known hosts of this organism are domestic cats and their relatives. Ingestion of tissue cysts	d. Transplacental transmission		B	b. Ingestion of oocysts			Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P105, Q16: Infection with T. gondii can manifest in many ways. Which of the following types of toxoplasmosis results from congenital infection that is reactivated in a patient’s late teens or 20s?	a) Acute	b) Disseminated	c) CNS	d) Ocular		D	Ocular	Reactivation of a quiescent congenital *Toxoplasma* infection often manifests as recurrent **Ocular Toxoplasmosis** (retinochoroiditis) in adolescents and young adults.	Ocular Toxoplasmosis is a common reactivation of congenital infection.	Toxoplasmosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P105, Q17: What things can you get from a restaurant that will cause you to gain this parasite?	a) Rotten foods	b) Uncooked meat	c) clean water	d) Unwashed vegetables	e) B&D	f) A&D	E	B&D	*Toxoplasma gondii* is acquired by consuming **tissue cysts** in undercooked meat (B) or **oocysts** in contaminated produce such as unwashed vegetables (D).	*T. gondii* transmission is from undercooked meat or oocysts in unwashed produce.				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P106, Q18: Toxoplasmosis is diagnosed using an indirect fluorescent antibody (IFA) test or enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for IgG or IgM antibodies. ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P106, Q19: If prenatal diagnosis reveals infection in the fetus, the pregnant patient should receive ?	a) Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine	b) folinic acid	c) Spiramycin	d) A&B	D	D	A&B	Confirmed fetal Toxoplasmosis treatment: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Folinic Acid.
