ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P107, Q1: The following are risk factor for candida infection except?	A. HIV and AIDS	B- Long term steroids use	C- HAV	D- Immunosupressive therapy	E- Long term antibiotics use	C	HAV	*Candida* infection risk factors include conditions causing immunosuppression (HIV/AIDS, steroids, immunosuppressive therapy) and disruption of normal flora (long-term antibiotics). **Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)** is a viral infection of the liver and is **not** a risk factor for candidiasis.	Hepatitis A (HAV) is not a risk factor for *Candida* infection; immunosuppression is the main factor.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P107, Q2: All of the following antifungal medications may be used for the treatment of Candida albicans fungemia except	A. amphotericin B	B. Caspofungin	C. fluconazole	D. Terbinafine	E. voriconazole	D	Terbinafine	**Terbinafine** is an allylamine antifungal primarily used topically for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea) and orally for onychomycosis, but it is **not** used for the systemic treatment of *Candida* fungemia. Amphotericin B, Caspofungin (echinocandin), Fluconazole (azole), and Voriconazole (azole) are all standard options.	Terbinafine is for dermatophytes (skin/nail fungi), not systemic candidemia.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P107, Q3: One of these fungal infections has bad prognosis if associated with covid 19	A. Cryptococcosis	B. Candidiasis	C. Mucormycosis	D. Histoplasmosis	E. Asperigillosis	C	Mucormycosis	**Mucormycosis** (Black Fungus) has been notoriously associated with a particularly **bad prognosis** in COVID-19 patients, especially those with pre-existing or steroid-induced diabetes, due to the rapid, invasive nature of the infection.	Mucormycosis has a notably high mortality rate in COVID-19/diabetic patients.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P107, Q4: The following are risk factor for candid infection except?	A. HIV and AIDS	B. Long term steroids use	C. HAV	D. Immunosupressive therapy	E. Long term antibiotics use	C	HAV	**Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)** is a viral infection and not a risk factor for *Candida* infection. The other options are all established risk factors due to immunosuppression or altered microbial flora.	HAV infection does not increase the risk of Candidiasis.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P108, Q5: In which of these fungal infections we use maximum tolerated dose of amphotracin B	A. Candida	B. Cryptococosis	C. Asperigillosis	D. Mucormycosis		D	Mucormycosis	Invasive Fungal Infections like Mucormycosis require maximal Amphotericin B dosage.	**Mucormycosis** (caused by *Mucorales*) is a rapidly progressive and highly invasive fungal infection requiring aggressive surgical debridement and high-dose antifungal therapy. It is typically treated with a high or **maximum tolerated dose of liposomal Amphotericin B**.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P108, Q6: Who of those not at risk of fungal infection	A. Low birth weight infant	B. Neutropenic patient	C. Organ transplantation	D. Hypertensive patient		D	Hypertensive patient	Hypertension itself is not a primary risk factor for opportunistic fungal infections.	Fungal infections primarily target **immunosuppressed individuals** (neutropenic, transplant recipients, HIV/AIDS) or those with compromised barriers/conditions (LBW infants, diabetes). A **hypertensive patient** without other comorbidities is not at increased risk for opportunistic fungal infections.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P108, Q7: One of these fungal infections has bad prognosis if associated with covid 19	A. Cryptococcosis	B. Candidiasis	C. Mucormycosis	D. Histoplasmosis	E. Asperigillosis	C	Mucormycosis	**Mucormycosis** is an angioinvasive mold infection that has been recognized as having a particularly high fatality rate when occurring in patients with severe COVID-19, especially in the context of corticosteroid treatment and diabetes.	Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection with a poor prognosis in COVID-19 patients.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P108, Q8: A 45-year-old male presents with yellow discolouration of his nails. On examination he has thickened yellow toe nails. You decide to treat him with terbinafine. What is the mechanism of action of terbinafine?	A. Interacts with microtubules to disrupt mitotic spindle	Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase	C. Binds with ergosterol	D. Converted to 5-fluorouracil	B	B	Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase	Terbinafine blocks squalene epoxidase.	**Terbinafine** is an allylamine antifungal drug used primarily for onychomycosis (nail fungus). Its mechanism of action is the **inhibition of the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase**, leading to a toxic accumulation of squalene inside the fungal cell.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P109, Q9: A 48-year-old man with a past medical history of poorly controlled HIV is admitted with shortness of breath. He also complains of haemoptysis. Imaging and blood tests confirm a diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. He is treated with amphotericin B. What is the mechanism of action of amphotericin B?	A. Inhibits DNA polymerase	B. Converted to to 5-fluorouracil	C. Binds with ergosterol	D. Inhibits synthesis of beta-glucan	E. Interacts with microtubules to disrupt mitotic spindle	C	Binds with ergosterol	**Amphotericin B** is a polyene antifungal that acts by binding to **ergosterol**, a critical component of the fungal cell membrane, leading to pore formation, leakage of cell contents, and fungal cell death.	Amphotericin B kills fungi by binding to Ergosterol in the cell membrane.	Pharmacology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P110, Q1: One of these fungal infections has bad prognosis if associated with covid 19	A. Cryptococcosis	B. Candidiasis	C. Mucormycosis	D. Histoplasmosis	E. Asperigillosis	C	Mucormycosis	**Mucormycosis** (Black Fungus) is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection with a high mortality rate, particularly noted in association with COVID-19 in patients who are immunosuppressed or diabetic.	Mucormycosis is a severe fungal complication of COVID-19/diabetes.	Fungal infection				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P111, Q1: The main causative agent of urinary tract infections is:	Klebsiella pneumonia	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Escherichia coli		D	Escherichia coli	**Escherichia coli** (*E. coli*) is, by far, the most common bacterial pathogen causing both uncomplicated and complicated Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs), responsible for over 75% of community-acquired cases.	*E. coli* is the most common cause of UTI (Uncomplicated $\ge 75\%$).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P111, Q2: Gonococcal urethritis can be treated by	Ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly for 7 days .	Azithromycin 1g daily for 5 days .	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of Metronidazole 2 gm.	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of azithromycin 1g.		D	Single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM plus oral dose of azithromycin 1g.	Gonococcal Urethritis treatment: Ceftriaxone IM + Azithromycin PO (dual therapy for Chlamydia co-infection).	Due to the risk of co-infection with *Chlamydia trachomatis* and emerging antibiotic resistance, the standard treatment for **Gonococcal Urethritis** is a **single intramuscular dose of Ceftriaxone (to treat the gonococcus)**, co-administered with a single oral dose of **Azithromycin** (to treat presumptive chlamydia co-infection).					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P111, Q3: Non-gonococcal urethritis can be treated by	Oral single dose of azithromycin 500mg once daily for 5 days	Oral single dose of azithromycin 500mg once daily for 5 days plus metronidazole 2 gm daily for 7 days	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily plus metronidazole 2 gm daily	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily		C	7-day course of doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily	NGU first-line treatment is Doxycycline 100mg BID for 7 days.	The current first-line treatment for **Non-Gonococcal Urethritis (NGU)** (most often caused by *C. trachomatis* or *U. urealyticum*) is a **7-day course of oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily**. An alternative is a single dose of Azithromycin 1g.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P111, Q4: In urinary tract infections, the most common rout of infection is	Ascending infection.	Lymphatic spread	Direct spread	Hematogenous spread		A	Ascending infection.	The most common mechanism for acquiring a Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) is the **Ascending Route**, where microorganisms (most commonly *E. coli*) colonize the periurethral area and then ascend the urethra into the bladder and potentially the kidneys.	Most UTIs occur via the Ascending Route (bacteria travel up the urethra).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q5: The main causative agent of urinary tract infections is	Klebsiella pneumonia	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Pseudomonas aeruginosa	Escherichia coli		D	Escherichia coli	**Escherichia coli** (*E. coli*) is the predominant pathogen responsible for the vast majority of all Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs), especially community-acquired ones.	*E. coli* is the most common cause of UTI.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q6: Which one of the followings is considered to be complicated acute pyelonephritis?	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with sever flank pain	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	Acute pyelonephritis with high fever		C	Acute pyelonephritis with renal dysfunction	**Complicated acute pyelonephritis** refers to infection in a patient with underlying structural, functional, or metabolic abnormalities. The presence of **renal dysfunction** (e.g., elevated creatinine, impaired GFR) indicates a complication or underlying compromise, classifying it as complicated.	Pyelonephritis with structural/functional abnormality (e.g., renal dysfunction) is Complicated Pyelonephritis.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q7: Which one of the following need treatment at hospital?	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	Acute pyelonephritis with high pyuria	Acute pyelonephritis with high leukocytosis	Acute pyelonephritis with fever 39 C		A	Acute pyelonephritis with DM	Acute Pyelonephritis requires hospital admission and IV antibiotics if there are signs of severe sepsis, inability to tolerate oral intake, or the presence of complicating factors. **Diabetes Mellitus (DM)** is a complicating factor that often mandates inpatient treatment due to increased risk of complications (e.g., emphysematous pyelonephritis) and treatment failure.	Acute Pyelonephritis in a diabetic patient often requires hospital admission for IV antibiotics.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q8: Microscopic pyuria defined as pyuria associated with	WBCs more than 10/CM	WBCs more than 50/CM	WBCs more than 100/CM	Positive leukocyte esterase		A	WBCs more than 10/CM	**Microscopic pyuria** is generally defined as the presence of $\ge 10$ leukocytes (white blood cells) per cubic millimeter (or per high-power field, depending on the standard used) in a urine sample.	Pyuria is defined as $\ge 10$ WBCs/CM (or per HPF).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q9: In patients with urinary tract infections, the ultrasonography indicated in	Patients with severe flank pain	Patients with high fever	Patients with high pyuria	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment		D	Patients not improved after 3 days of treatment	Imaging (Ultrasound) is indicated for UTI/Pyelonephritis that fails to respond to 3 days of antibiotics.	Imaging (Ultrasound or CT) is typically indicated in a patient with a Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) when there is suspicion of a complicating factor (obstruction, abscess) or when the patient **fails to clinically improve after 48-72 hours (3 days) of appropriate antibiotic treatment**.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P112, Q10: Patients with acute pyelonephritis can be treated by	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	Ciprofloxacin orally for 14 days	Ciprofloxacin, IV for 7 days	Ceftriaxone 1 g IV for 5 days		A	Ciprofloxacin, orally for 7 days	Uncomplicated Pyelonephritis can be treated with oral Ciprofloxacin for 7 days.	For uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis, oral antibiotic therapy is appropriate, typically for a duration of **5-7 days for fluoroquinolones (like Ciprofloxacin)** or 7-10 days for other agents. 14 days is unnecessarily long.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P113, Q11: Infection with Schistosoma haematobium is most strongly associated with:	A. Transitional cell bladder cancer	B. Lung cancer	C. Hepatoma	D. Vulval carcinoma	E. Squamous cell bladder cancer	E	Squamous cell bladder cancer	Chronic infection and inflammation of the bladder wall caused by **Schistosoma haematobium** (urinary schistosomiasis) is a major risk factor for the development of **Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Bladder**, a relatively rare form of bladder cancer otherwise.	*S. haematobium* causes chronic bladder inflammation, a risk factor for Squamous Cell Bladder Cancer.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P113, Q12: A 54 year old female is admitted with a severe pneumonia following a holiday in Turkey. Bloods reveal both hyponatraemia and deranged liver function tests. A chest xray shows patchy alveolar infiltrates with consolidation in the right lower lobe. Which one of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the probable diagnosis?	A. Sputum culture	B. Urinary antigen	C. Blood cultures	D. Bone marrow aspirate	E. Lumbar puncture	B	Urinary antigen	The presentation (severe pneumonia, hyponatremia, deranged LFTs, travel history) is highly suggestive of **Legionella pneumonia**. The most reliable and rapid non-invasive test for *Legionella pneumophila* serogroup 1 (the most common cause) is the **Urinary Antigen Test**.	Pneumonia + Hyponatremia + Travel = Legionella. Test of choice is Urinary Antigen.	Respiratory Infections				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P113, Q13: A 23-year-old male presents with a purulent urethral discharge. A sample of the discharge is shown to be a Gram negative diplococcus. What is the most appropriate antimicrobial therapy?	Oral ciprofloxacin for 7 days	Oral penicillin V for 7 days	Oral doxycycline for 7 days	Oral azithromycin stat dose	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	E	Intramuscular ceftriaxone stat dose + oral azithromycin stat dose	The finding of a Gram-negative diplococcus in urethral discharge is diagnostic of **Gonococcal Urethritis** (*Neisseria gonorrhoeae*). The recommended first-line treatment is **dual therapy**: a single IM dose of **Ceftriaxone** (for *N. gonorrhoeae*) plus a single oral dose of **Azithromycin** (to cover co-infection with *C. trachomatis*).	Gonococcal Urethritis: Ceftriaxone IM + Azithromycin PO dual therapy.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P114, Q14: A 22-year-old female presents with an offensive vaginal discharge. History and examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. What is the most appropriate initiaL management?	A. Oral azithromycin	B. Topical hydrocortisone	C. Oral metronidazole	D. Clotrimazole pessary	E. Advice regarding hygiene and cotton underwear	C	Oral metronidazole	**Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)** is characterized by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., *Gardnerella*), leading to a fishy-smelling discharge. The first-line treatment is either oral or topical **Metronidazole**, or topical Clindamycin.	Bacterial Vaginosis treatment is Metronidazole (oral or topical).	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P114, Q15: A 24-year-old heterosexual man presents to GUM with a history of dysuria, urethral irritation and milky discharge from the urethra. Urethral microscopy reveals >10 polynuclear lymphocytes per field but no gonorrhoea is seen and urine dip is normal. He did a home test 3 days ago when his symptoms started and Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea NAATs were negative. His urine dipstick is normal. His last sexual encounter was 3 weeks ago. You make a clinical diagnosis of non specific urethritis (NSU). What is the most appropriate action to take?	A. Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	B. Reassure the patient; his symptoms will resolve spontaneously	C. Tell the patient to repeat his Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea tests in 2 weeks' time.	D. Start oral aciclovir	E. Refer to urology for their assessment and opinion	A	Start oral doxycycline for 1 week	The clinical presentation (urethral discharge, dysuria, pyuria) confirms **Non-Specific Urethritis (NSU)**/NGU. Although initial NAATs were negative (possibly too early at 3 days post-exposure), empirical treatment is indicated. The first-line treatment for NGU is oral **Doxycycline for 7 days**.	Clinical Non-Gonococcal Urethritis needs empirical treatment with Doxycycline for 7 days.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P114, Q16: A nurse in a GUM clinic asks you to look at a rectal gramstained slide for a symptomatic patient she has just seen. It shows pinkish/red stained intracellular diplococci. What is the most likely organism?	A. Neisseria Meningitidis	B. Probable contaminant/commensal organism	C. Chlamydia trachomatis	D. Escherichia coli	E. Neisseria gonorrhea	E	Neisseria gonorrhea	**Gram-negative (pink/red) intracellular diplococci** seen on a Gram stain of an endocervical, urethral, or rectal specimen are considered diagnostic for **Neisseria gonorrhoeae** infection.	Gram-negative intracellular diplococci from a genital/rectal swab = *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P115, Q17: A 34-year-old man from Zimbabwe is admitted with abdominal pain to the Emergency Department. An abdominal x-ray reveals urinary bladder calcification. What is the most likely cause?	A. Schistosoma mansoni	B. Sarcoidosis	C. Leishmaniasis	D. Tuberculosis	E. Schistosoma haematobium	E	Schistosoma haematobium	**Urinary bladder calcification** (a late complication of chronic inflammation) in a patient from an endemic area (Zimbabwe/Africa) is the hallmark finding for chronic infection with **Schistosoma haematobium** (Urinary Schistosomiasis).	Bladder Calcification + African Travel = Chronic *Schistosoma haematobium* infection.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P115, Q18: A 24-year-old woman presents due to an itchy vulva and pain during sex. She also mentions a green, offensive vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Candida	B. Bacterial vaginosis	C. Gonorrhoea	D. Trichomonas vaginalis	E. Chlamydia	D	Trichomonas vaginalis	The classic presentation of **Trichomoniasis** (*Trichomonas vaginalis*) is a highly characteristic **green/yellow, frothy, offensive vaginal discharge**, often accompanied by vulval itching (pruritus) and dyspareunia (painful sex).	Green, frothy, offensive discharge + Pruritus = *Trichomonas vaginalis*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P115, Q19: A 24-year-old student returns from a gap year in Malawi complaining of visible haematuria, dysuria and urinary frequency. She says she felt well throughout her trip but experienced an itchy rash on her legs a few hours after swimming in Lake Malawi which has now resolved. Her blood results show: Hb 98 g/l, Platelets 150 * 10^9/l, WBC 9.0 * 10^9/l, Neutrophils 4.0 * 10^9/l, Lymphocytes 2.5 * 10^9/l, Eosinophils 0.5 * 10^9/l. How would you treat her?	A. Albendazole	B. Trimethoprim	C. Prednisolone	D. Doxycycline	E. Praziquantel	E	Praziquantel	The presentation (swimming in Lake Malawi, a transient itchy rash - 'swimmer's itch', and subsequent **haematuria/cystitis symptoms** with **eosinophilia**) is classic for acute **Schistosoma haematobium** infection. The treatment of choice for schistosomiasis is **Praziquantel**.	Schistosomiasis (from freshwater exposure) treatment is Praziquantel.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P116, Q20: A 31-year-old woman presents as she has noted an offensive, fishy vaginal discharge. She describes a grey, watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Trichomonas vaginalis	B. Candida	C. Chlamydia	D. Bacterial vaginosis	E. Physiological discharge	D	Bacterial vaginosis	The classic presentation of **Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)** is a thin, homogenous **grey or white vaginal discharge** with a characteristic **'fishy' odor** (due to volatile amines).	Grey, watery, fishy-smelling discharge = Bacterial Vaginosis.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P116, Q21: A 27-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant presents with 'cystitis'. She describes a two day history of dysuria, suprapubic pains and frequency. There has been no vaginal bleeding. Urine dipstick is positive for leucocytes and nitrites. Her temperature is 37.6ºC. What is the most appropriate management?	A. Oral nitrofurantoin	B. Await the midstream specimen of urine (MSU) result	C. Oral trimethoprim	D. Oral ciprofloxacin	E. Topical clotrimazole	A	Oral nitrofurantoin	A pregnant woman with symptoms and dipstick findings consistent with a UTI (Cystitis) requires prompt treatment. **Nitrofurantoin** is one of the safest and most effective first-line antibiotics for UTI in the first trimester of pregnancy. Trimethoprim and Ciprofloxacin are generally avoided in early and late pregnancy, respectively.	First-line UTI treatment in the first trimester of pregnancy is Nitrofurantoin.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P117, Q22: What would be the next step to manage his bacteriuria?	A. This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	B. Commence nitrofurantoin 100 mg four times a day for 3 days	C. Commence one stat dose of gentamicin intravenously and if no response contact microbiology	D. Check sensitivities first and commence antibiotics regardless of clinic	E. Remove catheter immediately and contact urology	A	This bacteriuria should not be treated. Ensure good hydration and monitor any urinary symptoms or pyrexia	The patient has a long-term catheter and a positive urine culture (ESBL *E. coli*), but he is **asymptomatic** (no dysuria, no fever, hemodynamically stable, no pyuria/hematuria mentioned). This represents **Asymptomatic Catheter-Associated Bacteriuria (CA-B)**, which should **not** be treated with antibiotics to prevent resistance and adverse effects.	Asymptomatic Catheter-Associated Bacteriuria (CA-B) should not be treated with antibiotics.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P118, Q22: A 35-year-old man returns from a two week holiday in Italy. He has a 10 day history of rectal bleeding associated with lower back pain. On examination there is a painful swelling of his right knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Gonococcal septicaemia	B. Amoebiasis	C. Crohn's disease	D. Tuberculosis	E. Ulcerative colitis	A	A. Gonococcal septicaemia			Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P118, Q23: A 30-year-old woman presents with a white, malodorous vaginal discharge. There is no associated itch or dyspareunia. A diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is suspected. Overgrowth of which one of the following organisms is most likely to cause this presentation?	A. Lactobacilli	B. Trichomonas	C. Candida	D. Mycoplasma hominis	E. Gardnerella	E	Gardnerella	**Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)** is characterized by a reduction in protective *Lactobacilli* and an overgrowth of various anaerobic bacteria, predominantly **Gardnerella vaginalis**, which is responsible for the characteristic fishy odor and grey discharge.	Bacterial Vaginosis is caused by overgrowth of *Gardnerella vaginalis* and other anaerobes.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P118, Q24: An 18-year-old male is admitted with fever, headache and neck stiffness. He receives IV ceftriaxone. A lumbar puncture and culture of his cerebrospinal fluid reveal that the pathogenic organism is Neisseria meningitides. What is the appearance of this bacterium on gram staining?	A. Gram-positive cocci	B. Gram-negative cocci	C. Gram-positive rod	D. Gram-negative rod	E. Poorly staining organism	B	Gram-negative cocci	**Neisseria meningitidis** is a classic encapsulated, non-motile, oxidase-positive bacterium that is classified as a **Gram-negative diplococcus (cocci)**.	*Neisseria meningitidis* is a Gram-negative diplococcus.	Microbiology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P119, Q25: A 19-year-old woman is reviewed in the genitourinary medicine clinic. She presented with vaginal discharge and dysuria. Microscopy of an endocervical swab showed a Gram-negative coccus that was later identified as Neisseria gonorrhoea. This is her third episode of gonorrhoea in the past two years. What is the most likely complication from repeated infection?	A. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome	B. Cervical cancer	C. Arthropathy	D. Infertility	E. Uterine abscess	D	Infertility	Repeated episodes of **Gonococcal infection** (and Chlamydia) in women cause chronic, ascending infection that leads to **Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)**. PID causes scarring of the fallopian tubes, which is the most common cause of tubal-factor **infertility** and ectopic pregnancy.	Recurrent Gonorrhea/Chlamydia most commonly leads to Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) and subsequent Infertility.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P119, Q26: A 38-year-old man presents to the genitourinary clinic with multiple, painless genital ulcers. A diagnosis of granuloma inguinale is made. What is the causative organism?	A. Klebsiella granulomatis	B. Chlamydia	C. Herpes simplex virus	D. Treponema pallidum	E. Haemophilus ducreyi	A	Klebsiella granulomatis	**Granuloma Inguinale** (Donovanosis) is a rare, chronic, sexually transmitted infection characterized by progressive, painless, beefy-red ulcers. It is caused by the bacterium **Klebsiella granulomatis** (formerly *Calymmatobacterium granulomatis*).	Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) is caused by *Klebsiella granulomatis*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P119, Q27: A 25-year-old sexually active woman presents with dysuria and urgency. A urine dipstick is positive for leukocytes and nitrites. Urine culture and gram staining reveal a grampositive organism in clusters that is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely causative organism?	A. Escherichia coli	B. Staphylococcus aureus	C. Staphylococcus saprophyticus	D. Proteus mirabilis	E. Klebsiella	C	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	The patient has a UTI (dysuria/urgency + positive dipstick). In young, sexually active women, the second most common cause of UTI (after *E. coli*) is **Staphylococcus saprophyticus**, which is a **Gram-positive coccus** that is typically **coagulase-negative**. *S. aureus* is coagulase-positive.	UTI in young sexually active woman + Coagulase-negative Gram-positive cocci = *Staphylococcus saprophyticus*.	Urology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P120, Q1: Which type of bite represents a potential medical emergency in an asplenic patient?	A-Cat bite	B- Dog bite	C- Fish bite	D- Human bite		B	Dog bite	Both dog and cat bites are associated with the risk of overwhelming sepsis from *Capnocytophaga canimorsus*, a risk that is critically high in asplenic patients, making it a medical emergency. **Dog bites** are generally more common, and this is the classic teaching scenario.	Dog/Cat bites are a high-risk source of *Capnocytophaga canimorsus* sepsis in asplenic patients.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P120, Q2: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. He states that the symptoms are worse with eating, and that his abdominal pain has been increasing over the past three to four months. He reports a history of travel to endemic area with parasites five months ago. After that he developed a cough associated with mild shortness of breath which he attributed to a viral respiratory infection, as it resolved shortly thereafter. His physical examination is significant for moderate periumbilical tenderness. His laboratory results are significant for an eosinophil count of 20 percent. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed small bowel dilation proximal to a whirlpool-like mass in the mid-jejunum causing intestinal obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Clonorchis sinensis	B. Ascaris lumbricoides	C. Trichuris trichiura	D. Cystoisospora belli	E. Taenia saginata	B	Ascaris lumbricoides	The key findings are a history of travel (endemic exposure), the migration/pulmonary phase (**cough/SOB**), **high eosinophilia** (20%), and the presence of a mass (worm bolus) in the small bowel causing **intestinal obstruction** (whirlpool sign/dilation). This clinical picture is characteristic of heavy infection with the roundworm **Ascaris lumbricoides**.	Small Bowel Obstruction + Eosinophilia + Cough phase + Endemic area = *Ascaris lumbricoides* infection.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P121, Q3: A 24 years old male coming to you complaining of epigastic discomfort and vomiting ,You requested testing for H.pylori which was positive .In addition to PPI .Choose the most suitable antimicrobials	A- Ceftriaxone	B- Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	C- Azithromycin	D- Doxycyclin		B	Clarithromycin, and amoxicillin	The standard triple therapy for **Helicobacter pylori** infection is a Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI) plus two antibiotics: usually **Clarithromycin and Amoxicillin** (or Metronidazole if penicillin-allergic) for 10-14 days.	*H. pylori* first-line treatment is PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin (Triple Therapy).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P121, Q4: Which of the following statements regarding Clostridium difficile associated disease relapses is true?	A. A first recurrence does not imply greater risk of further recurrences.	B. Most recurrences are due to antibiotic resistance.	C. Recurrent C. difficile–associated disease has been associated with a higher risk of colon cancer.	D. Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	E. Testing for clearance of C. difficile is warranted after treating recurrences.	D	Recurrent disease is associated with serious complications.	Recurrent *C. difficile* infection (CDI) is a significant clinical problem, with a risk of further relapse. Each subsequent recurrence is associated with an **increased risk of serious complications**, including toxic megacolon and death. Testing for clearance (E) is generally not recommended.	Recurrent *C. difficile* infection significantly increases the risk of severe complications and subsequent relapses.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P121, Q5: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Ascaris lumbricoides infection except:	asymptomatic carriage	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	non-productive cough and pleurisy with eosinophilia	right upper quadrant pain and fever	small-bowel obstruction	B	fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity, and eosinophilia	*Ascaris lumbricoides* infection presents in two phases: asymptomatic carriage (A) or the pulmonary/migratory phase (Löffler syndrome: cough, eosinophilia, C), followed by the intestinal phase, which can cause obstruction (E) or biliary/pancreatic symptoms (RUQ pain, D). The symptoms listed in B (meningism) are characteristic of **meningitis/encephalitis**, not typical *Ascaris* manifestations.	*Ascaris* infection involves pulmonary migration (Löffler syndrome) and intestinal symptoms (obstruction), but not CNS infection/meningism.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P121, Q6: Refering to the last question, one month after receiving a 14-day course of the antimicrobials, you prescribed for Helicobacter pylori. He still has mild dyspepsia and pain after meals. What is the appropriate next step in management?	Empirical long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy	Endoscopy with biopsy to rule out gastric adenocarcinoma	Second-line therapy for H. pylori with omeprazole, bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole	Urea breath test	H. pylori serology testing	D	Urea breath test	Since the patient was treated for *H. pylori*, the first step in managing persistent symptoms is to confirm the eradication of the bacterium. The non-invasive **Urea Breath Test (UBT)** is the preferred method for assessing eradication success 4 weeks after antibiotic therapy.	Test-of-Cure for *H. pylori* (4 weeks post-treatment): Urea Breath Test (UBT) or Fecal Antigen Test (FAT).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P122, Q7: All of the following diseases can cause huge splenomegaly except:	A-HCV infection	B- Biharziasis	C-Thalassemia	D-Malaria		A	HCV infection	Huge (massive) splenomegaly is common in chronic hemolytic anemias (Thalassemia), chronic protozoal infections (Malaria), and hepatic diseases causing portal hypertension (*Schistosomiasis*, historically called Bilharziasis). **Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) infection** typically causes chronic liver disease/cirrhosis, but **not** massive splenomegaly unless associated with portal hypertension.	Massive splenomegaly is associated with hemolysis, severe malaria, and Schistosomiasis, but not typically chronic HCV infection alone.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P122, Q8: A 31-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 5-day history of abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and loose stools, accompanied by progressively increasing fever. He also has a moderate headache and a rash. On physical examination, temperature is 40 °C , pulse rate is 64/min, normal blood pressure and respiratory rate, The patient appears sick. There are blanching erythematous macules on the lower chest and upper abdominal wall. The pharynx is erythematous. Abdominal examination reveals tender hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination is normal .His CBC shows leucopenia with lymphopenia. liver profile shows elevated liver enzymes. Two sets of aerobic blood cultures show gram-negative bacilli . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	A- Brucellosis	B- Lassa fever	C- Leptospirosis	D- Typhoid fever		D	Typhoid fever	The classic combination of high fever with **relative bradycardia** (Temp 40°C, Pulse 64/min, Faget's sign), the presence of blanching **'rose spots'** (rash), **hepatosplenomegaly**, and laboratory findings of **leukopenia** and positive **Gram-negative bacilli** blood cultures is diagnostic of **Typhoid Fever** (*Salmonella typhi*).	High Fever + Relative Bradycardia (Faget's sign) + Rose Spots + Leukopenia + Hepatosplenomegaly = Typhoid Fever.	Typhoid fever				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P123, Q9: Male patient 50 years old, farmer, came to ER by hematemesis, splenic size was 25 cm, esophageal varices, etiology of splenomegaly in such case is	a. Myelofibrosis	b. Egyptian splenomegaly	c. Syphilis	d. Hyperthyroidism		B	Egyptian splenomegaly	The context of massive splenomegaly ($\ge 25~cm$), portal hypertension signs (**hematemesis from esophageal varices**), and the high-risk occupation/endemic area implies chronic **Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis** (Bilharziasis), which is historically termed **Egyptian Splenomegaly**.	Massive Splenomegaly + Variceal Bleeding in a Farmer = Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis ('Egyptian Splenomegaly').	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P123, Q10: Which is not a recognised complication of acute shigellosis	a. Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome	B. Reiter's syndrome	c. Liver abscess	d. Endotoxic shock		C	Liver abscess	Acute Shigellosis can lead to severe systemic disease, including Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS), post-infectious Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's syndrome), and shock. **Liver abscess** is not a typical complication of *Shigella* but is associated with amebiasis (*Entamoeba histolytica*).	Liver abscess is associated with Amoebiasis, not a recognized complication of Shigellosis.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P123, Q11: A 53-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for fever. He underwent elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery 2 days ago. urinary catheter was inserted in the operating room. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications . On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C, blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg, pulse rate is 88/min, and respiration rate is 18/min. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The sternotomy incision site is clean and dry. He has mild suprapubic tenderness but no costovertebral angle or flank tenderness. Urine analysis reveals 10 to 20 leukocytes/hpf. Urine culture reveals> 400 colonies gram-negative rods. Chest radiograph shows no infiltrate . In addition to removing the urinary catheter, which of the following is the most appropriate management?	A- wait antimicrobial sensitivity before beginning antimicrobial therapy	B- Begin antimicrobial therapy now	C- Repeat urinalysis and urine culture in 24 hours	D -Provide no additional treatment		B	B- Begin antimicrobial therapy now		Urology					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P124, Q12: Generalized lymphadenopathy is considered if there is	a. Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	b. Enlargement of less than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	c. Enlargement of more than two contiguous lymph node groups.	d. Enlargement of one lymph node group.		A	Enlargement of more than two non-contiguous lymph node groups.	**Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA)** is defined as the enlargement of lymph nodes in **two or more non-contiguous** (non-adjacent) lymph node regions.	GLA = Enlargement of lymph nodes in $\ge 2$ non-contiguous areas.	Infectious Diseases				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P124, Q13: Malta fever is caused by	A. Pasteurella tularensis	B. Haemophilus influenzae	C. Brucella abortus	D. Pseudomonas mallei		C	Brucella abortus	**Malta Fever** is the alternative name for **Brucellosis**, caused by species of the genus *Brucella*, including *B. abortus*.	Malta Fever is Brucellosis (*Brucella* species).	Brucellosis				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P124, Q14: In the developed world, seroprevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection is currently	A. Decreasing	B. increasing	C. staying the same	D. unknown		A	Decreasing	Due to improved sanitation, better hygiene, and increased use of antibiotics, the prevalence and acquisition rate (and thus seroprevalence) of *Helicobacter pylori* infection have been **decreasing** significantly in developed countries over the past few decades.	*H. pylori* prevalence is decreasing in developed nations due to improved sanitation/antibiotics.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P124, Q15: A 19-year-old student presents with a fifteen week history of diarrhoea. He has lost 2kg in weight, and has no recent travel abroad. A smear of a duodenal biopsy reveals many trophozoites. What is the best treatment option?	A- Ciprofloxacin	B- Gluten free diet	C- Metronidazole	D- Prednisolone	E- Quinine	C	Metronidazole	The diagnosis, confirmed by the finding of **trophozoites** in the small bowel (duodenal biopsy), is **Giardiasis** (*Giardia lamblia*), which often presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. The treatment of choice for Giardiasis is oral **Metronidazole** or Tinidazole.	Chronic Diarrhea + Duodenal Trophozoites (*Giardia*) = Treat with Metronidazole.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P125, Q16: A person with liver disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni would be most likely to have	A. Ascites	B. esophageal varices	C. gynecomastia	D. Jaundice	E. spider nevi	B	esophageal varices	Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis (*S. mansoni*) causes periportal fibrosis (Symmers' fibrosis) leading to **presinusoidal portal hypertension**. This portal hypertension results in severe complications such as **esophageal varices** and subsequent variceal bleeding. Jaundice is rare in pure schistosomiasis.	Hepatosplenic Schistosomiasis causes presinusoidal portal hypertension, leading to Esophageal Varices.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P125, Q17: Which of these is a common cause of diarrhea?	a) Contaminated food or water	b) Viral infection	c) Imbalance of good and bad bacteria in the gut	d) All the above		D	d) All the above	Diarrhea causes include infection (viral/bacterial/parasitic), toxins, and gut flora imbalance.	Diarrhea is a non-specific symptom that can be caused by various factors, including ingestion of contaminated food/water (infectious or toxin-mediated, A), viral enteritis (B), and dysbiosis (imbalance of flora, C), making all three correct.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P125, Q18: All of the following organisms can cause Dysentery except:	a) Entamoeba histolytica	b) Rota virus	c) Shigella spp.,	d) Nontyphoid Salmonella,		B	b) Rota virus	Dysentery (bloody/mucus diarrhea) is caused by invasive pathogens (*Shigella*, *E. histolytica*), not Rotavirus.	**Dysentery** is defined as inflammatory diarrhea, often with visible blood and mucus. It is typically caused by invasive organisms like *Entamoeba histolytica* (amoebic dysentery) and *Shigella spp.*, and sometimes invasive *Salmonella*. **Rotavirus** causes non-inflammatory, watery diarrhea.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P126, Q19: Traveler’s diarrhea can be caused by several pathogens, the most common of which is:	a) Salmonella,	b) Shigella,	c) Enterotoxigenic E. coli.	d) Campylobacter,		C	Enterotoxigenic E. coli.	ETEC (*E. coli*) is the most common cause of Traveler's Diarrhea.	**Enterotoxigenic *E. coli* (ETEC)** is the single most frequently identified bacterial cause of traveler's diarrhea worldwide, responsible for up to 50% of cases.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P126, Q20: In a hospitalized patient who develop diarrhea after receiving Clindamycin, what is most causative pathogen causing diarrhea in such case:	a) Clostridium difficile	b) Entamoeba histolytica	c) Rota virus	d) Enterotoxigenic E. coli.		A	a) Clostridium difficile	Clindamycin use is strongly associated with *Clostridium difficile* infection (CDI).	Antibiotic-Associated Diarrhea (AAD), particularly following broad-spectrum antibiotics like **Clindamycin** or cephalosporins, is overwhelmingly most commonly caused by **Clostridium difficile** infection (CDI) due to disruption of the normal gut flora.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P126, Q21: Therapy in Acute diarrhea should be directed at:	a) Using antidiarrheal agent to stop diarrhea	b) Preventing dehydration and restoring fluid losses	c) Using antimicrobial to kill the pathogen	d) High sugar containing fluids		B	Preventing dehydration and restoring fluid losses	The primary therapy for acute diarrhea is Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT) to prevent dehydration.	The single most important goal in the management of acute diarrhea, especially in severe cases, infants, and the elderly, is **rehydration** (oral or intravenous) to prevent and correct life-threatening dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.					
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P126, Q22: A 50 year old woman presents with dysphagia and intermittent vomiting. Endoscopy shows narrowing in the distal esophagus but no associated mucosal abnormalities. What is the investigation of choice to reach the diagnosis?	A. Abdominal CT	B. Barium swallow	C. Esophageal motility and manometry test	D. Endoscopic ultrasound	E. Tissue biopsy	C	Esophageal motility and manometry test	The symptoms of dysphagia and regurgitation (vomiting), combined with an endoscopic finding of esophageal narrowing but **no mucosal abnormalities**, strongly suggests a primary **motility disorder** (e.g., achalasia, spasm). The definitive investigation for esophageal motility disorders is **esophageal manometry**.	Dysphagia + No mucosal abnormality = Motility Disorder. Diagnose with Esophageal Manometry.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P127, Q23: A 42-year-old male presents with a 12-hour history of severe abdominal pain, fever and myalgia. On examination he is pyrexial, temperature 39°c and has generalised abdominal tenderness and guarding. Bowel sounds are quiet. He has a healed laparotomy scar from a previous hospital admission with similar symptoms which was inconclusive and was given broad spectrum antibiotics. On this occasion, plain abdominal X-ray is unremarkable with normal CBC. Eighteen hours after admission, his symptoms have resolved. He comments that his brother has similar symptoms. Which medication would you prescribe?	A. Colchicin	B. Indomethacine	C. Metronidazole	D. Prednisolone	E. Sulphasalazine.	A	Colchicin	The presentation of **recurrent episodes** of severe, generalized abdominal pain and fever/systemic inflammation that **spontaneously resolves** (usually within 12-72 hours) and often involves other family members strongly suggests a diagnosis of **Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF)**. The primary treatment for FMF to prevent attacks and amyloidosis is daily **Colchicine**.	Recurrent, self-resolving serositis/abdominal pain + Fever = Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF). Treat with Colchicine.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P127, Q24: A 65-year-old presents with iron-deficiency anemia, refractory to iron treatment. No history of overt gastrointestinal bleeding, but fecal occult blood tests were positive on 4 of 5 occasions. A previous EGD showed a large hiatal hernia. Two colonoscopies and a small bowel radiographic series were unremarkable. A repeated EGD shows large hiatal hernia with linear ulcers along the gastric folds at the level of the diaphragmatic hiatus. What is the diagnosis of these lesions?	A. Gastroesophageal reflux disease	B. Cameron ulcers	C. Gastric ulcers	D. Mallory Wiess tear	E. Esophageal candidaiasis	B	Cameron ulcers	**Cameron ulcers** are linear gastric erosions or ulcers seen on the mucosal folds of a large **hiatal hernia** where the hernia sac rubs against the diaphragm. They are a recognized cause of chronic, occult blood loss leading to iron-deficiency anemia.	Cameron ulcers: Erosions at the neck of a large hiatal hernia, causing chronic blood loss/anemia.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P128, Q25: Which of the following is the most appropriate management of the above condition?	A. Endoscopic ligation	B. Endoscopic sclerotherapy	C. Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication	D. Distal esophagectomy	E. Oral administration of a proton pump inhibitor twice daily and iron replacement therapy.	E	Oral administration of a proton pump inhibitor twice daily and iron replacement therapy.	The initial management for Cameron ulcers involves medical therapy aimed at reducing acid production and allowing the ulcers to heal. This is best achieved with a high-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor (**PPI**) regimen (often twice daily) combined with **iron replacement therapy** to correct the anemia. Surgery is reserved for refractory cases.	Cameron Ulcers initial treatment: High-dose PPI + Iron Replacement.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P128, Q26: A 32-year-old man is seen with a long history of microcytic hypochromic anemia. His past medical history includes an episode of intussusception 1 year ago. On examination, the only significant findings are melanin spots on his buccal mucosa and fingers. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy are normal. Lower duodenal biopsies are normal. enteroscopy shows multiple hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Cowden syndrome	B. Familial adenomatosis polyposis	C. Gardner's syndrome	D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome	E. Pseudopolyps	D	Peutz-Jeghers syndrome	The triad of **mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation** (buccal mucosa, lips, fingers), a history of **intussusception** (due to a lead point), and the presence of scattered **hamartomatous polyps** throughout the gastrointestinal tract (seen on enteroscopy) is the classic presentation of **Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)**.	Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome Triad: Mucocutaneous pigmentation + Hamartomatous polyps + Risk of intussusception.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P128, Q27: Obesity affects the hepatobiliary system, primarily by causing cholelithiasis. Which of the following could increase the incidence of cholelithiasis development?	A. High serum triglycerides	B. High FSH:oestrogen ratio	C. High serum cholesterol	D. High Mid-thigh:hip ratio	E. Rapid weight loss	E	Rapid weight loss	**Rapid weight loss** (e.g., after bariatric surgery or due to crash dieting) significantly increases the risk of gallstone formation (cholelithiasis) because it causes increased mobilization of cholesterol and saturation of bile.	Rapid weight loss is a major risk factor for developing cholesterol gallstones.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P129, Q28: An 82-year-old debilitated woman with coronary artery disease and breast cancer presents with hematochezia requiring 4 units of blood. Colonoscopy up to ceacumshowsde fresh blood in the left colon with marked diverticulosis and active oozing of blood from the neck of a diverticulum in the distal sigmoid colon. What is the most appropriate management?	A. Angiography	B. Endoscopic therapy of the bleeding diverticulum	C. Immediate surgical therapy	D. Supportive care with transfusion requirements as necessary	E. Technetium RBC scan	B	Endoscopic therapy of the bleeding diverticulum	The colonoscopy has successfully localized the source of the severe bleeding: an actively **oozing diverticulum**. The most appropriate and immediate management, given that the lesion is identified and accessible during the colonoscopy, is direct **endoscopic therapy** (e.g., clipping, band ligation, cautery) to control the hemorrhage.	Active Diverticular Bleeding identified endoscopically should be treated immediately with Endoscopic Therapy.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P129, Q29: A 61-year-old male presented with recent onset of ascites. Paracentesis was done and he results show a white blood cell count of 100 leukocytes 25% polymorphonuclear cells. The peritoneal albumin level is 1.2 g/dL, protein is 2.0 g/dL, and triglycerides are 20 mg/dL. Peritoneal cultures arepending. Serum albumin is 2.6 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?	A. Bacterial peritonitis	B. Chylous ascites	C. Congestive heart failure	D. Peritoneal carcinomatosis	E. Peritoneal tuberculosis	C	C. Congestive heart failure			Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P129, Q30: Which of the following could be a high risk for development of type II diabetes in obese patients?	a- BMI below 22 kg/m2	b- High total body fat	c- High abdominal subcutaneous fat	d- High waist circumference values	e- Weight gain after age 18 years in women and 20 years in men.	D	High waist circumference values	The distribution of fat is a key risk factor for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM). **Central (visceral) obesity**, which is measured by a **high waist circumference**, is strongly and independently associated with insulin resistance and the development of T2DM, much more so than total body fat or BMI alone in the obese.	High Waist Circumference (visceral fat) is the strongest anthropometric predictor of insulin resistance and T2DM risk in obese patients.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P130, Q31: A 38-year-old male is seen in the urgent care center with several hours of severe abdominal pain. he reports several months of pain in the epigastrium after. He takes no medications and has no other medical problems or habits. On physical examination temperature is 38.0°C, pulse 130/min, respiratory rate 24/min, and blood pressure 110/50 mmHg. His abdomen has absent bowel sounds and is rigid with involuntary guarding diffusely. A plain film of the abdomen is obtained and shows free air under the diaphragm. Which of the following is most likely to be found in the operating room?	A. Necrotic bowel	B. Necrotic pancreas	C. Perforated duodenal ulcer	D. Perforated gallbladder	E. Perforated gastric ulcer	C	Perforated duodenal ulcer	The clinical presentation (**sudden onset severe abdominal pain**, **rigid abdomen/guarding**, signs of septic shock, and the classic X-ray finding of **free air under the diaphragm** (pneumoperitoneum)) is diagnostic of a perforated viscus. The most common cause of spontaneous perforation is a **perforated peptic ulcer**, particularly a **duodenal ulcer**.	Free air under the diaphragm (Pneumoperitoneum) + Rigid Abdomen = Perforated Peptic Ulcer (most commonly duodenal).	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P130, Q32: Which of the following serological markers is of value in diagnosis of Acute Hepatitis B infection in the window-phase:	a) HBeAg	b) HBeAb	c) HBsAg	d) HBc-IgM	e) HBc-IgG	D	HBc-IgM	The **'Window Phase'** of acute Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) infection occurs when the Surface Antigen (HBsAg) has disappeared but the Surface Antibody (Anti-HBs) has not yet appeared. During this brief period, the only detectable serological marker for acute infection is the **Hepatitis B Core Antibody, IgM class (HBc-IgM)**.	Acute HBV Window Phase: HBsAg is negative, Anti-HBs is negative, but HBc-IgM is positive.	Hepatitis viruses				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P130, Q33: A 45-years old known hepatic patient presenting with a big oblique inguinal heria was referred to you from surgery for pre operative assessment. Serum ALT was 40 (N. 45 IU/dl), s. bilirubin 3.5mg/dl (N. up to 1mg/dl), s. albumin 3.3gm/dl and prothrombin time INR was1.5. what is the Child-TurcottePugh Classification and total score of that patient?	a) Child-C score 10	b) Child-B score 10	c) Child-B score 8	d) Child-B score 6	e) Child-C score 12	B	b) Child-B score 10			Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P131, Q34: A 24-years old man was doing pre-employment examination. Clinical examination revealed evidence of chronic liver disease. Results of liver chemistry were: Serum ALT: 55, Serum AST: 45 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AP: 320 (30 – 120 U/L), Serum GGT: 150 (9 – 50 U/L), Serum BILIRUBIN: TOTAL: 7.3(0.3 – 1 mg/dl), DIRECT: 6.5.3 (0.1 – 0.3 mg/dl), Serum ALBUMINE: 3.9 (3.5 – 5.5 g/dl), PROTHROMIN TIME: 18 sec. (control 12 sec.). The best diagnosis is:	a) Cholestatic liver disease	b) Decompensated liver cirrhosis	c) Compensated liver cirrhosis	d) Acute hepatitis	e) Chronic hepatitis	A	Cholestatic liver disease	The key abnormalities are markedly elevated **Alkaline Phosphatase (AP) ($320~U/L$)** and **Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT) ($150~U/L$)**, along with a high total and predominantly high **direct bilirubin** ($6.5~mg/dl$). Liver enzymes (ALT/AST) are only mildly elevated. This profile is characteristic of **Cholestatic Liver Disease**.	Markedly High ALP/GGT + High Direct Bilirubin = Cholestatic Liver Disease.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P132, Q35: A 24-years old man was doing pre-employment examination. Clinical examination revealed evidence of chronic liver disease. Results of liver chemistry were: Serum ALT: 30, Serum AST: 45 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AP: 66 (30 – 120 U/L), Serum GGT: 45 (9 – 50 U/L), Serum BILIRUBIN: TOTAL: 0.9 (0.3 – 1 mg/dl), DIRECT: 0.3 (0.1 – 0.3 mg/dl), Serum ALBUMINE: 3.8 (3.5 – 5.5 g/dl), PROTHROMIN TIME: 12 sec. (control 12 sec.). What is the best diagnosis?	Cholestatic liver disease	Decompensated liver cirrhosis	Compensated liver cirrhosis	Acute hepatitis	Chronic hepatitis	C	Compensated liver cirrhosis	"The liver enzymes (ALT/AST) are normal/near-normal. Synthetic function (Albumin $3.8~g/dl$, INR 1.0/PT 12 sec) and Bilirubin are normal. However, the history mentions evidence of chronic liver disease"" (though not detailed). Normal synthetic function and absence of overt symptoms or complications suggest the patient is in a **Compensated Liver Cirrhosis** stage."""	Normal synthetic function (Albumin, PT/INR) + Clinical evidence of chronic disease = Compensated Cirrhosis.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P132, Q36: A 35-old lady was presented to OPD with fatigue and anorexia. She was clinically examined and blood test for liver chemistry was done. The results was: Serum ALT: 88 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AST: 76 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AP: 120 (30 – 120 U/L), Serum GGT: 75 (9 – 50 U/L), Serum BILIRUBIN: TOTAL: 2.5 (0.3 – 1 mg/dl), DIRECT: 1.3 (0.1 – 0.3 mg/dl), Serum ALBUMINE: 3.3 (3.5 – 5.5 g/dl), PROTHROMIN TIME: 14 sec. (control 12 sec.). What is the best diagnosis?	Cholestatic liver disease	Decompensated liver cirrhosis	Compensated liver cirrhosis	Acute hepatitis	Chronic hepatits	E	Chronic hepatits	The key findings are moderate **transaminase elevation** (ALT 88, AST 76), indicating ongoing **hepatocellular injury**. Synthetic function (Albumin 3.3, PT 14s) is slightly impaired, and the bilirubin is elevated (2.5). This sustained hepatocellular injury, in the absence of massive acute enzyme spikes, is characteristic of **Chronic Hepatitis**.	Chronic Hepatitis shows sustained, moderate elevation of ALT/AST with possible mild impairment of synthetic function.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبMCQ infections ملف صهيب	P133, Q37: A16-years old student presented to family doctor with severe malaise, nausea and anorexia. He was clinically examined and blood test for liver chemistry was done. The results was: Serum ALT: 820 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AST: 790 (0 – 35 U/L), Serum AP: 110 (30 – 120 U/L), Serum GGT: 160 (9 – 50 U/L), Serum BILIRUBIN: TOTAL: 4.5 (0.3 – 1 mg/dl), DIRECT: 2.9 (0.1 – 0.3 mg/dl), Serum ALBUMINE: 4 (3.5 – 5.5 g/dl), PROTHROMIN TIME: 18 sec. (control 12 sec.). What is the best diagnosis?	Cholestatic liver disease	Decompensated liver cirrhosis	Compensated liver cirrhosis	Acute hepatitis		D	Acute hepatitis	The most striking finding is the **massive elevation of transaminases** (ALT 820, AST 790), indicating widespread **acute hepatocellular necrosis**. This magnitude of enzyme elevation is characteristic of **Acute Hepatitis**. Synthetic function is mildly deranged (PT 18s/INR $\approx 1.5$), but albumin is still preserved.	Massive spike in ALT/AST (hundreds or thousands) = Acute Hepatocellular Injury/Acute Hepatitis.	Gastroenterology				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P1, Q1: All of the following are skin manifestations of COVID-19 except:	A) Acral papules and vesicles	B) Pseudo chilblains	C) Urticarial lesions	D. ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P14, Q10: The chain of infection has five main components. Trypanosomiasis (African sleeping sickness)		C	Schistosomalasis	Praziquantel is the drug of choice for all species of Schistosoma (bilharzia).	Praziquantel for Schistosomiasis. ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P22, Q20: Which of the following is most unlikely to be found in Clostridium difficile infection:	A-Bloody diarrhea	B-Fever	C-mild	D-Leukocytosis	E-Recurrence after therapy	A	Bloody diarrhea	C. difficile infection typically causes watery, non-bloody diarrhea. Bloody diarrhea suggests other causes like enterohemorrhagic E. coli or inflammatory bowel disease.	C. diff → Watery diarrhea, NOT typically bloody.					
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P22, Q21: A patient with a previous history of tuberculosis now complaining of hemoptysis. A-Asperergillus flavus	B - Coccidioidomycosis	C - Human Parvovirus	D - CMV		A	Asperergillus flavus	An aspergilloma (fungus ball) can form in a pre-existing lung cavity (e.g., from prior TB), appearing as a mass with an air crescent sign on imaging, and can cause hemoptysis.	TB cavity + air crescent sign → Aspergilloma.	Pulmonology/Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P22, Q22: A 20-year-old female sexually active with a 2-day history of dysuria, lower abdominal pain, and grade fever. Her urine is cloudy with pyuria and abundant Gram-positive bacteria are present. The organism is most likely to cause these symptoms:	A - Enterococcus feacalis	D - Candida albicans	B - Escherichia coli	C - Neisseria gonorrhoeae	E - Staphylococcus saprophyticus	E	Staphylococcus saprophyticus	Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common cause of UTI in young, sexually active women, and appears as Gram-positive cocci in clusters.	Young female UTI: S. saprophyticus (Gram-positive).					
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P22, Q23: As régard Yellow fever which is trust	a - has a case fatality rate of 50%	b-is caused by a flavi virus	c-is spread by anopheline mosquitoes	d-epidemics should be controlled by strict isolation of cases		B	is caused by a flavi virus	Yellow fever virus is a flavivirus. It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, not Anopheles. The case fatality rate is about 20-50% for severe cases, but not a blanket 50%.	Yellow fever = Flavivirus, Aedes mosquito vector.	Virology

Infectious causes of cancer: HPV, HBV/HCV, EBV, HHV-8, H. pylori.

ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P23, Q27: Which of the following vaccine can be given to immunocompromized patients safely?	A-Varicella	B-Zoster vaccine	C-Measles	D-HBV vaccine		D	HBV vaccine	Inactivated vaccines (like HBV, DTaP, IPV) are safe in immunocompromised individuals. Live attenuated vaccines (Varicella, Zoster, MMR) are generally contraindicated.	Immunocompromised: Safe = Inactivated vaccines; Avoid = Live vaccines.	Vaccinology				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P23, Q28: Which of the following are the reservoirs of the filea-borne typhus also called murina typhus?	A. Rats	B. Dogs	C. Ticks	D-mites		A	Rats	Murine typhus (endemic typhus) is caused by Rickettsia typhi and is transmitted by fleas, with rats being the primary reservoir.	Murine typhus reservoir = Rats; vector = Fleas. ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P23, Q29: A nurse is teaching a new nursing assistant about ways to prevent the spread of infection, included in the instruction would be that the cycle of the infectious process must be broken, which may be	A-Hand washing before and between providing client	B-Thoroughly cleaning the environment. "Hand hygiene = #1 way to break chain of infection."	Infection Control

Endoscopy shows ulcerations.	HIV, CD4<50, bloody diarrhea → Think CMV colitis.					
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P24, Q32: A 20 year old man who presented with persistent diarrhea and abdominal bleating after returning from a gap year in Africa is diagnosed as having strongyioidiasis. Strongyloides stercoralis infects humans when filariform larvae in contaminated soil penetrate the skin, usually the feet.	Strongyloides: Larvae penetrate skin.	Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P24, Q33: a 20-years old male presented with fever for 10 days and abdominal pain and constipation since last two days the fever chart shows step ladder pattern of fever on examination mild hepatomegaly which of the following is the most likely the diagnosis:	A-Typhoid fever	B-Amoebiasis	C-Tuberculosis	D-Dengue fever		A	Typhoid fever	Enteric fever (typhoid) caused by Salmonella Typhi classically presents with step-ladder fever, relative bradycardia, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly. Constipation can occur early.	Typhoid: Step-ladder fever, abdominal pain, constipation/Diarrhea.	Infectious Disease				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P24, Q34: Drug of choice of complicated malaria during pregnancy is:	A-Mefloquine	B-Primaquine	C-Artesunate	D-Quinine		C	Artesunate	Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), particularly artesunate, are recommended for the treatment of complicated malaria in all trimesters of pregnancy due to superior efficacy.	Complicated malaria in pregnancy: Artesunate.	Obstetrics/Parasitology				
ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P24, Q35: Patient with intermittent fever presents with features of chested successfully with doxycycline and rifampicin, probable diagnosis is	A-Brucellosis	B-Francisella tularensis	C-Bordetella pertussis	D-Mycoplasma		A	Brucellosis	The combination of doxycycline and rifampicin (or streptomycin/gentamicin) is a standard regimen for the treatment of brucellosis. ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P25, Q39: A 14-Years old elementary school teacher presents with fever, sore throat, and diffuse lacy rash she subsequently develop arthralgia of small joints of the hand what is the etiology:	A-Epstein Bar Virus	B-Parvovirus	C-Diphtheria	D-Plaemophilus influenzae		B	Parvovirus	Parvovirus B19 causes Fifth disease (erythema infectiosum) with a 'slapped cheek' rash and a lacy reticular rash on the body, and can cause arthralgia/arthritis in adults. ريحانة الطبTropical exams last years	P25, Q40: A 30-Years old pregnant women develop sepsis with headache and neck stiffness other eating coleslaw, soft cheese and cantaloupes at potluck dinner, two another women who attended the event self-limiting abdominal cramps, nausea and vomiting the causative organism is	A-Enterococcus faecalis	B-Listeria monocytogenes	C-Herpes simplex virus	D-staph saprophyticus		B	Listeria monocytogenes	Listeria monocytogenes is a foodborne pathogen associated with unpasteurized dairy, soft cheeses, and ready-to-eat foods. It can cause severe infection in pregnant women, presenting with flu-like symptoms, sepsis, and meningitis.	Pregnant + Meningitis/Sepsis → Think Listeria.	Obstetrics/Infectious Disease
